VETA: (Moja prekladateľka Chie vyjadrila prekvapenie, keď som si odmietol rezervovať súkromnú izbu za osemtisíc jenov na moje sedenie s plačom; uistil som ju, že hoci je šermiar novinkou, nebude to ani môj prvý, ani s najväčšou pravdepodobnosťou, naposledy som plakal na verejnosti.)

TEXT_SOURCE: The swordsman, a willowy youth with chiselled features and an expression of great sensitivity, wore a garment made by a designer specializing in modernistic reinterpretations of traditional Japanese dress.
VETA: Šermiar, vŕbový mladík s vytesanými črtami a výrazom veľkej citlivosti, mal na sebe odev od dizajnéra, ktorý sa špecializoval na modernistické reinterpretácie tradičného japonského odevu.

TEXT_SOURCE: He began our session by reading me a children’s book in which a little boy in Fukushima writes a letter to his grandmother and her dog, who have been washed away in the tsunami.
VETA: Naše stretnutie začal tým, že mi prečítal detskú knihu, v ktorej malý chlapec vo Fukušime píše list svojej babičke a jej psovi, ktorých zaplavila vlna cunami.

TEXT_SOURCE: Are you crying?
VETA: Plačeš?

TEXT_SOURCE: You have to cry, or he can’t wipe away your tears.
VETA: Musíš plakať, inak ti nebude môcť utrieť slzy.

TEXT_SOURCE: The swordsman, who is also a freelance model, looked solicitously into my face, holding a crisply ironed blue-and-white striped handkerchief.
VETA: Šermiar, ktorý je tiež modelom na voľnej nohe, sa mi starostlivo zahľadel do tváre a v ruke držal nastrouhanú modro-bielu pásikavú vreckovku.

TEXT_SOURCE: I explained that I had felt close to tears when the grandmother and the dog received the letter in Heaven and it made the dog’s tail wag.
VETA: Vysvetlil som, že som sa cítil blízko k slzám, keď babička a pes dostali list v nebi a pes krútil chvostom.

TEXT_SOURCE: They all cry when the dog wags its tail, the swordsman said, nodding knowledgeably.
VETA: Všetci plačú, keď pes vrtí chvostom, povedal šermiar a vedome prikývol.

TEXT_SOURCE: Next, we all watched a YouTube video about a father who played the saxophone at his son’s wedding.
VETA: Ďalej sme si všetci pozreli video na YouTube o otcovi, ktorý hral na saxofóne na svadbe svojho syna.

TEXT_SOURCE: I waited in dread for the father to turn out to have cancer.
VETA: S hrôzou som čakala, kedy sa ukáže, že otec má rakovinu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Suddenly, the video was over.
VETA: Zrazu sa video skončilo.

TEXT_SOURCE: Nothing bad had happened.
VETA: Nič zlé sa nestalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: But when I looked up, I saw a perfectly formed tear rolling toward the swordsman’s jaw.
VETA: Ale keď som zdvihol zrak, uvidel som dokonale tvarovanú slzu kotúľajúcu sa k čeľusti šermiara.

TEXT_SOURCE: Chie, too, was crying.
VETA: Chie tiež plakal.

TEXT_SOURCE: Terai explained that, for him, the really tear-inducing moment was when it transpired that the groom’s sisters had secretly prepared a piano accompaniment to the father’s saxophone solo.
VETA: Terai vysvetlil, že pre neho bol skutočne slzotvorný moment, keď sa ukázalo, že sestry ženícha potajomky pripravili klavírny sprievod k otcovmu saxofónovému sólu.

TEXT_SOURCE: All the same, Terai wanted to take pictures of the swordsman drying my tears.
VETA: Napriek tomu si Terai chcela odfotiť šermiara, ktorý mi sušil slzy.

TEXT_SOURCE: Just try to look sad, he said.
VETA: Len sa snaž vyzerať smutne, povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: I looked at the floor and the swordsman leaned toward me with the handkerchief.
VETA: Pozrel som sa na podlahu a šermiar sa ku mne naklonil s vreckovkou.

TEXT_SOURCE: He told me about his audition for the weeping service, which had been recorded by a news program.
VETA: Rozprával mi o svojom konkurze do služby plačúcich, ktorý zaznamenala spravodajská relácia.

TEXT_SOURCE: To his mortification, he had been unable to cry for the camera: I had tears in the corner of my eye, but they didn’t overflow.
VETA: Na svoje poníženie nedokázal plakať pre kameru: V kútiku očí som mal slzy, ale nepretiekli.

TEXT_SOURCE: The tear has to roll down the face, Terai said.
VETA: Slza sa musí kotúľať po tvári, povedal Terai.

TEXT_SOURCE: But he had given the swordsman another chance.
VETA: Ale dal šermiarovi ďalšiu šancu.

TEXT_SOURCE: He couldn’t cry then, but I could imagine his crying face, he said.
VETA: Vtedy nemohol plakať, ale vedel som si predstaviť jeho plačúcu tvár, povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: And when I saw him cry, I was exactly right.
VETA: A keď som ho videl plakať, mal som pravdu.

TEXT_SOURCE: My next appointment, with Family Romance, was two hours with a rental mother, in the shopping district of Shibuya.
VETA: Moje ďalšie stretnutie s Family Romance boli dve hodiny s nájomnou matkou v nákupnej štvrti Shibuya.

TEXT_SOURCE: One afternoon in Tokyo, on a commuter train, Chie helped me fill out the order form.
VETA: Jedno popoludnie v Tokiu mi Chie v prímestskom vlaku pomohol vyplniť objednávkový formulár.

TEXT_SOURCE: There’s a space here for your fond childhood memories, she said.
VETA: Je tu priestor pre vaše milé spomienky z detstva, povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: I found myself telling her about the day when I was three or four and my mother, a young doctor, who worked long hours, came home early and took me out to buy a doll stroller.
VETA: Pristihla som sa, že jej hovorím o dni, keď som mala tri alebo štyri roky a moja matka, mladá lekárka, ktorá pracovala dlhé hodiny, prišla domov skôr a zobrala ma kúpiť kočík pre bábiky.

TEXT_SOURCE: This unhoped-for happiness was somehow intensified by the unnecessariness, the surplus value, of the doll stroller.
VETA: Toto netušené šťastie bolo akosi umocnené nepotrebnosťou, nadhodnotou kočíka pre bábiky.

TEXT_SOURCE: The day we got the stroller, the stroller day, became shorthand for what?
VETA: Deň, keď sme dostali kočík, deň kočíka, sa stal skratkou pre čo?

TEXT_SOURCE: For a happy day, though I remember at a later date asking my mother why mentioning it always felt somehow sad.
VETA: Za šťastný deň, aj keď si pamätám, že som sa neskôr opýtal mamy, prečo mi to pri zmienke vždy pripadalo akosi smutné.

TEXT_SOURCE: I was worried that she would tell me not to be morbid, not to find ways to be sad about things that were happy.
VETA: Bála som sa, že mi povie, aby som nebola morbídna, aby som nenachádzala spôsoby, ako byť smutná z vecí, ktoré sú šťastné.

TEXT_SOURCE: Instead she said, without missing a beat, Because why wasn’t every day the stroller day?
VETA: Namiesto toho povedala bez toho, aby vynechala pauzu, pretože prečo nie je každý deň deň kočíka?

TEXT_SOURCE: I met the rental mother in the café of a department store.
VETA: S nájomníčkou som sa stretol v kaviarni obchodného domu.

TEXT_SOURCE: I hadn’t seen her picture, so it took some time to identify the right person: a petite, middle-aged Japanese woman, her long hair dyed the color of honey.
VETA: Nevidel som jej fotku, takže chvíľu trvalo, kým som identifikoval tú správnu osobu: drobnú Japonku v strednom veku s dlhými vlasmi zafarbenými na medovú farbu.

TEXT_SOURCE: She stood as I approached.
VETA: Keď som sa blížil, stála.

TEXT_SOURCE: Mom!
VETA: mami!

TEXT_SOURCE: She returned my embrace, a shade distantly.
VETA: Opätovala moje objatie, len o tieň ďalej.

TEXT_SOURCE: So how should we do this? she asked, speaking in unaccented American English.
VETA: Ako by sme to teda mali urobiť? spýtala sa hovoriac americkou angličtinou bez prízvuku.

TEXT_SOURCE: Would you like to interview me, or do you want to do the role-playing?
VETA: Chceli by ste so mnou urobiť rozhovor alebo chcete hrať rolu?

TEXT_SOURCE: Having booked her for two hours, I suggested that we might do both.
VETA: Po rezervácii na dve hodiny som navrhol, že by sme mohli urobiť oboje.

TEXT_SOURCE: This is a little bit weird for me, because usually when I play a mother the daughter is in her twenties, she said, adding that she was fifty-six, which made her only sixteen years older than me.
VETA: To je pre mňa trochu divné, pretože zvyčajne, keď hrám matku, dcéra má dvadsať rokov, povedala a dodala, že má päťdesiatšesť rokov, čím je odo mňa staršia len o šestnásť rokov.

TEXT_SOURCE: Should I pretend to be in my twenties?
VETA: Mám predstierať, že mám dvadsať?

TEXT_SOURCE: No, I can act older, she said.
VETA: Nie, môžem sa správať staršie, povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: As our backstory, she proposed that my mother had moved to Japan for some reason, and that we would be seeing each other for the first time in years.
VETA: Ako náš príbeh zo zákulisia navrhla, že moja matka sa z nejakého dôvodu presťahovala do Japonska a že sa po rokoch uvidíme prvýkrát.

TEXT_SOURCE: I agreed.
VETA: Súhlasil som.

TEXT_SOURCE: All of a sudden, her expression softened.
VETA: Zrazu jej výraz zmäkol.

TEXT_SOURCE: It’s been such a long time since we’ve seen each other.
VETA: Už je to tak dlho, čo sme sa nevideli.

TEXT_SOURCE: Her voice, too, was softer, more wistful.
VETA: Aj jej hlas bol mäkší, tesknejší.

TEXT_SOURCE: I felt a mild jolt of emotion.
VETA: Pocítil som mierny nával emócií.

TEXT_SOURCE: It’s been really long, I said.
VETA: Je to naozaj dlho, povedal som.

TEXT_SOURCE: I don’t know how much you remember.
VETA: neviem, koľko si pamätáš.

TEXT_SOURCE: I don’t know if you remember the times we spent together.
VETA: Neviem, či si pamätáš časy, ktoré sme spolu strávili.

TEXT_SOURCE: The sorrow in her voice made me think of my real mother when she talked about the time after my parents’ divorce, when I lived with my father.
VETA: Smútok v jej hlase ma prinútil myslieť na moju skutočnú mamu, keď hovorila o čase po rozvode mojich rodičov, keď som žil s otcom.

TEXT_SOURCE: Of course I remember, I said encouragingly, and even found myself trying to retrieve an actual memory, before I remembered that there were no actual memories, because we had only just met.
VETA: Samozrejme, že si pamätám, povedal som povzbudzujúco a dokonca som sa pristihol, že sa snažím získať skutočnú spomienku, skôr ako som si spomenul, že neexistujú žiadne skutočné spomienky, pretože sme sa práve stretli.

TEXT_SOURCE: Well, I remember every minute we spent together, and I cherish every minute.
VETA: Pamätám si každú minútu, ktorú sme spolu strávili, a vážim si každú minútu.

TEXT_SOURCE: I only wish there had been more of them, she said.
VETA: Len by som si priala, aby ich bolo viac, povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: I didn’t have as much time to spend with you as I wanted, because of my work.
VETA: Kvôli mojej práci som s tebou nemal toľko času, koľko som chcel.

TEXT_SOURCE: That’s something I regret now.
VETA: To je niečo, čo teraz ľutujem.

TEXT_SOURCE: I felt a wave of panic, as if a fortune-teller had told me something eerily accurate.
VETA: Pocítil som vlnu paniky, ako keby mi veštec povedal niečo strašidelne presné.

TEXT_SOURCE: You had to work so hard, I said.
VETA: Musel si tak tvrdo pracovať, povedal som.

TEXT_SOURCE: But what about your work?
VETA: Ale čo vaša práca?

TEXT_SOURCE: How do you cope with all the pressure? she asked—and the spell was broken, because my real mother knows all about my work, and wouldn’t have asked me that.
VETA: Ako zvládate všetok ten tlak? spýtala sa – a kúzlo bolo prerušené, pretože moja skutočná matka vie všetko o mojej práci a na to by sa ma nepýtala.

TEXT_SOURCE: I found myself telling the rental mother about the meditation app on my phone, and asking if she liked to meditate.
VETA: Pristihla som sa, že hovorím mame z požičovne o meditačnej aplikácii na mojom telefóne a pýtam sa, či rada medituje.

TEXT_SOURCE: I guess we’re talking as ourselves now, she said, echoing my thought.
VETA: Myslím, že teraz hovoríme ako my sami, povedala a zopakovala moju myšlienku.

TEXT_SOURCE: I started to interview her.
VETA: Začal som s ňou robiť rozhovor.

TEXT_SOURCE: Her name was Airi and she had spent most of her childhood in the United States and Canada, because of her father’s work as a research physicist.
VETA: Volala sa Airi a väčšinu svojho detstva strávila v Spojených štátoch a Kanade, pretože jej otec pracoval ako výskumný fyzik.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the seventies, she did some TV acting, playing a happy Asian kid in the background of sitcoms.
VETA: V sedemdesiatych rokoch sa venovala televíznemu herectvu a hrala šťastné ázijské dieťa v pozadí situačných komédií.

TEXT_SOURCE: When she was fourteen, her father sent her to Japan, to go into the system.
VETA: Keď mala štrnásť rokov, otec ju poslal do Japonska, aby išla do systému.

TEXT_SOURCE: Censured and ostracized for using English words, she learned to keep her mouth shut until she could speak perfect Japanese.
VETA: Odsudzovaná a ostrakizovaná za používanie anglických slov sa naučila držať jazyk za zubami, kým nebude hovoriť perfektne japonsky.

TEXT_SOURCE: After completing her education, she joined the corporate workforce, climbing to the upper levels of various international companies, before leaving her last position, two years ago.
VETA: Po ukončení svojho vzdelania sa pripojila k podnikovej pracovnej sile a vyšplhala sa na vyššie úrovne rôznych medzinárodných spoločností, než pred dvoma rokmi opustila svoju poslednú pozíciu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Airi registered with Family Romance shortly afterward, and now gets a couple of assignments every month.
VETA: Airi sa krátko nato zaregistrovala v Family Romance a teraz dostáva niekoľko úloh každý mesiac.

TEXT_SOURCE: She doesn’t have any children or close relatives; she lost her husband, her parents, and a hundred-and-ten-year-old grandmother in a span of twenty years.
VETA: Nemá žiadne deti ani blízkych príbuzných; prišla v priebehu dvadsiatich rokov o manžela, rodičov a stodesaťročnú babičku.

TEXT_SOURCE: We talked about the article I was interviewing her for.
VETA: Rozprávali sme sa o článku, pre ktorý som s ňou robil rozhovor.

TEXT_SOURCE: I guess I’ll just be a few lines, she said, and I suddenly started to feel guilty about my rental mother.
VETA: Myslím, že budem len pár riadkov, povedala a ja som sa zrazu začal cítiť vinný za svoju nájomnú matku.

TEXT_SOURCE: I felt physical pain when she briefly alluded to her financial uncertainty and said that she couldn’t go on living like this forever, and when she proposed that I hire her as a translator and I had to tell her I already had one.
VETA: Cítil som fyzickú bolesť, keď sa krátko zmienila o svojej finančnej neistote a povedala, že takto nemôže žiť navždy, a keď mi navrhla, aby som ju zamestnal ako prekladateľku a musel som jej povedať, že už jednu mám.

TEXT_SOURCE: The worst moment was when she mentioned that none of the daughters who’d hired her had ever asked to see her again, and I realized I wouldn’t be seeing her again, either.
VETA: Najhorší moment bol, keď spomenula, že žiadna z dcér, ktoré si ju najali, sa s ňou už nikdy nepýtala, a ja som si uvedomil, že ju už tiež neuvidím.

TEXT_SOURCE: When she offered to show me around the department store even though our time was up, I found myself saying yes.
VETA: Keď mi ponúkla, že ma prevedie obchodným domom, hoci náš čas vypršal, zistil som, že hovorím áno.

TEXT_SOURCE: Like many aspects of Japanese society, rental relatives are often explained with reference to the binary of honne and tatemae, or genuine individual feelings and societal expectations.
VETA: Rovnako ako mnoho aspektov japonskej spoločnosti, nájomní príbuzní sa často vysvetľujú s odkazom na dvojhviezdu honne a tatemae alebo skutočné individuálne pocity a spoločenské očakávania.

TEXT_SOURCE: Authenticity and consistency aren’t necessarily valued for their own sake, and the concealment of authentic honne behind conventional tatemae is often construed as an act of unselfishness and sociability, rather than of deception or hypocrisy.
VETA: Autenticita a konzistentnosť sa nemusia nevyhnutne hodnotiť samy osebe a skrytie autentického honne za konvenčnými tatemae sa často vykladá ako akt nesebeckosti a spoločenskosti, a nie klamu alebo pokrytectva.

TEXT_SOURCE: A case in point: the man who hired fake parents for his wedding because his real ones were dead eventually told his wife.
VETA: Príklad: muž, ktorý si na svadbu najal falošných rodičov, pretože jeho skutoční boli mŕtvi, to nakoniec povedal svojej manželke.

TEXT_SOURCE: It went fine.
VETA: Išlo to v pohode.

TEXT_SOURCE: She said that she understood that his goal was not to deceive her but to avoid trouble at their wedding.
VETA: Povedala, že chápe, že jeho cieľom nie je oklamať ju, ale vyhnúť sa problémom na ich svadbe.

TEXT_SOURCE: She even thanked him for being so considerate.
VETA: Dokonca sa mu poďakovala, že bol taký ohľaduplný.

TEXT_SOURCE: Still, although it goes without saying that many aspects of the Japanese rental-relative business must be specific to Japan, it is also the case that people throughout human history have been paying strangers to fill roles that their kinsfolk performed for free.
VETA: Napriek tomu, hoci je samozrejmé, že mnohé aspekty japonského biznisu súvisiaceho s prenájmom musia byť špecifické pre Japonsko, je tiež pravdou, že ľudia počas ľudskej histórie platili cudzincom, aby obsadili úlohy, ktoré ich príbuzní vykonávali zadarmo.

TEXT_SOURCE: Hired mourners existed in ancient Greece, Rome, and China, in the Judeo-Christian tradition, and in the early Islamic world; they were denounced by Solon, by St. Paul, and by St. John Chrysostom.
VETA: Najatí smútiaci existovali v starovekom Grécku, Ríme a Číne, v židovsko-kresťanskej tradícii a v ranom islamskom svete; boli odsúdení Solónom, svätým Pavlom a svätým Jánom Zlatoústym.

TEXT_SOURCE: They still exist in China, India, and, lately, England, where an Essex-based service, Rent A Mourner, has been operating since 2013.
VETA: Stále existujú v Číne, Indii a nedávno aj v Anglicku, kde od roku 2013 funguje služba Rent A Mourner so sídlom v Essexe.

TEXT_SOURCE: And what are babysitters, nurses, and cooks if not rental relatives, filling some of the roles traditionally performed by mothers, daughters, and wives?
VETA: A čo sú pestúnky, zdravotné sestry a kuchárky, ak nie nájomní príbuzní, ktorí zastávajú niektoré z úloh, ktoré tradične vykonávajú matky, dcéry a manželky?

TEXT_SOURCE: I TRAVELLED the next day on a train along a secondary railway line to Zidani Most and then changed and took a train to Zagreb.
VETA: Na druhý deň som CESTOVAL vlakom po vedľajšej železničnej trati do Zidani Most a potom som prestúpil a išiel na vlak do Záhrebu.

TEXT_SOURCE: This time, there were no patrols at the border; in fact, I had no idea where the border was.
VETA: Tentoraz na hraniciach neboli žiadne hliadky; vlastne som ani netušil, kde je hranica.

TEXT_SOURCE: The show of Slovenian strength was for the mainline only, it seemed.
VETA: Zdalo sa, že ukážka slovinskej sily bola len pre hlavnú líniu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Along the way I could see the spiky spires of churches on the top of wooded hills.
VETA: Cestou som videl ostnaté veže kostolov na vrcholkoch zalesnených kopcov.

TEXT_SOURCE: We passed small holdings with barns beside them in the shape of oversized abacuses for drying hay or wood.
VETA: Míňali sme malé farmy s maštaľami vedľa nich v tvare nadrozmerných počítadiel na sušenie sena alebo dreva.

TEXT_SOURCE: As we passed each station the station master would walk out on to the platform, perfectly dressed, and salute the train.
VETA: Keď sme prechádzali každou stanicou, prednosta vyšiel na nástupište, dokonale oblečený a zasalutoval vlaku.

TEXT_SOURCE: In Zagreb I left my bags in the station and bought a ticket for the night train to Vienna.
VETA: V Záhrebe som si nechal tašky na stanici a kúpil si lístok na nočný vlak do Viedne.

TEXT_SOURCE: I walked up to the main square, which was different on an ordinary working evening: there were crowds of people waiting for trams, it was busier, the shops were all lit up, and the cafes on the upper side of the square nearest the cathedral seemed more elegant now that it was not drizzling.
VETA: Vyšiel som na hlavné námestie, ktoré bolo počas bežného pracovného večera iné: boli tam davy ľudí čakajúcich na električky, bolo rušnejšie, všetky obchody boli vysvietené a kaviarne na hornej strane námestia najbližšie ku katedrále vyzeralo to elegantnejšie, keď nemrholilo.

TEXT_SOURCE: I spent a couple of hours wandering around the square as though it were a little city in itself.
VETA: Strávil som pár hodín túlaním sa po námestí, ako keby to bolo malé mesto samo o sebe.

TEXT_SOURCE: Every now and then the general sense of ordinariness, the city at the end of the day, was disrupted by the appearance of soldiers in fatigues, big serious-looking fellows crossing the square, but no one else paid any attention to them.
VETA: Z času na čas bol všeobecný pocit obyčajnosti mesta na konci dňa narušený objavením sa vojakov v maskáčoch, veľkých serióznych chlapíkov prechádzajúcich námestím, ale nikto iný im nevenoval žiadnu pozornosť.

TEXT_SOURCE: In one cafe, I watched as friends arrived at the neighbouring table and there was the ceremony of greeting and sitting down again and looking at the menu and talking to the waitress.
VETA: V jednej kaviarni som sledoval, ako priatelia prišli k susednému stolu a tam bol obrad pozdravu a opätovného sadnutia, prezerania jedálneho lístka a rozhovoru s čašníčkou.

TEXT_SOURCE: A feeling that these people had money and had been doing this sort of thing all their lives.
VETA: Pocit, že títo ľudia mali peniaze a celý život robili takéto veci.

TEXT_SOURCE: I watched from the plate-glass window of a cafe as the rush in the square slowed down and settled into silence for the evening.
VETA: Sledoval som z preskleného okna kaviarne, ako sa zhon na námestí spomalil a ustálil sa na večernom tichu.

TEXT_SOURCE: There were a lot of desolate-looking people hanging around the corridors of the railway station, the only place where you could keep warm in the city if you had no money.
VETA: Po chodbách železničnej stanice, jediného miesta, kde sa dalo v meste zohriať, keby ste nemali peniaze, sa motalo množstvo opustene vyzerajúcich ľudí.

TEXT_SOURCE: I watched as one of them, a man in his forties, strayed into the bar.
VETA: Sledoval som, ako jeden z nich, štyridsiatnik, zablúdil do baru.

TEXT_SOURCE: A Croatian soldier moved slowly towards him, to the amusement of his colleagues, ceremoniously caught him by the shoulders and steered him back to the corridor.
VETA: Chorvátsky vojak sa k nemu pomaly približoval, na pobavenie kolegov ho obradne chytil za ramená a nasmeroval späť do chodby.

TEXT_SOURCE: At the border between Croatia and Austria, a guard opened the door of my sleeping cabin and shone a torch in my face and asked me if l had any whisky or cigarettes.
VETA: Na hranici medzi Chorvátskom a Rakúskom strážnik otvoril dvere mojej kabínky na spanie, zasvietil mi baterkou do tváre a spýtal sa ma, či nemám whisky alebo cigarety.

TEXT_SOURCE: I told him I did not.
VETA: Povedal som mu, že nie.

TEXT_SOURCE: The next guard wanted to see my passport.
VETA: Ďalší strážca chcel vidieť môj pas.

TEXT_SOURCE: I fell asleep again and the next time I woke up the train was about to arrive in Vienna.
VETA: Opäť som zaspal a nabudúce, keď som sa zobudil, vlak mal prísť do Viedne.

TEXT_SOURCE: Within half an hour I found a connection to Bratislava and arrived there around midday.
VETA: Do pol hodiny som našiel spoj do Bratislavy a okolo poludnia som tam dorazil.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was now the Friday of Easter week.
VETA: Teraz bol piatok veľkonočného týždňa.

TEXT_SOURCE: I booked into a hotel overlooking the Danube and rang a man called Juraj Mihalik whose name I had been given as a good guide to the recent changes in Slovakia.
VETA: Zarezervoval som si hotel s výhľadom na Dunaj a zavolal som pánovi Jurajovi Mihálikovi, ktorého meno som dostal ako dobrý sprievodca nedávnymi zmenami na Slovensku.

TEXT_SOURCE: As I walked around Bratislava I realised that it did not match Prague as a capital city, which must be difficult for the new state: everyone from outside would immediately start comparing it to the Czech Republic.
VETA: Keď som sa prechádzal po Bratislave, uvedomil som si, že sa Praha ako hlavné mesto nevyrovná, čo musí byť pre nový štát ťažké: každý zvonku by ju hneď začal porovnávať s Českom.

TEXT_SOURCE: Some of the old buildings were stately and dignified, but there seemed to be restoration and reconstruction going on in every street so that it was hard to look at the city as you walked around without seeing cement-mixers and lorries.
VETA: Niektoré zo starých budov boli majestátne a dôstojné, ale zdalo sa, že na každej ulici prebiehala obnova a rekonštrukcia, takže bolo ťažké pozerať sa na mesto, keď ste sa prechádzali bez toho, aby ste videli miešačky cementu a nákladné autá.

TEXT_SOURCE: I went into the new national gallery, and I tried to stop myself thinking of the national gallery in Prague up on the hill, the sheer grandeur of it, as against the modesty of this small building in a provincial capital on the Danube which had suddenly and unexpectedly become the capital city of a new state.
VETA: Vošiel som do novej národnej galérie a snažil som sa prestať myslieť na národnú galériu v Prahe na kopci, na jej úplnu vznešenosť, na rozdiel od skromnosti tejto malej budovy v hlavnom meste provincie na Dunaji, ktorá sa zrazu a nečakane sa stane hlavným mestom nového štátu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Close to my hotel was another gallery, which had obviously been restored inthe 196os: originally, there was an eighteenth-century building overlooking the river to which had been added a huge monstrosity like the sort of corridor which gets you from one terminal to another in an airport; this linked the upper storeys of the two wings.
VETA: Neďaleko môjho hotela bola ďalšia galéria, ktorá bola očividne zrekonštruovaná v 196-tych rokoch: pôvodne tam bola budova z osemnásteho storočia s výhľadom na rieku, ku ktorej bola pridaná obrovská príšernosť ako chodba, ktorá vás dostane z jedného terminálu do druhého. letisko; toto spájalo horné poschodia dvoch krídel.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was out on its own as a piece of interventionist architecture.
VETA: Bolo to samo o sebe ako kus intervencionistickej architektúry.

TEXT_SOURCE: That evening I took a taxi to Juraj Mihalik's apartment, which was in a large cement-faced house on a hill not far from the city centre.
VETA: V ten večer som sa taxíkom odviezol do bytu Juraja Mihálika, ktorý bol vo veľkom betónovom dome na kopci neďaleko centra mesta.

TEXT_SOURCE: He was in his early forties, a friendly, relaxed, open-faced character.
VETA: Mal niečo po štyridsiatke, bol priateľský, uvoľnený, s otvorenou tvárou.

TEXT_SOURCE: The main room of his apartment was one of those rooms that you catch a glimpse of in foreign cities: full of shadowy, lamp-lit spaces, walls painted white, paintings and a sense of people at ease in the evening.
VETA: Hlavná miestnosť jeho bytu bola jednou z tých miestností, ktoré zahliadnete v cudzích mestách: plná tienistých, lampami osvetlených priestorov, stien natretých nabielo, obrazov a pocitu, že ľudia sú vo večerných hodinách v pohode.

TEXT_SOURCE: Juraj 's wife, Tana, was in the room, wearing jeans and a loose top and no shoes.
VETA: V miestnosti bola Jurajova manželka Tana, oblečená mala v rifliach, vo voľnom tope a bez topánok.

TEXT_SOURCE: They both exuded physical wellbeing; there was not an ounce of spare flesh on either of them; they could have been Americans in an apartment in Manhattan.
VETA: Obaja vyžarovali fyzickú pohodu; na žiadnom z nich nebolo ani unca voľného mäsa; mohli to byť Američania v byte na Manhattane.

TEXT_SOURCE: We had a drink and sat down.
VETA: Dali sme si drink a sadli sme si.

TEXT_SOURCE: Juraj began to talk, moving back and forth over Slovakian history and recent political upheavals.
VETA: Juraj začal rozprávať, posúval sa tam a späť cez slovenské dejiny a nedávne politické otrasy.

TEXT_SOURCE: Tana interrupted him often, making him explain things in more detail, or adding comments.
VETA: Tana ho často prerušovala, nútila ho vysvetľovať veci podrobnejšie alebo pridávala komentáre.

TEXT_SOURCE: I wanted to know their views first on what had happened in Slovakia during the war.
VETA: Chcel som poznať najprv ich názory na to, čo sa na Slovensku dialo počas vojny.

TEXT_SOURCE: I don't know why I believed that this was a good place to start.
VETA: Neviem, prečo som veril, že toto je dobré miesto na začiatok.

TEXT_SOURCE: Slovakia was more or less on Hitler's side, Juraj said.
VETA: Slovensko bolo viac-menej na Hitlerovej strane, povedal Juraj.

TEXT_SOURCE: The state of Czechoslovakia was created after the First World War, but since the Czech Republic was richer, Slovakia was always treated as its little brother to the east; there was tension between the two all the time.
VETA: Po prvej svetovej vojne vznikol štát Česko-Slovensko, ale keďže Česko bolo bohatšie, Slovensko sa vždy chovalo ako jeho malý brat na východe; po celý čas bolo medzi nimi napätie.

TEXT_SOURCE: Slovakia took its historical chance in the Second World War, he said, and agreed to play the role of a puppet state for Hitler.
VETA: Slovensko podľa neho využilo svoju historickú šancu v druhej svetovej vojne a súhlasilo s tým, že bude hrať úlohu bábkového štátu pre Hitlera.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was a free state, a fascistic state, with a Catholic priest for president.
VETA: Bol to slobodný štát, fašistický štát s katolíckym kňazom za prezidenta.

TEXT_SOURCE: Sixty thousand Jews were deported to Poland in the first years of the war, but deportations were stopped in the later years, once it became clear that they were being deported to death-camps.
VETA: Šesťdesiattisíc Židov bolo deportovaných do Poľska v prvých rokoch vojny, ale deportácie boli zastavené v neskorších rokoch, keď sa ukázalo, že boli deportovaní do táborov smrti.

TEXT_SOURCE: But Slovakia had the same laws against Jews as did Germany.
VETA: Ale Slovensko malo rovnaké zákony proti Židom ako Nemecko.

TEXT_SOURCE: There was no war in Slovakia until the main war was over; the country was liberated by the Americans and the Russians.
VETA: Na Slovensku nebola vojna, kým sa neskončila hlavná vojna; krajinu oslobodili Američania a Rusi.

TEXT_SOURCE: In school, in the 1950s, the fascist period in Slovakia's history was completely ignored; instead, teachers concentrated on the uprising at the end of the war and the heroism of the communists.
VETA: V školstve sa v 50. rokoch 20. storočia fašistické obdobie v dejinách Slovenska úplne ignorovalo; namiesto toho sa učitelia sústredili na povstanie na konci vojny a hrdinstvo komunistov.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was not illegal to go to church then, Juraj said, but if you went you were in serious trouble, you could lose your job, your children would not be asked to attend secondary school.
VETA: Vtedy nebolo protizákonné chodiť do kostola, povedal Juraj, ale keby ste išli, mali by ste vážne problémy, mohli ste prísť o prácu, vaše deti by nepožiadali o strednú školu.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the 1950s older people, retired people and workers who had bad jobs went to church, people who had nothing to lose.
VETA: V 50. rokoch chodili do kostola starší ľudia, dôchodcovia a robotníci, ktorí mali zlú prácu, ľudia, ktorí nemali čo stratiť.

TEXT_SOURCE: The regime, he told me, tried to influence the church, and priests collaborated with the regime while others did not.
VETA: Povedal mi, že režim sa snažil ovplyvňovať cirkev a kňazi s režimom kolaborovali, zatiaľ čo iní nie.

TEXT_SOURCE: He himself did not make his first communion but others did; many went out to villages and did it secretly.
VETA: On sám nepristúpil k prvému svätému prijímaniu, ale iní áno; mnohí vyšli do dedín a robili to tajne.

TEXT_SOURCE: In 1971 his own sister got married and had a wedding in a church in a small village.
VETA: V roku 1971 sa jeho vlastná sestra vydala a mala svadbu v kostole v malej dedinke.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Prague Spring was led by Dubcek, a Slovak who spoke Slovakian, unlike others who went to Prague and spoke only Czech.
VETA: Pražskú jar viedol Dubček, Slovák, ktorý hovoril po slovensky, na rozdiel od iných, ktorí chodili do Prahy a hovorili len po česky.

TEXT_SOURCE: Later, he would get to know Dubcek and admire him for his sense of justice and his sense of humour.
VETA: Neskôr sa s Dubčekom zoznámi a bude ho obdivovať pre jeho zmysel pre spravodlivosť a zmysel pre humor.

TEXT_SOURCE: But the idea that he would travel one day to Washington with Dubcek was unimaginable in the dark years after the Prague Spring.
VETA: No predstava, že raz pocestuje s Dubčekom do Washingtonu, bola v temných rokoch po Pražskej jari nepredstaviteľná.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was always difficult being a Slovak in the federation, he said.
VETA: Byť Slovákom vo federácii bolo podľa neho vždy ťažké.

TEXT_SOURCE: Anyone in Bratislava who wanted to improve their career prospects moved to Prague.
VETA: Do Prahy sa presťahoval každý v Bratislave, kto si chcel zlepšiť kariérne vyhliadky.

TEXT_SOURCE: Only about 4 per cent of those working in the diplomatic service were Slovaks.
VETA: Len asi 4 percentá pracujúcich v diplomatických službách boli Slováci.

TEXT_SOURCE: Juraj himself had good friends in Prague: they had a common problem - communism.
VETA: Sám Juraj mal v Prahe dobrých priateľov: mali spoločný problém – komunizmus.

TEXT_SOURCE: There were only about seventy people killed during the Russian invasion, and in the immediate aftermath people were not sent to prison.
VETA: Počas ruskej invázie bolo zabitých len asi sedemdesiat ľudí a bezprostredne po nej neboli ľudia poslaní do väzenia.

TEXT_SOURCE: Things were done slowly step by step.
VETA: Veci sa robili pomaly krok za krokom.

TEXT_SOURCE: Since Juraj's parents were not communists he could not get into art school in Czechoslovakia; instead, he got a place in Krakow.
VETA: Keďže Jurajovi rodičia neboli komunisti, nemohol sa dostať na umeleckú školu v Československu; namiesto toho dostal miesto v Krakove.

TEXT_SOURCE: In 1975 he was invited by a family to visit the United States.
VETA: V roku 1975 ho rodina pozvala na návštevu Spojených štátov.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was always possible, he said, to get an exit visa, even though very few did.
VETA: Vždy bolo možné, povedal, získať výstupné vízum, aj keď len veľmi málo z nich.

TEXT_SOURCE: He loved New York.
VETA: Miloval New York.

TEXT_SOURCE: By this time he was studying at the Academy of Fine Arts in Bratislava, and, on his return he was expelled, told that he would have an imperialist influence on his fellow- students.
VETA: V tom čase už študoval na Vysokej škole výtvarných umení v Bratislave a po návrate ho vylúčili a povedali mu, že bude mať na svojich spolužiakov imperialistický vplyv.

TEXT_SOURCE: The official reason was given as 'a sudden loss of talent'.
VETA: Oficiálny dôvod bol uvedený ako náhla strata talentu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Even though he now views the election of Pope John Paul II as vitally important, in 1978 he viewed it merely as a big event for Poland.
VETA: Aj keď dnes považuje zvolenie pápeža Jána Pavla II. za životne dôležité, v roku 1978 to považoval len za veľkú udalosť pre Poľsko.

TEXT_SOURCE: The relationship between Prague and Bratislava remained the same throughout this period.
VETA: Vzťah medzi Prahou a Bratislavou zostal počas celého tohto obdobia rovnaký.

TEXT_SOURCE: For everything important you had to go to Prague; Slovakia was for lakes and rivers and mountains.
VETA: Pre všetko dôležité ste museli ísť do Prahy; Slovensko bolo pre jazerá, rieky a hory.

TEXT_SOURCE: Slovakia was a poor primitive country; the industry and the wealth were in the hands of the Czechs.
VETA: Slovensko bola chudobná primitívna krajina; priemysel a bohatstvo boli v rukách Čechov.

TEXT_SOURCE: There were no embassies in Bratislava, and none of the connections to the outside world which the western embassies in Prague offered to dissidents.
VETA: V Bratislave neboli žiadne veľvyslanectvá a žiadne spojenie s okolitým svetom, ktoré západné veľvyslanectvá v Prahe ponúkali disidentom.

TEXT_SOURCE: While there were a thousand Czech signatories to Charter 77, only fifty Slovaks signed.
VETA: Kým z českých signatárov Charty 77 bolo tisíc, Slovákov podpísalo len päťdesiat.

TEXT_SOURCE: But there was a dissident movement within Slovakia, he said, operating through the Church and the environmental movement, rather than Charter 77 or foreign channels.
VETA: Na Slovensku však podľa neho existuje disidentské hnutie, ktoré funguje skôr cez cirkev a ekologické hnutie ako cez Chartu 77 alebo zahraničné kanály.

TEXT_SOURCE: In 1983 Juraj was permitted to make and sell flower-pots; in the looser atmosphere of the Gorbachev years he began to export ceramics to Austria, and this business grew throughout the 198os.
VETA: V roku 1983 dostal Juraj povolenie vyrábať a predávať kvetináče; vo voľnejšej atmosfére gorbačovských rokov začal vyvážať keramiku do Rakúska a tento biznis rástol počas 88. rokov.

TEXT_SOURCE: In 1989 he went to the United States once more, but this time was disappointed.
VETA: V roku 1989 odišiel do Spojených štátov ešte raz, no tentoraz bol sklamaný.

TEXT_SOURCE: In his subsequent book about the Velvet Revolution, Velvet Failures, he wrote: 'During this stay in the US I totally lost my illusions about this paradise on earth.
VETA: Vo svojej nasledujúcej knihe o Nežnej revolúcii, Sametové zlyhania, napísal: Počas tohto pobytu v USA som úplne stratil ilúzie o tomto raji na zemi.

TEXT_SOURCE: I stayed with various people, particularly among the lower class.
VETA: Zostal som s rôznymi ľuďmi, najmä medzi nižšou triedou.

TEXT_SOURCE: I could not believe how hard the life was for some Americans.
VETA: Nemohol som uveriť, aký ťažký život mali niektorí Američania.

TEXT_SOURCE: The driver on the New York bus line who worked ten hours a day could not afford to pay health insurance, let alone for a private flat in Manhattan.
VETA: Vodič newyorskej autobusovej linky, ktorý pracoval desať hodín denne, si nemohol dovoliť platiť zdravotné poistenie, nieto ešte súkromný byt na Manhattane.

TEXT_SOURCE: I was told that more than twenty per cent of Americans couldn't afford health insurance.
VETA: Bolo mi povedané, že viac ako dvadsať percent Američanov si nemôže dovoliť zdravotné poistenie.

TEXT_SOURCE: I met an emigrant from Slovakia who worked as a shop assistant.
VETA: Stretol som emigranta zo Slovenska, ktorý pracoval ako predavač.

TEXT_SOURCE: In a pub fight he lost his front teeth, and because of this ugly hole in his mouth he lost his job next day.
VETA: V krčmovej bitke prišiel o predné zuby a kvôli tejto škaredej diere v ústach prišiel na druhý deň o prácu.

TEXT_SOURCE: He didn't have the money to pay his dentist so he also couldn't pay his rent either and eventually became homeless.'
VETA: Nemal peniaze na zaplatenie svojho zubára, takže tiež nemohol platiť nájomné a nakoniec sa stal bezdomovcom.

TEXT_SOURCE: The first open demonstration in Slovakia against the regime was organised through the Catholic Church.
VETA: Prvá otvorená demonštrácia na Slovensku proti režimu bola organizovaná prostredníctvom katolíckej cirkvi.

TEXT_SOURCE: It took place on 25 March 1988.
VETA: Stalo sa to 25. marca 1988.

TEXT_SOURCE: People were asked to walk out of the churches and gather in one of the city's squares to ask for civil and religious freedom.
VETA: Ľudia boli požiadaní, aby vyšli z kostolov a zhromaždili sa na jednom z námestí mesta, aby požiadali o občiansku a náboženskú slobodu.

TEXT_SOURCE: They were asked to carry lighted candles and remain silent.
VETA: Boli požiadaní, aby niesli zapálené sviečky a mlčali.

TEXT_SOURCE: The atmosphere was scary, Juraj said.
VETA: Atmosféra bola desivá, povedal Juraj.

TEXT_SOURCE: The police surrounded the square, they had water cannon and police dogs, but nothing happened.
VETA: Policajti obkľúčili námestie, mali vodné delo a policajné psy, no nič sa nestalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: In November the following year he was driving back to Bratislava when he heard the news that the Velvet Revolution had begun.
VETA: V novembri nasledujúceho roku sa vracal autom do Bratislavy, keď sa dozvedel, že sa začala Nežná revolúcia.

TEXT_SOURCE: In Bratislava old friends of his, artists and actors, became the leaders of the revolution, and formed political parties m the new democracy.
VETA: V Bratislave sa jeho starí priatelia, umelci a herci, stali vodcami revolúcie a vytvorili politické strany novej demokracie.

TEXT_SOURCE: At the beginning, Juraj said, Vaclav Havel was loved by everybody, and the problems between the two parts of Czechoslovakia did not surface.
VETA: Na začiatku, ako povedal Juraj, Václava Havla všetci milovali a problémy medzi oboma časťami Československa nevyplávali na povrch.

TEXT_SOURCE: As he wrote: 'Before 1989I did not have any strong feelings of nationality.
VETA: Ako napísal: Pred rokom 1989 som nemal žiadne silné pocity národnosti.

TEXT_SOURCE: I literally hated Slovak folklore, since it had always been supported by communists to the detriment of modern world culture, which was forbidden.
VETA: Slovenský folklór som doslova neznášal, keďže ho vždy podporovali komunisti na úkor modernej svetovej kultúry, ktorá bola zakázaná.

TEXT_SOURCE: I did not feel myself to be either Slovak or Czechoslovak. The only place I felt I belonged was Bratislava.
VETA: Necítil som sa byť ani Slovákom, ani Čechoslovákom. Jediné miesto, kde som cítil, že sem patrím, bola Bratislava.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the days after the revolution there was talk that the capital of the federation should be in Brno, which is halfway between Prague and Bratislava.
VETA: V dňoch po revolúcii sa hovorilo o tom, že hlavným mestom federácie by malo byť Brno, ktoré je na polceste medzi Prahou a Bratislavou.

TEXT_SOURCE: But there was a real sense that the Czechs did not understand Slovak sensitivities.
VETA: Ale bolo cítiť, že Česi nerozumejú slovenskej citlivosti.

TEXT_SOURCE: The idea, Juraj said, that there was no time for such matters now, that the establishment of a market economy must come first, was quite shocking for him.
VETA: Myšlienka, že na takéto veci teraz nie je čas, že najprv musí byť nastolenie trhového hospodárstva, bola pre neho dosť šokujúca.

TEXT_SOURCE: He had been sure that Havel would understand the problem, that it could not continue under democracy as it had under communism.
VETA: Bol si istý, že Havel problém pochopí, že to nemôže pokračovať za demokracie ako za komunizmu.

TEXT_SOURCE: After the revolution Juraj became a member of the Co-ordinating Committee of the Revolution, a twelve member body.
VETA: Po revolúcii sa Juraj stal členom Koordinačného výboru revolúcie, dvanásťčlenného orgánu.

TEXT_SOURCE: He spoke better English than the rest and worked on international relations.
VETA: Hovoril lepšie po anglicky ako ostatní a pracoval na medzinárodných vzťahoch.

TEXT_SOURCE: In February 1990 he became acutely conscious that there were going to be serious difficulties between Havel and the Slovaks.
VETA: Vo februári 1990 si naplno uvedomil, že medzi Havlom a Slovákmi budú vážne problémy.

TEXT_SOURCE: Havel had organised a trip to Washington and other North American capitals.
VETA: Havel zorganizoval cestu do Washingtonu a ďalších hlavných miest Severnej Ameriky.

TEXT_SOURCE: The delegation consisted of two hundred and ten people, the second biggest foreign delegation to Washington in history (the biggest was headed by de Gaulle).
VETA: Delegáciu tvorilo dvesto desať ľudí, druhá najväčšia zahraničná delegácia do Washingtonu v histórii (najväčšiu viedol de Gaulle).

TEXT_SOURCE: Originally, there were to be eight Slovaks, but the new government rang from Prague and reduced the number to four, and then put it back to eight when there were protests.
VETA: Pôvodne malo byť osem Slovákov, ale nová vláda zazvonila z Prahy a znížila počet na štyroch a potom, keď boli protesty, vrátila na osem.

TEXT_SOURCE: This was followed by a trip to Israel. No Slovak politician was included; the two Slovaks in the delegation were representatives of the Jewish community.
VETA: Potom nasledovala cesta do Izraela. Nebol zaradený žiadny slovenský politik; dvaja Slováci v delegácii boli zástupcami židovskej komunity.

TEXT_SOURCE: For Juraj, it was vital that a Slovak politician be present to apologise for what happened to the Jews in Slovakia during the war, and to make clear that the new Slovakia harboured no anti-Semitic feelings.
VETA: Pre Juraja bolo životne dôležité, aby bol prítomný slovenský politik, ktorý by sa ospravedlnil za to, čo sa stalo Židom na Slovensku počas vojny, a dal najavo, že nové Slovensko neprechováva žiadne antisemitské pocity.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the end the actor Milan Knazko, a close friend of Juraj's and a leader of the revolution in Bratislava, went and made a speech.
VETA: Na záver išiel s prejavom herec Milan Kňažko, Jurajov blízky priateľ a vodca revolúcie v Bratislave.

TEXT_SOURCE: Milan Knazko's story,' Juraj wrote in his book, 'as Havel's Slovak adviser at the Prague Castle speaks for itself.
VETA: Príbeh Milana Kňazka, napísal Juraj vo svojej knihe, ako hovorí Havlov slovenský poradca na Pražskom hrade.

TEXT_SOURCE: He accepted the post with the original intention that he would later become a vice-president - a step that Slovakia would have welcomed, but it never came about.
VETA: Funkciu prijal s pôvodným zámerom, že sa neskôr stane podpredsedom – krok, ktorý by Slovensko privítalo, no nikdy k nemu nedošlo.

TEXT_SOURCE: The opposite happened, since Knazko often disagreed with Havel and his team and strongly fought for Slovak interests. After several weeks in the Castle he lost direct access to the President and sometimes found himself waiting for days before Havel would agree to meet him.
VETA: Stal sa opak, keďže Kňažko často nesúhlasil s Havlom a jeho tímom a tvrdo bojoval za slovenské záujmy. Po niekoľkých týždňoch na Hrade stratil priamy prístup k prezidentovi a niekedy čakal, že celé dni čaká, kým Havel súhlasil so stretnutím.

TEXT_SOURCE: There were ten million Czechs and five million Slovaks; the ruling class in Bratislava came to feel throughout 1990 that they were being treated as nice peasants who lived in the mountains, who did not know enough to be part of the great velvet future, whose education out of their fascism and their Catholicism would take a long time.
VETA: Čechov bolo desať miliónov a Slovákov päť miliónov; vládnuca trieda v Bratislave po celý rok 1990 pocítila, že sa s nimi zaobchádza ako s milými roľníkmi, ktorí žili v horách, ktorí nevedeli dosť na to, aby boli súčasťou veľkej zamatovej budúcnosti, ktorých vzdelanie z fašizmu a katolicizmu bude trvať dlho. dlho.

TEXT_SOURCE: Prague was not even aware that there was a festering Slovak problem, as there was no Slovak newspaper available in Prague and no Slovak politician close to Havel.
VETA: Praha si ani neuvedomovala, že existuje hnisavý slovenský problém, keďže v Prahe neboli dostupné žiadne slovenské noviny a žiaden slovenský politik blízky Havlovi.

TEXT_SOURCE: Slovak emigrants in the United States pointed out that as far as the western media were concerned, Slovakia did not exist.
VETA: Slovenskí emigranti v USA upozorňovali, že pokiaľ ide o západné médiá, Slovensko neexistuje.

TEXT_SOURCE: In Prague, members of the old communist ruling class were slowly returning to positions of power, but in Bratislava, no one in the VPN (People Against Violence) had any political experience.
VETA: V Prahe sa do mocenských pozícií pomaly vracali príslušníci starej komunistickej vládnucej triedy, no v Bratislave nemal nikto vo VPN (Ľudia proti násiliu) politické skúsenosti.

TEXT_SOURCE: Juraj wrote: 'Our ideas about the world of politics, diplomacy and security were based on adventure novels rather than experience or logic.
VETA: Juraj napísal: Naše predstavy o svete politiky, diplomacie a bezpečnosti boli založené skôr na dobrodružných románoch než na skúsenostiach či logike.

TEXT_SOURCE: I remember my naivety when I agreed to go to the US embassy in Vienna, contact the CIA there and ask them to come to the VPN headquarters to check whether the building was bugged.
VETA: Pamätám si na svoju naivitu, keď som súhlasil, že pôjdem na americkú ambasádu vo Viedni, skontaktujem sa tam s CIA a požiadam ich, aby prišli do centrály VPN skontrolovať, či budova nie je odpočúvaná.

TEXT_SOURCE: They couldn't believe their ears when I asked them to put me in touch with the secret service and said there were no such people there.
VETA: Neverili vlastným ušiam, keď som ich požiadal, aby mi dali kontakt na tajnú službu a povedal, že tam takí ľudia nie sú.

TEXT_SOURCE: Eventually, a man responsible for security matters did see me.
VETA: Nakoniec ma uvidel muž zodpovedný za bezpečnostné záležitosti.

TEXT_SOURCE: He might have been from the CIA but could naturally never say so.
VETA: Mohol byť zo CIA, ale prirodzene to nikdy nemohol povedať.

TEXT_SOURCE: He gave me an address of an Austrian firm that provided this service, warned me it was expensive and saw me out the door.'
VETA: Dal mi adresu rakúskej firmy, ktorá túto službu poskytovala, varoval ma, že je to drahé a videl ma za dverami.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the spring of 1990 discussion began over the name of the federation and whether there should be a dash between Czech and Slovak.
VETA: Na jar 1990 sa začalo diskutovať o názve federácie a o tom, či by mala byť pomlčka medzi češtinou a slovenčinou.

TEXT_SOURCE: Various Czech politicians openly made fun of the Slovaks and said that the dash could be used in Bratislava but not abroad.
VETA: Rôzni českí politici si zo Slovákov otvorene robili srandu a hovorili, že pomlčka sa dá použiť v Bratislave, ale nie v zahraničí.

TEXT_SOURCE: Slovaks, in turn, suggested that their state should be mentioned first, as in Slovakoczech.
VETA: Slováci zasa navrhovali, aby sa ako v slovakčeštine najprv spomínal ich štát.

TEXT_SOURCE: In Prague, this was viewed as a joke.
VETA: V Prahe to považovali za vtip.

TEXT_SOURCE: Still, throughout 1990 Juraj believed that the federation could be preserved and he wanted to remain a citizen of Czechoslovakia, whether it had a dash or not.
VETA: Napriek tomu Juraj celý rok 1990 veril, že federácia sa dá zachovať a chcel zostať občanom Československa, či už to malo pomlčku alebo nie.

TEXT_SOURCE: But early in 1991 he began to change his mind.
VETA: Ale začiatkom roku 1991 začal meniť názor.

TEXT_SOURCE: On 14 March a demonstration was organised in Bratislava to commemorate the setting up of the Slovak state in 1939.
VETA: Dňa 14. marca sa v Bratislave konala demonštrácia na pamiatku vzniku Slovenského štátu v roku 1939.

TEXT_SOURCE: Between two and three thousand people attended, which was tiny compared to the huge demonstrations which had taken place at the time of the revolution when more than a hundred thousand people would turn up.
VETA: Zúčastnilo sa jej dve až tri tisícky ľudí, čo bolo málo v porovnaní s obrovskými demonštráciami, ktoré sa konali v čase revolúcie, keď prišlo viac ako stotisíc ľudí.

TEXT_SOURCE: There were two thousand wild Slovaks, Juraj remembered, a mixture of fascists, communists, anti-Semites and nationalists.
VETA: Divokých Slovákov bolo dvetisíc, spomínal Juraj, zmes fašistov, komunistov, antisemitov a nacionalistov.

TEXT_SOURCE: For them, Vaclav Havel was the real enemy.
VETA: Václav Havel bol pre nich skutočným nepriateľom.

TEXT_SOURCE: Juraj noticed that there was a surprising number of foreign journalists and camera crews covering this demonstration and then he understood.
VETA: Juraj si všimol, že túto demonštráciu sledovalo prekvapivo veľa zahraničných novinárov a kameramanov a potom pochopil.

TEXT_SOURCE: Without informing the Slovak minister for the interior, 'Citizen' Havel, as Juraj called him, had arrived in Slovakia and begun a walkabout during the demonstration.
VETA: Občan Havel, ako ho Juraj nazval, bez toho, aby o tom informoval slovenského ministra vnútra, pricestoval na Slovensko a začal počas demonštrácie obchádzať.

TEXT_SOURCE: The demonstrators attacked Havel, spat on him, kicked him and shouted abuse at him and the TV crews filmed all of this.
VETA: Demonštranti na Havla útočili, pľuli na neho, kopali do neho a kričali na neho nadávky a televízne štáby to všetko natáčali.

TEXT_SOURCE: They had, Juraj said, beautiful material of primitive Slovaks attacking the most loved politician in the world.
VETA: Mali, povedal Juraj, krásny materiál primitívnych Slovákov útočiacich na najobľúbenejšieho politika sveta.

TEXT_SOURCE: Havel, he believed, must have known that they would get such footage.
VETA: Havel, veril, musel vedieť, že dostanú takéto zábery.

TEXT_SOURCE: He blamed Havel for coming to Bratislava that day.
VETA: Havlovi vyčítal, že v ten deň prišiel do Bratislavy.

TEXT_SOURCE: He was also outraged by the way friends of his who had become Slovak politicians had been treated; one, he believed, had been accused of being a police informer under the old regime because he opposed Havel's policies on Slovakia.
VETA: Pobúrilo ho aj to, ako sa zaobchádzalo s jeho priateľmi, ktorí sa stali slovenskými politikmi; jedného z nich obvinili, že bol za starého režimu policajným informátorom, pretože bol proti Havlovej politike na Slovensku.

TEXT_SOURCE: He noticed that former friends now in power were becoming increasingly pompous.
VETA: Všimol si, že bývalí priatelia, ktorí sú teraz pri moci, sú čoraz pompéznejšie.

TEXT_SOURCE: In his book he wrote of a former colleague:
VETA: Vo svojej knihe o bývalom kolegovi napísal:

TEXT_SOURCE: When I visited him in Prague and tried to explain something which he wasn't prepared to accept as valid, he asked whether I realised I was talking to the Federal Minister of the Interior.
VETA: Keď som ho navštívil v Prahe a snažil sa mu vysvetliť niečo, čo nebol ochotný uznať za platné, spýtal sa, či som si uvedomil, že hovorím s federálnym ministrom vnútra.

TEXT_SOURCE: Another example: a director who was spontaneously greeted on the street by her friend's son lectured the boy the times have changed and you cannot address me as Susanne anymore.
VETA: Ďalší príklad: režisérka, ktorú na ulici spontánne privítal syn jej kamarátky, chlapcovi predniesla časy sa zmenili a už ma nemôžete oslovovať Susanne.

TEXT_SOURCE: On holidays in the mountains, a minister's wife wanted us to respect her husband's office.
VETA: Na dovolenke v horách chcela manželka ministra, aby sme rešpektovali úrad jej manžela.

TEXT_SOURCE: No one in the political mainstream in Slovakia had ever intended to secede from Czechoslovakia, he insisted, but when Havel announced, for example, that his country was not going to produce arms any more he did so without considering that Slovakia was where the arms were produced, and a sudden shut-down of arms factories would have a devastating effect on the economy there.
VETA: Nikto z hlavného politického prúdu na Slovensku nemal nikdy v úmysle odtrhnúť sa od Československa, trval na tom, ale keď napríklad Havel oznámil, že jeho krajina už nebude vyrábať zbrane, urobil tak bez toho, aby zvážil, že tam, kde sú zbrane, je Slovensko. vyrobené a náhle zatvorenie zbrojných tovární by malo na tamojšiu ekonomiku zničujúci dopad.

TEXT_SOURCE: Even after separation, Juraj believed, the campaign against Slovakia was still going on; the idea was being put out that the Czechs were good, progressive, smart, intelligent and the Slovaks were unstable, anti-Semitic old-fashioned, pro-communist.
VETA: Aj po odlúčení Juraj veril, že ťaženie proti Slovensku stále pokračuje; šírila sa myšlienka, že Česi sú dobrí, pokrokoví, bystrí, inteligentní a Slováci nestabilní, antisemitskí staromódni, prokomunistickí.

TEXT_SOURCE: There are differences between the Czechs and the Slovaks, he said.
VETA: Medzi Čechmi a Slovákmi sú podľa neho rozdiely.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Czechs are more eloquent, they have a stronger literary and artistic tradition, they are more secular, like Protestants, and they take ideology seriously.
VETA: Česi sú výrečnejší, majú silnejšiu literárnu a umeleckú tradíciu, sú sekulárnejší ako protestanti a ideológiu berú vážne.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Slovaks are more conservative, seventy per cent of them are Catholic, they are more down to earth and not so ready to be influenced by ideology.
VETA: Slováci sú konzervatívnejší, 70 percent z nich sú katolíci, sú viac pri zemi a nie sú tak pripravení na ovplyvnenie ideológiou.

TEXT_SOURCE: The way the Czechs have been treating us, he said, seems OK only because we are Catholics, but if we were Muslims it would be quite different, there would be war.
VETA: Spôsob, akým sa k nám Česi správajú, sa podľa neho zdá byť v poriadku len preto, že sme katolíci, ale keby sme boli moslimovia, bolo by to úplne iné, bola by vojna.

TEXT_SOURCE: In Slovakia, he told me, there has never been the same urge for revenge for what happened under the communists, they were ready to forgive; the Czechs, on the other hand, wanted to go through the files and blame people.
VETA: Povedal mi, že na Slovensku nikdy nebolo rovnaké nutkanie pomstiť sa za to, čo sa stalo za komunistov, boli pripravení odpustiť; Česi naopak chceli prechádzať spisy a obviňovať ľudí.

TEXT_SOURCE: They are more cerebral, he said, more interested in money; we are more emotional.
VETA: Povedal, že sú viac mozgoví, viac sa zaujímajú o peniaze; sme emotívnejší.

TEXT_SOURCE: The two nations did not have to separate; but, at the time, there was no better solution.
VETA: Oba národy sa nemuseli oddeliť; ale v tom čase neexistovalo lepšie riešenie.

TEXT_SOURCE: He himself decided to get out of politics and turned down several offers, including the Ministry for Culture and the ambassadorship to Washington.
VETA: Sám sa rozhodol odísť z politiky a odmietol niekoľko ponúk vrátane ministerstva kultúry a veľvyslanca vo Washingtone.

TEXT_SOURCE: He wanted to build up his business and was glad, he laughed, that he did not have to get up in the morning for meetings.
VETA: Chcel si vybudovať biznis a bol rád, smial sa, že nemusí ráno vstávať na stretnutia.

TEXT_SOURCE: He had been talking for hours, and I had been taking notes and asking questions, and Tana had been listening and adding details.
VETA: Hovoril celé hodiny a ja som si robil poznámky a kládol otázky a Tana počúvala a pridávala podrobnosti.

TEXT_SOURCE: We were exhausted. It was late.
VETA: Boli sme vyčerpaní. Bolo to neskoro.

TEXT_SOURCE: I felt that they still saw themselves as having a role in the new Slovakia, and talking to me, telling me about events from the Slovak point of view, was part of this.
VETA: Mal som pocit, že sa stále vidia v tom, že majú svoju úlohu v novom Slovensku, a to, že sa so mnou rozprávali, rozprávali mi o udalostiach zo slovenského pohľadu, k tomu patrili.

TEXT_SOURCE: We had a beer.
VETA: Dali sme si pivo.

TEXT_SOURCE: Juraj went to the phone and discovered that the KDH, the Christian Democratic Party, which had been in a coalition government after the 1990 elections but was now in opposition, was having its annual conference.
VETA: Juraj išiel k telefónu a zistil, že KDH, Kresťanskodemokratická strana, ktorá bola po voľbách v roku 1990 v koaličnej vláde, ale teraz bola v opozícii, má výročnú konferenciu.

TEXT_SOURCE: It might be difficult for him to go there, he said, making clear that the divisions and splits in the years since the fall of communism had caused a good deal of personal bitterness in Bratislava.
VETA: Asi bude pre neho ťažké tam ísť, povedal, čím dal najavo, že rozkoly a rozkoly v rokoch od pádu komunizmu spôsobili v Bratislave poriadnu osobnú horkosť.

TEXT_SOURCE: But he would take me there at lunchtime and see what happened.
VETA: Ale vzal ma tam na obed a videl, čo sa stalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: He and Tana discussed various characters who would be there, people they had worked with just a few years ago, and they laughed at what it would be like for Juraj to appear suddenly at the party conference.
VETA: S Taňou diskutovali o rôznych postavách, ktoré tam budú, o ľuďoch, s ktorými pracovali len pred pár rokmi, a smiali sa, aké by to bolo, keby sa Juraj zrazu objavil na straníckej konferencii.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was hard to sleep after all this information.
VETA: Po všetkých týchto informáciách sa mi ťažko spalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: Juraj and Tana had talked as though all this had just happened to them, they had spoken with that peculiar intensity of people after an accident or a bereavement.
VETA: Juraj a Tana sa rozprávali, akoby sa im to všetko práve stalo, rozprávali sa s tou zvláštnou intenzitou ľudí po nehode alebo smútku.

TEXT_SOURCE: I tried to think about it, work it all out, but when I saw them again at noon the next day, I felt as though I had not left their company at all.
VETA: Snažil som sa na to myslieť, všetko vyriešiť, ale keď som ich na druhý deň napoludnie opäť uvidel, mal som pocit, akoby som ich spoločnosť vôbec neopustil.

TEXT_SOURCE: Juraj had a fancy car outside the apartment building, and I could see, as we sat in it to drive to his studio, that he enjoyed having a car like this.
VETA: Juraj mal luxusné auto pred bytovkou a videl som, keď sme v ňom sedeli a odviezli sa k nemu do ateliéru, že ho baví mať takéto auto.

TEXT_SOURCE: He put a tape on as he drove up through the city and then along narrow twisting roads, climbing all the time.
VETA: Nalepil si pásku, keď išiel hore mestom a potom po úzkych kľukatých cestách, pričom neustále stúpal.

TEXT_SOURCE: The studio was a house in its own grounds at the end of a lane.
VETA: Štúdio bol dom na vlastnom pozemku na konci uličky.

TEXT_SOURCE: I had never really asked what sort of ceramics he made, and there seemed to be no examples in his apartment.
VETA: Nikdy som sa naozaj nepýtal, aký druh keramiky vyrába, a zdalo sa, že v jeho byte nie sú žiadne príklady.

TEXT_SOURCE: But, here I could see what he did and why it was so successful.
VETA: Ale tu som videl, čo urobil a prečo to bolo také úspešné.

TEXT_SOURCE: His pieces were elaborate jokes: his tea-pot, for example, was not completely useful, but it would be a good souvenir, or present; it looked well made and funny at the same time.
VETA: Jeho kúsky boli prepracované vtipy: jeho čajník napríklad nebol úplne užitočný, ale bol by to dobrý suvenír alebo darček; vyzeralo to dobre spracované a vtipné zároveň.

TEXT_SOURCE: I could see how it might be more fun making these and marketing them than being the Slovak Ambassador to Washington.
VETA: Videl som, že ich výroba a marketing môže byť zábavnejšia ako byť slovenským veľvyslancom vo Washingtone.

TEXT_SOURCE: Juraj was thinking about the Christian Democrats, going through the names of people who might be there, wondering whom I should meet. '
VETA: Juraj premýšľal o kresťanských demokratoch, prechádzal mená ľudí, ktorí by tam mohli byť, rozmýšľal, koho by som mal stretnúť. '

TEXT_SOURCE: The Christian Democrats feel so bad about being out of power,' he said and chuckled.
VETA: Kresťanskí demokrati sa cítia tak zle, že sú bez moci, povedal a zasmial sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: We drove back down to the city centre; he parked outside a modern building where the conference was going on.
VETA: Odviezli sme sa späť do centra mesta; zaparkoval pred modernou budovou, kde sa konala konferencia.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was now lunchtime, so there should be people free, he said.
VETA: Teraz bol obed, takže ľudia by mali byť voľní, povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: As soon as we went into the main hall I could see why Juraj was not a member of the Christian Democrats.
VETA: Len čo sme vošli do hlavnej sály, videl som, prečo Juraj nie je členom kresťanských demokratov.

TEXT_SOURCE: There were groups of men standing around; those who were not middle-aged looked as though they soon would be.
VETA: Okolo stáli skupiny mužov; tí, ktorí neboli v strednom veku, vyzerali, že čoskoro budú.

TEXT_SOURCE: They all had that slightly worn, cautious appearance of men who join centrist political parties.
VETA: Všetci mali taký mierne opotrebovaný, opatrný vzhľad mužov, ktorí sa pripájajú k centristickým politickým stranám.

TEXT_SOURCE: Juraj might have been the wayward son of any of these men in suits, although he was the same age as some of them.
VETA: Juraj mohol byť svojhlavým synom ktoréhokoľvek z týchto mužov v oblekoch, hoci bol v rovnakom veku ako niektorí z nich.

TEXT_SOURCE: He was dressed confidently in casual clothes, his hair was styled. He stood out in the hall.
VETA: Bol sebavedome oblečený v neformálnom oblečení, vlasy mal upravené. Vyčnieval v sále.

TEXT_SOURCE: He greeted a few people and then spoke to a man who moved quickly away.
VETA: Pozdravil niekoľko ľudí a potom sa dal do reči s mužom, ktorý sa rýchlo vzdialil.

TEXT_SOURCE: A few people looked at him.
VETA: Zopár ľudí sa naňho pozrelo.

TEXT_SOURCE: I was standing close to the door.
VETA: Stál som blízko pri dverách.

TEXT_SOURCE: He came over and said that this wasn't easy, but he thought he might be able to get me a senior figure who spoke English.
VETA: Prišiel za mnou a povedal, že to nebolo ľahké, ale myslel si, že by mi mohol zohnať seniora, ktorý hovorí po anglicky.

TEXT_SOURCE: One man, with whom he had worked, had moved away from him, he said.
VETA: Jeden muž, s ktorým pracoval, sa od neho odsťahoval, povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: I told him that I had seen this happen.
VETA: Povedal som mu, že som to videl.

TEXT_SOURCE: After a while we were ushered into a long office which was comfortably furnished.
VETA: Po chvíli sme boli uvedení do dlhej kancelárie, ktorá bola pohodlne zariadená.

TEXT_SOURCE: I felt that Juraj was excited being here and was looking forward to what the politician, who was called Jan Carnogursky, was going to say to a foreign journalist.
VETA: Cítil som, že Juraj je tu nadšený a teší sa, čo ten politik, ktorý sa volal Ján Čarnogurský, povie zahraničnému novinárovi.

TEXT_SOURCE: Carnogursky was in his fifties. He was a thin man with a cautious and serious appearance.
VETA: Čarnogurský mal po päťdesiatke. Bol to štíhly muž s opatrným a vážnym vzhľadom.

TEXT_SOURCE: His parents were both teachers, he said, but his father had been a political activist before the war and had supported the Slovak state during the war.
VETA: Jeho rodičia boli obaja učitelia, povedal, ale jeho otec bol pred vojnou politickým aktivistom a počas vojny podporoval Slovenský štát.

TEXT_SOURCE: After the war he had tried to establish a Catholic party, and was imprisoned.
VETA: Po vojne sa pokúsil založiť katolícku stranu a bol uväznený.

TEXT_SOURCE: Carnogursky was brought up as a Catholic.
VETA: Čarnogurský bol vychovaný ako katolík.

TEXT_SOURCE: He went to Mass on Sunday.
VETA: V nedeľu išiel na svätú omšu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Everyone around him, he said, was anti-communist.
VETA: Všetci okolo neho boli podľa neho antikomunisti.

TEXT_SOURCE: He didn't think that anyone in Slovakia was pro-communist, although some people joined the party.
VETA: Nemyslel si, že by bol niekto na Slovensku prokomunistický, hoci niektorí ľudia vstúpili do strany.

TEXT_SOURCE: But there was only one youth organisation, which was communist-run and he was a member; almost all young people were members.
VETA: Ale bola len jedna mládežnícka organizácia, ktorá bola riadená komunistami a on bol členom; takmer všetci mladí ľudia boli členmi.

TEXT_SOURCE: He lost three years of schooling because of the political activities of his father; he wasn't allowed into secondary school.
VETA: Kvôli politickým aktivitám svojho otca stratil tri roky školskej dochádzky; nepustili ho na strednú školu.

TEXT_SOURCE: He got a secondary education simply because his father had friends in the north of the country and he went to school there; the communists were not well-organised enough throughout the country to know who he was and prevent him.
VETA: Stredoškolské vzdelanie získal jednoducho preto, že jeho otec mal priateľov na severe krajiny a chodil tam do školy; komunisti neboli dostatočne dobre organizovaní v celej krajine, aby vedeli, kto je a zabránili mu.

TEXT_SOURCE: He did not support the Prague Spring.
VETA: Pražskú jar nepodporil.

TEXT_SOURCE: His family remained anti-communist, and the fact that this softening in the regime was run by communists was enough for him.
VETA: Jeho rodina zostala antikomunistická a stačilo mu, že toto zmäkčenie v režime riadili komunisti.

TEXT_SOURCE: He managed to study to become a lawyer and specialised in labour law, representing, for example, teachers who had been seen at Mass and fired, or teachers who had sent their children for religious instruction and been fired, or a senior doctor who had attended Mass and was fired.
VETA: Podarilo sa mu vyštudovať právnika a špecializovať sa na pracovné právo, pričom zastupoval napríklad učiteľov, ktorých videli na omši a vyhodili ich, alebo učiteľov, ktorí poslali svoje deti na vyučovanie náboženstva a boli prepustení, alebo staršieho lekára, ktorý sa zúčastnil omšu a bol prepustený.

TEXT_SOURCE: These were all unwritten rules, he said, and thus could be challenged in the courts.
VETA: Všetko sú to nepísané pravidlá, povedal, a preto môžu byť napadnuté na súdoch.

TEXT_SOURCE: Later, he defended people who had signed Charter 77, but in 1981 he was banned from practising as a lawyer.
VETA: Neskôr obhajoval ľudí, ktorí podpísali Chartu 77, no v roku 1981 mu zakázali vykonávať advokátsku prax.

TEXT_SOURCE: He drove a factory jeep for a while, then worked as a lawyer for the factory, then for a farmers' co-operative.
VETA: Chvíľu jazdil na továrenskom džípe, potom pracoval ako právnik v továrni, potom v roľníckom družstve.

TEXT_SOURCE: From 1987 he was unemployed again and the following years he started secretly to edit and distribute Christian Democratic propaganda.
VETA: Od roku 1987 bol opäť nezamestnaný a v nasledujúcich rokoch začal tajne upravovať a šíriť kresťanskodemokratickú propagandu.

TEXT_SOURCE: The second half of the 198os, he said, saw the rise of the organised Catholic movement in Slovakia.
VETA: V druhej polovici 88. rokov 20. storočia podľa jeho slov došlo na Slovensku k vzostupu organizovaného katolíckeho hnutia.

TEXT_SOURCE: There were pilgrimages to holy shrines.
VETA: Konali sa púte do svätyne.

TEXT_SOURCE: In 1987, for example, he told me, about six hundred thousand people took part in pilgrimages in Slovakia, and through this a self-conscious Catholic movement took shape.
VETA: Napríklad v roku 1987 mi povedal, že na Slovensku sa pútí zúčastnilo asi šesťstotisíc ľudí a vďaka tomu sa formovalo uvedomelé katolícke hnutie.

TEXT_SOURCE: The state allowed and, in certain respects, encouraged an official church, but this was organised by a secret church, and it was the secret church which planned that first demonstration in March 1988, a secret church made up of priests and lay activists.
VETA: Štát povoľoval a v určitých ohľadoch podporoval oficiálnu cirkev, ale organizovala ju tajná cirkev a bola to práve tajná cirkev, ktorá plánovala prvú demonštráciu v marci 1988, tajná cirkev zložená z kňazov a laických aktivistov.

TEXT_SOURCE: In 1989 he was imprisoned; in November when the revolution began he was sharing a tiny cell.
VETA: V roku 1989 bol uväznený; v novembri, keď začala revolúcia, zdieľal malú celu.

TEXT_SOURCE: He knew that the Berlin Wall had fallen, and he knew there were demonstrations in Prague and Bratislava, but one night he could hear clapping and shouting, he could hear the crowds outside.
VETA: Vedel, že padol Berlínsky múr a vedel, že v Prahe a Bratislave sú demonštrácie, ale raz v noci počul tlieskanie a krik, počul davy vonku.

TEXT_SOURCE: That was 23 November 1989 and there were five thousand people demonstrating in front of the prison.
VETA: Bolo to 23. novembra 1989 a pred väznicou demonštrovalo päťtisíc ľudí.

TEXT_SOURCE: ('I was there,' Juraj interjected as Carnogursky described the scene.)
VETA: (Bol som tam, vložil sa do toho Juraj, keď Čarnogurský opísal scénu.)

TEXT_SOURCE: Two days later he was released, let out into the street alone.
VETA: O dva dni neskôr bol prepustený a pustený sám na ulicu.

TEXT_SOURCE: He took a tram home.
VETA: Išiel domov električkou.

TEXT_SOURCE: A few days later he was a member of the delegation which negotiated with the government, demanding the participation of the opposition in a new government, followed by free elections.
VETA: O niekoľko dní bol členom delegácie, ktorá rokovala s vládou a požadovala účasť opozície v novej vláde, po ktorej nasledovali slobodné voľby.

TEXT_SOURCE: He was the only Slovak in the ten-person delegation, but that was not an issue then; overcoming communism, he said, was the aim, everyone's overwhelming aim.
VETA: Bol jediným Slovákom v desaťčlennej delegácii, ale o to vtedy nešlo; Prekonanie komunizmu, povedal, bolo cieľom, zdrvujúcim cieľom každého.

TEXT_SOURCE: On 10 December, two weeks after he was freed, the government caved in.
VETA: 10. decembra, dva týždne po jeho prepustení, vláda ustúpila.

TEXT_SOURCE: Suddenly, he was deputy prime minister of Czechoslovakia. He had cars, telephones, a secretariat.
VETA: Zrazu bol podpredsedom československej vlády. Mal autá, telefóny, sekretariát.

TEXT_SOURCE: After twenty-five years in opposition all at once he had to become engaged in all aspects of the state.
VETA: Po dvadsiatich piatich rokoch v opozícii sa zrazu musel angažovať vo všetkých aspektoch štátu.

TEXT_SOURCE: He just changed his point of view, he said, as if it all had really been very easy.
VETA: Len zmenil uhol pohľadu, povedal, akoby to všetko bolo naozaj veľmi jednoduché.

TEXT_SOURCE: He was in charge of new legislation, passing, for example, a law governing the freedom of the press.
VETA: Mal na starosti novú legislatívu, prijal napríklad zákon upravujúci slobodu tlače.

TEXT_SOURCE: Although he was based in Prague he started to organise his party in Bratislava.
VETA: Hoci sídlil v Prahe, svoju párty začal organizovať v Bratislave.

TEXT_SOURCE: He had always been aware, he said, of the problems between the Czechs and the Slovaks and he gave me precisely the same definition of the difference as had Juraj.
VETA: Vždy si bol vedomý problémov medzi Čechmi a Slovákmi a dal mi presne rovnakú definíciu rozdielu ako Juraj.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Czechs were more rational and western; the Slovaks more emotional.
VETA: Česi boli racionálnejší a západnejší; Slováci viac emotívni.

TEXT_SOURCE: In ways, he said, the difficulties between the two nations were caused by Czech lethargy in relation to Slovak grievances.
VETA: Ťažkosti medzi oboma národmi podľa neho svojím spôsobom spôsobila česká letargia vo vzťahu k slovenským krívam.

TEXT_SOURCE: He was not a Slovak nationalist; for him anti-communism was more important.
VETA: Nebol slovenský národovec; pre neho bol dôležitejší antikomunizmus.

TEXT_SOURCE: Nationalism, he said, is always quite easy to misuse, as a means of mobilising people.
VETA: Nacionalizmus je podľa neho vždy celkom ľahko zneužiteľný ako prostriedok mobilizácie ľudí.

TEXT_SOURCE: A good number of former communists, he told me, quickly became nationalists.
VETA: Z mnohých bývalých komunistov, povedal mi, sa rýchlo stali nacionalisti.

TEXT_SOURCE: He himself wanted the relationship between the two states to be modelled on states of the European Union.
VETA: Sám chcel, aby sa vzťah medzi oboma štátmi riadil podľa vzoru štátov Európskej únie.

TEXT_SOURCE: I asked him about the war years.
VETA: Spýtal som sa ho na vojnové roky.

TEXT_SOURCE: During the war, he said, Slovakia was formally independent for the first time.
VETA: Počas vojny bolo podľa neho Slovensko po prvý raz formálne samostatné.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Slovak state was quite successful, he said, economically, culturally, politically.
VETA: Slovenský štát bol celkom úspešný, povedal, ekonomicky, kultúrne, politicky.

TEXT_SOURCE: Its president was a Catholic priest, Dr Josef Tiso, and there is, he said, a positive feeling among Catholics about this state.
VETA: Jeho prezidentom bol katolícky kňaz Dr. Josef Tiso a medzi katolíkmi je podľa neho pozitívny pocit z tohto štátu.

TEXT_SOURCE: At the time, Carnogursky believed, Slovakia had two options: to be divided between Poland, Hungary and Germany, or to become a puppet state under Hitler.
VETA: Čarnogurský veril, že Slovensko malo v tom čase dve možnosti: rozdeliť sa medzi Poľsko, Maďarsko a Nemecko, alebo sa stať bábkovým štátom pod vedením Hitlera.

TEXT_SOURCE: I merely asked questions.
VETA: Len som kládol otázky.

TEXT_SOURCE: I did not argue, I underlined what he had said in my notebook: The Slovak state was quite successful, economically, culturally, politically.
VETA: Nehádal som sa, podčiarkol som to, čo povedal v mojom zošite: Slovenský štát bol celkom úspešný, ekonomicky, kultúrne, politicky.

TEXT_SOURCE: I had expected him to hedge his bets, fudge the issue, but he seemed to have no idea how important this was.
VETA: Očakával som od neho, že zaistí svoje stávky, prešibe problém, ale zdalo sa, že netuší, aké dôležité to je.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was the same problem as the Croatians had: how to deal with that period when Hitler offered them a quisling state and they accepted, how to deal with history that was still remembered by others such as Serbs and Jews as dark and murderous, but by Croats and Slovaks as the first time they had a state as well as a nation.
VETA: Bol to ten istý problém, aký mali Chorváti: ako sa vysporiadať s tým obdobím, keď im Hitler ponúkol šibalský štát a oni ho prijali, ako sa vysporiadať s históriou, ktorú si iní ako Srbi a Židia stále pamätali ako temnú a vražednú, ale Chorváti a Slováci ako prvý mali štát aj národ.

TEXT_SOURCE: No one in the West now in a Christian Democratic party would admit to seeing the Hitler period as anything other than disgusting.
VETA: Nikto na Západe teraz v kresťanskodemokratickej strane by nepriznal, že Hitlerovu dobu považuje za niečo iné ako nechutné.

TEXT_SOURCE: Carnogursky was naive; he was just beginning.
VETA: Čarnogurský bol naivný; ešte len začínal.

TEXT_SOURCE: But I felt, all the same, that he needed to know, as other countries had learned in the years after the war, what the word Hitler meant to Jews, gypsies and homosexuals in Europe; and how the quisling states bear a guilt for what happened.
VETA: Ale napriek tomu som cítil, že potrebuje vedieť, ako sa ostatné krajiny naučili roky po vojne, čo slovo Hitler znamená pre Židov, Rómov a homosexuálov v Európe; a ako quislingské štáty nesú vinu za to, čo sa stalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: As we left the building I presumed that Juraj had similar feelings and I spoke to him as though we shared a political outlook.
VETA: Keď sme vychádzali z budovy, predpokladal som, že Juraj má podobné pocity a hovoril som s ním, ako keby sme zdieľali politické názory.

TEXT_SOURCE: But he did not understand what I was talking about.
VETA: Ale nerozumel, o čom hovorím.

TEXT_SOURCE: The war years, he said, we have nothing to do with them; and we still don't know enough about them.
VETA: Vojnové roky, povedal, s nimi nemáme nič spoločné; a stále o nich nevieme dosť.

TEXT_SOURCE: I walked to the car with him and we drove back towards his studio.
VETA: Išiel som s ním k autu a išli sme späť smerom k jeho štúdiu.

TEXT_SOURCE: I spent that afternoon in a house close to the studio which had a big garden.
VETA: To popoludnie som strávil v dome blízko ateliéru, ktorý mal veľkú záhradu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Friends of Juraj and Tana's were hosting a barbecue.
VETA: Priatelia Juraja a Tany organizovali grilovačku.

TEXT_SOURCE: People dropped in for a while, had a drink and left, and then others came.
VETA: Ľudia na chvíľu zapadli, vypili a odišli a potom prišli ďalší.

TEXT_SOURCE: Juraj and Tana went to do some work, but I stayed on.
VETA: Juraj s Tanou išli robiť nejaké práce, no ja som zostal.

TEXT_SOURCE: Everyone was bright and well-dressed and thirtysomething.
VETA: Všetci boli bystrí a dobre oblečení a mali okolo tridsať.
