VETA: Tým, že som opustil Disney World, som konečne našiel skutočný americký Epcot, rovnako ako Eric našiel svoje Kerouacove zjavenie.

TEXT_SOURCE: The monk blessed me, he remembered.
VETA: Mních ma požehnal, spomenul si.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Romanovs, in a 1913 photo.
VETA: Romanovci na fotografii z roku 1913.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the center of the group, Tsar Nicholas II sits with his wife, the tsarina Alexandra.
VETA: V strede skupiny sedí cár Mikuláš II so svojou manželkou, cárkou Alexandrou.

TEXT_SOURCE: Behind, from left to right, are their daughters Maria, Olga, and Tatiana.
VETA: Za nimi sú zľava doprava ich dcéry Mária, Oľga a Tatiana.

TEXT_SOURCE: Their youngest daughter, Anastasia, is seated on the stool, and Alexei, their only son, kneels in front.
VETA: Ich najmladšia dcéra Anastasia sedí na stoličke a Alexej, ich jediný syn, kľačí vpredu.

TEXT_SOURCE: On a July night 100 years ago, the family's rule of Russia came to a decisive, bloody end.
VETA: Jednej júlovej noci pred 100 rokmi sa rodinná vláda v Rusku definitívne, krvavo skončila.

TEXT_SOURCE: Revolution came to Russia in February 1917, and a month later Nicholas II, emperor and autocrat of all the Russias, abdicated his throne to become plain Nicholas Romanov.
VETA: Revolúcia prišla do Ruska vo februári 1917 a o mesiac neskôr sa Mikuláš II., cisár a samovládca všetkých Rusov, vzdal svojho trónu a stal sa obyčajným Nicholasom Romanovom.

TEXT_SOURCE: With revolution at home and catastrophic failure in the First World War abroad, the Romanov dynasty, which had celebrated its third century in power in 1913, came to a swift end.
VETA: S revolúciou doma a katastrofálnym neúspechom v prvej svetovej vojne v zahraničí sa dynastia Romanovcov, ktorá v roku 1913 oslávila tretie storočie pri moci, rýchlo skončila.

TEXT_SOURCE: Bolshevik forces held the Romanov family as prisoners, moving from place to place until one bloody night in July 1918.
VETA: Boľševické sily držali rodinu Romanovcov ako zajatcov, presúvali sa z miesta na miesto až do jednej krvavej noci v júli 1918.

TEXT_SOURCE: The entire family was wiped out, victims to a fate that they refused to see coming.
VETA: Celá rodina bola zničená, obete osudu, ktorý odmietli vidieť prísť.

TEXT_SOURCE: (Read more about Russia's chaotic year of revolution.)
VETA: (Prečítajte si viac o ruskom chaotickom roku revolúcie.)

TEXT_SOURCE: Abdication could have been a relief for Nicholas, who took the throne in 1894 after the death of his father, Alexander III.
VETA: Abdikácia mohla byť úľavou pre Mikuláša, ktorý nastúpil na trón v roku 1894 po smrti svojho otca Alexandra III.

TEXT_SOURCE: Described as an unimaginative and limited man, he was suited neither by his abilities nor temperament to rule during such turbulent times.
VETA: Opisovaný ako nenápaditý a obmedzený muž, nevyhovoval ani svojimi schopnosťami, ani temperamentom, aby vládol v takýchto turbulentných časoch.

TEXT_SOURCE: Chronically indecisive, Nicholas would put off issuing an order until the last minute and then simply repeat the most recent piece of advice he had been given.
VETA: Chronicky nerozhodný Nicholas odkladal vydanie príkazu na poslednú chvíľu a potom jednoducho zopakoval poslednú radu, ktorú dostal.

TEXT_SOURCE: A joke making the rounds in St. Petersburg said that the two most powerful people in Russia were the tsar and whoever had spoken to him last.
VETA: Vtip, ktorý koloval v Petrohrade, hovoril, že dvaja najmocnejší ľudia v Rusku boli cár a ten, kto s ním hovoril ako posledný.

TEXT_SOURCE: (See photos of St. Petersburg, Russia today.)
VETA: (Pozrite si dnešné fotografie Petrohradu v Rusku.)

TEXT_SOURCE: Nicholas was not a progressive overlord and firmly believed in his divine right to rule, a view his wife, Alexandra, shared.
VETA: Nicholas nebol progresívnym vládcom a pevne veril vo svoje božské právo vládnuť, čo zdieľala aj jeho manželka Alexandra.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Okhrana—his secret police, a terrible and murderous organization—operated with impunity.
VETA: Okhrana – jeho tajná polícia, hrozná a vražedná organizácia – fungovala beztrestne.

TEXT_SOURCE: As a leader, Tsar Nicholas knew few successes.
VETA: Cár Mikuláš ako vodca poznal málo úspechov.

TEXT_SOURCE: In 1904, he fought and lost a war with Japan, and in 1905, faced a revolution at home against his autocratic regime.
VETA: V roku 1904 bojoval a prehral vojnu s Japonskom a v roku 1905 čelil doma revolúcii proti svojmu autokratickému režimu.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the October Manifesto of 1905 he grudgingly pledged to create the Duma, an elected legislative body.
VETA: V októbrovom manifeste z roku 1905 sa neochotne zaviazal vytvoriť Dumu, volený zákonodarný orgán.

TEXT_SOURCE: Before it had held its first session, the tsar limited its powers in an attempt to hold on to his governing power.
VETA: Predtým, ako sa konalo prvé zasadanie, cár obmedzil svoje právomoci v snahe udržať si svoju vládnu moc.

TEXT_SOURCE: When World War I came in 1914, Nicholas led his people into a conflict that would strain the nation’s resources and cost millions of lives.
VETA: Keď v roku 1914 prišla prvá svetová vojna, Nicholas priviedol svoj ľud do konfliktu, ktorý by zaťažil národné zdroje a stál milióny životov.

TEXT_SOURCE: Despite it all, he remained blind to his growing unpopularity and was convinced that the people loved him nonetheless.
VETA: Napriek tomu všetkému zostal slepý k svojej rastúcej neobľúbenosti a bol presvedčený, že ho ľudia napriek tomu milujú.

TEXT_SOURCE: The people, for their part, took a different view.
VETA: Ľudia mali iný názor.

TEXT_SOURCE: Their nickname for him was Nicholas the Bloody.
VETA: Ich prezývka pre neho bola Nicholas the Bloody.

TEXT_SOURCE: (Read about the U. S. entry into World War I.)
VETA: (Prečítajte si o vstupe USA do 1. svetovej vojny.)

TEXT_SOURCE: A 19th-century lithograph depicts the coronation of Tsar Nicholas II.
VETA: Litografia z 19. storočia zobrazuje korunováciu cára Mikuláša II.

TEXT_SOURCE: Used to crown Nicholas II in 1896, the Imperial Crown was first used at the coronation of Catherine the Great in 1762.
VETA: Cisárska koruna, ktorá bola použitá na korunováciu Mikuláša II. v roku 1896, bola prvýkrát použitá pri korunovácii Kataríny Veľkej v roku 1762.

TEXT_SOURCE: It is encrusted with nearly 5,000 carefully arranged diamonds.
VETA: Je pokrytý takmer 5000 starostlivo usporiadanými diamantmi.

TEXT_SOURCE: Perhaps the most famous treasures, jeweled eggs were made for the tsars every Easter since 1885 by the House of Fabergé in St. Petersburg.
VETA: Azda najznámejšie poklady, vajíčka zdobené šperkami, vyrábali pre cárov každú Veľkú noc od roku 1885 rod Fabergé v Petrohrade.

TEXT_SOURCE: The 1913 egg, shown here, was created to mark the tercentenary of the dynasty’s founding.
VETA: Vajíčko z roku 1913, ktoré je tu zobrazené, bolo vytvorené pri príležitosti tristého výročia založenia dynastie.

TEXT_SOURCE: Painted by Johannes Zehngraf in the 1890s, these miniature likenesses of Tsar Nicholas II and his eldest child, Olga, are mounted on gold- and jewel-inlaid jade pedestals, created by the House of Fabergé.
VETA: Tieto miniatúrne podobizne cára Mikuláša II. a jeho najstaršieho dieťaťa Oľgy, ktoré namaľoval Johannes Zehngraf v 90. rokoch 19. storočia, sú namontované na zlatom a drahokamami vykladanom nefritovom podstavci, ktorý vytvoril rod Fabergé.

TEXT_SOURCE: Few objects better express the Romanov dynasty’s blend of piety and conspicuous consumption than this set of gold vessels used to celebrate Mass.
VETA: Len málo predmetov lepšie vyjadruje zmes zbožnosti a nápadnej konzumácie dynastie Romanovcov ako táto sada zlatých nádob používaných na slávenie omše.

TEXT_SOURCE: Commissioned by the 17th-century tsar Fyodor III, they are inlaid with 10 types of jewels.
VETA: Na objednávku cára Fjodora III. zo 17. storočia sú vykladané 10 druhmi šperkov.

TEXT_SOURCE: State Armory, Moscow.
VETA: Štátna zbrojnica, Moskva.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Catherine Palace, built by Catherine the Great (r. 1762-1796) in the town of Tsarskoye Selo near St. Petersburg, was the summer residence of the tsars.
VETA: Katarínsky palác, ktorý postavila Katarína Veľká (r. 1762-1796) v mestečku Cárskoje Selo neďaleko Petrohradu, bol letným sídlom cárov.

TEXT_SOURCE: The nearby Alexander Palace, also built in Catherine’s reign, was Nicholas II’s favorite residence.
VETA: Neďaleký Alexandrov palác, tiež postavený za vlády Kataríny, bol obľúbeným sídlom Mikuláša II.

TEXT_SOURCE: after his abdication in 1917, Nicholas and his family were held captive there.
VETA: po jeho abdikácii v roku 1917 tam bol Nicholas s rodinou držaný v zajatí.

TEXT_SOURCE: Royal Family Nicholas was, however, a family man.
VETA: Kráľovská rodina Nicholas bol však rodinný muž.

TEXT_SOURCE: He loved his wife, Alexandra, and she loved him.
VETA: Miloval svoju manželku Alexandru a ona milovala jeho.

TEXT_SOURCE: They were lucky to have such a match at a time when the general rule was that monarchs wed for dynastic convenience rather than affection.
VETA: Mali šťastie, že mali takýto zápas v čase, keď všeobecným pravidlom bolo, že panovníci sa ženili skôr pre dynastické pohodlie než pre náklonnosť.

TEXT_SOURCE: Married in 1894, they had four daughters, Olga, Tatiana, Maria, and Anastasia in succession.
VETA: Zosobášili sa v roku 1894 a mali postupne štyri dcéry, Oľgu, Tatianu, Máriu a Anastáziu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Alexei, the longed-for son and heir, was their last child, born in 1904.
VETA: Alexej, vytúžený syn a dedič, bol ich posledným dieťaťom, ktoré sa narodilo v roku 1904.

TEXT_SOURCE: By all reports, the Romanovs were a happy and devoted family.
VETA: Podľa všetkých správ boli Romanovci šťastná a oddaná rodina.

TEXT_SOURCE: The five children of Tsar Nicholas II of Russia in a 1910 photo, eight years before war and revolution would sweep them all to a violent death.
VETA: Päť detí ruského cára Mikuláša II. na fotografii z roku 1910, osem rokov pred vojnou a revolúciou, by ich všetkých zmietlo na násilnú smrť.

TEXT_SOURCE: Below right, a plate depicting Tsar Nicholas and his wife, Alexandra, in honor of the couple’s visit to France in 1896.
VETA: Vpravo dole je doska zobrazujúca cára Mikuláša a jeho manželku Alexandru na počesť návštevy páru vo Francúzsku v roku 1896.

TEXT_SOURCE: German by birth and granddaughter of Britain’s Queen Victoria, Alexandra possessed a more powerful and imposing character than her husband.
VETA: Alexandra, pôvodom Nemka a vnučka britskej kráľovnej Viktórie, mala silnejší a impozantnejší charakter ako jej manžel.

TEXT_SOURCE: An introverted and distant manner alienated her from the Russian people, who saw her as an outsider.
VETA: Introvertný a vzdialený spôsob ju odcudzil od ruského ľudu, ktorý ju považoval za outsidera.

TEXT_SOURCE: Unlike her husband, Alexandra recognized her own unpopularity, which made her highly sensitive, controlling, and paranoid.
VETA: Na rozdiel od svojho manžela si Alexandra uvedomila svoju neobľúbenosť, vďaka čomu bola veľmi citlivá, ovládajúca sa a paranoidná.

TEXT_SOURCE: (Also learn the love story behind Queen Victoria's crown jewels.)
VETA: (Naučte sa tiež príbeh lásky za korunovačnými klenotmi kráľovnej Viktórie.)

TEXT_SOURCE: Sigmund Freud once remarked that a family tends to organize itself around its most damaged member.
VETA: Sigmund Freud raz poznamenal, že rodina má tendenciu organizovať sa okolo svojho najviac poškodeného člena.

TEXT_SOURCE: For the Romanovs that could have been Alexandra.
VETA: Pre Romanovcov to mohla byť Alexandra.

TEXT_SOURCE: Her high-strung temperament ensured the constant attention and solicitude of her husband and daughters.
VETA: Jej temperamentný temperament zaisťoval neustálu pozornosť a starostlivosť jej manžela a dcér.

TEXT_SOURCE: Six years separated the oldest from the youngest grand duchess;Alexandra relied on all of them and kept them close.
VETA: Najstaršiu a najmladšiu veľkovojvodkyňu delilo šesť rokov; Alexandra sa na všetkých spoliehala a držala ich blízko seba.

TEXT_SOURCE: The family fondly nicknamed the older daughters Olga and Tatiana the Big Pair, and the younger sisters Maria and Anastasia, the Little Pair.
VETA: Staršie dcéry Oľga a Tatiana rodina s obľubou prezývala Veľký pár a mladšie sestry Máriu a Anastasiu Malý pár.

TEXT_SOURCE: All of the family, especially Alexandra, doted on the youngest child, Alexei.
VETA: Celá rodina, najmä Alexandra, milovala najmladšie dieťa Alexeja.

TEXT_SOURCE: The heir to the throne was born with hemophilia, which came from Alexandra’s side of the family.
VETA: Následník trónu sa narodil s hemofíliou, ktorá pochádzala z Alexandrinej strany rodiny.

TEXT_SOURCE: His health became the main focus of their lives.
VETA: Jeho zdravie sa stalo hlavnou náplňou ich života.

TEXT_SOURCE: Nearly any activity carried the risk of a knock or cut that could trigger catastrophic bouts of bleeding.
VETA: Takmer každá činnosť znamenala riziko úderu alebo rezu, ktoré by mohli vyvolať katastrofické záchvaty krvácania.

TEXT_SOURCE: Alexandra would sleep on the floor by his bedside during the weeks of recuperation.
VETA: Alexandra spala na zemi pri jeho posteli počas týždňov zotavovania.

TEXT_SOURCE: The boy was gentle, with a mischievous streak and spoiled by his mother and sisters.
VETA: Chlapec bol nežný, so šibalským šmrncom a rozmaznaný svojou matkou a sestrami.

TEXT_SOURCE: In a period where parents of the upper classes cultivated a distant relationship with their children, Alexei’s physical dependence bonded him tightly to his mother and father.
VETA: V období, keď si rodičia vyšších vrstiev pestovali vzdialený vzťah so svojimi deťmi, Alexejova fyzická závislosť ho pevne pripútala k matke a otcovi.

TEXT_SOURCE: Alexei, age eight or nine, gazes into the camera while playing with his mother’s pearl necklace in this 1913 image.
VETA: Alexej, ktorý má osem alebo deväť rokov, hľadí do kamery a hrá sa s perlovým náhrdelníkom svojej matky na tomto obrázku z roku 1913.

TEXT_SOURCE: It also made them vulnerable.
VETA: Robilo ich to aj zraniteľnými.

TEXT_SOURCE: When someone came along who could exploit that vulnerability, they fell for him completely.
VETA: Keď sa objavil niekto, kto mohol využiť túto zraniteľnosť, úplne mu prepadli.

TEXT_SOURCE: Grigory Rasputin, born in western Siberia, was a self-proclaimed holy man.
VETA: Grigorij Rasputin, narodený v západnej Sibíri, bol samozvaným svätým mužom.

TEXT_SOURCE: He had a mixed reputation for licentious behavior, healing powers, and the ability to see the future.
VETA: Mal zmiešanú povesť pre neslušné správanie, liečivé schopnosti a schopnosť vidieť budúcnosť.

TEXT_SOURCE: Whether he was a huckster or believed he had supernatural powers is unclear.
VETA: Či bol podvodník alebo veril, že má nadprirodzené schopnosti, nie je jasné.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Romanovs definitely believed in him, and he wielded powerful influence over the royal family, especially Alexandra.
VETA: Romanovci v neho rozhodne verili a on mal silný vplyv na kráľovskú rodinu, najmä na Alexandru.

TEXT_SOURCE: Healing Hopes
VETA: Liečivé nádeje

TEXT_SOURCE: When Rasputin first met the Romanovs in 1905, the tsarina was desperate.
VETA: Keď sa Rasputin v roku 1905 prvýkrát stretol s Romanovcami, cárka bola zúfalá.

TEXT_SOURCE: The 1905 revolution had almost seen the monarchy overthrown.
VETA: Revolúcia v roku 1905 bola takmer svedkom zvrhnutia monarchie.

TEXT_SOURCE: The birth of Alexei the previous year gave them the heir she had been hoping for, but his hemophilia was not only a personal tragedy but also a threat to the dynasty.
VETA: Narodenie Alexeja v predchádzajúcom roku im dalo dediča, v ktorého dúfala, no jeho hemofília nebola len osobnou tragédiou, ale aj hrozbou pre dynastiu.

TEXT_SOURCE: This situation of political crisis and maternal agony enabled Rasputin to insinuate himself into the family.
VETA: Táto situácia politickej krízy a materskej agónie umožnila Rasputinovi preniknúť do rodiny.

TEXT_SOURCE: In 1908 Alexei suffered a severe bleeding episode and Rasputin was able to ease the boy’s pain.
VETA: V roku 1908 Alexej utrpel ťažkú epizódu krvácania a Rasputin dokázal chlapcovu bolesť zmierniť.

TEXT_SOURCE: The mystic allegedly warned Nicholas and Alexandra that the child’s health would be linked to the strength of the dynasty.
VETA: Mystik údajne varoval Nicholasa a Alexandru, že zdravie dieťaťa bude spojené so silou dynastie.

TEXT_SOURCE: Rasputin’s ability to keep the child healthy would secure him a place in the palace and the power to influence the tsar.
VETA: Rasputinova schopnosť udržať dieťa zdravé by mu zabezpečila miesto v paláci a moc ovplyvňovať cára.

TEXT_SOURCE: Grigory Rasputin (above in an undated image) was a peasant-born mystic whose influence on the tsarina stoked huge resentment, culminating in his murder in 1916, on the eve of revolution.
VETA: Grigorij Rasputin (vyššie na nedatovanom obrázku) bol mystik roľníckeho pôvodu, ktorého vplyv na cárku vyvolal obrovskú nevôľu, ktorá vyvrcholila jeho vraždou v roku 1916, v predvečer revolúcie.

TEXT_SOURCE: The relationship may have helped the tsarevitch, but it wrecked Alexandra’s reputation and further distanced her from the Russian people.
VETA: Vzťah možno pomohol cárovi, ale zničil Alexandrinu povesť a ešte viac ju vzdialil od ruského ľudu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Rumors swirled that Rasputin’s debauched behavior included seducing the tsarina.
VETA: Povrávalo sa, že Rasputinovo zhýralé správanie zahŕňalo zvádzanie cárky.

TEXT_SOURCE: Although he almost certainly was not her lover, he did have affairs with untold numbers of women at the Romanov court.
VETA: Hoci takmer určite nebol jej milencom, na Romanovskom dvore mal pomery s nespočetným množstvom žien.

TEXT_SOURCE: Nicholas ignored the calls to remove Rasputin from court, further angering the Russian people.
VETA: Nicholas ignoroval výzvy na odstránenie Rasputina zo súdu, čo ešte viac rozhnevalo ruský ľud.

TEXT_SOURCE: Keeping his wife happy and his child happy kept Nicholas from removing the threat.
VETA: To, že bola jeho žena šťastná a jeho dieťa šťastné, bránilo Nicholasovi odstrániť hrozbu.

TEXT_SOURCE: (See how the faith of the Russian tsars now enjoys favored status.)
VETA: (Pozrite sa, ako sa viera ruských cárov teraz teší zvýhodnenému postaveniu.)

TEXT_SOURCE: In September 1915, during World War I, Nicholas II traveled to the front to take personal command of Russian forces.
VETA: V septembri 1915, počas prvej svetovej vojny, Nicholas II cestoval na front, aby prevzal osobné velenie ruských síl.

TEXT_SOURCE: The tsarina saw to domestic affairs, and Rasputin’s influence on her became evident in her choice of incompetent ministers.
VETA: Cárska sa starala o domáce záležitosti a Rasputinov vplyv na ňu sa prejavil v jej výbere nekompetentných ministrov.

TEXT_SOURCE: Losses on the front and Rasputin’s conduct at home turned the Russian people against their tsar and his family.
VETA: Straty na fronte a Rasputinovo správanie doma obrátili ruský ľud proti cárovi a jeho rodine.

TEXT_SOURCE: The time was ripe for revolution.
VETA: Nastal čas na revolúciu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Life in Captivity
VETA: Život v zajatí

TEXT_SOURCE: For the Bolsheviks, once they took power in November 1917, the Romanovs simultaneously became a bargaining chip and a headache.
VETA: Po prevzatí moci v novembri 1917 sa pre boľševikov stali Romanovci súčasne vyjednávacím čipom a bolesťou hlavy.

TEXT_SOURCE: Russia needed to negotiate its exit from World WarI while also avoiding a foreign invasion.
VETA: Rusko potrebovalo vyjednať odchod z prvej svetovej vojny a zároveň sa vyhnúť cudzej invázii.

TEXT_SOURCE: The country’s enemies would be watching what happened to the former rulers, but if the Romanovs remained alive they would forever be a symbol for the monarchist movement.
VETA: Nepriatelia krajiny by sledovali, čo sa stalo bývalým vládcom, ale ak by Romanovci zostali nažive, boli by navždy symbolom monarchistického hnutia.

TEXT_SOURCE: Some wanted them sent into exile, some wanted them put on trial for their perceived crimes, and some wanted them to disappear, for good.
VETA: Niektorí chceli, aby ich poslali do vyhnanstva, niektorí chceli, aby ich súdili za ich vnímané zločiny a niektorí chceli, aby definitívne zmizli.

TEXT_SOURCE: At first the family was sent to the palace at Tsarskoye Selo. Security concerns then sent them to Tobol’sk, east of the Ural Mountains.
VETA: Najprv bola rodina poslaná do paláca v Carskoje Selo. Bezpečnostné obavy ich potom poslali do Tobolska, východne od pohoria Ural.

TEXT_SOURCE: They were not treated badly, and Nicholas even seemed to thrive.
VETA: Nezaobchádzalo sa s nimi zle a Mikulášovi sa dokonca zdalo, že sa mu darí.

TEXT_SOURCE: He enjoyed the outdoor, rural life and did not miss the stress of being tsar.
VETA: Užíval si vonkajší, vidiecky život a nechýbal mu ani stres z toho, že je cárom.

TEXT_SOURCE: The family retained a generous staff: 39 servants altogether.
VETA: Rodina si zachovala veľkorysý personál: spolu 39 sluhov.

TEXT_SOURCE: They kept many of their personal possessions, including their beloved family leather-bound photograph albums.
VETA: Ponechali si veľa svojho osobného majetku, vrátane svojich milovaných rodinných albumov s fotografiami viazanými v koži.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was still possible in these early days of their imprisonment to dream of a happy ending.
VETA: V týchto prvých dňoch ich uväznenia bolo ešte možné snívať o šťastnom konci.

TEXT_SOURCE: They might reach England and live in exile with their British cousin King George V. Better still, perhaps they would be allowed to retire to their estate in the Crimea, the scene of many happy summers.
VETA: Mohli by sa dostať do Anglicka a žiť v exile so svojím britským bratrancom kráľom Jurajom V. A čo je ešte lepšie, možno by im bolo dovolené odísť na svoje panstvo na Kryme, dejisku mnohých šťastných letov.

TEXT_SOURCE: They did not understand that, little by little, each escape route was closing until only one was left, the worst one: the road to Yekaterinburg.
VETA: Nechápali, že každá úniková cesta sa postupne uzatvára, až kým nezostala len jedna, tá najhoršia: cesta do Jekaterinburgu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Six of the Romanovs sit on the roof of the country estate in Tobol’sk, where they were held from summer 1917 to spring 1918. Tatiana and Anastasia, working in the gardens of the Alexander Palace, Tsarskoye Selo, 1917.
VETA: Šesť Romanovcov sedí na streche vidieckeho statku v Tobolsku, kde boli držaní od leta 1917 do jari 1918. Tatiana a Anastasia, pracujúce v záhradách Alexandrovho paláca, Carskoje Selo, 1917.

TEXT_SOURCE: Anastasia, Tatiana, Olga, and Maria at the Alexander Palace, Tsarskoye Selo, 1917.
VETA: Anastasia, Tatiana, Olga a Maria v Alexandrovom paláci, Carskoje Selo, 1917.

TEXT_SOURCE: After a bout of measles, the sisters had shaved their heads, following the medical procedure of the time.
VETA: Po záchvate osýpok si sestry oholili hlavy podľa vtedajšieho lekárskeho postupu.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Ipatiev House, where the Romanovs and their servants were killed, appears in this 1928 photo.
VETA: Na tejto fotografii z roku 1928 je Ipatievov dom, kde boli zabití Romanovci a ich služobníci.

TEXT_SOURCE: The family and their servants were taken to the basement of the Ipatiev house, shown here, and killed in July 1918.
VETA: Rodina a ich služobníci boli odvedení do suterénu domu Ipatiev, ktorý je tu zobrazený, a zabití v júli 1918.

TEXT_SOURCE: The most radicalized city in Russia, Yekaterinburg was strongly communist and fanatically anti-tsarist.
VETA: Najradikalizovanejšie mesto v Rusku Jekaterinburg bolo silne komunistické a fanaticky proticárske.

TEXT_SOURCE: I would go anywhere at all, only not to the Urals, Nicholas is reported to have said as the train approached his final residence.
VETA: Išiel by som vôbec kamkoľvek, len nie na Ural, údajne povedal Nicholas, keď sa vlak blížil k jeho konečnému bydlisku.

TEXT_SOURCE: The family stayed in a large building known as the Ipatiev House, after its former owner.
VETA: Rodina bývala vo veľkej budove známej ako Ipatievov dom po bývalom majiteľovi.

TEXT_SOURCE: A high wooden palisade was constructed to cut off the outside world.
VETA: Vysoká drevená palisáda bola postavená tak, aby odrezala vonkajší svet.

TEXT_SOURCE: They had the use of a garden for exercise.
VETA: Na cvičenie mali záhradu.

TEXT_SOURCE: The man in charge, Avdeev, was corrupt (his men stole freely from the Romanovs) but not cruel.
VETA: Muž, ktorý to mal na starosti, Avdeev, bol skorumpovaný (jeho muži voľne kradli Romanovcom), ale nie krutý.

TEXT_SOURCE: The guards were ordinary men, recruited from local factories.
VETA: Strážcovia boli obyčajní muži, regrutovaní z miestnych tovární.

TEXT_SOURCE: As time went on they became familiar and even friendly with their charges.
VETA: Postupom času sa zoznámili a dokonca spriatelili so svojimi zverencami.

TEXT_SOURCE: It couldn’t last.
VETA: Nedalo sa to vydržať.

TEXT_SOURCE: The local Bolsheviks replaced Avdeev with Yakov Yurovsky, the man who would orchestrate their murders.
VETA: Miestni boľševici nahradili Avdeeva Jakovom Jurovským, mužom, ktorý mal organizovať ich vraždy.

TEXT_SOURCE: He stopped the petty thieving that had gone unpunished by his predecessor, but he instituted a much harsher regime and recruited stricter, more disciplined guards.
VETA: Zastavil drobné zlodejiny, ktoré jeho predchodca nepotrestal, no zaviedol oveľa tvrdší režim a naverboval prísnejších a disciplinovanejších dozorcov.

TEXT_SOURCE: He maintained a distant but professional relationship with Nicholas and Alexandra, even as he planned their deaths.
VETA: S Nicholasom a Alexandrou udržiaval vzdialený, ale profesionálny vzťah, aj keď plánoval ich smrť.

TEXT_SOURCE: Nicholas—getting it wrong yet again—even seemed to like him.
VETA: Nicholas – opäť to pochopil zle – dokonca sa zdalo, že ho má rád.

TEXT_SOURCE: Nicholas II and Alexei reviewing troops in 1915.
VETA: Nicholas II a Alexej hodnotia jednotky v roku 1915.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Last Days
VETA: Posledné dni

TEXT_SOURCE: The last civilians to see the Romanovs alive were four women who had been brought in from the town to clean the Ipatiev House.
VETA: Poslednými civilistami, ktorí videli Romanovcov nažive, boli štyri ženy, ktoré priviezli z mesta, aby vyčistili Ipatievov dom.

TEXT_SOURCE: Mariya Starodumova, Evdokiya Semenova, Varvara Dryagina, and an unidentified fourth gave the family a small amount of relief from the boredom of their confinement, and one final contact with the outside world.
VETA: Mariya Starodumova, Evdokiya Semenova, Varvara Dryagina a neidentifikovaná štvrtá dali rodine malú úľavu od nudy vo väzení a posledný kontakt s vonkajším svetom.

TEXT_SOURCE: The testimony of these women has given the most penetrating and humane portrait of the doomed family.
VETA: Svedectvo týchto žien poskytlo najprenikavejší a najhumánnejší portrét rodiny odsúdenej na zánik.

TEXT_SOURCE: Forbidden to speak to the Romanovs, the cleaners nevertheless had the chance to observe them at close quarters.
VETA: Upratovačky, ktorým bolo zakázané hovoriť s Romanovcami, ich napriek tomu mali možnosť pozorovať zblízka.

TEXT_SOURCE: At first, they were struck by the contrast between the tales of the family’s arrogance disseminated by anti-tsarist propaganda and the modest people they found before them.
VETA: Najprv ich zarazil kontrast medzi rozprávkami o rodinnej arogancii šírenej proticárskou propagandou a skromnými ľuďmi, ktorých našli pred nimi.

TEXT_SOURCE: The grand duchesses were ordinary girls.
VETA: Veľké vojvodkyne boli obyčajné dievčatá.

TEXT_SOURCE: As for poor, broken Alexei, he looked to Semenova like the epitome of delicate suffering.
VETA: Čo sa týka úbohého, zlomeného Alexeja, vyzeral na Semenovú ako na stelesnenie jemného utrpenia.

TEXT_SOURCE: Like so many before her, she was particularly struck by his eyes, which were soft and callow, but which appeared to Semenova to be full of sadness.
VETA: Tak ako mnohých pred ňou, aj ona bola zasiahnutá jeho očami, ktoré boli mäkké a necitlivé, no Semenovej sa zdali byť plné smútku.

TEXT_SOURCE: The family, however, was delighted with the diversion.
VETA: Rodina sa však tomuto odklonu potešila.

TEXT_SOURCE: The sisters threw themselves into helping scrub the floors, taking the opportunity to speak with the cleaners in defiance of house rules.
VETA: Sestry sa vrhli na pomoc pri umývaní podláh a využili príležitosť porozprávať sa s upratovačkami v rozpore s domácimi pravidlami.

TEXT_SOURCE: Semenova managed to say a few kind words to Alexandra.
VETA: Semenovej sa podarilo Alexandre povedať pár milých slov.

TEXT_SOURCE: One of the scenes Semenova and Starodumova both remembered with great clarity was when Yurovsky sat down next to the tsarevitch and inquired after the boy’s health.
VETA: Jedna zo scén, ktoré si Semenova a Starodumová s veľkou jasnosťou pamätali, bola, keď sa Jurovskij posadil vedľa cáreviča a pýtal sa na chlapcovo zdravie.

TEXT_SOURCE: A scene of rare kindness and sympathy made retrospectively sinister by the fact that Yurovsky was perfectly aware that within a short time he would be the child’s executioner.
VETA: Scéna vzácnej láskavosti a sympatií, ktorá sa spätne stala zlovestnou skutočnosťou, že Jurovskij si bol dokonale vedomý toho, že v krátkom čase bude katom dieťaťa.

TEXT_SOURCE: The visit to the Ipatiev House made a deep impression on the women.
VETA: Návšteva Ipatievovho domu na ženy hlboko zapôsobila.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Romanovs were to be killed because they were the supreme symbols of autocracy.
VETA: Romanovci mali byť zabití, pretože boli najvyššími symbolmi autokracie.

TEXT_SOURCE: The irony was that, in Yekaterinburg, the Bolsheviks had turned them into the opposite of aristocrats.
VETA: Iróniou bolo, že v Jekaterinburgu z nich boľševici urobili opak aristokratov.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the words of Evdokiya Semenova, they were not gods.
VETA: Slovami Evdokiya Semenovej to neboli bohovia.

TEXT_SOURCE: They were actually ordinary people like us.
VETA: Boli to vlastne obyčajní ľudia ako my.

TEXT_SOURCE: Simple mortals.
VETA: Jednoduchí smrteľníci.

TEXT_SOURCE: On the night of July 16, a telegram was sent to Moscow informing Lenin of the decision to carry out the murders.
VETA: V noci 16. júla bol do Moskvy zaslaný telegram informujúci Lenina o rozhodnutí vykonať vraždy.

TEXT_SOURCE: Rousing the family and the four servants from bed at 1:30 a. m. , Yurovsky informed them that fighting between Red and White forces was threatening the city and that they must be moved down to the basement for their own safety.
VETA: Zobudenie rodiny a štyroch sluhov z postele o 1:30 hod. m. Jurovskij ich informoval, že mestu ohrozujú boje medzi Červenými a Bielymi silami a že sa musia pre vlastnú bezpečnosť presunúť dolu do suterénu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Yekaterinburg-born geologist Alexander Avdonin teamed up with Russian filmmaker Geli Ryabov in the 1970s to find the burial place of the seven Romanovs.
VETA: Geológ narodený v Jekaterinburgu Alexander Avdonin sa v 70. rokoch spojil s ruským filmárom Geli Rjabovom, aby našli pohrebisko siedmich Romanovcov.

TEXT_SOURCE: Because of his previous employment with the Soviet Ministry of Internal Affairs, Ryabov was able to access classified documents that contained valuable clues.
VETA: Vďaka svojmu predchádzajúcemu zamestnaniu na sovietskom ministerstve vnútra mal Rjabov prístup k tajným dokumentom, ktoré obsahovali cenné stopy.

TEXT_SOURCE: One 1926 publication described the grave site as a swampy place, while a 1919 photo of a bridge intrigued them.
VETA: Jedna publikácia z roku 1926 opísala hrobové miesto ako bažinaté miesto, zatiaľ čo fotografia mosta z roku 1919 ich zaujala.

TEXT_SOURCE: Their team, working secretly, was able to locate the structure and in May 1979 uncovered a grave.
VETA: Ich tímu, ktorý pracoval tajne, sa podarilo štruktúru lokalizovať a v máji 1979 odkryl hrob.

TEXT_SOURCE: Fearful of Soviet reprisals, they decided to keep their discovery quiet.
VETA: V strachu zo sovietskych represálií sa rozhodli svoj objav utajiť.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the photo above, amid birch forests 10 miles north of Yekaterinburg, Russian Orthodox crosses mark the site of the mass grave where the bodies of nine of the 11 victims of the Romanov household were buried.
VETA: Na fotografii vyššie, uprostred brezových lesov 10 míľ severne od Jekaterinburgu, ruské pravoslávne kríže označujú miesto masového hrobu, kde boli pochované telá deviatich z 11 obetí rodiny Romanovcov.

TEXT_SOURCE: As the Soviet Union fell, Avdonin’s find was made public.
VETA: Keď padol Sovietsky zväz, Avdoninov nález bol zverejnený.

TEXT_SOURCE: In 1991 an official excavation began, revealing that the grave held only nine people: five Romanovs and four of their servants.
VETA: V roku 1991 sa začal oficiálny výkop, ktorý odhalil, že v hrobe bolo iba deväť ľudí: päť Romanovcov a štyria ich služobníci.

TEXT_SOURCE: Soviet forensic expert Sergei Abramov, above, used cranial measurements to painstakingly identify the bones, while British scientists took mitochondrial DNA from the remains and compared it to known relatives.
VETA: Sovietsky forenzný expert Sergej Abramov použil lebečné merania na starostlivú identifikáciu kostí, zatiaľ čo britskí vedci odobrali mitochondriálnu DNA z pozostatkov a porovnali ju so známymi príbuznými.

TEXT_SOURCE: In 1993 it was announced that the remains were Nicholas II, Alexandra, Olga (whose skull is shown above), Tatiana, and Anastasia.
VETA: V roku 1993 bolo oznámené, že pozostatky boli Nicholas II, Alexandra, Olga (ktorej lebka je zobrazená vyššie), Tatiana a Anastasia.

TEXT_SOURCE: In 2007 human remains were found buried near the first grave, and DNA analysis showed them to be Maria and Alexei.
VETA: V roku 2007 boli pri prvom hrobe nájdené ľudské pozostatky a analýza DNA ukázala, že ide o Máriu a Alexeja.

TEXT_SOURCE: At long last, the outcome of that terrible night was clear: All had perished.
VETA: Nakoniec bol výsledok tej hroznej noci jasný: Všetci zahynuli.

TEXT_SOURCE: There were no survivors.
VETA: Žiadni neprežili.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Romanov remains found in the large grave were held in storage until July 17, 1998, when they were laid to rest in the traditional burial place of the tsars, St. Petersburg’s Sts. Peter and Paul Cathedral, 80 years to the day of their murder.
VETA: Romanovské pozostatky nájdené vo veľkom hrobe boli uložené do 17. júla 1998, kedy boli uložené na tradičnom pohrebisku cárov, v Petrohrade sv. Petra a Pavla, 80 rokov odo dňa ich vraždy.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Last Night
VETA: Minulú noc

TEXT_SOURCE: No evidence survives to suggest the Romanovs reacted with anything but docility.
VETA: Nezachovali sa žiadne dôkazy, ktoré by naznačovali, že Romanovci reagovali niečím iným ako poslušnosťou.

TEXT_SOURCE: Carrying the tsarevitch in his arms, Nicholas led the family and the four servants—family doctor Eugene Botkin, maid Anna Demidova, chef Ivan Kharitonov, and footman Alexei Trupp—down to the cellar.
VETA: Nicholas niesol cároviča v náručí a viedol rodinu a štyroch služobníkov – rodinného lekára Eugena Botkina, slúžku Annu Demidovovú, kuchára Ivana Kharitonova a sluhu Alexeja Truppa – do pivnice.

TEXT_SOURCE: Chairs were fetched for Alexandra and Alexei while the others stood.
VETA: Pre Alexandru a Alexeja boli prinesené stoličky, kým ostatní stáli.

TEXT_SOURCE: Yurovsky approached them, with the executioners behind him in the doorway, and read from a prepared statement to the astonished prisoners:
VETA: Jurovskij k nim pristúpil s katmi za chrbtom vo dverách a z pripravenej výpovede prečítal užasnutým väzňom:

TEXT_SOURCE: The presidium of the Regional Soviet, fulfilling the will of the Revolution, has decreed that the former Tsar Nicholas Romanov, guilty of countless bloody crimes against the people, should be shot.
VETA: Prezídium regionálneho sovietu, plniace vôľu revolúcie, rozhodlo, že bývalý cár Mikuláš Romanov, vinný z nespočetných krvavých zločinov proti ľudu, by mal byť zastrelený.

TEXT_SOURCE: When he finished, they began firing on the family.
VETA: Keď skončil, začali na rodinu strieľať.

TEXT_SOURCE: Accounts are conflicting, but most say that the tsar was the main target, and that he died from several gunshots.
VETA: Účty sú protichodné, ale väčšina hovorí, že hlavným cieľom bol cár a že zomrel na niekoľko výstrelov.

TEXT_SOURCE: The tsarina died from a bullet to the head.
VETA: Cárka zomrela guľkou do hlavy.

TEXT_SOURCE: As the room filled with gun smoke, discipline among the killers vanished.
VETA: Keď sa miestnosť naplnila dymom zo zbraní, disciplína medzi vrahmi zmizla.

TEXT_SOURCE: The grand duchesses seemed unharmed by the bullets, which had ricocheted off their bodies (it was later discovered that diamond jewelry sewn into their clothing had acted like armor during the initial assault).
VETA: Zdalo sa, že veľké vojvodkyne neboli zranené guľkami, ktoré sa odrazili od ich tiel (neskôr sa zistilo, že diamantové šperky všité do ich odevu pôsobili počas počiatočného útoku ako brnenie).

TEXT_SOURCE: One of the murderers—a drunkard named Ermakov—lost all control and began to slash at the Romanovs with a bayonet.
VETA: Jeden z vrahov – opilec menom Ermakov – sa úplne neovládol a začal do Romanovcov sekať bajonetom.

TEXT_SOURCE: Finally, after a horror-filled 20 minutes, the entire family and their servants were all dead: shot, stabbed, and beaten.
VETA: Nakoniec, po 20 minútach plných hrôzy, bola celá rodina a ich služobníci mŕtvi: zastrelení, dobodaní a zbití.

TEXT_SOURCE: The 11 bodies were hauled out of the house and loaded onto a truck.
VETA: 11 tiel vytiahli z domu a naložili na nákladné auto.

TEXT_SOURCE: The disposal of the remains was chaotic.
VETA: Likvidácia pozostatkov bola chaotická.

TEXT_SOURCE: Scholars believe the bodies were first dumped in a shallow mine called Ganina Yama, which the Bolsheviks tried to collapse with grenades.
VETA: Vedci sa domnievajú, že telá boli najskôr vyhodené do plytkej bane s názvom Ganina Yama, ktorú sa boľševici pokúsili zrútiť pomocou granátov.

TEXT_SOURCE: The shaft stayed intact, so the bodies were hastily removed.
VETA: Šachta zostala neporušená, takže telá boli urýchlene odstránené.

TEXT_SOURCE: On the way to the new burial site, the truck got mired in mud, and two bodies—now believed to be Alexei and Maria—were removed and disposed of in the forest.
VETA: Na ceste k novému pohrebisku sa nákladné auto uviazlo v bahne a dve telá, o ktorých sa teraz predpokladá, že sú to Alexej a Mária, boli odstránené a zlikvidované v lese.

TEXT_SOURCE: The nine other bodies were burned, doused with acid, and buried in a separate grave not too far away.
VETA: Deväť ďalších tiel bolo spálených, poliatých kyselinou a pochovaných v samostatnom hrobe neďaleko.

TEXT_SOURCE: Rumors that some of the Romanovs had survived their execution arose almost immediately after their deaths.
VETA: Chýry o tom, že niektorí z Romanovcov prežili svoju popravu, sa objavili takmer okamžite po ich smrti.

TEXT_SOURCE: Because their bodies remained undiscovered for decades and Communist authorities were coy about the events at the Ipatiev House, these whispers grew into legends.
VETA: Pretože ich telá zostali po desaťročia neobjavené a komunistické úrady boli voči udalostiam v Ipatievovom dome ostýchavé, tieto šepoty prerástli do legiend.

TEXT_SOURCE: All of the Romanov children were impersonated at one time or another, but Anastasia was at the center of the most notorious claims to the Romanov estate.
VETA: Všetky deti Romanovovcov boli v tej či onej dobe zosobnené, ale Anastasia bola v centre najznámejších nárokov na Romanovov majetok.

TEXT_SOURCE: Perhaps the most famous claimant was a woman rescued from a Berlin canal in 1920.
VETA: Snáď najznámejšou žiadateľkou bola žena zachránená z berlínskeho kanála v roku 1920.

TEXT_SOURCE: Admitted to the hospital, and carrying no identification, she reluctantly told the authorities she was Anastasia Romanov and recounted a detailed story of how she had escaped the slaughter.
VETA: Keď bola prijatá do nemocnice a nemala žiadnu identifikáciu, neochotne povedala úradom, že je Anastasia Romanovová, a podrobne vyrozprávala príbeh o tom, ako unikla zo zabíjania.

TEXT_SOURCE: She later moved to the United States, where she went by the name Anna Anderson and continued claiming she was Anastasia until her death in 1984.
VETA: Neskôr sa presťahovala do Spojených štátov amerických, kde vystupovala pod menom Anna Anderson a naďalej tvrdila, že je Anastasia až do svojej smrti v roku 1984.

TEXT_SOURCE: Although it is generally believed Anderson was a mentally ill Polish factory worker, her extraordinary story became the subject of public fascination, and the inspiration for the 1956 movie Anastasia starring Ingrid Bergman as the lost grand duchess.
VETA: Hoci sa všeobecne verí, že Anderson bola duševne chorá poľská továrenská robotníčka, jej výnimočný príbeh sa stal predmetom verejnej fascinácie a inšpiráciou pre film Anastasia z roku 1956 s Ingrid Bergman v hlavnej úlohe stratenej veľkovojvodkyne.

TEXT_SOURCE: When the last of the Romanov remains were identified in 2008, any lingering hopes that some might have survived were put to rest.
VETA: Keď boli v roku 2008 identifikované posledné pozostatky Romanova, všetky pretrvávajúce nádeje, že niektoré mohli prežiť, boli potlačené.

TEXT_SOURCE: Truth Comes Out
VETA: Pravda vyjde najavo

TEXT_SOURCE: After the Romanov family’s murder, Soviet officials were cagey when addressing the topic.
VETA: Po vražde rodiny Romanovcov boli sovietski predstavitelia pri riešení tejto témy opatrní.

TEXT_SOURCE: Even shortly after the Bolsheviks announced Nicholas’s death, they were claiming that Alexandra and Alexei were alive in a safe place.
VETA: Dokonca aj krátko po tom, čo boľševici oznámili Nicholasovu smrť, tvrdili, že Alexandra a Alexej žijú na bezpečnom mieste.

TEXT_SOURCE: The deaths would not be officially confirmed until 1926, and even then the Soviets refused to accept responsibility for the execution.
VETA: Úmrtia budú oficiálne potvrdené až v roku 1926 a aj vtedy Sovieti odmietli prevziať zodpovednosť za popravu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Josef Stalin officially suppressed discussion of the family’s fate in 1938, and the Ipatiev House was demolished in 1977 as Soviets decreed it had no historical value.
VETA: Josef Stalin oficiálne potlačil diskusiu o osude rodiny v roku 1938 a Ipatievov dom bol zbúraný v roku 1977, keďže Sovieti vyhlásili, že nemá žiadnu historickú hodnotu.

TEXT_SOURCE: The forced silence surrounding the Romanovs’ fate may have quelled open discussion, but it fueled unending curiosity.
VETA: Nútené ticho okolo osudu Romanovcov mohlo potlačiť otvorenú diskusiu, no podnietilo nekonečnú zvedavosť.

TEXT_SOURCE: Royal imposters would spring up in the coming decades, most claiming to be one of the tsar’s children.
VETA: V nasledujúcich desaťročiach sa objavia kráľovskí podvodníci, z ktorých väčšina tvrdí, že sú jedným z cárskych detí.

TEXT_SOURCE: Each time a new claimant appeared, the story would be resurrected, making it impossible for the mystery to die as the Soviets hoped it would.
VETA: Zakaždým, keď sa objaví nový žiadateľ, príbeh bude vzkriesený, čo znemožní, aby záhada zomrela, ako Sovieti dúfali.

TEXT_SOURCE: In 1979 a pair of amateur sleuths found the larger burial site near Yekaterinburg, but the find was kept secret until after the collapse of the Soviet Union.
VETA: V roku 1979 dvojica amatérskych detektívov našla väčšie pohrebisko neďaleko Jekaterinburgu, ale nález zostal utajený až do rozpadu Sovietskeho zväzu.

TEXT_SOURCE: As a new revolution spread through Russia, scientists returned to Yekaterinburg in 1991 to reclaim history.
VETA: Keď sa Ruskom šírila nová revolúcia, vedci sa v roku 1991 vrátili do Jekaterinburgu, aby znovu získali históriu.

TEXT_SOURCE: They exhumed the remains of nine people, who were later scientifically identified as Nicholas, Alexandra, Olga, Tatiana, Anastasia, and their four servants.
VETA: Exhumovali pozostatky deviatich ľudí, ktorí boli neskôr vedecky identifikovaní ako Nicholas, Alexandra, Olga, Tatiana, Anastasia a ich štyria služobníci.

TEXT_SOURCE: Finding their bones began a healing process in which both the horrors of their deaths and their places in history could be acknowledged.
VETA: Nájdenie ich kostí začalo liečebný proces, v ktorom bolo možné uznať hrôzy ich smrti a ich miesto v histórii.

TEXT_SOURCE: In 1998 these remains were laid to rest in St. Petersburg’s Sts. Peter and Paul Cathedral, traditional burial place of the tsars.
VETA: V roku 1998 boli tieto pozostatky uložené v St. Petra a Pavla, tradičné pohrebisko cárov.

TEXT_SOURCE: In 2000 the Russian Orthodox Church canonized Nicholas, Alexandra, and their children as passion-bearers. At Ganina Yama—the first place where Bolsheviks tried to dispose of the bodies— the Russian Orthodox Church erected a monastery.
VETA: V roku 2000 ruská pravoslávna cirkev kanonizovala Mikuláša, Alexandru a ich deti ako nositeľov vášní. V Ganine Yama – prvom mieste, kde sa boľševici pokúšali zbaviť tiel – ruská pravoslávna cirkev postavila kláštor.

TEXT_SOURCE: Where the Ipatiev House once stood, the magnificent Church on the Blood was consecrated in 2003 and has since become a pilgrimage site.
VETA: Na mieste, kde kedysi stál Ipatievov dom, bol v roku 2003 vysvätený nádherný Kostol na krvi a odvtedy sa stal pútnickým miestom.

TEXT_SOURCE: In 2007 Alexei’s and Maria’s remains were found, and later identified using DNA analysis.
VETA: V roku 2007 boli nájdené pozostatky Alexeja a Márie, ktoré boli neskôr identifikované pomocou analýzy DNA.

TEXT_SOURCE: It has been said that families who are closely attached may cut themselves off from the outside world.
VETA: Hovorí sa, že rodiny, ktoré sú úzko spojené, sa môžu odrezať od vonkajšieho sveta.

TEXT_SOURCE: So it was with the Romanovs.
VETA: Tak to bolo aj s Romanovcami.

TEXT_SOURCE: Their self-absorption made them slow to appreciate their danger, but their love strengthened each other and made their confinement bearable.
VETA: Ich pohltenie do seba spôsobilo, že si pomaly uvedomovali svoje nebezpečenstvo, ale ich láska sa navzájom posilnila a ich uväznenie bolo znesiteľné.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was the greatest mercy of their last months that, right up to the terrible end, they were, at the very least, all together.
VETA: Bolo to najväčšie milosrdenstvo ich posledných mesiacov, že až do toho hrozného konca boli prinajmenšom všetci spolu.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was during the first snowstorm of the new year.
VETA: Bolo to počas prvej snehovej búrky v novom roku.

TEXT_SOURCE: The color green was something you saw in pictures tacked to the wall or in a memory from what felt like years ago.
VETA: Zelená farba bola niečo, čo ste videli na obrázkoch prilepených na stene alebo v spomienkach z toho, čo ste mali pred rokmi.

TEXT_SOURCE: I was living alone in a studio apartment in a shitty section of west Cleveland.
VETA: Žil som sám v garsónke v zasratej časti západného Clevelandu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Everything was the same color in that neighborhood, even in the summer.
VETA: V tej štvrti malo všetko rovnakú farbu, dokonca aj v lete.

TEXT_SOURCE: There were no stairs to get to my apartment.
VETA: Do môjho bytu neviedli žiadne schody.

TEXT_SOURCE: I was as far down as you can get without going under.
VETA: Bol som tak ďaleko, ako sa len dá dostať bez toho, aby som klesol.

TEXT_SOURCE: I slept in the same room as the oven, but I liked the smallness of it.
VETA: Spala som v tej istej miestnosti ako pec, ale páčila sa mi jej maličkosť.

TEXT_SOURCE: When I was young my sister and I used to zip each other into suitcases.
VETA: Keď som bol malý, so sestrou sme sa navzájom zipsovali do kufrov.

TEXT_SOURCE: We would drag the suitcases up and down the stairs, and all around the living room, laughing hysterically.
VETA: Ťahali sme kufre hore a dole po schodoch a všade po obývačke a hystericky sme sa smiali.

TEXT_SOURCE: That first morning I wrapped a scarf around my neck and lit the stove.
VETA: V prvé ráno som si omotal šatku okolo krku a zapálil sporák.

TEXT_SOURCE: I tripped over my shoes on my way to the sink to fill the pot.
VETA: Cestou k umývadlu som zakopol o topánky, aby som naplnil hrniec.

TEXT_SOURCE: I looked down at them accusingly, as if anyone but me could have put them there.
VETA: Vyčítavo som sa na nich pozrela, akoby ich tam mohol dať ktokoľvek okrem mňa.

TEXT_SOURCE: I looked up after kicking them across the room and that was when I saw him for the first time.
VETA: Keď som ich kopol cez izbu, zdvihol som zrak a vtedy som ho prvýkrát uvidel.

TEXT_SOURCE: I wouldn't find out until later that he had been there for weeks.
VETA: To, že tam bol týždne, som sa dozvedela až neskôr.

TEXT_SOURCE: Inches away from me as I slept. An arm's reach as I showered and dressed each morning.
VETA: Niekoľko centimetrov odo mňa, keď som spal. Na dosah ruky, keď som sa každé ráno sprchoval a obliekal.

TEXT_SOURCE: He sat with me while I overcooked my eggs and searched the internet for a cat to adopt, each time deciding against it because I could imagine it snowballing into two or three until I became one of those women.
VETA: Sedel so mnou, zatiaľ čo som si pripravovala vajíčka a hľadala na internete mačku, ktorú by som si mohla adoptovať, zakaždým som sa rozhodla proti, pretože som si vedela predstaviť, že sa to rozdelí na dve alebo tri, až kým sa nestanem jednou z tých žien.

TEXT_SOURCE: The outside world that day, and every day since I had been living there, was a white swirling mixture of ground and sky.
VETA: Vonkajší svet v ten deň a každý deň, odkedy som tam žil, bol bielou víriacou zmesou zeme a neba.

TEXT_SOURCE: Set against the bright seamless backdrop was the outline of a man.
VETA: Na jasnom bezšvovom pozadí bol obrys muža.

TEXT_SOURCE: He was fading in and out with each gust of wind, like a Polaroid gone backwards.
VETA: S každým poryvom vetra sa strácal a mizal ako polaroid, ktorý šiel dozadu.

TEXT_SOURCE: But I saw him.
VETA: Ale videl som ho.

TEXT_SOURCE: I saw the tip of one of his pink fingers poking out of a hole in his glove.
VETA: Videl som, ako špička jedného z jeho ružových prstov trčí z diery v jeho rukavici.

TEXT_SOURCE: His hands were up against his mouth which was covered in a thick dark beard and his breath came in a long slow billow of white smoke, like the mouth of a gutter under a frozen street.
VETA: Ruky mal opreté o ústa pokryté hustou tmavou bradou a jeho dych vychádzal v dlhom pomalom prúde bieleho dymu, ako ústie žľabu pod zamrznutou ulicou.

TEXT_SOURCE: His hood was pulled up over his head which made his eyes ever brighter in the shadow.
VETA: Na hlave mal natiahnutú kapucňu, vďaka čomu mal v tieni ešte jasnejšie oči.

TEXT_SOURCE: I couldn't tell what color they were, but they seemed to have a reflection inside them like the round outline of a flashbulb in the eye of a magazine model.
VETA: Nevedel som povedať, akú majú farbu, ale zdalo sa, že majú v sebe odraz ako okrúhly obrys bleskovej žiarovky v oku modelky z časopisu.

TEXT_SOURCE: I didn't scream.
VETA: Nekričal som.

TEXT_SOURCE: I felt nothing like adrenaline, or dread. Or that feeling when your heart beats so fast it makes you want to throw up.
VETA: Necítil som nič ako adrenalín alebo hrôzu. Alebo ten pocit, keď vám srdce bije tak rýchlo, že sa vám chce zvracať.

TEXT_SOURCE: Nothing like that happened.
VETA: Nič také sa nestalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: If someone told me that they saw a strange man staring at them through their window I would have expected to hear them say, And then I screamed and dropped my glass and it shattered and I ran to the phone and dialed 911andthen I ran to my front door and pulled the deadbolt acrossand then I hid in the bathroom with the doorclosedand I couldn't stop shaking.
VETA: Ak by mi niekto povedal, že cez okno na nich videl cudzieho muža, čakal by som, že ich počujem povedať: A potom som skríkol a pustil pohár, rozbilo sa a bežal som k telefónu a vytočil 911 a potom som utekal pred seba. dvere a potiahol som západku naprieč a potom som sa schoval v kúpeľni so zatvorenými dverami a nemohol som sa prestať triasť.

TEXT_SOURCE: But I didn't do any of that.
VETA: Ale nič z toho som neurobil.

TEXT_SOURCE: I stood completely still as if someone was holding me there, and I watched as the man I saw so clearly disappeared into the endless white.
VETA: Stál som úplne nehybne, akoby ma tam niekto držal, a sledoval som, ako muž, ktorého som tak jasne videl, mizne v nekonečnej bielej.

TEXT_SOURCE: There was nothing in my apartment that anyone would want.
VETA: V mojom byte nebolo nič, čo by niekto chcel.

TEXT_SOURCE: My possessions were piled in and out of boxes and I didn't even own a real bed.
VETA: Môj majetok sa hromadil v škatuliach a von z nich a dokonca som nevlastnil ani skutočnú posteľ.

TEXT_SOURCE: I had a mattress on the floor that tripled as a couch and dining room table.
VETA: Na podlahe som mal matrac, ktorý sa strojnásobil ako gauč a jedálenský stôl.

TEXT_SOURCE: I did own a laptop but I took it with me to work.
VETA: Vlastnil som notebook, no vzal som si ho so sebou do práce.

TEXT_SOURCE: I didn't own a TV, or a toaster oven, or even a decent pair of shoes.
VETA: Nevlastnil som televízor, ani hriankovač, ba ani poriadne topánky.

TEXT_SOURCE: I just decided that since there was nothing for him to steal, and I was sure he figured that out if he took a good look, that I would go on about my day despite his strange appearance outside my window.
VETA: Len som sa rozhodol, že keďže tu nie je nič, čo by mohol ukradnúť, a bol som si istý, že na to prišiel, ak sa dobre pozrie, budem pokračovať vo svojom dni aj napriek jeho zvláštnemu vzhľadu za mojím oknom.

TEXT_SOURCE: It felt less like a decision to ignore it, and more like it didn't happen at all.
VETA: Pripadalo mi to menej ako rozhodnutie ignorovať to a skôr ako keby sa to vôbec nestalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: And that is exactly how it ended up.
VETA: A presne tak to aj skončilo.

TEXT_SOURCE: Each morning while I boiled water and ladled my mug into the steaming pot, I saw him.
VETA: Každé ráno, keď som varil vodu a naberal svoj hrnček do pariaceho hrnca, videl som ho.

TEXT_SOURCE: I didn't own a tea kettle either.
VETA: Nevlastnil som ani rýchlovarnú kanvicu.

TEXT_SOURCE: I didn't see why people spent money on things like that when they could function perfectly well without them.
VETA: Nechápal som, prečo ľudia míňajú peniaze na takéto veci, keď bez nich môžu fungovať úplne dobre.

TEXT_SOURCE: But anyway, each night when I came home from work and my apartment was dark and quiet and anyone would think that I should be scared, I wasn't.
VETA: Ale každopádne, každú noc, keď som sa vrátil z práce a môj byt bol tmavý a tichý a niekto by si myslel, že by som sa mal báť, nebol som.

TEXT_SOURCE: There was no one waiting for me behind the shower curtain.
VETA: Za závesom v sprche ma nikto nečakal.

TEXT_SOURCE: Nothing was ever out of place.
VETA: Nikdy nič nebolo na mieste.

TEXT_SOURCE: There were never any footprints circling my apartment, or scratch marks around my doorknob.
VETA: Nikdy po mojom byte neboli žiadne stopy, ani škrabance okolo kľučky.

TEXT_SOURCE: I came and went peacefully and each morning I shared a moment with a stranger whose eye brows curled up like a puppy and whose fingers were always bent across his mouth.
VETA: Pokojne som prichádzal a odchádzal a každé ráno som zdieľal chvíľku s neznámym človekom, ktorý mal obočie zvinuté ako šteňa a prsty mal vždy zohnuté cez ústa.

TEXT_SOURCE: It went on for about a week that way.
VETA: Takto to pokračovalo asi týždeň.

TEXT_SOURCE: I continued to start my car ten minutes early with the keys dangling in the ignition, so it could thaw.
VETA: Pokračoval som v štartovaní auta o desať minút skôr s kľúčmi visiacimi v zapaľovaní, aby sa mohlo rozmraziť.

TEXT_SOURCE: I guess in hindsight that was a pretty stupid thing to do in west Cleveland anyway, random man or not.
VETA: Myslím, že pri spätnom pohľade to bola dosť hlúpa vec, ktorú robiť v západnom Clevelande, či už náhodný alebo nie.

TEXT_SOURCE: But I mean I just lived my life normally, with the exception of my gloomy window friend stopping by more and more often.
VETA: Ale chcem povedať, že som len normálne žil svoj život, s výnimkou môjho zachmúreného priateľa z okna, ktorý sa u mňa zastavoval čoraz častejšie.

TEXT_SOURCE: Once while I was watching TV late at night, something caught my eye at the window.
VETA: Raz, keď som neskoro večer pozeral televíziu, niečo ma upútalo na okne.

TEXT_SOURCE: Of course it was him.
VETA: Samozrejme, že to bol on.

TEXT_SOURCE: I just kept on eating my popcorn until I was full and there was still half a bowl left.
VETA: Len som pokračoval v jedení popcornu, kým som sa nenasýtil a ešte mi zostala polovica misky.

TEXT_SOURCE: I hated to waste food, and I always felt bad for the little birds that hopped over the snow, and wondered what the hell they ate in this neighborhood at twelve below.
VETA: Nenávidel som plytvanie jedlom a vždy mi bolo zle z malých vtákov, ktoré poskakovali po snehu, a premýšľal som, čo do pekla jedia v tejto štvrti o dvanástej nižšie.

TEXT_SOURCE: So sometimes I would throw food outside for them. Or for the squirrels.
VETA: Občas som im teda hodil jedlo von. Alebo pre veveričky.

TEXT_SOURCE: So I went to the window.
VETA: Išiel som teda k oknu.

TEXT_SOURCE: I had never really…confronted the man.
VETA: Nikdy som toho muža naozaj...nekonfrontoval.

TEXT_SOURCE: I stayed a room's length away from him as he peered at me sadly.
VETA: Stála som od neho na dĺžku miestnosti, keď na mňa smutne pozeral.

TEXT_SOURCE: I got up and saw his outline like the moon must have been fat and shining right behind him, casting a line of white around his face.
VETA: Vstal som a uvidel som jeho obrysy, ako keby mesiac musel byť tučný a svietil priamo za ním a okolo jeho tváre vrhal bielu čiaru.

TEXT_SOURCE: My eyes went to the top of the window to unhook the lock, and when they returned to him there was only the snow.
VETA: Moje oči zamierili na hornú časť okna, aby som odomkol zámok, a keď sa k nemu vrátili, bol tam len sneh.

TEXT_SOURCE: I put my face into the cold, that kind of cold that feels more like fire than ice, and I looked for him.
VETA: Položil som svoju tvár do chladu, takého chladu, ktorý mi viac pripomína oheň ako ľad, a hľadal som ho.

TEXT_SOURCE: The snow was covered in a layer of glass.
VETA: Sneh bol pokrytý vrstvou skla.

TEXT_SOURCE: I threw the leftover popcorn and it rolled like dice across the ground.
VETA: Hodil som zvyšky pukancov a tie sa kotúľali ako kocky po zemi.

TEXT_SOURCE: There were no signs of his tracks.
VETA: Po jeho stopách neboli žiadne stopy.

TEXT_SOURCE: I noticed, as I pulled the window back down, that there was no moon that night.
VETA: Keď som stiahol okno, všimol som si, že v tú noc nebol mesiac.

TEXT_SOURCE: The next morning I saw the white grey billows of exhaust fumes pouring out of a piece of shit station wagon in front of my apartment.
VETA: Na druhý deň ráno som videl biele sivé obláčiky výfukových plynov, ktoré sa valili z kusu posraného kombi pred mojím bytom.

TEXT_SOURCE: I saw the woman's eyes, and they were glossy and dull.
VETA: Videl som oči tej ženy a boli lesklé a matné.

TEXT_SOURCE: I had seen her baby basset hound eyebrows before, on the man at my window.
VETA: Už predtým som videl jej obočie baseta na mužovi pri mojom okne.

TEXT_SOURCE: She just stared at the door as if she was waiting for someone to come out.
VETA: Len pozerala na dvere, akoby čakala, že niekto vyjde.

TEXT_SOURCE: I came out.
VETA: Vyšiel som von.

TEXT_SOURCE: It happened that way three times.
VETA: Stalo sa to tak trikrát.

TEXT_SOURCE: Not all at once, but spread so far out across two weeks that I had to keep reminding myself that it wasn't a déjà vu, and that yes, this had really happened before.
VETA: Nie naraz, ale rozložené na dva týždne tak ďaleko, že som si musel neustále pripomínať, že to nebolo déjà vu, a že áno, toto sa už naozaj stalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: The fourth time I decided had to be different.
VETA: Štvrtýkrát som sa rozhodol, že musím byť iný.

TEXT_SOURCE: Something about her felt so much like the man at my window, but maybe it was just her coming and going. And her staring. And those eyebrows arching up.
VETA: Niečo na nej sa tak podobalo na muža pri mojom okne, ale možno to bolo len jej prichádzať a odchádzať. A jej pohľad. A tie vyklenuté obočie.

TEXT_SOURCE: But her hands were not covering her mouth; they were white and exposed even in this weather, and they were gripping the steering wheel.
VETA: Ale ruky jej nezakrývali ústa; boli biele a odhalené aj v tomto počasí a držali volant.

TEXT_SOURCE: So I could see that her lips were moving tightly against each other, and on top of each other, pulling in and out of her mouth.
VETA: Takže som videl, že jej pery sa tesne pohybujú proti sebe a na sebe a vťahujú a vyťahujú sa z úst.

TEXT_SOURCE: This fourth time she didn't drive away when I walked out onto the ice.
VETA: Tento štvrtýkrát neodišla, keď som vyšiel na ľad.

TEXT_SOURCE: I stood waiting for her to do it; to drive away as she always had.
VETA: Stál som a čakal, kým to urobí; odviezť ako vždy.

TEXT_SOURCE: But she just looked ahead at the road, and then back into my face.
VETA: Ale ona sa len pozrela pred seba na cestu a potom späť do mojej tváre.

TEXT_SOURCE: Then I saw her hand move to the door, and the window rolled down.
VETA: Potom som videl, ako sa jej ruka posunula k dverám a okno sa stiahlo.

TEXT_SOURCE: I walked towards her casually, not like someone who had seen her on three previous mornings, but like someone who was going to ask her if she needed directions.
VETA: Išiel som k nej nenútene, nie ako niekto, kto ju videl tri predchádzajúce rána, ale ako niekto, kto sa jej chystal spýtať, či nepotrebuje cestu.

TEXT_SOURCE: So I did ask her that, because I wasn't sure what else to say.
VETA: Tak som sa jej to spýtal, pretože som si nebol istý, čo iné povedať.

TEXT_SOURCE: The wind stole the words and spread them out across the trees and the pavement and the kicked over silver trash cans.
VETA: Vietor ukradol slová a rozložil ich po stromoch a chodníku a prekopal strieborné odpadkové koše.

TEXT_SOURCE: She said nothing.
VETA: Nepovedala nič.

TEXT_SOURCE: She looked like she might drive away again.
VETA: Vyzerala, že by mohla znova odísť.

TEXT_SOURCE: She put her hands back on the wheel and looked straight ahead.
VETA: Položila ruky späť na volant a pozrela sa priamo pred seba.

TEXT_SOURCE: But then she turned and looked past me at my apartment.
VETA: Potom sa však otočila a pozrela sa popri mne na môj byt.

TEXT_SOURCE: I looked back then too, like maybe I was missing something.
VETA: Tiež som sa vtedy obzrel, akoby mi niečo chýbalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: She was looking at the right side of the house, at the space between it and the neighbor's fence, which was all of four feet.
VETA: Pozerala sa na pravú stranu domu, na priestor medzi ním a susedovým plotom, ktorý mal celý štyri stopy.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was the space where I saw my window friend each morning standing, waiting to watch me curse at my hair for making me late.
VETA: Bol to priestor, kde som každé ráno videl môjho priateľa pri okne stáť a čakať, ako si nadávam na vlasy, že som meškal.

TEXT_SOURCE: Are you looking for him? I asked.
VETA: Hľadáte ho? Opýtal som sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: Feeling as soon as I said it, the longing to take it back.
VETA: Pocit hneď, ako som to povedal, túžbu vziať to späť.

TEXT_SOURCE: I wasn't sure what I would say if she asked Who?
VETA: Nebol som si istý, čo by som povedal, keby sa spýtala Kto?

TEXT_SOURCE: Oh, just that man who stares in my window every day.
VETA: Ach, len ten muž, ktorý každý deň hľadí do môjho okna.

TEXT_SOURCE: The one who for all I know could be a serial killer casing out his next victim.
VETA: Ten, čo viem, by mohol byť sériovým vrahom vyháňajúcim svoju ďalšiu obeť.

TEXT_SOURCE: I know that's what people would think if I told them.
VETA: Viem, že to by si ľudia mysleli, keby som im to povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: But it didn't feel like that at all.
VETA: Ale vôbec mi to tak nepripadalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: But she didn't ask me who, she didn't say anything for about a minute, she just stared blankly back and forth between me and the apartment, and I knew that I would be late for work again.
VETA: Ale nepýtala sa ma kto, asi minútu nič nehovorila, len tupo hľadela sem a tam medzi mňa a byt a ja som vedel, že zase budem meškať do práce.

TEXT_SOURCE: She looked like she was about to say something, her mouth kept moving and tears starting falling into it from her eyes.
VETA: Vyzerala, akoby sa chystala niečo povedať, ústa sa jej pohybovali a z očí jej začali tiecť slzy.

TEXT_SOURCE: I remembered the landlord speaking to me in broken English, telling me how grateful he was that he didn't need to help me carry furniture.
VETA: Spomenul som si, ako sa ku mne domáci pán prihováral lámanou angličtinou a hovoril mi, aký je vďačný, že mi nemusí pomáhať nosiť nábytok.

TEXT_SOURCE: I remembered him telling me that a couple had lived there before me. And he kept saying something in Spanish that sounded like tragic.
VETA: Spomenul som si, ako mi hovoril, že tam predo mnou žil pár. A stále hovoril niečo po španielsky, čo znelo tragicky.

TEXT_SOURCE: Do you need help? I asked, coming a little closer to the window.
VETA: Potrebuješ pomoc? spýtal som sa a podišiel trochu bližšie k oknu.

TEXT_SOURCE: She just kept crying, harder now.
VETA: Stále plakala, teraz silnejšie.

TEXT_SOURCE: I squeezed my cell phone for the time and saw that I was still early.
VETA: Stlačil som mobil na čas a videl som, že som ešte skoro.

TEXT_SOURCE: I always turned my car on too soon, and by the time I got inside it the snow was pouring from the roof like rain.
VETA: Vždy som zapínal auto príliš skoro, a kým som sa dostal dovnútra, sneh sa sypal zo strechy ako dážď.

TEXT_SOURCE: You can come inside and we can have some tea if you want.
VETA: Môžete ísť dovnútra a môžeme si dať čaj, ak chcete.

TEXT_SOURCE: Or maybe you just want to talk?
VETA: Alebo sa možno len chcete porozprávať?

TEXT_SOURCE: Is that why you keep coming here? I just kept talking.
VETA: Preto sem stále chodíš? Stále som len rozprával.

TEXT_SOURCE: I didn't know what else to do with her.
VETA: Nevedel som, čo iné s ňou robiť.

TEXT_SOURCE: What's your name?
VETA: Ako sa voláš?

TEXT_SOURCE: I just moved here a few weeks ago, actually I guess it's been more than a month.
VETA: Prisťahoval som sa sem len pred pár týždňami, v skutočnosti je to už viac ako mesiac.

TEXT_SOURCE: I don't know anyone.
VETA: ja nikoho nepoznam.

TEXT_SOURCE: I work downtown at a magazine. I do graphic design.
VETA: Pracujem v centre mesta v časopise. Robím grafický dizajn.

TEXT_SOURCE: She started to calm down a little and looked at me.
VETA: Začala sa trochu upokojovať a pozrela sa na mňa.

TEXT_SOURCE: Amy, she said quietly.
VETA: Amy, povedala potichu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Hey Amy, I said, a little too cheerfully.
VETA: Hej Amy, povedal som trochu príliš veselo.

TEXT_SOURCE: I'm Ellen.
VETA: Ja som Ellen.

TEXT_SOURCE: Is this where you used to live? I said, pointing back at my little faded blue apartment and the trees, and the trash cans that were glued to the sidewalk now from all the ice.
VETA: Toto je miesto, kde ste bývali? Povedal som a ukázal som späť na svoj malý vyblednutý modrý byt a stromy a smetné koše, ktoré boli teraz prilepené na chodníku od všetkého ľadu.

TEXT_SOURCE: She stared at the apartment and nodded at it, as if it had asked her the question.
VETA: Zadívala sa na byt a prikývla naň, akoby jej položil otázku.

TEXT_SOURCE: Well, did you want to come in for a little while?
VETA: No, nechceli ste prísť na chvíľu?

TEXT_SOURCE: I can't stay long, I do have to go soon, but you can come in for a few minutes if you want.
VETA: Nemôžem zostať dlho, musím čoskoro ísť, ale ak chceš, môžeš prísť na pár minút.

TEXT_SOURCE: I know when I moved from my first house I always wanted to go back and see what they did to my old room.
VETA: Viem, že keď som sa presťahoval zo svojho prvého domu, vždy som sa chcel vrátiť a pozrieť sa, čo urobili s mojou starou izbou.

TEXT_SOURCE: See if they painted it a different color or anything.
VETA: Pozrite sa, či to namaľovali inou farbou alebo niečo iné.

TEXT_SOURCE: I didn't paint anything yet.
VETA: Ešte som nič nemaľoval.

TEXT_SOURCE: Maybe I will in the summer.
VETA: Možno budem v lete.

TEXT_SOURCE: I smiled at her, and she smiled back slowly, as if her face had forgotten which muscles it took to pull up the chapped corners of her mouth.
VETA: Usmial som sa na ňu a ona mi úsmev pomaly opätovala, ako keby jej tvár zabudla, aké svaly potrebovala na to, aby stiahla popraskané kútiky úst.

TEXT_SOURCE: She stared at the house, and then at me and then back at the house again, and without saying anything she unlocked her seat belt and got out of the car.
VETA: Pozrela sa na dom, potom na mňa a potom znova na dom, a bez toho, aby čokoľvek povedala, odomkla si bezpečnostný pás a vystúpila z auta.

TEXT_SOURCE: We were standing there in the middle of the frozen street, her car was still running and dripping fluid, making a little puddle that was curling and flowing over the cracks in the ice and the dirty solid snow that was pushed up onto the curb.
VETA: Stáli sme tam uprostred zamrznutej ulice, jej auto stále bežalo a kvapkala z neho tekutina, robila malú kaluž, ktorá sa vlnila a tiekla cez trhliny v ľade a špinavý pevný sneh, ktorý bol natlačený na obrubník.

TEXT_SOURCE: Did you want to…? I motioned to the keys hanging in the ignition.
VETA: Chceli ste…? Ukázal som na kľúče visiace v zapaľovaní.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was alright for me to leave my car running, but if hers got stolen I would feel pretty terrible.
VETA: Bolo pre mňa v poriadku nechať auto bežať, ale keby mi ukradli to jej, cítil by som sa hrozne.

TEXT_SOURCE: Oh, yeah, thanks, she said softly.
VETA: Ach, áno, ďakujem, povedala potichu.

TEXT_SOURCE: I watched her lean into her car and shut it off, pull the keys out and put them in the pocket of her coat.
VETA: Sledoval som, ako sa naklonila do auta, vypla ho, vytiahla kľúče a dala si ich do vrecka kabáta.

TEXT_SOURCE: When she turned to face me again I smiled a sort of awkward, ok right this way, kind of smile, and turned to walk to the apartment.
VETA: Keď sa znova otočila tvárou ku mne, usmial som sa akosi trápne, dobre, takto, trochu s úsmevom, a otočil som sa, aby som išiel do bytu.

TEXT_SOURCE: She followed me hesitantly and I heard her take in a deep breath.
VETA: Váhavo ma nasledovala a počul som, ako sa zhlboka nadýchla.

TEXT_SOURCE: The cold air must have stung her lungs because she started coughing.
VETA: Studený vzduch ju zrejme štípal v pľúcach, pretože začala kašľať.

TEXT_SOURCE: You ok? I said, turning to look at her over my shoulder as I opened the door and walked in.
VETA: Si v poriadku? Povedal som a otočil som sa, aby som sa na ňu pozrel cez rameno, keď som otvoril dvere a vošiel dnu.

TEXT_SOURCE: She just nodded, and I saw her eyebrows start to go higher, and her lips start to pull into her mouth.
VETA: Len prikývla a videl som, ako jej obočie začalo stúpať vyššie a pery sa jej začali vťahovať do úst.

TEXT_SOURCE: I wasn't sure if this was such a great idea after all.
VETA: Nebol som si istý, či je to nakoniec taký skvelý nápad.

TEXT_SOURCE: What was I supposed to do with some strange sobbing woman?
VETA: Čo som mal robiť s nejakou zvláštnou vzlykajúcou ženou?

TEXT_SOURCE: I remembered that I didn't have anywhere for her to sit, and it felt like an even worse idea.
VETA: Spomenul som si, že si nemám kam sadnúť a pripadalo mi to ako ešte horší nápad.

TEXT_SOURCE: I took in a deep breath of the frozen air as we walked into the apartment.
VETA: Keď sme vošli do bytu, zhlboka som sa nadýchol zamrznutého vzduchu.

TEXT_SOURCE: She was my first guest and I was suddenly a little self conscious about my housekeeping.
VETA: Bola mojím prvým hosťom a ja som si zrazu začal trochu uvedomovať svoje upratovanie.

TEXT_SOURCE: I scooped up the cold soggy tea bags from the counter and threw them in the trash, and moved a few things aroundso I didn't look like a slob.
VETA: Zobral som studené rozmočené čajové vrecúška z pultu a hodil ich do koša a premiestnil som pár vecí, aby som nevyzeral ako flákač.

TEXT_SOURCE: Do you want some tea?
VETA: Chceš nejaký čaj?

TEXT_SOURCE: Or hot chocolate maybe?
VETA: Alebo možno horúcu čokoládu?

TEXT_SOURCE: I don't have a coffee maker.
VETA: Nemám kávovar.

TEXT_SOURCE: I grabbed two mugs before she could answer, refilled the pot that was on the stove, and started it to boil.
VETA: Než stihla odpovedať, schmatol som dva hrnčeky, naplnil hrniec, ktorý bol na sporáku, a začal vrieť.

TEXT_SOURCE: She didn't say anything, and I looked behind me to see her standing in what I guess had been her living room, looking around the apartment like Dorothy when she came out of her little spinning cabin.
VETA: Nič nepovedala a ja som sa obzrel za seba a videl som ju, ako stojí v hádam bývalej obývačke a rozhliada sa po byte ako Dorothy, keď vyšla zo svojej malej otočnej kabínky.

TEXT_SOURCE: I think I feel like some hot chocolate, I said, trying to break her from her daze.
VETA: Myslím, že mám chuť na horúcu čokoládu, povedal som a snažil som sa ju vytrhnúť z jej omámenia.

TEXT_SOURCE: She stared at me as if she had forgotten where she was.
VETA: Pozrela sa na mňa, akoby zabudla, kde je.

TEXT_SOURCE: Sure, she said finally.
VETA: Jasné, povedala nakoniec.

TEXT_SOURCE: I attempted small talk, mostly to myself, while the water boiled.
VETA: Kým voda vrie, pokúsil som sa o rozhovory, väčšinou pre seba.

TEXT_SOURCE: I asked her questions and got a nod here and there.
VETA: Pýtal som sa jej otázky a sem-tam som prikývol.

TEXT_SOURCE: Finally I had two cups of hot chocolate and I stirred at them violently trying to get the lumps out.
VETA: Nakoniec som si dal dve šálky horkej čokolády a prudko som do nich zamiešal, aby som dostal hrudky von.

TEXT_SOURCE: I wish I had some of those tiny marshmallows.
VETA: Prial by som si mať nejaké tie maličké marshmallows.

TEXT_SOURCE: They're fun, I said, smiling awkwardly as I handed her the mug.
VETA: Sú zábavné, povedal som a rozpačito sa usmial, keď som jej podával hrnček.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was from some rest stop in the Redwood Forrest, Paul Bunyan and his big blue Ox.
VETA: Bolo to z nejakého odpočívadla v Redwood Forrest, Paul Bunyan a jeho veľký modrý vôl.

TEXT_SOURCE: I wished I would have noticed and given her the one with the Dalmatian instead.
VETA: Prial som si, aby som si to všimol a dal jej namiesto toho tú s dalmatínkou.

TEXT_SOURCE: That would have seemed a little less awkward.
VETA: To by vyzeralo o niečo menej trápne.

TEXT_SOURCE: My mom sent it to me because when I was little I loved Dalmatians.
VETA: Poslala mi ho mama, pretože keď som bol malý, miloval som dalmatíncov.

TEXT_SOURCE: I tried to explain to her that, thanks to Disney, lots of little kids liked Dalmatians and that the phase was over, but she still kept sending me mugs and birthday cards with black spots.
VETA: Snažil som sa jej vysvetliť, že vďaka Disneymu sa veľa malých detí páčilo dalmatíncom a že fáza sa skončila, ale stále mi posielala hrnčeky a narodeninové pohľadnice s čiernymi škvrnami.

TEXT_SOURCE: I guess you could sit…on my bed if you want?
VETA: Myslím, že by si mohol sedieť...na mojej posteli, ak chceš?

TEXT_SOURCE: I'm sorry, that's pretty creepybut I don't have any chairs yet.
VETA: Prepáčte, je to dosť strašidelné, ale ešte nemám žiadne stoličky.

TEXT_SOURCE: I looked around at the empty walls and the posters rolled up on the floor and told myself I would hang them up tonight. But I knew I wouldn't.
VETA: Poobzeral som sa po prázdnych stenách a plagátoch zrolovaných na zemi a povedal som si, že ich dnes večer zavesím. Ale vedel som, že to neurobím.

TEXT_SOURCE: She walked over to my bed and sat down on the corner.
VETA: Prešla k mojej posteli a sadla si na roh.

TEXT_SOURCE: I pulled up a box full of books and sat down on it.
VETA: Vytiahol som krabicu plnú kníh a sadol som si na ňu.

TEXT_SOURCE: I sipped at the hot chocolate and got a big chunk of powder.
VETA: Popíjala som horúcu čokoládu a dostala som veľký kus prášku.

TEXT_SOURCE: I hoped I had stirred hers a little better.
VETA: Dúfal som, že som ju trochu lepšie rozhýbal.

TEXT_SOURCE: So, you lived here before me? I asked quietly. Hoping not to start another round of hysterics; she had finally seemed to calm down.
VETA: Takže, ty si tu býval predo mnou? spýtal som sa potichu. Dúfajúc, že nezačneme ďalšie kolo hysteriky; zdalo sa, že sa konečne upokojila.

TEXT_SOURCE: Yes.
VETA: Áno.

TEXT_SOURCE: Did you live alone? I squeezed the hot mug, already feeling like I knew the answer.
VETA: Žili ste sami? Stlačil som horúci hrnček a už som mal pocit, že poznám odpoveď.

TEXT_SOURCE: She must have been part of the couple the landlord attempted to gossip with me about.
VETA: Musela byť súčasťou páru, o ktorom sa ma snažil prenajímateľ ohovárať.

TEXT_SOURCE: Maybe it was a really bad breakup. Maybe he was still looking for her, still stalking her.
VETA: Možno to bol naozaj zlý rozchod. Možno ju stále hľadal, stále ju prenasledoval.

TEXT_SOURCE: I thought of the man who I guess was stalking me.
VETA: Myslel som na muža, ktorý ma tuším prenasledoval.

TEXT_SOURCE: But he didn't seem like he would hurt anybody.
VETA: Ale nezdalo sa, že by niekomu ublížil.

TEXT_SOURCE: He was too sad, too cold and lonely.
VETA: Bol príliš smutný, príliš chladný a osamelý.

TEXT_SOURCE: No, she said, and then she breathed into the steaming mug, and I waited, hoping that maybe she would tell me her story so that I didn't ask the wrong question and make her cry.
VETA: Nie, povedala a potom sa nadýchla do pariaceho sa hrnčeka a ja som čakal v nádeji, že mi možno povie svoj príbeh, aby som sa nespýtal zle a nerozplakal ju.

TEXT_SOURCE: I lived with my fiancé, Eric.
VETA: Žil som so svojím snúbencom Erikom.

TEXT_SOURCE: He was a musician.
VETA: Bol hudobníkom.

TEXT_SOURCE: We had rugs and towels hanging all over the walls, - she pointed to the tiny holes, the ones I never noticed - and his friends would come over and practice.
VETA: Všade po stenách sme mali viseli koberce a uteráky, - ukázala na drobné dierky, tie, ktoré som si nikdy nevšimla - a jeho priatelia prišli a cvičili.

TEXT_SOURCE: Band practice in this place?
VETA: Cvičenie kapely na tomto mieste?

TEXT_SOURCE: That must have been crazy.
VETA: To muselo byť šialené.

TEXT_SOURCE: She smiled bigger now.
VETA: Teraz sa usmievala ešte viac.

TEXT_SOURCE: I was sure she was transporting herself back there, and I pictured four or five guys with guitars huddled around the bed where she sat and listened, maybe a drummer with his chair stuck inside the bathroom.
VETA: Bol som si istý, že sa tam prepravovala, a predstavil som si štyroch alebo piatich chlapov s gitarami, ktorí sa tlačili okolo postele, kde sedela a počúvala, možno bubeníka so stoličkou zastrčenou v kúpeľni.

TEXT_SOURCE: She stopped talking and stared down into her mug.
VETA: Prestala rozprávať a zahľadela sa do svojho hrnčeka.

TEXT_SOURCE: We sat in silence and then my eyes went to the window.
VETA: Sedeli sme v tichosti a potom môj pohľad zamieril k oknu.

TEXT_SOURCE: He was back.
VETA: Bol späť.

TEXT_SOURCE: Amy noticed the way I looked at the window suddenly, and she looked too, but nothing happened.
VETA: Amy si všimla, ako som sa zrazu pozrela na okno, pozrela sa aj ona, no nič sa nestalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: She didn't see him.
VETA: Nevidela ho.
