VETA: Okrem toho, posledný odkaz, ktorý jej bol odovzdaný v roku 1429, a Blomfieldov dátum z roku 1443 ukazujú, že mohla žiť veľmi dlhý život, takmer sto rokov.

TEXT_SOURCE: This is all the sure information we have about Julian’s life.
VETA: Toto sú všetky spoľahlivé informácie, ktoré máme o Julianovom živote.

TEXT_SOURCE: We do not know where she was born, what the history of her family was, nor is there any information available about the time and place of her death and burial.
VETA: Nevieme, kde sa narodila, aká bola história jej rodiny, ani nie sú dostupné žiadne informácie o čase a mieste jej smrti a pohrebu.

TEXT_SOURCE: She does not even mention any of the sad events that were taking place around her.
VETA: Na žiadne smutné udalosti, ktoré sa okolo nej diali, ani nespomína.

TEXT_SOURCE: She remains completely silent about everything that has no bearing on her message of God’s love.
VETA: Úplne mlčí o všetkom, čo nemá vplyv na jej posolstvo o Božej láske.

TEXT_SOURCE: All the extrasthat have been told about her life by the historians are mostly deductions based on the sources we have at our disposal.
VETA: Všetko extra, čo o jej živote rozprávali historici, sú väčšinou dedukcie založené na zdrojoch, ktoré máme k dispozícii.

TEXT_SOURCE: We do not even know her real name.
VETA: Nepoznáme ani jej skutočné meno.

TEXT_SOURCE: She possibly took her name Julian from St. Julian, the patron saint of the Church to which she was attached as an anchoress.
VETA: Svoje meno Julian možno prevzala od svätého Juliána, patróna Cirkvi, ku ktorej bola pripútaná ako kotva.

TEXT_SOURCE: It is likely that the saint in question was Julian the Hospitaller, the patron saint of ferrymen, since the Church stands near the River Wensum and there must have been a ferry to get across the river.
VETA: Je pravdepodobné, že daným svätcom bol Júlián Špitál, patrón prievozníkov, keďže kostol stojí neďaleko rieky Wensum a cez rieku musel byť prievoz.

TEXT_SOURCE: J. B. Holloway makes a hypothesis that Julian’s real name might have been Mary Westwick, since there is a manuscript that speaks of her having visions that are similar to Julian’s.
VETA: J. B. Holloway vyslovil hypotézu, že Julianovo skutočné meno mohlo byť Mary Westwicková, keďže existuje rukopis, ktorý hovorí o tom, že mala vízie podobné Julianovým.

TEXT_SOURCE: There was a Westwick area in Norwich, near the Castle, that had once been inhabited by Jewish families.
VETA: V Norwichi neďaleko hradu bola oblasť Westwick, ktorú kedysi obývali židovské rodiny.

TEXT_SOURCE: It is possible that Julian may have stemmed from one of these families that converted to Christianity when Jews were expelled from England in 1290.
VETA: Je možné, že Julian mohol pochádzať z jednej z týchto rodín, ktoré konvertovali na kresťanstvo, keď boli Židia vyhostení z Anglicka v roku 1290.

TEXT_SOURCE: But this lack of information about Julian’s life is not surprising.
VETA: Ale tento nedostatok informácií o Julianovom živote nie je prekvapujúci.

TEXT_SOURCE: She chose the life of a recluse and intended to remain hidden, being aware that it was the message of the revelations that was important and not her person.
VETA: Vybrala si život samotára a chcela zostať skrytá, uvedomujúc si, že dôležité je posolstvo zjavení a nie jej osoba.

TEXT_SOURCE: Then will you soon forget me who am a wretch, she writes, and do this, so that I am no hindrance to you, and you will contemplate Jesus, who is every man’s teacher(ST 135).
VETA: Potom na mňa, ktorá som úbohá, čoskoro zabudnete, píše a urobte to, aby som vám neprekážala, a budete kontemplovať Ježiša, ktorý je učiteľom každého človeka (ST 135).

TEXT_SOURCE: In this act of putting on a veil of concealment and anonymity, Julian points to the concealment and anonymity of God himself.
VETA: V tomto akte nasadenia závoja utajenia a anonymity Julian poukazuje na utajenie a anonymitu samotného Boha.

TEXT_SOURCE: God reveals himself to the world, and yet he always remains a Deus absconditus.
VETA: Boh sa zjavuje svetu, a predsa vždy zostáva Deus absconditus.

TEXT_SOURCE: In a similar way, Julian’s work has been made known to the world, and yet in her vocation of an anchoress and spiritual mother she reminds us of the existence of an invisible and spiritual world.
VETA: Podobným spôsobom sa svet dostáva do povedomia aj Julianova tvorba, no vo svojom povolaní kotvy a duchovnej matky nám pripomína existenciu neviditeľného a duchovného sveta.

TEXT_SOURCE: Adrienne von Speyr, a Swiss mystic of the XX century, who converted to Catholicism under the guidance of H. U. von Balthasar who edited most of her works, in the first part of her book on the saints and their life of prayer, Das Allerheiligenbuch, gives us a precious insight into the interior life of Julian of Norwich.
VETA: Adrienne von Speyr, švajčiarska mystička 20. storočia, ktorá konvertovala na katolicizmus pod vedením H. U. von Balthasara, ktorý upravil väčšinu jej diel, v prvej časti svojej knihy o svätých a ich živote modlitby Das Allerheiligenbuch uvádza nám vzácny pohľad do vnútorného života Juliana z Norwichu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Today, the life of a recluse may seem somewhat unusual to us, but it was not a rare phenomenon in the early centuries of the Church and in the Middle Ages.
VETA: Dnes sa nám život samotára môže zdať akosi nezvyčajný, no v prvých storočiach Cirkvi a v stredoveku to nebol zriedkavý jav.

TEXT_SOURCE: The word anchoriteis derived from the Greek verb anachorein and means to retireor to withdraw.
VETA: Slovo anchorite je odvodené z gréckeho slovesa anachorein a znamená dôchodca stiahnuť sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: An anchorite, male or female, retired from the world to lead a life of penance and prayer.
VETA: Anachoréta, muž alebo žena, odišiel zo sveta, aby viedol život pokánia a modlitby.

TEXT_SOURCE: This solitary life–style developed from the tradition of the first Desert Fathers who, like Anthony, Paul the Hermit, Macarius or Arsenius, in their search for a deeper communion with God retreated to the desert, away from the noise of the city.
VETA: Tento osamelý životný štýl sa vyvinul z tradície prvých púštnych otcov, ktorí sa podobne ako Anthony, Pavol Pustovník, Macarius či Arsenius pri hľadaní hlbšieho spoločenstva s Bohom stiahli na púšť, ďaleko od hluku mesta.

TEXT_SOURCE: Their hermitical ideal, narrated in a text known as Vitas Patrum, was soon to be followed by the first female anchoresses, known as Desert Mothers.
VETA: Ich pustovnícky ideál, vyrozprávaný v texte známom ako Vitas Patrum, mali čoskoro nasledovať prvé ženské moderátorky, známe ako Púštne matky.

TEXT_SOURCE: The eastern tradition has in its possession a similar collection of sayings and deeds of these holy mothers, called Meterikon.
VETA: Východná tradícia vlastní podobnú zbierku výrokov a skutkov týchto svätých matiek, nazývanú Meterikon.

TEXT_SOURCE: Moreover, the female anchoritic life has a scriptural foundation, namely, in the figure of Anna, mentioned in the scene of the Presentation of the Lord in the temple.
VETA: Navyše, ženský anachoretický život má biblický základ, a to v postave Anny, spomínanej v scéne Predstavenia Pána v chráme.

TEXT_SOURCE: The evangelist Luke defines her as a prophetess, which could be translated today in terms of a mysticendowed with spiritual understanding and visions.
VETA: Evanjelista Lukáš ju definuje ako prorokyňu, čo by sa dnes dalo preložiť ako mystika obdarená duchovným chápaním a víziami.

TEXT_SOURCE: He tells us that she never left the Temple, and served God night and day with fasting and prayer (Lk 2, 36-37).
VETA: Hovorí nám, že nikdy neopustila chrám a vo dne v noci slúžila Bohu pôstom a modlitbami (Lk 2, 36-37).

TEXT_SOURCE: This picture presents her as a recluse of the temple, who lived there for God and for the sanctification of the priests.
VETA: Tento obraz ju predstavuje ako samotárku z chrámu, ktorá tam žila pre Boha a pre posvätenie kňazov.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the Middle Ages the monastic and anchoritic life experienced a revival.
VETA: V stredoveku došlo k oživeniu kláštorného a anachoretického života.

TEXT_SOURCE: A. K. Warren, studying the wills with their bequests to local anchorites, estimates that in the 14th century there lived around 96 female anchorites in England alone, and in the 15th the number increased to 1103 .
VETA: A. K. Warren, študujúc testamenty s ich odkazmi miestnym anachorétom, odhaduje, že len v Anglicku žilo v 14. storočí okolo 96 anachorétok a v 15. storočí sa ich počet zvýšil na 1103.

TEXT_SOURCE: The nuns and anchoresses had an enormous impact on the people of that time and exercised a role of praying, counselling and reconciling.
VETA: Mníšky a kotvy mali na vtedajších ľudí obrovský vplyv a plnili úlohu modlitby, poradenstva a zmierovania.

TEXT_SOURCE: Some of the great women of the medieval ages had even a teaching role in the Church, like for example, Hildegard of Bingen, Mechtild of Hackeborn, Gertrude the Great, Catherine of Genoa and Catherine of Siena.
VETA: Niektoré z veľkých žien stredoveku mali dokonca učiteľskú úlohu v Cirkvi, ako napríklad Hildegarda z Bingenu, Mechtild z Hackebornu, Gertrúda Veľká, Katarína z Janova a Katarína Sienská.

TEXT_SOURCE: This shows that their withdrawal from the world was not an escape from serving the people and exercising the role of spiritual motherhood towards them.
VETA: To ukazuje, že ich odchod zo sveta nebol únikom zo služby ľuďom a vykonávania úlohy duchovného materstva voči nim.

TEXT_SOURCE: The anchoress’ intent was not to work only for her own salvation, but to pray and do penance on behalf of others.
VETA: Zámerom kotvy nebolo pracovať len pre svoje spasenie, ale modliť sa a konať pokánie v mene druhých.

TEXT_SOURCE: In this way, the anchoritic life-style became a form of vicarious substitution, participating in the universal mediation of Christ.
VETA: Týmto spôsobom sa anachoretický spôsob života stal formou zástupnej substitúcie, podieľajúcej sa na univerzálnom Kristovom prostredníctve.

TEXT_SOURCE: Therefore they were given a high social status, for the citizens were proud to have a recluse who offered her daily prayers for them.
VETA: Preto dostali vysoké spoločenské postavenie, pretože občania boli hrdí na samotárku, ktorá sa za nich denne modlila.

TEXT_SOURCE: Aelred of Rievaulx, in his rule for recluses, indicates this essential point of the solitary life: Embrace the whole world with the arms of your love and in that act at once consider and congratulate the good, contemplate and mourn over the wicked.
VETA: Aelred z Rievaulx vo svojom pravidle pre samotárov naznačuje tento podstatný bod osamelého života: Objímte celý svet náručou svojej lásky a v tomto akte naraz zvážte a blahoželajte dobrým, kontemplujte a smúťte nad bezbožnými.

TEXT_SOURCE: In that act look upon the afflicted and the oppressed and feel compassion for them…
VETA: V tomto čine sa pozrite na utrápených a utláčaných a precíťte s nimi súcit...

TEXT_SOURCE: In that act call to mind the wretchedness of the poor, the groans of the orphans, the abandonment of widows, the gloom of the sorrowful, the needs of travellers, the prayers of virgins, the perils of those at sea, the temptations of monks, the responsibilities of prelates, the labours of those waging Ancrene Riwle.
VETA: Pri tomto čine si spomeňte na biedu chudobných, stonanie sirôt, opustenosť vdov, chmúru smútiacich, potreby cestujúcich, modlitby panien, nebezpečenstvá tých, ktorí sú na mori, pokušenia mníchov. , zodpovednosti prelátov, práce tých, ktorí vedú Ancrene Riwle.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the Middle Ages a number of such rules were written.
VETA: V stredoveku bolo napísaných niekoľko takýchto pravidiel.

TEXT_SOURCE: Already in the ninth century, a monk named Grimlaic wrote the Regula Solitarium and in the eleventh century we find the rule of Aelred of Rievaulx written for his anchoress sister.
VETA: Už v deviatom storočí napísal mních menom Grimlaic Solitarium Regula a v jedenástom storočí nachádzame pravidlo Aelreda z Rievaulx napísané pre jeho sestru kotvu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Finally, in the thirteenth century the most famous collection of instructions for anchoresses, the so-called Ancrene Riwle or Ancrene Wisse was written.
VETA: Napokon v trinástom storočí vznikla najznámejšia zbierka inštrukcií pre kotvy, takzvaná Ancrene Riwle alebo Ancrene Wisse.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Rule concentrates, above all, on the inner life of a recluse and sets up as an example of contemplative life the Gospel story of Mary who sat at Jesus’ feet and chose the better part: Ye anchorites have taken to yourselves Mary’s part, which our Lord himself commended…
VETA: Regula sa sústreďuje predovšetkým na vnútorný život samotára a ako príklad kontemplatívneho života dáva evanjeliový príbeh o Márii, ktorá sedela pri Ježišových nohách a vybrala si lepšiu časť: Vy, anachoréti, ste si vzali Máriinu časť, ktorá Sám náš Pán pochválil...

TEXT_SOURCE: Housewifery is Martha’s part, and Mary’s part is quietness and rest from all the world’s din, that nothing may hinder her from hearing the voice of God.
VETA: Domácnosť je súčasťou Marty a súčasťou Márie je ticho a odpočinok od všetkého hluku sveta, aby jej nič nebránilo počuť Boží hlas.

TEXT_SOURCE: As a bride of Christ, the essential virtue of the anchoress was chastity and there are many concrete precepts in the Ancrene Riwle that should help her avoid any violation of it.
VETA: Ako Kristovej neveste bola základnou čnosťou kotvy cudnosť a v Ancrene Riwle je veľa konkrétnych prikázaní, ktoré by jej mali pomôcť vyhnúť sa akémukoľvek ich porušovaniu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Her contact with men was severely restricted and she was counselled to choose as her confessor an elderly priest of good reputation.
VETA: Jej styk s mužmi bol prísne obmedzený a bolo jej odporučené, aby si za spovedníka vybrala staršieho kňaza dobrej povesti.

TEXT_SOURCE: The document also gives practical instructions about the external life of an anchoress.
VETA: Dokument tiež poskytuje praktické pokyny o vonkajšom živote kotvy.

TEXT_SOURCE: It sets down precise rules about what she should eat and wear, when she might sleep and what sort of prayers she should say.
VETA: Stanovuje presné pravidlá o tom, čo by mala jesť a nosiť, kedy môže spať a aké modlitby by sa mala modliť.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Rule sets down that the anchoress could have two meals a day from Easter until Holy Cross Day in September, and only one meal the rest of the year and on all Fridays.
VETA: Pravidlo stanovuje, že od Veľkej noci až do sviatku svätého Kríža v septembri môže mať moderátorka dve jedlá denne a po zvyšok roka a všetky piatky iba jedno jedlo.

TEXT_SOURCE: She was allowed no meat except in time of illness.
VETA: Nemala povolené žiadne mäso, okrem času choroby.

TEXT_SOURCE: As for the clothes, no particular colour is specified, but it is said only that it should be plain and warm in winter.
VETA: Čo sa týka oblečenia, žiadna konkrétna farba nie je špecifikovaná, ale hovorí sa len, že by malo byť v zime obyčajné a teplé.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Rule is very severe, though, about any sort of unhealthy exaggeration, both in meals as well as in clothes.
VETA: Pravidlo je však veľmi prísne, pokiaľ ide o akýkoľvek druh nezdravého preháňania, a to ako v jedle, tak aj v oblečení.

TEXT_SOURCE: Recalling the famous words of St. Paul in 1 Cor 13 about love, the author of the Ancrene Riwle says: Though I inflicted upon my body all the pains and all the sufferings that a body could endure; and though I gave poor men all that I had; unless I had therewith love to God and to all men, in him and for him, it were all lost.
VETA: Autor knihy Ancrene Riwle, pripomínajúc slávne slová sv. Pavla v 1. Kor 13 o láske, hovorí: Hoci som spôsobil na svoje telo všetky bolesti a všetky utrpenia, ktoré telo mohlo zniesť; a hoci som chudobným dal všetko, čo som mal; ak by som tým nemal lásku k Bohu a ku všetkým ľuďom, v ňom a pre neho, bolo by to všetko stratené.

TEXT_SOURCE: Though the anchoress did not live in a monastic community where the daily life was regimented by monastic routine, she was supposed to follow a certain schedule of prayer, contemplation, work and rest as well.
VETA: Hoci nebývala v mníšskom spoločenstve, kde bol každodenný život riadený mníšskym režimom, mala sa držať aj určitého harmonogramu modlitby, rozjímania, práce a odpočinku.

TEXT_SOURCE: Once the anchoress entered her anchorhold, she was not allowed to leave it anymore on pain of excommunication.
VETA: Keď kotva vstúpila do svojho kotviska, nesmela ho už opustiť pod hrozbou exkomunikácie.

TEXT_SOURCE: There was even a special enclosure rite celebrated at her departure from the world, such as a Requiem Mass and a procession to the cell.
VETA: Dokonca sa pri jej odchode zo sveta slávil špeciálny obrad, ako napríklad zádušná svätá omša a sprievod do cely.

TEXT_SOURCE: Afterwards, the main celebrant, normally the local bishop or his representative, administered extreme unction to the anchoress, scattered ashes on her and her cell, and bricked her in.
VETA: Potom hlavný celebrant, zvyčajne miestny biskup alebo jeho zástupca, udelil kotvičke krajnú pomstu, rozsypal na ňu a jej celu popol a zamuroval ju.

TEXT_SOURCE: She was considered dead to the world.
VETA: Pre svet bola považovaná za mŕtvu.

TEXT_SOURCE: It consisted of a suite of rooms and was built next to the Church, with one window looking into the Church so that the anchoress could take part in the liturgical services and, with another window open to the world to allow people to come for counsel.
VETA: Pozostávala zo sady miestností a bola postavená vedľa kostola, pričom jedným oknom sa pozeralo do kostola, aby sa kotvkyňa mohla zúčastniť na liturgických obradoch, a druhým oknom otvoreným do sveta, aby sa ľudia mohli prísť poradiť.

TEXT_SOURCE: One of the rooms would serve as an oratory where daily prayers were said.
VETA: Jedna z miestností slúžila ako oratórium, kde sa denne modlili.

TEXT_SOURCE: There might even have been a garden or a courtyard attached to the anchorhold.
VETA: Ku kotvisku mohla byť dokonca pripojená záhrada alebo nádvorie.

TEXT_SOURCE: Besides, the anchoress was allowed to keep a servant who would take care of all necessary provisions in the household.
VETA: Okrem toho si kotvička mohla ponechať sluhu, ktorý sa staral o všetko potrebné v domácnosti.

TEXT_SOURCE: Following the guidelines of the Ancrene Riwle, we can easily imagine what the life of Julian looked like.
VETA: Podľa smerníc Ancrene Riwle si ľahko vieme predstaviť, ako vyzeral život Juliana.

TEXT_SOURCE: Though there is no information about the time she entered the anchorhold, it seems plausible that it was only after the revelations took place that she started to live an enclosed life, along with two maidservants, Alice and Sara, as we learn from the wills, in a cell adjacent to the parish Church of St. Julian at Norwich, opposite the house of the Augustinian Friars.
VETA: Hoci neexistujú žiadne informácie o tom, kedy vstúpila do kotviska, zdá sa pravdepodobné, že až po odhaleniach začala žiť uzavretý život spolu s dvoma slúžkami, Alicou a Sarou, ako sa dozvedáme zo závetov, v cele susediacej s farským kostolom sv. Juliána v Norwichi, oproti domu bratov augustiniánov.

TEXT_SOURCE: Though she was allowed to receive Holy Communion only a couple of times a year, through the window of her cell she could look onto the altar and participate in the celebration of Holy Mass.
VETA: Hoci jej bolo dovolené pristupovať k svätému prijímaniu len niekoľkokrát do roka, cez okno svojej cely sa mohla pozerať na oltár a zúčastniť sa na slávení svätej omše.

TEXT_SOURCE: She spent most of her day in prayer, in the contemplation of the Bible and other spiritual and theological texts, in editing her own visions, and in giving counsel to people, as the case of Margery Kempe shows.
VETA: Väčšinu dňa strávila v modlitbách, rozjímaní nad Bibliou a inými duchovnými a teologickými textami, upravovaním vlastných vízií a poskytovaním rád ľuďom, ako ukazuje prípad Margery Kempeovej.

TEXT_SOURCE: Once upon a time the fairies of the west, going home from a hurling-match with the fairies of the lakes, rested in Dooros Wood for three days and three nights.
VETA: Kedysi dávno víly západu, idúce domov z vrhacieho zápasu s vílami jazier, odpočívali v Dooros Wood tri dni a tri noci.

TEXT_SOURCE: They spent the days feasting and the nights dancing in the light of the moon, and they danced so hard that they wore the shoes off their feet, and for a whole week after the leprechauns, the fairies’ shoemakers, were working night and day making new ones, and the rip, rap, tap, tap of their little hammers were heard in all the hedgerows.
VETA: Dni trávili hodovaním a noci tancovali vo svetle mesiaca a tancovali tak tvrdo, že si obuli topánky z nôh a celý týždeň potom, čo škriatkovia, obuvníci víl, pracovali vo dne v noci. nové a vo všetkých živých plotoch bolo počuť trhanie, klepanie, klopkanie, klopkanie ich malých kladív.

TEXT_SOURCE: The food on which the fairies feasted were little red berries, and were so like those that grow on the rowan tree that if you only looked at them you might mistake one for the other; but the fairy berries grow only in fairyland, and are sweeter than any fruit that grows here in this world, and if an old man, bent and grey, ate one of them, he became young and active and strong again; and if an old woman, withered and wrinkled, ate one of them, she became young and bright and fair; and if a little maiden who was not handsome ate of them, she became lovelier than the flower of beauty.
VETA: Jedlo, na ktorom si víly pochutnávali, boli malé červené bobule a boli také ako tie, ktoré rastú na jarabine, že keby ste sa na ne len pozreli, mohli by ste si pomýliť jednu s druhou; ale rozprávkové bobule rastú iba v rozprávkovej krajine a sú sladšie ako akékoľvek ovocie, ktoré rastie tu na tomto svete, a ak starý muž, ohnutý a sivý, zjedol jedno z nich, stal sa opäť mladým, aktívnym a silným; a ak jedna z nich zjedla stará žena, uschnutá a vráskavá, stala sa mladou, jasnou a krásnou; a ak ich zjedla malá panna, ktorá nebola pekná, stala sa krajšou ako kvet krásy.

TEXT_SOURCE: The fairies guarded the berries as carefully as a miser guards his gold, and whenever they were about to leave fairyland they had to promise in the presence of the king and queen that they would not give a single berry to mortal man, nor allow one to fall upon the earth; for if a single berry fell upon the earth a slender tree of many branches, bearing clusters of berries, would at once spring up, and mortal men might eat of them.
VETA: Víly strážili bobule tak starostlivo, ako si lakomec svoje zlato, a vždy, keď sa chystali opustiť rozprávkovú krajinu, museli v prítomnosti kráľa a kráľovnej sľúbiť, že smrteľnému človeku nedajú ani bobuľu, ani nedovolia, aby padnúť na zem; lebo keby na zem padla jediná bobuľa, odrazu by vyrástol štíhly strom s mnohými vetvami nesúci strapce bobúľ a smrteľníci by z nich mohli jesť.

TEXT_SOURCE: But it chanced that this time they were in Dooros Wood they kept up the feasting and dancing so long, and were so full of joy because of their victory over the lake fairies, that one little, weeny fairy, not much bigger than my finger, lost his head, and dropped a berry in the wood.
VETA: Ale náhoda, že tentoraz boli v Dooros Wood, vydržali hodovať a tancovať tak dlho a boli takí plní radosti z víťazstva nad jazernými vílami, že jedna malá, malá víla, nie oveľa väčšia ako môj prst, stratil hlavu a spadol bobule do lesa.

TEXT_SOURCE: When the feast was ended the fairies went back to fairyland, and were at home for more than a week before they knew of the little fellow’s fault, and this is how they came to know of it.
VETA: Keď sa hostina skončila, víly sa vrátili do rozprávkovej krajiny a boli doma viac ako týždeň, kým sa nedozvedeli o vine drobčeka, a tak sa to dozvedeli.

TEXT_SOURCE: A great wedding was about to come off, and the queen of the fairies sent six of her pages to Dooros Wood to catch fifty butterflies with golden spots on their purple wings, and fifty white without speck or spot, and fifty golden, yellow as the cowslip, to make a dress for herself, and a hundred white, without speck or spot, to make dresses for the bride and bridesmaids.
VETA: Chystala sa veľká svadba a kráľovná víl poslala šesť svojich pážat do Dooros Wood, aby chytili päťdesiat motýľov so zlatými škvrnami na fialových krídlach a päťdesiat bielych bez fľakov a škvŕn a päťdesiat zlatých, žltých. kravský papuček, aby si ušila šaty, a sto bielych, bez fľakov a škvŕn, aby ušila šaty pre nevestu a družičky.

TEXT_SOURCE: When the pages came near the wood they heard the most wonderful music, and the sky above them became quite dark, as if a cloud had shut out the sun.
VETA: Keď sa stránky priblížili k lesu, počuli tú najúžasnejšiu hudbu a obloha nad nimi celkom potemnela, akoby mrak zakryl slnko.

TEXT_SOURCE: They looked up, and saw that the cloud was formed of bees, who in a great swarm were flying towards the wood and humming as they flew.
VETA: Pozreli sa hore a videli, že oblak tvorili včely, ktoré vo veľkom roji lietali smerom k lesu a hučali, keď lietali.

TEXT_SOURCE: Seeing this they were sore afraid until they saw the bees settling on a single tree, and on looking closely at the tree they saw it was covered with fairy berries.
VETA: Keď to videli, veľmi sa báli, až kým nezbadali, ako sa včely usadzujú na jednom strome, a keď sa pozorne pozreli na strom, videli, že je pokrytý rozprávkovými plodmi.

TEXT_SOURCE: The bees took no notice of the fairies, and so they were no longer afraid, and they hunted the butterflies until they had captured the full number of various colours.
VETA: Včely si víly nevšímali, a tak sa už nebáli a lovili motýle, kým nezachytili plný počet rôznych farieb.

TEXT_SOURCE: Then they returned to fairyland, and they told the queen about the bees and the berries, and the queen told the king.
VETA: Potom sa vrátili do rozprávkovej krajiny a povedali kráľovnej o včelách a plodoch a kráľovná to povedala kráľovi.

TEXT_SOURCE: The king was very angry, and he sent his heralds to the four corners of fairyland to summon all his subjects to his presence that he might find out without delay who was the culprit.
VETA: Kráľ sa veľmi nahneval a poslal svojich zvestovateľov do štyroch kútov rozprávkovej krajiny, aby predvolali všetkých svojich poddaných, aby bez meškania zistil, kto je vinníkom.

TEXT_SOURCE: They all came except the little weeny fellow who dropped the berry, and of course every one said that it was fear that kept him away, and that he must be guilty.
VETA: Všetci prišli okrem malého chlapíka, ktorý vypustil bobuľu, a samozrejme každý povedal, že to bol strach, ktorý ho držal preč, a že musí byť vinný.

TEXT_SOURCE: The heralds were at once sent in search of him, and after a while they found him hiding in a cluster of ferns, and brought him before the king.
VETA: Heroldi ho ihneď poslali hľadať a po chvíli ho našli ukrytého v zhluku papradí a priviedli ho pred kráľa.

TEXT_SOURCE: The poor little fellow was so frightened that at first he could scarcely speak a word, but after a time he told how he never missed the berry until he had returned to fairyland, and that he was afraid to say anything to anyone about it.
VETA: Úbohý chlapček bol taký vystrašený, že spočiatku sotva prehovoril slovo, ale po čase povedal, že mu bobuľka nechýbala, kým sa nevrátil do rozprávkovej krajiny a že sa bál o tom niekomu niečo povedať.

TEXT_SOURCE: The king, who would hear of no excuse, sentenced the little culprit to be banished into the land of giants beyond the mountains, to stay there for ever and a day unless he could find a giant willing to go to Dooros Wood and guard the fairy tree.
VETA: Kráľ, ktorý nepočul žiadne ospravedlnenie, odsúdil malého vinníka, aby bol vyhnaný do krajiny obrov za horami, aby tam zostal na veky a deň, pokiaľ nenájde obra ochotného ísť do Dooros Wood a strážiť vílu. strom.

TEXT_SOURCE: When the king had pronounced sentence everyone was very sorry, because the little fellow was a favourite with them all.
VETA: Keď kráľ vyriekol rozsudok, všetci to veľmi ľutovali, pretože toho malého chlapca mali všetci radi.

TEXT_SOURCE: No fairy harper upon his harp, or piper upon his pipe, or fiddler upon his fiddle, could play half so sweetly as he could play upon an ivy leaf; and when they remembered all the pleasant moonlit nights on which they had danced to his music, and thought that they should never hear or dance to it any more, their little hearts were filled with sorrow.
VETA: Žiadna víla na harfe, píšťalka na píšťalke alebo huslista na husliach nedokázali hrať tak sladko, ako na liste brečtanu; a keď si spomenuli na všetky tie príjemné mesačné noci, počas ktorých tancovali na jeho hudbu, a mysleli si, že by ju už nikdy nemali počuť ani tancovať, ich srdiečka boli naplnené smútkom.

TEXT_SOURCE: The queen was as sad as any of her subjects, but the king’s word should be obeyed.
VETA: Kráľovná bola smutná ako ktorýkoľvek z jej poddaných, ale kráľovo slovo treba poslúchnuť.

TEXT_SOURCE: When the time came for the little fellow to set out into exile the queen sent her head page to him with a handful of berries.
VETA: Keď prišiel čas, aby sa drobec vydal do vyhnanstva, kráľovná mu poslala svoju hlavovú stránku s hrsťou bobúľ.

TEXT_SOURCE: These the queen said he was to offer to the giants, and say at the same time that the giant who was willing to guard the tree could feast on berries just as sweet from morn till night.
VETA: Kráľovná povedala, že ich má ponúknuť obrom, a zároveň povedať, že obr, ktorý je ochotný strážiť strom, môže od rána do večera hodovať na rovnako sladkých plodoch.

TEXT_SOURCE: As the little fellow went on his way nearly all the fairies followed him to the borders of the land, and when they saw him go up the mountain towards the land of the giants, they all took off their little red caps and waved them until he was out of sight.
VETA: Keď chlapček išiel svojou cestou, takmer všetky víly ho nasledovali až k hraniciam krajiny, a keď ho videli ísť hore horou smerom ku krajine obrov, všetky si sňali červené čiapočky a mávali nimi, kým bol v nedohľadne.

TEXT_SOURCE: On he went walking all day and night, and when the sun rose on the morrow he was on the top of the mountain, and he could see the land of the giants in the valley stretched far below him.
VETA: Ďalej chodil celý deň a noc, a keď na druhý deň vyšlo slnko, bol na vrchole hory a videl krajinu obrov v údolí, rozprestierajúcom sa hlboko pod ním.

TEXT_SOURCE: Before beginning his descent he turned round for a last glimpse of fairyland; but he could see nothing, for a thick, dark cloud shut it out from view.
VETA: Pred začiatkom zostupu sa otočil, aby naposledy zazrel rozprávkovú krajinu; ale nevidel nič, lebo hustý, tmavý mrak ho zakrýval.

TEXT_SOURCE: He was very sad, and tired, and footsore, and as he struggled down the rough mountain side, he could not help thinking of the soft, green woods and mossy pathways of the pleasant land he had left behind him.
VETA: Bol veľmi smutný, unavený a boleli ho nohy, a keď sa boril dole drsným úbočím hôr, nemohol nemyslieť na mäkké, zelené lesy a machové chodníky príjemnej krajiny, ktorú za sebou zanechal.

TEXT_SOURCE: When he awoke the ground was trembling, and a noise that sounded like thunder fell on his ears.
VETA: Keď sa zobudil, zem sa triasla a do uší mu dopadol zvuk, ktorý znel ako hrom.

TEXT_SOURCE: He looked up and saw coming towards him a terrible giant, with one eye that burned like a live coal in the middle of his forehead, his mouth stretched from ear to ear, his teeth were long and crooked, the skin of his face was as black as night, and his arms and chest were all covered with black, shaggy hair; round his body was an iron band, and hanging from this by a chain was a great club with iron spikes.
VETA: Pozrel sa hore a uvidel, ako k nemu prichádza strašný obr, s jedným okom, ktoré mu horelo ako živý uhlík uprostred čela, ústa natiahnuté od ucha k uchu, dlhé a krivé zuby, pokožka jeho tváre bola taká čierny ako noc a jeho ruky a hruď boli celé pokryté čiernymi, strapatými vlasmi; okolo jeho tela bol železný pás a na reťazi na ňom visel veľký palica so železnými hrotmi.

TEXT_SOURCE: With one blow of this club he could break a rock into splinters, and fire could not burn him, and water could not drown him, and weapons could not wound him, and there was no way to kill him but by giving him three blows of his own club.
VETA: Jedným úderom tohto kyjaka mohol rozbiť skalu na úlomky a oheň ho nemohol spáliť, voda ho nemohla utopiť a zbrane ho nemohli zraniť, a neexistoval spôsob, ako ho zabiť, iba tri rany. svoj vlastný klub.

TEXT_SOURCE: And he was so bad-tempered that the other giants called him Sharvan the Surly.
VETA: A bol taký zlý, že ho ostatní obri volali Sharvan the Surly.

TEXT_SOURCE: When the giant spied the red cap of the little fairy he gave the shout that sounded like thunder.
VETA: Keď obr zazrel červenú čiapočku malej víly, vydal výkrik, ktorý znel ako hrom.

TEXT_SOURCE: The poor fairy was shaking from head to foot.
VETA: Úbohá víla sa triasla od hlavy po päty.

TEXT_SOURCE: What brought you here? said the giant.
VETA: Čo ťa sem priviedlo? povedal obr.

TEXT_SOURCE: Please, Mr. Giant, said the fairy, the king of the fairies banished me here, and here I must stay for ever and a day, unless you come and guard the fairy tree in Dooros Wood.
VETA: Prosím, pán Obr, povedala víla, kráľ víl ma sem vyhnal a tu musím zostať navždy a jeden deň, pokiaľ neprídete strážiť rozprávkový strom v Dooros Wood.

TEXT_SOURCE: Unless what? roared the giant, and he gave the fairy a touch of his foot that sent the little fellow rolling down head over heels.
VETA: Ibaže čo? zareval obr a dotkol sa víly svojej nohy, čo spôsobilo, že sa malý chlapík skotúľal po päty.

TEXT_SOURCE: The poor fairy lay as if he were dead, and then the giant, feeling sorry for what he had done, took him up gently between his finger and thumb.
VETA: Úbohá víla ležala, ako keby bol mŕtvy, a potom ho obr, ľutujúc, čo urobil, jemne zdvihol medzi prst a palec.

TEXT_SOURCE: Don’t be frightened, little man, said he, and now, tell me all about the tree.
VETA: Neboj sa, malý muž, povedal, a teraz mi povedz všetko o strome.

TEXT_SOURCE: It is the tree of the fairy berry that grows in the Wood of Dooros, said the fairy, and I have some of the berries with me.
VETA: Je to strom rozprávkových bobúľ, ktoré rastú v lese Dooros, povedala víla, a ja mám niektoré bobule so sebou.

TEXT_SOURCE: Oh, you have, have you? said the giant.
VETA: Oh, máš, máš? povedal obr.

TEXT_SOURCE: Let me see them.
VETA: Dovoľte mi ich vidieť.

TEXT_SOURCE: The fairy took three berries from the pocket of his little green coat, and gave them to the giant.
VETA: Víla vybrala z vrecka jeho malého zeleného kabátika tri bobule a dala ich obrovi.

TEXT_SOURCE: The giant looked at them for a second.
VETA: Obr na nich chvíľu hľadel.

TEXT_SOURCE: He then swallowed the three together, and when he had done so, he felt so happy that he began to shout and dance for joy.
VETA: Potom všetkých troch spolu prehltol, a keď to urobil, pocítil takú radosť, že začal kričať a tancovať od radosti.

TEXT_SOURCE: More, you little thief! said he.
VETA: Viac, ty malý zlodej! povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: More, you little–––what’s your name? said the giant.
VETA: Viac, ty malý---ako sa voláš? povedal obr.

TEXT_SOURCE: Pinkeen, please, Mr. Giant, said the fairy, as he gave up all the berries.
VETA: Pinkeen, prosím, pán Obr, povedala víla, keď sa vzdal všetkých bobúľ.

TEXT_SOURCE: The giant shouted louder than before, and his shouts were heard by all the other giants, who came running towards him.
VETA: Obr kričal hlasnejšie ako predtým a jeho výkriky počuli aj všetci ostatní obri, ktorí sa k nemu rozbehli.

TEXT_SOURCE: When Sharvan saw them coming, he caught up Pinkeen, and put him in his pocket, that they shouldn’t see him.
VETA: Keď ich Sharvan videl prichádzať, chytil Pinkeena a strčil si ho do vrecka, aby ho nevideli.

TEXT_SOURCE: What were you shouting for? said the giants.
VETA: Čo si kričal? povedali obri.

TEXT_SOURCE: Because, said Sharvan, that rock there fell down on my big toe.
VETA: Pretože, povedal Sharvan, ten kameň mi tam spadol na palec na nohe.

TEXT_SOURCE: You did not shout like a man that was hurt, said they.
VETA: Nekričal si ako zranený muž, povedali.

TEXT_SOURCE: What is it to you what way I shouted? said he.
VETA: Čo je ti do toho, akým spôsobom som kričal? povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: You might give a civil answer to a civil question, said they; but sure you were always Sharvan the Surly; and they went away.
VETA: Môžete dať civilnú odpoveď na občiansku otázku, povedali; ale určite si bol vždy Sharvan the Surly; a odišli preč.

TEXT_SOURCE: When the giants were out of sight, Sharvan took Pinkeen out of his wallet.
VETA: Keď sa obri stratili z dohľadu, Sharvan vytiahol Pinkeen z peňaženky.

TEXT_SOURCE: Some more berries, you little thief––I mean little Pinkeen, said he.
VETA: Ešte nejaké bobule, ty malý zlodejko – myslím malý Pinkeen, povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: I have not any more, said Pinkeen; but if you will guard the tree in Dooros Wood you can feast on them from morn till night.
VETA: Už nemám, povedala Pinkeen; ale ak budete strážiť strom v Dooros Wood, môžete na nich hodovať od rána do večera.

TEXT_SOURCE: I’ll guard every tree in the wood, if I may do that, said the giant.
VETA: Budem strážiť každý strom v lese, ak to môžem urobiť, povedal obr.

TEXT_SOURCE: You’ll have to guard only one, said Pinkeen.
VETA: Budete musieť strážiť iba jedného, povedala Pinkeen.

TEXT_SOURCE: How am I to get to it? said Sharvan.s
VETA: Ako sa k tomu dostanem? povedal Sharvan.s

TEXT_SOURCE: You must first come with me towards fairyland, said the fairy.
VETA: Najprv musíš ísť so mnou do rozprávkovej krajiny, povedala víla.

TEXT_SOURCE: Very well, said Sharvan; let us go.
VETA: Veľmi dobre, povedal Sharvan; nechaj nás ísť.

TEXT_SOURCE: And he took up the fairy and put him into his wallet, and before very long they were on the top of the mountain.
VETA: A vzal vílu a vložil si ju do peňaženky a onedlho boli na vrchole hory.

TEXT_SOURCE: Then the giant looked around towards the giant’s land; but a black cloud shut it out from view, while the sun was shining on the valley that lay before him, and he could see away in the distance the green woods and shining waters of fairyland.
VETA: Potom sa obr rozhliadol smerom k obrovej krajine; ale čierny mrak ho zakrýval, zatiaľ čo slnko svietilo na údolie, ktoré ležalo pred ním, a on v diaľke videl zelené lesy a žiariace vody rozprávkovej krajiny.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was not long until he reached its borders, but when he tried to cross them his feet stuck to the ground and he could not move a step.
VETA: Netrvalo dlho, kým sa dostal k jej hraniciam, no keď sa ich pokúsil prekročiť, nohy sa mu prilepili na zem a nemohol sa pohnúť ani na krok.

TEXT_SOURCE: Sharvan gave three loud shouts that were heard all over fairyland, and made the trees in the woods tremble, as if the wind of a storm was sweeping over them.
VETA: Sharvan vydal tri hlasné výkriky, ktoré bolo počuť po celej rozprávkovej krajine, a spôsobil, že sa stromy v lese chveli, akoby sa cez ne prehnal vietor búrky.

TEXT_SOURCE: Oh, please, Mr. Giant, let me out, said Pinkeen.
VETA: Och, prosím, pán Obr, pustite ma von, povedala Pinkeen.

TEXT_SOURCE: Sharvan took out the little fellow, who, as soon as he saw he was on the borders of fairyland ran as fast as his legs could carry him, and before he had gone very far he met all the little fairies who, hearing the shouts of the giant, came trooping out from the ferns to see what was the matter.
VETA: Sharvan vzal malého chlapíka, ktorý, len čo videl, že je na hraniciach rozprávkovej krajiny, bežal tak rýchlo, ako ho nohy uniesli, a skôr, ako sa dostal veľmi ďaleko, stretol všetky malé víly, ktoré počuli výkriky obr, vyliezol z papradí, aby zistil, čo sa deje.

TEXT_SOURCE: Pinkeen told them it was the giant who was to guard the tree, shouting because he was stuck fast on the borders, and they need have no fear of him.
VETA: Pinkeen im povedala, že to bol obr, ktorý mal strážiť strom, kričiac, pretože bol prilepený na hraniciach a oni sa ho nemusia báť.

TEXT_SOURCE: The fairies were so delighted to have Pinkeen back again, that they took him up on their shoulders and carried him to the king’s palace, and all the harpers and pipers and fiddlers marched before him playing the most jocund music that was ever heard.
VETA: Víly boli tak potešené, že majú Pinkeen opäť späť, že ho vzali na plecia a odniesli do kráľovského paláca a všetci harfisti, píšťalky a huslistky pochodovali pred ním a hrali tú najrozmarnejšiu hudbu, akú kedy počuli.

TEXT_SOURCE: The king and queen were on the lawn in front of the palace when the gay procession came up and halted before them.
VETA: Kráľ a kráľovná boli na trávniku pred palácom, keď prišiel sprievod homosexuálov a zastavil sa pred nimi.

TEXT_SOURCE: The queen’s eyes glistened with pleasure when she saw the little favourite, and the king was also glad at heart, but he looked very grave as he said: Why have you returned, sirrah?
VETA: Kráľovnej sa oči leskli potešením, keď uvidela malého obľúbenca, a kráľ sa tiež v srdci tešil, ale vyzeral veľmi vážne, keď povedal: Prečo ste sa vrátili, sirrah?

TEXT_SOURCE: Then Pinkeen told his majesty that he had brought with him a giant who was willing to guard the fairy tree.
VETA: Potom Pinkeen povedal jeho veličenstvu, že so sebou priviedol obra, ktorý bol ochotný strážiť rozprávkový strom.

TEXT_SOURCE: And who is he and where is he? asked the king.
VETA: A kto to je a kde je? spýtal sa kráľ.

TEXT_SOURCE: The other giants called him Sharvan the Surly, said Pinkeen, and he is stuck fast outside the borders of fairyland.
VETA: Ostatní obri ho volali Sharvan the Surly, povedala Pinkeen, a on uviazol rýchlo za hranicami rozprávkovej krajiny.

TEXT_SOURCE: It is well, said the king, you are pardoned.
VETA: To je dobré, povedal kráľ, ste odpustení.

TEXT_SOURCE: When the fairies heard this they tossed their little red caps in the air, and cheered so loudly that a bee who was clinging to a rose-bud fell senseless to the ground.
VETA: Keď to víly počuli, vyhadzovali svoje malé červené čiapočky do vzduchu a jasali tak hlasno, že včela, ktorá sa držala púčika ruže, ako zmyslov zbavená padla na zem.

TEXT_SOURCE: Then the king ordered one of his pages to take a handful of berries, and to go to Sharvan and show him the way to Dooros Wood.
VETA: Potom kráľ prikázal jednému zo svojich pážat, aby vzal za hrsť bobúľ a išiel za Sharvanom a ukázal mu cestu do Dooros Wood.

TEXT_SOURCE: The page, taking the berries with him, went off to Sharvan, whose roaring nearly frightened the poor little fellow to death.
VETA: Pážo, ktoré vzalo so sebou bobule, odišlo k Sharvanovi, ktorého rev takmer vydesil úbohého chlapíka na smrť.

TEXT_SOURCE: But as soon as the giant tasted the berries he got into good humour, and he asked the page if he could remove the spell of enchantment from him.
VETA: Ale len čo obr ochutnal bobule, dostal dobrú náladu a spýtal sa stránky, či by z neho mohol odstrániť kúzlo očarovania.

TEXT_SOURCE: I can, said the page, and I will if you promise me that you will not try to cross the borders of fairyland.
VETA: Môžem, povedala stránka, a urobím to, ak mi sľúbiš, že sa nepokúsiš prekročiť hranice rozprávkovej krajiny.

TEXT_SOURCE: I promise that, with all my heart, said the giant.
VETA: Sľubujem, že z celého srdca povedal obr.

TEXT_SOURCE: But hurry on, my little man, for there are pins and needles in my legs.
VETA: Ale ponáhľaj sa, môj malý človiečik, lebo v nohách mám ihly a ihly.

TEXT_SOURCE: The page plucked a cowslip, and picking out the five little crimson spots in the cup of it, he flung one to the north, and one to the south, and one to the east, and one to the west, and one up into the sky, and the spell was broken, and the giant’s limbs were free.
VETA: Páža vytrhol kravskú pastu, vybral z nej päť malých karmínových škvŕn a hodil jednu na sever, jednu na juh, jednu na východ, jednu na západ a jednu hore do obloha a kúzlo bolo prerušené a končatiny obra boli voľné.

TEXT_SOURCE: Then Sharvan and the fairy page set off for Dooros Wood, and it was not long until they came within view of the fairy tree.
VETA: Potom sa Sharvan a rozprávková stránka vydali do Dooros Wood a netrvalo dlho, kým sa dostali k rozprávkovému stromu.

TEXT_SOURCE: When Sharvan saw the berries glistening in the sun, he gave a shout so loud and strong that the wind of it blew the little fairy back to fairyland.
VETA: Keď Sharvan videl, že sa bobule lesknú na slnku, vykríkol tak hlasno a silno, že vietor odvial malú vílu späť do rozprávkovej krajiny.

TEXT_SOURCE: But he had to return to the wood to tell the giant that he was to stay all day at the foot of the tree ready to do battle with anyone who might come to steal the berries, and that during the night he was to sleep amongst the branches.
VETA: Musel sa však vrátiť do lesa, aby povedal obrovi, že má zostať celý deň na úpätí stromu pripravený bojovať s každým, kto by mohol prísť ukradnúť bobule, a že v noci bude spať medzi stromami. pobočky.

TEXT_SOURCE: All right, said the giant, who could scarcely speak, as his mouth was full of berries.
VETA: Dobre, povedal obr, ktorý sotva hovoril, lebo mal ústa plné bobúľ.

TEXT_SOURCE: Well, the fame of the fairy-tree spread far and wide, and every day some adventurer came to try if he could carry away some of the berries; but the giant, true to his word, was always on the watch, and not a single day passed on which he did not fight and slay a daring champion, and the giant never received a wound, for fire could not burn him, nor water drown him, nor weapon wound him.
VETA: Nuž, sláva rozprávkového stromu sa šírila široko-ďaleko a každý deň prichádzal nejaký dobrodruh, aby si vyskúšal, či si odnesie nejaké tie bobule; ale obr, verný svojmu slovu, bol vždy v strehu a neprešiel jediný deň, kedy by nebojoval a nezabil odvážneho šampióna a obr nikdy nedostal ranu, pretože ho nemohol spáliť oheň ani voda. utopiť ho, ani ho nezraniť zbraňou.

TEXT_SOURCE: Now, at this time, when Sharvan was keeping watch and ward over the tree, a cruel king was reigning over the lands that looked towards the rising sun.
VETA: Teraz, v tomto čase, keď Sharvan držal stráž a strážil strom, krutý kráľ vládol nad krajinami, ktoré hľadeli na vychádzajúce slnko.

TEXT_SOURCE: He had slain the rightful king by foul means, and his subjects, loving their murdered sovereign, hated the usurper; but much as they hated him they feared him more, for he was brave and masterful, and he was armed with a helmet and shield which no weapon made by mortal hands could pierce, and he carried always with him two javelins that never missed their mark, and were so fatal that they were called the shafts of death.
VETA: Ohavným spôsobom zabil právoplatného kráľa a jeho poddaní, milujúc svojho zavraždeného panovníka, nenávideli uzurpátora; no napriek tomu, že ho nenávideli, báli sa ho ešte viac, pretože bol statočný a majstrovský a bol vyzbrojený prilbou a štítom, ktoré nedokázala preraziť žiadna zbraň vyrobená smrteľnými rukami, a vždy nosil so sebou dva oštepy, ktoré nikdy neminuli svoju značku. a boli také smrteľné, že ich nazvali hriadeľmi smrti.

TEXT_SOURCE: The murdered king had two children––a boy, whose name was Niall, and a girl, who was called Rosaleen––that is, little Rose; but no rose that ever bloomed was half as sweet or fresh or fair as she.
VETA: Zavraždený kráľ mal dve deti – chlapca, ktorý sa volal Niall, a dievča, ktoré sa volalo Rosaleen – teda malú Rose; ale žiadna ruža, ktorá kedy rozkvitla, nebola ani z polovice taká sladká, ani svieža alebo krásna ako ona.

TEXT_SOURCE: Cruel as the tyrant king was, he was afraid of the people to kill the children.
VETA: Aj keď bol kráľ tyran krutý, bál sa ľudí zabiť deti.

TEXT_SOURCE: He sent the boy adrift on the sea in an open boat, hoping the waves would swallow it; and he got an old witch to cast the spell of deformity over Rosaleen, and under the spell her beauty faded, until at last she became so ugly and wasted that scarcely anyone would speak to her.
VETA: Poslal chlapca na otvorenom člne na more a dúfal, že ho pohltia vlny; a dostal starú čarodejnicu, aby na Rosaleen uvrhla kúzlo deformácie a pod kúzlom jej krása vybledla, až sa napokon stala taká škaredá a zničená, že s ňou sotva niekto hovoril.

TEXT_SOURCE: And, shunned by everyone, she spent her days in the out-houses with the cattle, and every night she cried herself to sleep.
VETA: A všetci sa jej vyhýbali, trávila dni v domčekoch s dobytkom a každú noc plakala, aby spala.

TEXT_SOURCE: One day, when she was very lonely, a little robin came to pick the crumbs that had fallen about her feet.
VETA: Jedného dňa, keď bola veľmi osamelá, prišla malá červienka pozbierať omrvinky, ktoré jej popadali na nohy.

TEXT_SOURCE: He appeared so tame that she offered him the bread from her hand, and when he took it she cried with joy at finding that there was one living thing that did not shun her.
VETA: Zdal sa taký krotký, že mu ponúkla chlieb zo svojej ruky, a keď ho vzal, rozplakala sa od radosti, keď zistila, že existuje jedna živá bytosť, ktorá sa jej nevyhýba.

TEXT_SOURCE: After this the robin came every day, and he sang so sweetly for her that she almost forgot her loneliness and misery.
VETA: Potom červienka prichádzala každý deň a spieval jej tak sladko, že takmer zabudla na svoju samotu a biedu.

TEXT_SOURCE: But once while the robin was with her the tyrant king’s daughter, who was very beautiful, passed with her maids of honour, and, seeing Rosaleen, the princess said: Oh, there is that horrid ugly thing.
VETA: Ale raz, keď bola s ňou červienka, prešla dcéra tyranského kráľa, ktorá bola veľmi krásna, so svojimi slúžkami, a keď princezná uvidela Rosaleen, povedala: Ach, je tu tá strašná škaredá vec.

TEXT_SOURCE: The maids laughed and giggled, and said they had never seen such a fright.
VETA: Slúžky sa smiali a chichotali a hovorili, že taký strach ešte nevideli.

TEXT_SOURCE: Poor Rosaleen felt as if her heart would break, and when the princess and her maids were out of sight she almost cried her eyes out.
VETA: Úbohá Rosaleen mala pocit, že jej pukne srdce, a keď princezná a jej slúžky zmizli z dohľadu, takmer si vyplakala oči.

TEXT_SOURCE: When the robin saw her crying he perched on her shoulder and rubbed his little head against her neck and chirruped softly in her ear, and Rosaleen was comforted, for she felt she had at least one friend in the world, although it was only a little robin.
VETA: Keď ju červienka videl plakať, sadol si na jej rameno, obtrel jej hlavu o krk a jemne jej zacvrlikal do ucha, a Rosaleen sa utešila, pretože cítila, že má na svete aspoň jedného priateľa, hoci to bolo len málo. robin.

TEXT_SOURCE: But the robin could do more for her than she could dream of.
VETA: Červenka však pre ňu mohla urobiť viac, ako by si mohla vysnívať.

TEXT_SOURCE: He heard the remark made by the princess, and he saw Rosaleen’s tears, and he knew now why she was shunned by everybody, and why she was so unhappy.
VETA: Počul poznámku princeznej a videl Rosaleenine slzy a už vedel, prečo sa jej všetci vyhýbali a prečo bola taká nešťastná.

TEXT_SOURCE: And that very evening he flew off to Dooros Wood, and called on a cousin of his and told him all about Rosaleen.
VETA: A ešte v ten večer odletel do Dooros Wood, zavolal svojho bratranca a povedal mu všetko o Rosaleen.

TEXT_SOURCE: And you want some of the fairy berries, I suppose, said his cousin, Robin of the Wood.
VETA: A ty chceš nejaké tie rozprávkové bobule, predpokladám, povedal jeho bratranec Robin z lesa.

TEXT_SOURCE: I do, said Rosaleen’s little friend.
VETA: Áno, povedala Rosaleenina malá kamarátka.

TEXT_SOURCE: Ah, said Robin of the Wood, times have changed since you were here last.
VETA: Ach, povedal Robin z lesa, časy sa zmenili, odkedy si tu bol naposledy.

TEXT_SOURCE: The tree is guarded now all the day long by a surly giant.
VETA: Strom teraz celý deň stráži nevrlý obr.

TEXT_SOURCE: He sleeps in the branches during the night, and he breathes upon them and around them every morning, and his breath is poison to bird and bee.
VETA: V noci spí vo vetvách a každé ráno dýcha na ne a okolo nich a jeho dych je jedom pre vtáky a včely.

TEXT_SOURCE: There is only one chance open, and if you try that it may cost you your life.
VETA: Otvorená je len jedna šanca a ak to skúsite, môže vás to stáť život.

TEXT_SOURCE: Then tell me what it is, for I would give a hundred lives for Rosaleen, said her own little robin.
VETA: Potom mi povedz, čo to je, lebo za Rosaleen by som dala sto životov, povedala jej malá červienka.

TEXT_SOURCE: Well, said Robin of the Wood, every day a champion comes to battle with the giant, and the giant, before he begins the fight, puts a branch of berries in the iron belt that’s around his waist, so that when he feels tired or thirsty he can refresh himself, and there is just a bare chance, while he is fighting, of picking one of the berries from the branch; but if his breath fall on you it is certain death.
VETA: Nuž, povedal Robin z lesa, každý deň prichádza šampión bojovať s obrom a obr, predtým ako začne zápas, vloží vetvičku bobúľ do železného opasku, ktorý má okolo pása, takže keď sa cíti unavený, resp. smädný sa môže občerstviť a počas boja je len holá šanca natrhať si jednu z bobúľ z konára; ale ak na teba padne jeho dych, je to istá smrť.

TEXT_SOURCE: I will take the chance, said Rosaleen’s robin.
VETA: Využijem šancu, povedala Rosaleenina červienka.

TEXT_SOURCE: Very well, said the other.
VETA: Veľmi dobre, povedal druhý.

TEXT_SOURCE: And the two birds flew through the wood until they came within sight of the fairy tree.
VETA: A dva vtáky lietali lesom, kým sa nedostali na dohľad rozprávkového stromu.

TEXT_SOURCE: The giant was lying stretched at the foot of it, eating the berries; but it was not long until a warrior came, who challenged him to battle.
VETA: Obr ležal natiahnutý na jej úpätí a jedol bobule; ale netrvalo dlho a prišiel bojovník, ktorý ho vyzval do boja.

TEXT_SOURCE: The giant jumped up, and plucking a branch from the tree stuck it in his belt, and swinging his iron club above his head strode towards the warrior, and the fight began.
VETA: Obr vyskočil, odtrhol konár zo stromu a zapichol si ho do opaska, švihol železným kyjom nad hlavou a vykročil smerom k bojovníkovi a boj sa začal.

TEXT_SOURCE: The robin perched on a tree behind the giant, and watched and waited for his chance; but it was a long time coming, for the berries were in front of the giant’s belt.
VETA: Červenka sa posadila na strom za obrom, sledovala a čakala na svoju príležitosť; ale bolo to dlho, lebo bobule boli pred pásom obra.

TEXT_SOURCE: At last the giant, with one great blow, struck the warrior down, but as he did so he stumbled and fell upon him, and before he had time to recover himself the little robin darted towards him like a flash and picked off one of the berries, and then, as fast as wings could carry him, he flew towards home, and on his way he passed over a troop of warriors on snow-white steeds.
VETA: Nakoniec obrie jedným veľkým úderom zrazil bojovníka, no pri tom narazil a spadol naňho, a kým sa stihol spamätať, malý červiec sa k nemu vyrútil ako blesk a stiahol jedného z nich. bobule, a potom, ako rýchlo ho krídla dokázali uniesť, letel smerom k domovu a cestou prešiel cez tlupu bojovníkov na snehobielych koňoch.

TEXT_SOURCE: All the horsemen except one wore silver helmets and shining mantles of green silk, fastened by brooches of red gold, but the chief, who rode at the head of the troop, wore a golden helmet, and his mantle was of yellow silk, and he looked by far the noblest of them all.
VETA: Všetci jazdci okrem jedného mali na sebe strieborné prilby a lesklé plášte zo zeleného hodvábu, pripevnené brošňami z červeného zlata, ale náčelník, ktorý jazdil na čele oddielu, mal na hlave zlatú prilbu a plášť mal zo žltého hodvábu. vyzerali zďaleka najušľachtilejšie zo všetkých.

TEXT_SOURCE: When the robin had left the horsemen far behind him he spied Rosaleen sitting outside the palace gates bemoaning her fate.
VETA: Keď červienka nechala jazdcov ďaleko za sebou, zbadal Rosaleen sediacu pred bránami paláca a nariekajúc nad jej osudom.

TEXT_SOURCE: The robin perched upon her shoulder, and almost before she knew he was there he put the berry between her lips, and the taste was so delicious that Rosaleen ate it at once, and that very moment the witch’s withering spell passed away from her, and she became as lovely as the flower of beauty.
VETA: Červenka sa posadila na jej rameno a skoro predtým, ako vedela, že je tam, jej vložil bobule medzi pery a chuť bola taká lahodná, že to Rosaleen okamžite zjedla a práve v tom momente ju pominulo čarodejnícke kúzlo. stala sa pôvabnou ako kvet krásy.

TEXT_SOURCE: Just then the warriors on the snow-white steeds came up, and the chief with the mantle of yellow silk and the golden helmet leaped from his horse, and bending his knee before her, said: Fairest of all fair maidens, you are surely the daughter of the king of these realms, even though you are without the palace gates, unattended, and wear not royal robes.
VETA: Práve vtedy vystúpili bojovníci na snehobielych koňoch a náčelník s plášťom zo žltého hodvábu a zlatou prilbou zoskočil z koňa, pokrčil pred ňou koleno a povedal: Najkrajšia zo všetkých krásnych panien, ty si určite tá. dcéra kráľa týchto ríš, aj keď si bez brán paláca, bez dozoru a nenosíš kráľovské rúcha.

TEXT_SOURCE: I am the Prince of the Sunny Valleys.
VETA: Som princ Slnečných údolí.

TEXT_SOURCE: Daughter of a king I am, said Rosaleen, but not of the king who rules these realms.
VETA: Som dcéra kráľa, povedala Rosaleen, ale nie kráľa, ktorý vládne týmto ríšam.

TEXT_SOURCE: And saying this she fled, leaving the prince wondering who she could be.
VETA: A keď to povedala, utiekla a nechala princa premýšľať, kým by mohla byť.

TEXT_SOURCE: The prince then ordered his trumpeters to give notice of his presence outside the palace, and in a few moments the king and all his nobles came out to greet the prince and his warriors, and give them welcome.
VETA: Princ potom nariadil svojim trubačom, aby oznámili jeho prítomnosť pred palácom, a o chvíľu kráľ a všetci jeho šľachtici vyšli pozdraviť princa a jeho bojovníkov a privítať ich.

TEXT_SOURCE: That night a great feast was spread in the banquet-hall, and the Prince of the Sunny Valleys sat by the king, and beside the prince sat the king’s beautiful daughter, and then in due order sat the nobles of the court and the warriors who had come with the prince, and on the wall behind each noble and warrior his shield and helmet were suspended, flashing radiance through the room.
VETA: V tú noc sa v banketovej sieni usporiadala veľká hostina a princ zo Slnečných údolí sedel pri kráľovi a vedľa princa sedela kráľova krásna dcéra a potom v správnom poradí sedeli dvorní šľachtici a bojovníci, ktorí prišiel s princom a na stene za každým šľachticom a bojovníkom bol zavesený jeho štít a prilba, ktoré prežiarili miestnosť.

TEXT_SOURCE: During the feast the prince spoke most graciously to the lovely lady at his side, but all the time he was thinking of the unknown beauty he had met outside the palace gates, and his heart longed for another glimpse of her.
VETA: Počas sviatku sa princ najmilšie prihovoril milej dáme po svojom boku, no celý čas myslel na neznámu krásku, ktorú stretol za bránami paláca, a jeho srdce túžilo po jej ďalšom pohľade.

TEXT_SOURCE: When the feast was ended, and the jewelled drinking-cups had gone merrily around the table, the bards sang, to the accompaniment of harps, the Courtship of the Lady Eimer, and as they pictured her radiant beauty outshining that of all her maidens, the prince thought that fair as Lady Eimer was there was one still fairer.
VETA: Keď sa hostina skončila a poháre na pitie s drahokamami veselo obchádzali stôl, bardi za sprievodu harf spievali dvorenie lady Eimerovej, a keď si predstavovali jej žiarivú krásu, ktorá prevyšovala krásu všetkých jej panien, princ si myslel, že taká spravodlivá, ako bola lady Eimer, existuje ešte spravodlivejšia.

TEXT_SOURCE: When the feast was ended the king asked the prince what brought him into his realms.
VETA: Keď sa hostina skončila, kráľ sa spýtal princa, čo ho priviedlo do jeho ríš.

TEXT_SOURCE: I come, said the prince, to look for a bride, for it was foretold to me in my own country that here only I should find the lady who is destined to share my throne, and fame reported that in your kingdom are to be found the loveliest maidens in all the world, and I can well believe that, added the prince, after what I have seen to-day.
VETA: Prišiel som, povedal princ, hľadať nevestu, pretože v mojej vlastnej krajine mi bolo predpovedané, že len tu nájdem dámu, ktorá je predurčená zdieľať môj trón, a sláva hlásila, že vo vašom kráľovstve sa nachádza. najkrajšie devy na celom svete a ja tomu môžem dobre veriť, dodal princ po tom, čo som dnes videl.

TEXT_SOURCE: When the king’s daughter heard this she hung down her head and blushed like a rose, for, of course, she thought the prince was alluding only to herself, as she did not know that he had seen Rosaleen, and she had not heard of the restoration of her beauty.
VETA: Keď to počula kráľova dcéra, zvesila hlavu a začervenala sa ako ruža, pretože si, samozrejme, myslela, že princ narážal iba na seba, pretože nevedela, že videl Rosaleen a ani o tom nepočula. obnovenie jej krásy.

TEXT_SOURCE: Before another word could be spoken a great noise and the clang of arms were heard outside the palace.
VETA: Predtým, ako bolo možné vysloviť ďalšie slovo, bolo pred palácom počuť veľký hluk a rinčanie zbraní.

TEXT_SOURCE: The king and his guests started from their seats and drew their swords, and the bards raised the song of battle; but their voices were stilled and their harps silenced when they saw at the threshold of the banquet hall a battle champion, in whose face they recognised the features of their murdered king.
VETA: Kráľ a jeho hostia vyštartovali zo svojich sedadiel, vytasili meče a bardi spustili spev boja; ale ich hlasy stíchli a ich harfy stíchli, keď na prahu banketovej siene uvideli bojového šampióna, v ktorého tvári spoznali črty svojho zavraždeného kráľa.

TEXT_SOURCE: ’Tis Niall come back to claim his father’s throne, said the chief bard.
VETA: To je Niall, aby sa vrátil na trón svojho otca, povedal hlavný bard.

TEXT_SOURCE: Long live Niall!
VETA: Nech žije Niall!

TEXT_SOURCE: Long live Niall! answered all the others.
VETA: Nech žije Niall! odpovedal všetkým ostatným.

TEXT_SOURCE: The king, white with rage and amazement, turned to the chiefs and nobles of his court, and cried out: Is there none loyal enough to drive that intruder from the banquet hall?
VETA: Kráľ, biely od zúrivosti a úžasu, sa obrátil k náčelníkom a šľachticom svojho dvora a zvolal: Nie je nikto natoľko lojálny, aby vyhnal toho votrelca z hodovnej siene?

TEXT_SOURCE: But no one stirred, and no answer was given.
VETA: Ale nikto sa nehýbal a nedostal žiadnu odpoveď.

TEXT_SOURCE: Then the king rushed forward alone, but before he could reach the spot where Niall was standing he was seized by a dozen chiefs and at once disarmed.
VETA: Potom sa kráľ rútil vpred sám, ale skôr, než sa dostal na miesto, kde stál Niall, sa ho zmocnilo tucet náčelníkov a okamžite ho odzbrojili.

TEXT_SOURCE: During this scene the king’s daughter had fled frightened; but Rosaleen, attracted by the noise, and hearing her brother’s name and the cheers which greeted it, had entered the banquet hall unperceived by anyone.
VETA: Počas tejto scény kráľova dcéra vystrašená utiekla; ale Rosaleen, priťahovaná hlukom a počujúc meno svojho brata a jasot, ktorý ho privítal, vstúpila do banketovej siene nikým nepostrehnutá.

TEXT_SOURCE: But when her presence was discovered every eye was dazzled with her beauty.
VETA: Ale keď bola objavená jej prítomnosť, každé oko bolo oslnené jej krásou.

TEXT_SOURCE: Niall looked at her for a second, wondering if the radiant maiden before him could be the little sister he had been separated from for so many years.
VETA: Niall na ňu chvíľu hľadel a premýšľal, či tá žiarivá panna pred ním môže byť tá malá sestra, od ktorej bol toľko rokov oddelený.

TEXT_SOURCE: In another second she was clasped in his arms.
VETA: V ďalšej sekunde bola zovretá v jeho náručí.

TEXT_SOURCE: Then the feast was spread again, and Niall told the story of his adventures; and when the Prince of the Sunny Valley asked for the hand of Rosaleen, Niall told his lovely sister to speak for herself.
VETA: Potom sa hostina opäť rozšírila a Niall rozprával príbeh o svojich dobrodružstvách; a keď princ zo Slnečného údolia požiadal o ruku Rosaleen, Niall povedal svojej milej sestre, aby hovorila za seba.

TEXT_SOURCE: With downcast eyes and smiling lips she said, yes, and that very day was the gayest and brightest wedding that ever took place, and Rosaleen became the prince’s bride.
VETA: So sklopenými očami a usmiatymi perami povedala, áno, a práve v ten deň to bola tá najkrajšia a najjasnejšia svadba, aká sa kedy konala, a Rosaleen sa stala princovou nevestou.

TEXT_SOURCE: In her happiness she did not forget the little robin, who was her friend in sorrow.
VETA: Vo svojom šťastí nezabudla na malú červienku, ktorá bola jej kamarátkou v smútku.

TEXT_SOURCE: She took him home with her to Sunny Valleys, and every day she fed him with her own hands, and every day he sang for her the sweetest songs that were ever heard in lady’s bower.
VETA: Vzala ho so sebou domov do Sunny Valleys a každý deň ho kŕmila vlastnými rukami a on jej každý deň spieval tie najmilšie piesne, aké kedy počuli v altánku dámy.

TEXT_SOURCE: Specially designed polymers can dodge the body’s immune defenses to deliver vital medicine where it is needed most.
VETA: Špeciálne navrhnuté polyméry sa môžu vyhnúť imunitnej obrane tela a dodať životne dôležité lieky tam, kde je to najviac potrebné.

TEXT_SOURCE: Although we rarely think about it as we fill a prescription at the drugstore or refill an order through an online service, delivering medicine to its intended site inside the human body is an elaborate problem in materials science.
VETA: Aj keď na to len zriedka myslíme, keď vypĺňame recept v lekárni alebo dopĺňame objednávku prostredníctvom online služby, doručenie lieku na určené miesto v ľudskom tele je komplikovaný problém v oblasti materiálovej vedy.

TEXT_SOURCE: The challenge begins the moment a drug enters the digestive tract or the bloodstream.
VETA: Výzva začína v momente, keď sa liek dostane do tráviaceho traktu alebo krvného obehu.

TEXT_SOURCE: The body naturally strives to defend itself against foreign invasion, even if the invasive substance is a lifesaving medicine.
VETA: Telo sa prirodzene snaží brániť cudzej invázii, aj keď je invazívna látka liekom na záchranu života.

TEXT_SOURCE: Some of our inner defenses work strategically to destroy invading agents at the molecular level, such as the antibodies launched by the immune system that attack unfamiliar entities in the bloodstream.
VETA: Niektoré z našich vnútorných obranných mechanizmov fungujú strategicky na zničenie inváznych činiteľov na molekulárnej úrovni, ako sú protilátky vypustené imunitným systémom, ktoré útočia na neznáme entity v krvnom obehu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Others act more like physical walls to tightly regulate intruding agents, such as the blood-brain barrier, a dense network of capillaries that separate the brain from circulating blood.
VETA: Iné sa správajú skôr ako fyzické steny, aby pevne regulovali prenikavé látky, ako je hematoencefalická bariéra, hustá sieť kapilár, ktoré oddeľujú mozog od cirkulujúcej krvi.

TEXT_SOURCE: Even if a therapeutic compound clears these hurdles, it may still fail in its mission if it is prevented from dissolving properly, or even if it dissolves too quickly and is cleared from the body before it can act.
VETA: Aj keď terapeutická zlúčenina prekoná tieto prekážky, stále môže zlyhať vo svojom poslaní, ak sa jej bráni v správnom rozpustení, alebo dokonca ak sa rozpúšťa príliš rýchlo a je vylúčená z tela skôr, ako môže konať.

TEXT_SOURCE: When an effective drug reaches the correct location in the body, at the right concentrations, and continues to work for the optimal amount of time, this represents the finish line of a very long obstacle course.
VETA: Keď sa účinný liek dostane na správne miesto v tele, v správnych koncentráciách a pokračuje v účinku počas optimálnej doby, predstavuje to cieľovú čiaru veľmi dlhej prekážkovej dráhy.

TEXT_SOURCE: Some drugs manage to travel smoothly to their target site, whereas others are beset with challenges all the way.
VETA: Niektorým drogám sa darí hladko cestovať na svoje cieľové miesto, zatiaľ čo iné sú po celú dobu sužované výzvami.

TEXT_SOURCE: Unfortunately, this second category includes drugs that are vital to preventive care for some of the most lethal diseases, such as cancer.
VETA: Bohužiaľ, táto druhá kategória zahŕňa lieky, ktoré sú životne dôležité pre preventívnu starostlivosť o niektoré z najsmrteľnejších chorôb, ako je rakovina.

TEXT_SOURCE: To develop more effective therapeutic agents, researchers need to come up with not only viable drug candidates but also adaptive materials for drug delivery— materials that could respond to changes in the immediate environment by altering their own physical properties.
VETA: Na vývoj účinnejších terapeutických činidiel musia výskumníci prísť nielen s životaschopnými kandidátmi na lieky, ale aj s adaptívnymi materiálmi na dodávanie liekov - materiálmi, ktoré by mohli reagovať na zmeny v bezprostrednom prostredí zmenou svojich vlastných fyzikálnych vlastností.

TEXT_SOURCE: Thanks to major advances in molecular engineering, scientists are now able to design materials so that they respond to specific kinds of external stimuli, including temperature, acidity, mechanical force, pressure, electrical potential, solvents, chemical agents, and even magnetic field, ionic strength, or certain wavelengths of light.
VETA: Vďaka veľkému pokroku v molekulárnom inžinierstve sú teraz vedci schopní navrhnúť materiály tak, aby reagovali na špecifické druhy vonkajších podnetov, vrátane teploty, kyslosti, mechanickej sily, tlaku, elektrického potenciálu, rozpúšťadiel, chemických činidiel a dokonca aj magnetického poľa, iónových silu alebo určité vlnové dĺžky svetla.

TEXT_SOURCE: The nature of the response can vary as well: Modifications of a material’s shape or surface characteristics, self-assembly, the formation of more intricate molecules, and transitions in physical state are all possible under the right conditions.
VETA: Povaha odozvy sa môže tiež líšiť: Za správnych podmienok sú možné úpravy tvaru alebo povrchových vlastností materiálu, samozostavenie, tvorba zložitejších molekúl a prechody vo fyzikálnom stave.

TEXT_SOURCE: Different materials address different types of problems.
VETA: Rôzne materiály riešia rôzne typy problémov.

TEXT_SOURCE: One type turns into a gel when it warms up, then becomes a liquid again on cooling.
VETA: Jeden typ sa po zahriatí zmení na gél a po ochladení sa opäť zmení na kvapalinu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Another material can be woven into a textile that can break and re-form chemical bonds in response to photostimulation, enabling it to act as a light sensor.
VETA: Iný materiál môže byť votkaný do textílie, ktorá môže v reakcii na fotostimuláciu rozbiť a znovu vytvoriť chemické väzby, čo jej umožňuje pôsobiť ako svetelný senzor.

TEXT_SOURCE: These and other so-called smart materials are being developed right now in labs around the world.
VETA: Tieto a ďalšie takzvané inteligentné materiály sa práve teraz vyvíjajú v laboratóriách po celom svete.

TEXT_SOURCE: Such materials offer applications ranging from the delivery of therapeutics, tissue engineering, and bioseparation to intelligent optical systems, sensors, and coatings.
VETA: Takéto materiály ponúkajú aplikácie od dodania terapeutík, tkanivového inžinierstva a bioseparácie až po inteligentné optické systémy, senzory a nátery.

TEXT_SOURCE: Collectively, the new smart materials fall into the class that chemists call polymers.
VETA: Súhrnne spadajú nové inteligentné materiály do triedy, ktorú chemici nazývajú polyméry.

TEXT_SOURCE: The defining trait of polymers is that they consist of repeated chains of smaller molecules, like perfectly matched beads on a string.
VETA: Charakteristickou črtou polymérov je, že pozostávajú z opakujúcich sa reťazcov menších molekúl, ako sú dokonale zladené guľôčky na šnúrke.

TEXT_SOURCE: This versatile structure occurs throughout the natural world, forming the basis of materials as varied as rubber, beetle shells, and the silken threads of a spider’s web.
VETA: Táto všestranná štruktúra sa vyskytuje v celom prírodnom svete a tvorí základ rôznych materiálov ako guma, lastúry chrobákov a hodvábne vlákna pavúčej siete.

TEXT_SOURCE: The beads in a polymer (known, in chemical terms, as monomers) are all exactly the same and are bonded to one another—an arrangement that gives polymers strength and flexibility.
VETA: Guľôčky v polyméri (známe z chemického hľadiska ako monoméry) sú všetky úplne rovnaké a sú navzájom spojené – usporiadanie, ktoré dodáva polymérom pevnosť a pružnosť.

TEXT_SOURCE: Moreover, many different monomers can be built up into polymers.
VETA: Okrem toho sa do polymérov môže zabudovať mnoho rôznych monomérov.

TEXT_SOURCE: These compounds have long been an important part of the chemist’s bag of tricks, but it required molecular-level engineering to make the polymers smart, allowing them to adapt in desirable ways to changes in the environment.
VETA: Tieto zlúčeniny sú už dlho dôležitou súčasťou chemikov, ale vyžadovalo si inžinierstvo na molekulárnej úrovni, aby boli polyméry inteligentné, čo im umožnilo prispôsobiť sa žiaducim spôsobom zmenám v prostredí.

TEXT_SOURCE: A primary focus of the work in our lab is developing smart polymers that respond to changes in temperature.
VETA: Primárnym zameraním práce v našom laboratóriu je vývoj inteligentných polymérov, ktoré reagujú na zmeny teploty.

TEXT_SOURCE: If the chemical structure of a polymer resembles a long string of identical beads, thermo-responsive materials are made of polymers whose beads, suspended in a solution, change their behavior when the temperature of the solution reaches a certain threshold.
VETA: Ak chemická štruktúra polyméru pripomína dlhý reťazec rovnakých guľôčok, termoresponzívne materiály sú vyrobené z polymérov, ktorých guľôčky suspendované v roztoku menia svoje správanie, keď teplota roztoku dosiahne určitú prahovú hodnotu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Above that critical temperature, the individual molecules of the polymer are transformed from a hydrophilic to a hydrophobic, or water-repellant, state—that is, they alter their shape, allowing less of their surface area to come in contact with surrounding water molecules.
VETA: Nad touto kritickou teplotou sa jednotlivé molekuly polyméru premenia z hydrofilného na hydrofóbny alebo vodu odpudzujúci stav – to znamená, že zmenia svoj tvar, čo umožní menšej ploche ich povrchu prísť do kontaktu s okolitými molekulami vody.

TEXT_SOURCE: This change disrupts the hydrogen-bonded network between the polymer chains and the water molecules that are in the solution.
VETA: Táto zmena naruší vodíkom viazanú sieť medzi polymérnymi reťazcami a molekulami vody, ktoré sú v roztoku.

TEXT_SOURCE: The water is rapidly expelled and the polymeric chains collapse into globules, which causes the thermo-responsive material to precipitate out of the solution.
VETA: Voda sa rýchlo vytlačí a polymérne reťazce sa zrútia do guľôčok, čo spôsobí vyzrážanie materiálu citlivého na teplo z roztoku.

TEXT_SOURCE: If the temperature drops back below the critical point, the polymeric molecules change back from hydrophobic to hydrophilic, absorbing a significant amount of water and transforming the material from a solid back to a solution.
VETA: Ak teplota klesne späť pod kritický bod, polymérne molekuly sa zmenia späť z hydrofóbnej na hydrofilnú, absorbujúc značné množstvo vody a premenia materiál z pevnej látky späť na roztok.

TEXT_SOURCE: Even though this phase transition has been widely observed to occur in both directions and has been documented in many different polymeric materials, scientists continue to debate exactly why it occurs.
VETA: Aj keď bol tento fázový prechod široko pozorovaný v oboch smeroch a bol zdokumentovaný v mnohých rôznych polymérnych materiáloch, vedci pokračujú v diskusii o tom, prečo k nemu presne dochádza.

TEXT_SOURCE: According to one theory, disruption of the polymer-to-water interactions is the main factor that controls the phase transition.
VETA: Podľa jednej teórie je narušenie interakcií polymér-voda hlavným faktorom, ktorý riadi fázový prechod.

TEXT_SOURCE: Another theory holds that the most significant change takes place in the local structure of the water molecules surrounding the hydrophobic groups of the polymer.
VETA: Iná teória tvrdí, že najvýznamnejšia zmena nastáva v lokálnej štruktúre molekúl vody obklopujúcich hydrofóbne skupiny polyméru.

TEXT_SOURCE: A third theory offers a compromise of sorts: Perhaps, on reaching a critical temperature, the polymeric chains undergo a combination of changes occurring in both the hydrogen bonding and the hydrophobic interactions within the solution.
VETA: Tretia teória ponúka kompromis svojho druhu: Možno, že pri dosiahnutí kritickej teploty, polymérne reťazce podliehajú kombinácii zmien vyskytujúcich sa vo vodíkových väzbách a hydrofóbnych interakciách v roztoku.

TEXT_SOURCE: The phase transition in thermo-responsive polymers can also be explained from the point of view of thermodynamics.
VETA: Fázový prechod v termoresponzívnych polyméroch možno vysvetliť aj z hľadiska termodynamiky.

TEXT_SOURCE: At some critical temperature, it is energetically more favorable for phase separation to occur.
VETA: Pri určitej kritickej teplote je pre fázovú separáciu energeticky výhodnejšie.

TEXT_SOURCE: The entropy of the water is higher in the less ordered state, without polymer chains suspended in it.
VETA: Entropia vody je vyššia v menej usporiadanom stave, bez polymérových reťazcov v ňom zavesených.

TEXT_SOURCE: Diving deeper into the thermodynamic interpretation: Initially the water molecules are trapped by hydrogen bonding with the polar groups of the polymer chain.
VETA: Ponorenie sa hlbšie do termodynamickej interpretácie: Spočiatku sú molekuly vody zachytené vodíkovou väzbou s polárnymi skupinami polymérneho reťazca.

TEXT_SOURCE: These trapped water molecules form a thin shell of ordered structure around the hydrophilic part of the polymer.
VETA: Tieto zachytené molekuly vody tvoria okolo hydrofilnej časti polyméru tenký obal usporiadanej štruktúry.

TEXT_SOURCE: Meanwhile, elsewhere in the solution, water molecules interact with one another to form an ordered, ice-like structure around the hydrophobic part of the polymer chain.
VETA: Medzitým inde v roztoku molekuly vody navzájom interagujú a vytvárajú usporiadanú štruktúru podobnú ľadu okolo hydrofóbnej časti polymérneho reťazca.

TEXT_SOURCE: This hydrogen-bonded network contributes to a larger negative entropy change—in other words, a transformation to a more ordered state.
VETA: Táto sieť s vodíkovými väzbami prispieva k väčšej zmene negatívnej entropie – inými slovami, k transformácii do usporiadanejšieho stavu.
