VETA: Aby to bolo ešte horšie, práve v tomto období sa môj zbor zaplietol do rozsiahlej krízy zahŕňajúcej spory medzi niekoľkými dlhoročnými členmi.

TEXT_SOURCE: At meeting after meeting I was asked for my input as senior pastor, but instead of being able to respond, I could only sit by in silence and write down the things I most wanted to say.
VETA: Na stretnutí za stretnutím som bol požiadaný o môj príspevok ako starší pastor, ale namiesto toho, aby som mohol odpovedať, som mohol len ticho sedieť a zapisovať si veci, ktoré som chcel najviac povedať.

TEXT_SOURCE: When a capability like speech – or anything else we take for granted – is taken away from us, we can choose to see it with new appreciation, as the gift it is.
VETA: Keď je nám odobratá schopnosť ako reč – alebo čokoľvek iné, čo považujeme za samozrejmosť –, môžeme sa rozhodnúť, že ju budeme vnímať s novým ocenením, ako dar, ktorým je.

TEXT_SOURCE: But I was too anxious and upset to do that.
VETA: Bol som však príliš nervózny a rozrušený, aby som to urobil.

TEXT_SOURCE: To be honest, I was angry.
VETA: Úprimne povedané, bol som nahnevaný.

TEXT_SOURCE: Even if God was testing me, I said to myself, he couldn’t have picked a worse time.
VETA: Aj keby ma Boh skúšal, povedal som si, horší čas si nemohol vybrať.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was only with time that I was able to see the whole annoying predicament from another angle: I began to real-ize that it was providing me with an important chance to develop a more flexible outlook on life, to take myself less seriously, and to make the best of an imperfect situation.
VETA: Až časom som bol schopný vidieť celú nepríjemnú situáciu z iného uhla pohľadu: začal som si uvedomovať, že mi poskytuje dôležitú šancu vyvinúť si flexibilnejší pohľad na život, brať sa menej vážne a čo najlepšie využiť nedokonalú situáciu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Three months later, my voice began to return; now, seven years later, it is back to normal.
VETA: O tri mesiace neskôr sa mi začal vracať hlas; teraz, o sedem rokov neskôr, sa to vracia do normálu.

TEXT_SOURCE: But I have never forgotten those twelve weeks.
VETA: Ale na tých dvanásť týždňov som nikdy nezabudol.

TEXT_SOURCE: Andrea, a woman in my church, struggled to accept a much heavier burden: she miscarried three times before having a healthy child.
VETA: Andrea, žena v mojom zbore, mala problém prijať oveľa ťažšie bremeno: trikrát potratila, kým mala zdravé dieťa.

TEXT_SOURCE: Unlike mine, Andrea’s story is not, strictly speaking, about blaming or forgiving God.
VETA: Na rozdiel od môjho, Andrein príbeh nie je, prísne vzaté, o obviňovaní alebo odpustení Bohu.

TEXT_SOURCE: For her the battle was to accept the loss of her babies without succumbing to the fear that God was somehow trying to punish her.
VETA: Pre ňu bol boj prijať stratu svojich detí bez toho, aby podľahla strachu, že sa ju Boh nejakým spôsobom snaží potrestať.

TEXT_SOURCE: But in showing how she was able to wrestle through her emotions and find peace, it illustrates a similar theme.
VETA: Ale tým, že ukazuje, ako dokázala bojovať so svojimi emóciami a nájsť pokoj, ilustruje podobnú tému.

TEXT_SOURCE: Neil and I were delighted to find that I was pregnant after only six months of marriage.
VETA: Neil a ja sme boli potešení, keď sme len po šiestich mesiacoch manželstva zistili, že som tehotná.

TEXT_SOURCE: But one night, just before Christmas, I felt intense pain that grew rapidly worse.
VETA: Ale jednu noc, tesne pred Vianocami, som pocítil intenzívnu bolesť, ktorá sa rýchlo zhoršovala.

TEXT_SOURCE: Our doctor wanted to send me to the hospital, and our neighbor, a nurse, came to stay with me until we left for town.
VETA: Náš lekár ma chcel poslať do nemocnice a naša suseda, zdravotná sestra, prišla za mnou, kým sme neodišli do mesta.

TEXT_SOURCE: She confirmed my worst fears – I would probably lose my baby.
VETA: Potvrdila moje najhoršie obavy – pravdepodobne prídem o dieťa.

TEXT_SOURCE: The emotional pain was at least as severe as the physical.
VETA: Emocionálna bolesť bola prinajmenšom taká silná ako fyzická.

TEXT_SOURCE: Why, God?
VETA: Prečo, Bože?

TEXT_SOURCE: Why me?
VETA: Prečo ja?

TEXT_SOURCE: Why do you have to take away this tiny soul so soon?
VETA: Prečo musíš tak skoro odniesť túto malú dušičku?

TEXT_SOURCE: What have I done wrong?
VETA: Čo som urobil zle?

TEXT_SOURCE: In order to save my life, an operation was necessary.
VETA: Aby som si zachránil život, bola potrebná operácia.

TEXT_SOURCE: The baby was lost, and I spent weeks recuperating.
VETA: Dieťa sa stratilo a ja som sa týždne zotavovala.

TEXT_SOURCE: We agonized over our loss and felt alone in our pain.
VETA: Trápili sme sa nad našou stratou a cítili sme sa sami vo svojej bolesti.

TEXT_SOURCE: When one of our relatives said to us, Cheer up!
VETA: Keď nám jeden z našich príbuzných povedal: Vzbuďte sa!

TEXT_SOURCE: Maybe you’ll have better luck next time, I felt like I had been slapped in the face.
VETA: Možno budeš mať nabudúce viac šťastia, cítil som sa, akoby som dostal facku.

TEXT_SOURCE: Luck?
VETA: Šťastie?

TEXT_SOURCE: We had just lost a baby, a real person, a child!
VETA: Práve sme stratili dieťa, skutočnú osobu, dieťa!

TEXT_SOURCE: Someone sent me a card that said, The Lord giveth, and the Lord taketh away, blessed be the name of the Lord.
VETA: Niekto mi poslal pohľadnicu s nápisom: Pán dáva a Pán berie, nech je požehnané Pánovo meno.

TEXT_SOURCE: That made me really upset.
VETA: To ma poriadne naštvalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: How could I thank God for this horrible, painful experience?
VETA: Ako by som mohol poďakovať Bohu za túto hroznú, bolestivú skúsenosť?

TEXT_SOURCE: I couldn’t.
VETA: nemohol som.

TEXT_SOURCE: And I couldn’t stop thinking that somehow God was punishing me, even though I couldn’t understand why.
VETA: A nemohol som prestať myslieť na to, že ma Boh nejako trestá, aj keď som nechápal prečo.

TEXT_SOURCE: Our pastor consoled me: God is a God of love, not of punishment, and he is there to ease our pain.
VETA: Náš pastor ma utešoval: Boh je Bohom lásky, nie trestu, a je tu, aby zmiernil našu bolesť.

TEXT_SOURCE: I grasped at his words as a drowning person grabs onto a pole held out from the shore.
VETA: Zachytil som jeho slová, keď sa topiaci chytil tyče natiahnutej z brehu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Neil’s loving support seemed like a visible sign of this love, and we discovered that our pain united us in a new way.
VETA: Neilova láskavá podpora sa zdala byť viditeľným znakom tejto lásky a my sme zistili, že naša bolesť nás spojila novým spôsobom.

TEXT_SOURCE: The words Weeping shall endure for the night, but joy comes in the morning especially comforted me, even when I couldn’t feel that joy coming, when it seemed that dawn would never break.
VETA: Slová Plač vydrží celú noc, ale radosť príde ráno ma obzvlášť utešovali, aj keď som necítila prichádzajúcu radosť, keď sa zdalo, že úsvit nikdy nezačne.

TEXT_SOURCE: Slowly, with time and with the loving help of those around me, I was able to feel that this deeply painful experience had given me an inkling of the love of God, who cares about the suffering of people and who was, I am convinced, right there beside me in my pain.
VETA: Pomaly, časom a s láskavou pomocou ľudí okolo mňa som mohol cítiť, že táto hlboko bolestivá skúsenosť mi dala tušenie lásky Boha, ktorému záleží na utrpení ľudí a ktorý bol, som presvedčený, hneď vedľa mňa v mojej bolesti.

TEXT_SOURCE: God became more real to me, and I began to trust his love.
VETA: Boh sa pre mňa stal skutočnejším a ja som začala dôverovať jeho láske.

TEXT_SOURCE: But then, some months later, when I was expecting another baby and hoping fervently that all would go well, the same thing happened again.
VETA: Ale potom, o niekoľko mesiacov neskôr, keď som čakala ďalšie bábätko a vrúcne dúfala, že všetko dobre dopadne, sa to isté zopakovalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: Severe pain, an emergency trip to the hospital, and an operation to save my life.
VETA: Silná bolesť, núdzová cesta do nemocnice a operácia, ktorá mi zachránila život.

TEXT_SOURCE: Again another precious little person lost just after it had come into being.
VETA: Opäť ďalší vzácny malý človiečik stratený tesne po tom, čo vznikol.

TEXT_SOURCE: Deep pain tore my heart apart.
VETA: Hlboká bolesť mi roztrhala srdce.

TEXT_SOURCE: I wrote in my diary: I cannot see why; perhaps I never will.
VETA: Do denníka som si napísal: Nechápem prečo, možno nikdy nebudem.

TEXT_SOURCE: I need the assurance of faith – Help me!
VETA: Potrebujem istotu viery – pomôž mi!

TEXT_SOURCE: Neil stood faithfully beside me.
VETA: Neil stál verne vedľa mňa.

TEXT_SOURCE: He had lost a sister to cancer some years before, and what he had written then was a great source of sustenance: We are separated from God only in physical distance, and that distance is perhaps not great.
VETA: Pred niekoľkými rokmi stratil sestru na rakovinu a to, čo vtedy napísal, bolo veľkým zdrojom obživy: Od Boha sme oddelení iba vo fyzickej vzdialenosti a tá vzdialenosť možno nie je veľká.

TEXT_SOURCE: I hung on to that with all my strength.
VETA: Držal som sa toho zo všetkých síl.

TEXT_SOURCE: Slowly, over weeks and months, the pain of loss lessened, although it has never departed entirely.
VETA: Pomaly, v priebehu týždňov a mesiacov, sa bolesť zo straty zmenšovala, hoci nikdy úplne neodišla.

TEXT_SOURCE: About a year later I again lost an unborn child.
VETA: Asi po roku som opäť prišiel o nenarodené dieťa.

TEXT_SOURCE: Once more there was deep pain in my heart, but this time no desperation over why.
VETA: V mojom srdci bola opäť hlboká bolesť, ale tentoraz žiadne zúfalstvo z toho, prečo.

TEXT_SOURCE: Today Andrea is the mother of a beautiful six-year-old daughter.
VETA: Dnes je Andrea mamou krásnej šesťročnej dcérky.

TEXT_SOURCE: Although thinking about her first three pregnancies always brings back a flood of emotions, she is not bitter.
VETA: Hoci pri pomyslení na prvé tri tehotenstvá sa jej vždy vráti záplava emócií, nezatrpkne.

TEXT_SOURCE: In fact, she is even able to point to two good fruits of her anguish: a greater love for her husband, who went to hell and back with me,  and endless gratitude for her only child.
VETA: Dokonca dokáže poukázať na dva dobré plody svojho trápenia: väčšiu lásku k manželovi, ktorý išiel so mnou do pekla a späť a nekonečnú vďačnosť za svoje jediné dieťa.

TEXT_SOURCE: Like Andrea, Jon and Gretchen Rhoads – a young couple in a nearby community – eagerly awaited the birth of their first child.
VETA: Rovnako ako Andrea, aj Jon a Gretchen Rhoads – mladý pár z neďalekej komunity – netrpezlivo očakávali narodenie svojho prvého dieťaťa.

TEXT_SOURCE: Alan was born after a seemingly normal pregnancy, and in the beginning everything seemed all right.
VETA: Alan sa narodil po zdanlivo normálnom tehotenstve a na začiatku sa zdalo všetko v poriadku.

TEXT_SOURCE: After he was discharged from the hospital, though, his parents noticed something was wrong.
VETA: Keď ho prepustili z nemocnice, jeho rodičia si všimli, že niečo nie je v poriadku.

TEXT_SOURCE: Very wrong.
VETA: Veľmi nesprávne.

TEXT_SOURCE: Alan didn’t eat well.
VETA: Alan nejedol dobre.

TEXT_SOURCE: His muscle tone was poor.
VETA: Jeho svalový tonus bol slabý.

TEXT_SOURCE: He lay very still, almost without moving, and when he breathed, he occasionally made strange gurgling sounds.
VETA: Ležal veľmi nehybne, takmer bez pohybu, a keď dýchal, občas vydával zvláštne bublavé zvuky.

TEXT_SOURCE: Alan was quickly admitted to a nearby university hospital, but he was three months old before his problems became clear: he would probably never walk or talk; he was blind; and he had significant abnormalities of the hips, brain, ears, and stomach.
VETA: Alan bol rýchlo prijatý do neďalekej univerzitnej nemocnice, ale mal tri mesiace, kým sa jeho problémy nevyjasnili: pravdepodobne nikdy nebude chodiť ani rozprávať; bol slepý; a mal výrazné abnormality bedier, mozgu, uší a žalúdka.

TEXT_SOURCE: Jon and Gretchen were devastated.
VETA: Jon a Gretchen boli zničení.

TEXT_SOURCE: They had long suspected that something was wrong, but they hadn’t expected it to be this bad.
VETA: Už dlho tušili, že niečo nie je v poriadku, ale nečakali, že to bude také zlé.

TEXT_SOURCE: Right away they began to accuse themselves, and it wasn’t long before they began to accuse God: Why us?
VETA: Hneď sa začali obviňovať a netrvalo dlho a začali obviňovať Boha: Prečo my?

TEXT_SOURCE: Jon says that though he was angry, he could never real--ly say at whom.
VETA: Jon hovorí, že aj keď bol nahnevaný, nikdy nedokázal povedať na koho.

TEXT_SOURCE: Himself?
VETA: Sám seba?

TEXT_SOURCE: Gretchen?
VETA: Gretchen?

TEXT_SOURCE: Alan’s doctors?
VETA: Alanovi lekári?

TEXT_SOURCE: God?
VETA: Boh?

TEXT_SOURCE: Yes, perhaps God, but he couldn’t explain why.
VETA: Áno, možno Boh, ale nevedel vysvetliť prečo.

TEXT_SOURCE: Still, he refused to become bitter, but concluded instead that either God does not love us, or this is just how Alan is meant to be.
VETA: Napriek tomu odmietol byť zatrpknutý, ale namiesto toho dospel k záveru, že buď nás Boh nemiluje, alebo taký má byť Alan.

TEXT_SOURCE: We may never know why, but if we are resentful about Alan’s condition, we will kill any joy we have had in him.
VETA: Možno sa nikdy nedozvieme prečo, ale ak budeme naštvaní na Alanov stav, zabijeme akúkoľvek radosť, ktorú sme v ňom mali.

TEXT_SOURCE: Both Jon and Gretchen admit that acceptance is easier to talk about, than to actually practice.
VETA: Jon aj Gretchen pripúšťajú, že o prijatí je ľahšie hovoriť, ako skutočne praktizovať.

TEXT_SOURCE: There have been plenty of times when they wanted to run away from it all, when they simply couldn’t face another visitor offering meaningless words of sympathy.
VETA: Veľakrát chceli pred tým všetkým utiecť, keď jednoducho nedokázali čeliť inému návštevníkovi, ktorý ponúkal nezmyselné slová súcitu.

TEXT_SOURCE: And while some days bring progress and new hope, others bring setbacks and trials.
VETA: A kým niektoré dni prinášajú pokrok a novú nádej, iné prinášajú neúspechy a skúšky.

TEXT_SOURCE: In his first year alone Alan had a tracheotomy and numerous other surgeries, including an appendectomy.
VETA: Len v prvom roku absolvoval Alan tracheotómiu a množstvo ďalších operácií, vrátane apendektómie.

TEXT_SOURCE: How much more suffering will he have to endure?
VETA: Koľko utrpenia ešte bude musieť znášať?

TEXT_SOURCE: In a world quick to offer early diagnosis and abortion as the answer to imperfect babies, Alan’s parents refuse to see their child as a burden.
VETA: Vo svete, ktorý rýchlo ponúka včasnú diagnózu a interrupciu ako odpoveď na nedokonalé deti, Alanovi rodičia odmietajú vnímať svoje dieťa ako bremeno.

TEXT_SOURCE: He has a great deal to tell us, Gretchen wrote when he was almost one, and we are not about to let him go.
VETA: Má nám toho veľa čo povedať, napísala Gretchen, keď mal takmer jeden rok, a my ho nepustíme.

TEXT_SOURCE: His small hand reaches up through a tangle of wires to find my cheek.
VETA: Jeho malá ruka sa natiahne cez spleť drôtov, aby našla moje líce.

TEXT_SOURCE: As I stoop to lift him from his bed, his eyelids lift slightly and he gives me a sleepy grin…
VETA: Keď sa zohnem, aby som ho zdvihol z postele, jeho očné viečka sa mierne zdvihli a on mi venoval ospalý úsmev...

TEXT_SOURCE: In the eleven months since his birth, Alan has been hospitalized five times; we have long since stopped counting the outpatient appointments.
VETA: Za jedenásť mesiacov od narodenia bol Alan päťkrát hospitalizovaný; ambulantne sme uz davno prestali pocitat.

TEXT_SOURCE: Each time we come home with more questions and fewer answers; more tears, and less certainty.
VETA: Zakaždým, keď prídeme domov s viacerými otázkami a menším počtom odpovedí; viac sĺz a menej istoty.

TEXT_SOURCE: But as he snuggles against me and looks around curiously, he grins.
VETA: Ale keď sa ku mne túli a zvedavo sa obzerá okolo seba, uškrnie sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: His smile is a balm to my heart.
VETA: Jeho úsmev je balzamom na moje srdce.

TEXT_SOURCE: How much more pain can Alan bear?
VETA: Koľko bolesti ešte znesie Alan?

TEXT_SOURCE: What new hurdles await us?
VETA: Aké nové prekážky nás čakajú?

TEXT_SOURCE: His tracheostomy has taken away the few small adventures we had looked forward to: bottles and the chance to explore solid food.
VETA: Jeho tracheostómia nám vzala niekoľko malých dobrodružstiev, na ktoré sme sa tešili: fľaše a možnosť preskúmať pevné jedlo.

TEXT_SOURCE: No more gurgles of joy, either, and no more cries of frustration.
VETA: Už žiadne buchotanie radosti a žiadne výkriky frustrácie.

TEXT_SOURCE: If he lives, the doctor tells us, he may outgrow the need for these tubes.
VETA: Ak žije, povedal nám lekár, môže prerásť potrebu týchto hadičiek.

TEXT_SOURCE: If he lives.
VETA: Ak žije.

TEXT_SOURCE: He is teaching me acceptance every day.
VETA: Každý deň ma učí akceptovať.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the end, it is this acceptance Gretchen writes of that allows us to forgive God.
VETA: Nakoniec, práve toto prijatie, o ktorom Gretchen píše, nám umožňuje odpustiť Bohu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Without it, we are left rebelling against our lot in life, and fighting every cross we feel unjustly forced to bear.
VETA: Bez nej sme ponechaní v búrení sa proti nášmu životnému údelu a bojujeme s každým krížom, ktorý sa cítime nespravodlivo nútení niesť.

TEXT_SOURCE: With it, we gain the ability to see our hardships in relation to the suffering of others, and strength to carry them.
VETA: S ním získavame schopnosť vidieť svoje ťažkosti vo vzťahu k utrpeniu iných a silu ich niesť.

TEXT_SOURCE: Forgiving Ourselves
VETA: Odpúšťať sami sebe

TEXT_SOURCE: Without being forgiven, released from the consequences of what we have done, our capacity to act would, as it were, be confined to a single deed from which we could never recover; we would remain the victims of its consequences forever, not unlike the sorcerer’s apprentice who lacked the magic formula to break the spell.
VETA: Bez odpustenia, oslobodenia od dôsledkov toho, čo sme urobili, by sa naša schopnosť konať takpovediac obmedzila na jediný skutok, z ktorého by sme sa nikdy nemohli zotaviť; navždy zostaneme obeťami jeho následkov, nie na rozdiel od čarodejníckeho učňa, ktorému chýbala magická formulka na prelomenie kúzla.

TEXT_SOURCE: When we assure a person who has hurt us that we no longer hold anything against him, all he has to do is accept our kindness – at least that is what we might hope.
VETA: Keď ubezpečíme človeka, ktorý nám ublížil, že mu už nič nedržíme, stačí, aby prijal našu láskavosť – aspoň v to môžeme dúfať.

TEXT_SOURCE: But that is often more easily said than done.
VETA: Ale to sa často ľahšie povie, ako urobí.

TEXT_SOURCE: For many people, the problem of guilt cannot be solved with another’s forgiveness, or by any external means at all.
VETA: Pre mnohých ľudí sa problém viny nedá vyriešiť odpustením iného alebo vôbec žiadnymi vonkajšími prostriedkami.

TEXT_SOURCE: For them, peace of mind comes only when they are able to forgive themselves.
VETA: Pre nich pokoj nastáva až vtedy, keď sú schopní odpustiť sami sebe.

TEXT_SOURCE: I first met Delf Fransham in 1953.
VETA: Prvýkrát som sa stretol s Delfom Franshamom v roku 1953.

TEXT_SOURCE: That was the year he moved from the United States to the remote South American village where I grew up and began to teach at the local school.
VETA: V tom roku sa presťahoval zo Spojených štátov do odľahlej juhoamerickej dediny, kde som vyrastal a začal som učiť na miestnej škole.

TEXT_SOURCE: There were eleven of us in his class, all boys, and all ruffians, and a few days into his first term we decided to put him to the test.
VETA: V jeho triede nás bolo jedenásť, všetci chlapci a všetci darebáci, a pár dní pred jeho prvým funkčným obdobím sme sa rozhodli ho otestovať.

TEXT_SOURCE: One typical Paraguayan morning (humid and around 110 degrees), we offered to take him on a hike.
VETA: V jedno typické paraguajské ráno (vlhké a okolo 110 stupňov) sme mu ponúkli, že ho vezmeme na túru.

TEXT_SOURCE: Officially, we wanted to show him the sights.
VETA: Oficiálne sme mu chceli ukázať pamiatky.

TEXT_SOURCE: Privately, we wanted to see what he was made of.
VETA: Súkromne sme chceli vidieť, z čoho je vyrobený.

TEXT_SOURCE: After leading him at least ten kilometers through jungle, prairie, and swampland, we finally turned back.
VETA: Potom, čo sme ho viedli aspoň desať kilometrov cez džungľu, prériu a močiare, sme sa konečne otočili späť.

TEXT_SOURCE: Shortly after we arrived home he collapsed with heat stroke.
VETA: Krátko po našom príchode domov skolaboval úpalom.

TEXT_SOURCE: Delf was in bed for days, but we hardly gave it a thought.
VETA: Delf bola v posteli celé dni, ale my sme na to sotva pomysleli.

TEXT_SOURCE: We had achieved exactly what we wanted – proved him a sissy.
VETA: Dosiahli sme presne to, čo sme chceli – dokázali sme, že je sissy.

TEXT_SOURCE: But we were in for a small surprise.
VETA: Čakalo nás však malé prekvapenie.

TEXT_SOURCE: The day he came back to school he said, Boys, let’s try that hike again.
VETA: V deň, keď sa vrátil do školy, povedal: Chlapci, skúsme tú túru znova.

TEXT_SOURCE: We couldn’t believe it!
VETA: Nemohli sme tomu uveriť!

TEXT_SOURCE: We covered the same route again and, sure enough, this time he did not succumb to the heat.
VETA: Znova sme prešli tú istú trasu a veru, tentoraz horúčavám nepodľahol.

TEXT_SOURCE: Delf won our respect and our hearts that day, and we trusted him from then on.
VETA: Delf si v ten deň získal náš rešpekt a naše srdcia a odvtedy sme mu verili.

TEXT_SOURCE: (There was something else to it, too: a talented athlete, he taught us soccer and loved to play with us. )
VETA: (Bolo v tom aj niečo iné: talentovaný športovec, učil nás futbal a rád s nami hrával.)

TEXT_SOURCE: Decades later, and only by chance, I found out why Delf had poured so much love and energy into reaching his students.
VETA: O niekoľko desaťročí neskôr a len náhodou som zistil, prečo Delf vložil toľko lásky a energie, aby oslovil svojich študentov.

TEXT_SOURCE: He had lost a child of his own.
VETA: Stratil vlastné dieťa.

TEXT_SOURCE: Nicholas was born when the Franshams were still living in the United States, and one day as Delf was backing a truckload of firewood into their driveway, two-year-old Nicholas, who was playing outdoors, ran to meet his father.
VETA: Nicholas sa narodil, keď Franshamovci ešte žili v Spojených štátoch, a jedného dňa, keď Delf cúval nákladom palivového dreva na ich príjazdovú cestu, dvojročný Nicholas, ktorý sa hral vonku, bežal v ústrety svojmu otcovi.

TEXT_SOURCE: Delf did not see him until it was too late, and ran over him.
VETA: Delf ho uvidel, až keď bolo neskoro, a prešiel cez neho.

TEXT_SOURCE: Katie, Delf’s wife, was busy inside the house when he carried in their little boy, limp in his arms.
VETA: Katie, Delfova manželka, bola zaneprázdnená v dome, keď niesol ich malého chlapca bezvládneho v náručí.

TEXT_SOURCE: She remembers: I was beside myself – absolutely frantic – but Delf steadied me.
VETA: Pamätá si: Bola som bez seba – úplne šialená – ale Delf ma upokojil.

TEXT_SOURCE: We took Nicholas to our doctor, who was also the coroner, and explained what had happened…
VETA: Zobrali sme Nicholasa k nášmu lekárovi, ktorý bol tiež koronerom, a vysvetlili sme, čo sa stalo…

TEXT_SOURCE: There was never any question about forgiving my husband, as I knew I was just as much to blame.
VETA: Nikdy nebola žiadna otázka o odpustení môjmu manželovi, pretože som vedela, že za to môžem aj ja.

TEXT_SOURCE: Likewise he did not blame me, only himself.
VETA: Rovnako nevinil mňa, iba seba.

TEXT_SOURCE: We stood in our sorrow together.
VETA: Spolu sme stáli v našom smútku.

TEXT_SOURCE: Delf, however, could not forgive himself, and the accident haunted him for years.
VETA: Delf si to však nemohol odpustiť a nehoda ho prenasledovala roky.

TEXT_SOURCE: From then on, he went out of his way to make time for children – time he could not spend with the son he had killed.
VETA: Odvtedy sa snažil nájsť si čas na deti – čas, ktorý nemohol stráviť so synom, ktorého zabil.

TEXT_SOURCE: Looking back, I remember how his eyes often glistened with tears, and wonder what it was that made them come.
VETA: Keď sa obzriem späť, pamätám si, ako sa mu oči často leskli slzami, a rozmýšľam, čo ich prinútilo prísť.

TEXT_SOURCE: Was it that he saw his son in us?
VETA: Žeby v nás videl svojho syna?

TEXT_SOURCE: Was he imagining the boy his toddler would never become?
VETA: Predstavoval si chlapca, ktorým sa jeho batoľa nikdy nestane?

TEXT_SOURCE: Whatever the reason, it seems that Delf’s determination to show love to others was his way of making up for the anguish he had caused himself and his family by unintentionally taking a life.
VETA: Nech už je dôvod akýkoľvek, zdá sa, že Delfovo odhodlanie prejaviť lásku druhým bol jeho spôsob, ako nahradiť utrpenie, ktoré spôsobil sebe a svojej rodine tým, že neúmyselne pripravil o život.

TEXT_SOURCE: John Plummer lives the quiet life of a Methodist pastor in a sleepy Virginia town these days, but things weren’t always so.
VETA: John Plummer žije v týchto dňoch tichým životom metodistického pastora v ospalom meste Virginia, no nie vždy to tak bolo.

TEXT_SOURCE: A helicopter pilot during the Vietnam War, he helped organize a napalm raid on the village of Trang Bang in 1972 – a bombing immortalized by the prize-winning photograph of one of its victims, Phan Thi Kim Phuc.
VETA: Pilot helikoptéry počas vojny vo Vietname pomohol zorganizovať napalmový nálet na dedinu Trang Bang v roku 1972 – bombový útok zvečnený ocenenou fotografiou jednej z jeho obetí, Phan Thi Kim Phuc.

TEXT_SOURCE: For the next twenty-four years, John was haunted by the photograph – an image that for many people captured the essence of the war: a naked and burned nine-year-old running toward the camera, with plumes of black smoke billowing in the sky behind her.
VETA: Ďalších dvadsaťštyri rokov Johna prenasledovala fotografia – obraz, ktorý pre mnohých ľudí vystihol podstatu vojny: nahé a popálené deväťročné dieťa, ktoré beží k fotoaparátu, s obláčikmi čierneho dymu. obloha za ňou.

TEXT_SOURCE: For twenty-four years John’s conscience tormented him.
VETA: Dvadsaťštyri rokov ho trápilo Johnovo svedomie.

TEXT_SOURCE: He badly wanted to find the girl to tell her that he was sorry – but he could not.
VETA: Veľmi chcel nájsť dievča, aby jej povedal, že ho to mrzí – ale nemohol.

TEXT_SOURCE: Turning in on himself, he grew more and more depressed (the collapse of two marriages didn’t help), and he began to drink.
VETA: Keď sa obrátil na seba, bol čoraz viac deprimovaný (krach dvoch manželstiev nepomohol) a začal piť.

TEXT_SOURCE: Then, in an almost unbelievable coincidence, John met Kim during an event at the Vietnam War Memorial on Veterans Day, 1996.
VETA: Potom, takmer neuveriteľnou zhodou okolností, sa John stretol s Kim počas udalosti vo Vietnamskom vojnovom pamätníku na Deň veteránov v roku 1996.

TEXT_SOURCE: Kim had come to Washington, D. C. , to lay a wreath for peace; John had come with a group of former pilots unable to come to terms with their shared past, but determined to stick together anyway.
VETA: Kim prišla do Washingtonu, D. C., položiť veniec za mier; John prišiel so skupinou bývalých pilotov, ktorí sa nedokázali vyrovnať so spoločnou minulosťou, no napriek tomu boli odhodlaní držať spolu.

TEXT_SOURCE: In a speech to the crowd, Kim introduced herself as the girl in the famous photograph.
VETA: Kim sa v prejave k davu predstavila ako dievča na slávnej fotografii.

TEXT_SOURCE: She still suffered immensely from her burns, she said, but she was not bitter, and she wanted people to know that others had suffered even more than she had: Behind that picture of me, thousands and thousands of people…died.
VETA: Stále veľmi trpela popáleninami, povedala, ale nebola zatrpknutá a chcela, aby ľudia vedeli, že iní trpeli ešte viac ako ona: Za týmto mojím obrazom zomreli tisíce a tisíce ľudí.

TEXT_SOURCE: They lost parts of their bodies.
VETA: Prišli o časti tela.

TEXT_SOURCE: Their whole lives were destroyed, and nobody took their picture.
VETA: Celý ich život bol zničený a nikto ich neodfotil.

TEXT_SOURCE: Kim went on to say that although she could not change the past, she had forgiven the men who had bombed her village, and that she felt a calling to promote peace by fostering goodwill between America and Vietnam.
VETA: Kim ďalej povedala, že hoci nemohla zmeniť minulosť, odpustila mužom, ktorí bombardovali jej dedinu, a že cíti volanie podporovať mier podporovaním dobrej vôle medzi Amerikou a Vietnamom.

TEXT_SOURCE: John, beside himself, pushed through the crowds and managed to catch her attention before she was whisked away by a police escort.
VETA: John sa bez seba predieral davmi a podarilo sa mu upútať jej pozornosť skôr, ako ju odviedol policajný sprievod.

TEXT_SOURCE: He identified himself as a former pilot in Vietnam and said that he felt responsible for the bombing of her village twenty-four years before.
VETA: Identifikoval sa ako bývalý pilot vo Vietname a povedal, že sa cítil zodpovedný za bombardovanie jej dediny pred dvadsiatimi štyrmi rokmi.

TEXT_SOURCE: He says: Kim saw my grief, my pain, my sorrow…
VETA: Hovorí: Kim videla môj smútok, moju bolesť, môj smútok...

TEXT_SOURCE: She held out her arms to me and embraced me.
VETA: Natiahla ku mne ruky a objala ma.

TEXT_SOURCE: All I could say was I’m sorry; I’m sorry – over and over again.
VETA: Jediné, čo som mohol povedať, bolo Je mi to ľúto, je mi to ľúto – znova a znova.

TEXT_SOURCE: And at the same time she was saying, It’s all right, I forgive you.
VETA: A zároveň povedala: To je v poriadku, odpúšťam ti.

TEXT_SOURCE: John says that it was vital for him to meet face to face with Kim, and to tell her that he had agonized for years over her injuries.
VETA: John hovorí, že pre neho bolo životne dôležité stretnúť sa tvárou v tvár s Kim a povedať jej, že sa roky trápil kvôli jej zraneniam.

TEXT_SOURCE: Without having had the chance to get that off his chest, he is not sure he could have ever forgiven himself.
VETA: Bez toho, aby mal možnosť dostať to zo svojej hrude, si nie je istý, či by si niekedy mohol odpustiť.

TEXT_SOURCE: As it turned out, of course, he got even more than he hoped for: Kim forgave him.
VETA: Ako sa samozrejme ukázalo, dostal ešte viac, ako dúfal: Kim mu odpustila.

TEXT_SOURCE: Reflecting on the way the incident changed his life, John maintains that forgiveness is neither earned nor even deserved, but a gift.
VETA: John sa zamýšľa nad tým, ako mu incident zmenil život, a tvrdí, že odpustenie nie je ani zaslúžené, ani zaslúžené, ale dar.

TEXT_SOURCE: It is also a mystery.
VETA: To je tiež záhada.

TEXT_SOURCE: He still can’t quite grasp how a short conversation could wipe away a twenty-four-year nightmare.
VETA: Stále nemôže celkom pochopiť, ako môže krátky rozhovor vymazať dvadsaťštyriročnú nočnú moru.

TEXT_SOURCE: Pat, another Vietnam veteran, is a gentle, quiet man who loves children and horses.
VETA: Pat, ďalší veterán z Vietnamu, je jemný, tichý muž, ktorý miluje deti a kone.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the seven years since I first met him, however, I have become aware that he has a darker side – one that centers on his inability to forgive himself: Death is on my mind a lot.
VETA: Za tých sedem rokov, čo som sa s ním prvýkrát stretol, som si však uvedomil, že má aj temnejšiu stránku – tú, ktorá sa sústreďuje na jeho neschopnosť odpustiť si: Smrť mám na mysli.

TEXT_SOURCE: The deaths I have caused – and wanting my own death – are with me every day.
VETA: Úmrtia, ktoré som spôsobil – a túžiace po vlastnej smrti – sú so mnou každý deň.

TEXT_SOURCE: I joke around a lot with the people I work with.
VETA: Veľa žartujem s ľuďmi, s ktorými pracujem.

TEXT_SOURCE: I have to, to hide the pain and to keep my mind from thinking.
VETA: Musím, aby som skryl bolesť a aby moja myseľ nemyslela.

TEXT_SOURCE: I need to laugh. Laughing keeps the blues away.
VETA: Potrebujem sa smiať. Smiech drží blues preč.

TEXT_SOURCE: But I cannot love.
VETA: Ale nemôžem milovať.

TEXT_SOURCE: Part of my soul is missing, and it seems I won’t ever get it back.
VETA: Časť mojej duše chýba a zdá sa, že ju už nikdy nezískam späť.

TEXT_SOURCE: I don’t know if I can ever forgive myself for all of my wrongs.
VETA: Neviem, či si niekedy dokážem odpustiť všetky moje krivdy.

TEXT_SOURCE: I live day to day, but I am tired all the time – tired.
VETA: Žijem zo dňa na deň, ale stále som unavený – unavený.

TEXT_SOURCE: Will it ever end?
VETA: Skončí sa to niekedy?

TEXT_SOURCE: I don’t see how.
VETA: nechápem ako.

TEXT_SOURCE: It’s been with me over twenty-five years now.
VETA: Je to so mnou už viac ako dvadsaťpäť rokov.

TEXT_SOURCE: People like Pat are often urged to receive formal counseling, to join a support group, or to attend group therapy meetings so as to compare notes with others who have had similar experiences.
VETA: Ľudia ako Pat sú často vyzývaní, aby dostali formálne poradenstvo, aby sa pripojili k podpornej skupine alebo sa zúčastnili na skupinových terapeutických stretnutiach, aby si mohli porovnať poznámky s ostatnými, ktorí mali podobné skúsenosti.

TEXT_SOURCE: He has done all of this, and still not found peace.
VETA: Toto všetko urobil a stále nenašiel pokoj.

TEXT_SOURCE: Perhaps, like John, he wishes he could meet the families of those he killed – an unlikely opportunity – or bring the victims themselves back to life so he could ask their forgiveness – an obviously impossible one.
VETA: Možno si rovnako ako John želá, aby sa mohol stretnúť s rodinami tých, ktorých zabil – čo je nepravdepodobná príležitosť – alebo priviesť obete späť k životu, aby ich mohol požiadať o odpustenie – čo je zjavne nemožné.

TEXT_SOURCE: So what should he do?
VETA: Čo by teda mal robiť?

TEXT_SOURCE: A conversation Robert Coles once had with the psychoanalyst Anna Freud may hint at an answer.
VETA: Rozhovor, ktorý kedysi viedol Robert Coles s psychoanalytkou Annou Freud, môže naznačovať odpoveď.

TEXT_SOURCE: Discussing an elderly client with a long and troubled psychological history, Freud suddenly concluded: You know, before we say good-bye to this lady, we should wonder among ourselves not only what to think – we do that all the time! – but what in the world we would want for her.
VETA: Pri diskusii o staršom klientovi s dlhou a problematickou psychologickou históriou Freud náhle uzavrel: Viete, skôr ako sa s touto dámou rozlúčime, mali by sme sa medzi sebou zamyslieť nielen nad tým, čo si máme myslieť – robíme to stále! – ale čo by sme pre ňu chceli.

TEXT_SOURCE: Oh, I don’t mean psychotherapy; she’s had lots of that.
VETA: Ach, nemám na mysli psychoterapiu; mala toho veľa.

TEXT_SOURCE: It would take more years, I suspect, of psychoanalysis than the good Lord has given her…
VETA: Domnievam sa, že psychoanalýza by trvala viac rokov, ako jej dal dobrý Pán...

TEXT_SOURCE: No, she’s had her fill of us,  even if she doesn’t know it…
VETA: Nie, má nás dosýta, aj keď o tom nevie...

TEXT_SOURCE: This poor old lady doesn’t need us at all…
VETA: Táto úbohá stará dáma nás vôbec nepotrebuje...

TEXT_SOURCE: What she needs…is forgiveness.
VETA: To, čo potrebuje... je odpustenie.

TEXT_SOURCE: She needs to make peace with her soul, not talk about her mind.
VETA: Potrebuje sa zmieriť so svojou dušou, nie rozprávať o svojej mysli.

TEXT_SOURCE: There must be a God, somewhere, to help her, to hear her, to heal her…and we certainly aren’t the ones who will be of assistance to her in that regard!
VETA: Niekde musí byť Boh, ktorý jej pomôže, vypočuje ju, uzdraví... a my určite nie sme tí, ktorí jej budú v tomto smere nápomocní!

TEXT_SOURCE: All of us yearn for the freedom to live without guilt.
VETA: Všetci túžime po slobode žiť bez viny.

TEXT_SOURCE: At some level, every one of us longs for forgiveness.
VETA: Na určitej úrovni každý z nás túži po odpustení.

TEXT_SOURCE: Yet when all is said and done, we cannot acquire it.
VETA: Keď je však všetko povedané a urobené, nemôžeme to získať.

TEXT_SOURCE: Sometimes the person we have wronged is unable or unwilling to forgive us.
VETA: Niekedy nám človek, ktorému sme ublížili, nie je schopný alebo ochotný odpustiť.

TEXT_SOURCE: Sometimes we are unable or unwilling to forgive ourselves.
VETA: Niekedy nie sme schopní alebo ochotní odpustiť sami sebe.

TEXT_SOURCE: Even the best psychoanalysis, the most earnest confession of guilt, may not be enough to assure us of lasting relief or healing.
VETA: Ani tá najlepšia psychoanalýza, najvážnejšie priznanie viny nemusí stačiť na to, aby nás uistila o trvalej úľave alebo uzdravení.

TEXT_SOURCE: But the power of forgiveness still exists, and as John Plummer found out, it can work wonders even when we are sure that we have neither earned nor deserved it.
VETA: Ale sila odpustenia stále existuje a ako zistil John Plummer, dokáže zázraky, aj keď sme si istí, že sme si to ani nezaslúžili, ani nezaslúžili.

TEXT_SOURCE: It comes to us as a gift, often when we feel least worthy of receiving it.
VETA: Prichádza k nám ako dar, často vtedy, keď sa cítime najmenej hodní ho prijať.

TEXT_SOURCE: Finally, like any gift, it can be accepted or rejected.
VETA: Nakoniec, ako každý dar, môže byť prijatý alebo odmietnutý.

TEXT_SOURCE: What we do with it is up to us.
VETA: Čo s tým urobíme, je len na nás.

TEXT_SOURCE: Every time the happily married woman went away she wondered how it would feel to sleep with another man.
VETA: Zakaždým, keď šťastne vydatá žena odchádzala, premýšľala, aké by to bolo spať s iným mužom.

TEXT_SOURCE: That weekend she was determined to find out.
VETA: V ten víkend bola odhodlaná to zistiť.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was December; she felt a curtain closing on another year.
VETA: Bol december; cítila, ako sa zatvorila opona pred ďalším rokom.

TEXT_SOURCE: She wanted to do this before she got too old.
VETA: Chcela to urobiť skôr, než bude príliš stará.

TEXT_SOURCE: On Friday evening, she took the train into the city, sat reading in a first-class carriage.
VETA: V piatok večer sa vybrala vlakom do mesta a čítala si vo vozni prvej triedy.

TEXT_SOURCE: The crime novel didn’t hold her interest; she could already predict the ending.
VETA: Kriminálny román ju nezaujal; už vedela predvídať koniec.

TEXT_SOURCE: She stared out beyond the window.
VETA: Hľadela von cez okno.

TEXT_SOURCE: She had left a dish of macaroni cheese out for the kids, brought her husbandas suits back from the cleaners.
VETA: Nechala pre deti misu s makarónovým syrom a priniesla manželove obleky z upratovačiek.

TEXT_SOURCE: She’d told him she was going shopping for Christmas.
VETA: Povedala mu, že ide nakupovať na Vianoce.

TEXT_SOURCE: When she reached the city she took a taxi to the hotel.
VETA: Keď prišla do mesta, vzala si taxík do hotela.

TEXT_SOURCE: They gave her a small, white room with a view of Vicar’s Close, one of the oldest streets in England, a row of stone houses with tall, granite chimneys where the clergy lived.
VETA: Dali jej malú bielu izbu s výhľadom na Vicar’s Close, jednu z najstarších ulíc v Anglicku, rad kamenných domov s vysokými žulovými komínmi, kde bývali duchovní.

TEXT_SOURCE: She sat at the hotel bar that night nursing a tequila and lime, but there was nothing doing.
VETA: V ten večer sedela v hotelovom bare a popíjala tequilu a limetku, ale nič sa nerobilo.

TEXT_SOURCE: Old men were reading newspapers, business was slow, but she didn’t mind; she needed a good night’s sleep.
VETA: Starí muži čítali noviny, obchod bol pomalý, ale jej to nevadilo; potrebovala sa dobre vyspať.

TEXT_SOURCE: She fell into her rented bed, into a dreamless sleep, and woke to the sound of bells ringing in the cathedral.
VETA: Padla do prenajatej postele, do bezsenného spánku a zobudila sa na zvuk zvonov zvoniacich v katedrále.

TEXT_SOURCE: On Saturday she walked to the shopping centre.
VETA: V sobotu išla pešo do nákupného centra.

TEXT_SOURCE: Families were out, pushing buggies through the morning crowd, a thick stream of people flowing through glass automatic doors.
VETA: Rodiny boli vonku, tlačili buginy ranným davom, hustý prúd ľudí tiekol cez sklenené automatické dvere.

TEXT_SOURCE: She bought unusual gifts for her children, things she thought they wouldn’t predict.
VETA: Svojim deťom kúpila nezvyčajné darčeky, veci, o ktorých si myslela, že nepredvídajú.

TEXT_SOURCE: She bought an electric razor for her eldest son – he was getting to that age – an atlas for the girl, and for her husband an expensive gold watch with a plain, white face.
VETA: Najstaršiemu synovi – už sa dostával do tohto veku – kúpila pre dievča atlas a manželovi drahé zlaté hodinky s obyčajným bielym ciferníkom.

TEXT_SOURCE: She dressed up in the afternoon, put on a short plum-coloured dress, high heels, her darkest lipstick, and walked back into town.
VETA: Poobede sa obliekla, obliekla si krátke šaty slivkovej farby, vysoké opätky, najtmavší rúž a vrátila sa do mesta.

TEXT_SOURCE: A jukebox song, The Ballad of Lucy Jordan, lured her into a pub, a converted prison with barred windows and a low, beamed ceiling.
VETA: Jukeboxová pieseň The Ballad of Lucy Jordan ju prilákala do krčmy, prerobeného väzenia so zamrežovanými oknami a nízkym trámovým stropom.

TEXT_SOURCE: On the next stool sat a guy in a leather jacket that looked like he should have given it to Oxfam years ago.
VETA: Na ďalšej stoličke sedel chlapík v koženej bunde, ktorá vyzerala, akoby ju mal dať Oxfamu pred rokmi.

TEXT_SOURCE: Hello, he said.
VETA: Dobrý deň, povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: Haven’t seen you before.
VETA: ešte som ťa nevidel.

TEXT_SOURCE: He had a red complexion, a gold chain dangling inside a Hawaiian print shirt, mud-coloured hair.
VETA: Mal červenú pleť, zlatú retiazku visiacu vo vnútri košele s havajskou potlačou a vlasy blatovej farby.

TEXT_SOURCE: His glass was almost empty.
VETA: Jeho pohár bol takmer prázdny.

TEXT_SOURCE: What’s that you’re drinking? she said.
VETA: čo to piješ? povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: He turned out to be a real talker, told her his life story, how he worked nights at the old folks’ home.
VETA: Ukázalo sa, že je skutočným rečníkom, porozprával jej svoj životný príbeh, ako po nociach pracoval v dome dôchodcov.

TEXT_SOURCE: There were no rings on his fingers.
VETA: Na prstoch nemal žiadne prstene.

TEXT_SOURCE: I’m the loneliest man in the world, he said.
VETA: Som ten najosamelejší muž na svete, povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: How about you?
VETA: A čo ty?

TEXT_SOURCE: I’m married.
VETA: Som vydatá.

TEXT_SOURCE: He laughed.
VETA: Smial sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: Play pool with me.
VETA: Zahrajte si so mnou biliard.

TEXT_SOURCE: I don’t know how.
VETA: neviem ako.

TEXT_SOURCE: Doesn’t matter, he said, I’ll teach you.
VETA: Nevadí, povedal, naučím ťa.

TEXT_SOURCE: You’ll be potting that black before you know it.
VETA: Zalejete to čierne skôr, ako sa nazdáte.

TEXT_SOURCE: He put coins into a slot and pulled something and a little landslide of balls knuckled down into a black hole under the table.
VETA: Vložil mince do štrbiny a niečo potiahol a malý zosuv loptičiek sa prevalil do čiernej diery pod stolom.

TEXT_SOURCE: Stripes and solids, he said, chalking up the cue.
VETA: Prúžky a pevné látky, povedal a nakreslil tágo.

TEXT_SOURCE: You’re one or the other.
VETA: Ste jedno alebo druhé.

TEXT_SOURCE: I’ll break.
VETA: zlomím sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: He taught her to lean down low and sight the ball, to watch the cue ball when she took the shot, but he didn’t let her win one game.
VETA: Naučil ju, aby sa naklonila nízko a videla loptičku, aby sledovala bielu guľu, keď strieľala, ale nedovolil jej vyhrať jednu hru.

TEXT_SOURCE: When she went into the ladies’ room, she was drunk.
VETA: Keď vošla do dámskej toalety, bola opitá.

TEXT_SOURCE: She leaned her forehead against the cool of the mirror.
VETA: Oprela si čelo o chladné zrkadlo.

TEXT_SOURCE: She couldn’t remember ever being drunk like this.
VETA: Nepamätala si, že by bola niekedy takto opitá.

TEXT_SOURCE: They finished off their drinks and went outside.
VETA: Dopili drinky a vyšli von.

TEXT_SOURCE: The air spiked her lungs.
VETA: Vzduch jej rozprúdil pľúca.

TEXT_SOURCE: Clouds smashed into each other in the sky.
VETA: Na oblohe do seba narážali oblaky.

TEXT_SOURCE: She hung her head back to look at them.
VETA: Sklonila hlavu dozadu, aby sa na nich pozrela.

TEXT_SOURCE: Let’s walk, he said.
VETA: Poďme sa prejsť, povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: I’ll give you the tour.
VETA: Dám vám prehliadku.

TEXT_SOURCE: She fell into step beside him, listened to his jacket creaking as he led her down a path where the moat curved round the cathedral.
VETA: Spadla vedľa neho a počúvala, ako mu vŕzga sako, keď ju viedol po ceste, kde sa priekopa krútila okolo katedrály.

TEXT_SOURCE: An old man stood outside the Bishop’s Palace selling stale bread for the birds.
VETA: Pred biskupským palácom stál starý muž a predával zatuchnutý chlieb pre vtáky.

TEXT_SOURCE: They bought some and stood at the water’s edge feeding five cygnets whose feathers were turning white.
VETA: Kúpili si nejaké a stáli na brehu vody a kŕmili päť cygnetov, ktorých perie belelo.

TEXT_SOURCE: Brown ducks flew across the water and landed in a nice skim on the moat.
VETA: Hnedé kačice preleteli po vode a pristáli v peknom klbku na vodnej priekope.

TEXT_SOURCE: When a black Labrador came bounding down the path, a huddle of pigeons rose as one and settled magically in the trees.
VETA: Keď po ceste pribehol čierny labrador, zhluk holubov sa zdvihol ako jeden a magicky sa usadil na stromoch.

TEXT_SOURCE: I feel like Francis of Assisi, she laughed.
VETA: Cítim sa ako František z Assisi, zasmiala sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: Rain began to fall; she felt it falling on her face like small electric shocks.
VETA: Začal padať dážď; cítila, ako jej dopadá na tvár ako malé elektrické výboje.

TEXT_SOURCE: They backtracked through the market-place where stalls were set up in the shelter of tarpaulin.
VETA: Vrátili sa cez trhovisko, kde boli v plachtovom prístrešku rozmiestnené stánky.

TEXT_SOURCE: They sold everything: smelly second-hand books and china dishes, big red poinsettias, holly wreaths, brass ornaments, fresh fish with dead eyes lying on a bed of ice.
VETA: Predávali všetko: páchnuce antikvariáty a porcelánové riady, veľké červené vianočné hviezdy, cezmínové vence, mosadzné ozdoby, čerstvé ryby s mŕtvymi očami ležiace na ľadovom lôžku.

TEXT_SOURCE: Come home with me, he said.
VETA: Poď so mnou domov, povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: I’ll cook for you.
VETA: navarím pre vás.

TEXT_SOURCE: You’ll cook for me?
VETA: navaríš mi?

TEXT_SOURCE: You eat fish?
VETA: Jete ryby?

TEXT_SOURCE: I eat everything, she said, and he seemed amused.
VETA: Jem všetko, povedala a zdalo sa, že ho to pobavilo.

TEXT_SOURCE: I know your type, he said.
VETA: Poznám tvoj typ, povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: You’re wild.
VETA: Si divoký.

TEXT_SOURCE: He chose a trout that looked like it was still alive.
VETA: Vybral si pstruha, ktorý vyzeral, že ešte žije.

TEXT_SOURCE: The fishmonger chopped its head off and wrapped it up in foil.
VETA: Rybár mu odsekol hlavu a zabalil ju do fólie.

TEXT_SOURCE: He bought a tub of black olives and a slab of feta cheese from the Italian woman with deli stall at the end.
VETA: Od Talianky si kúpil vaničku čiernych olív a plátok syra feta s lahôdkami na konci.

TEXT_SOURCE: Always, as they passed the stalls, he asked her if she wanted anything.
VETA: Vždy, keď prechádzali okolo stánkov, spýtal sa jej, či niečo nechce.

TEXT_SOURCE: He was free with his money, kept it crumpled in his pockets like old receipts, didn’t smooth the notes out even when he was handing them over.
VETA: So svojimi peniazmi bol slobodný, mal ich pokrčené vo vreckách ako staré účtenky, neuhladzoval bankovky, ani keď ich odovzdával.

TEXT_SOURCE: On the way home they stopped at the off-licence, bought two bottles of Chianti and a lottery ticket, all of which she insisted on paying for.
VETA: Cestou domov sa zastavili v predajni, kúpili si dve fľaše Chianti a žreb do lotérie, pričom ona trvala na zaplatení.

TEXT_SOURCE: We’ll split it if we win, she said.
VETA: Rozdelíme si to, ak vyhráme, povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: Don’t hold your breath, he said, and watched her walk through the door he’d opened for her.
VETA: Nezadržiavaj dych, povedal a sledoval, ako prechádza dverami, ktoré jej otvoril.

TEXT_SOURCE: They strolled down cobbled streets, past barber’s where a man was sitting with his head back, being shaved.
VETA: Prechádzali sa po dláždených uliciach, okolo holičstva, kde sedel muž so zaklonenou hlavou a bol oholený.

TEXT_SOURCE: The streets grew narrow and winding; they were outside the city lights now.
VETA: Ulice boli úzke a kľukaté; teraz boli mimo svetiel mesta.

TEXT_SOURCE: You live in suburbia? she asked.
VETA: Žiješ na predmestí? opýtala sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: He did not answer, kept walking.
VETA: Neodpovedal, kráčal ďalej.

TEXT_SOURCE: She could smell the fish.
VETA: Cítila rybu vôňu.

TEXT_SOURCE: When they came to a wrought-iron gate he told her to hang a left.
VETA: Keď prišli k bráne z tepaného železa, povedal jej, aby obesila ľavicu.

TEXT_SOURCE: They passed under an archway and came out in a dead end.
VETA: Prešli pod klenbou a vyšli v slepej uličke.

TEXT_SOURCE: He unlocked a door to a block of flats and followed her upstairs to the top floor.
VETA: Odomkol dvere na paneláku a nasledoval ju na poschodie na najvyššie poschodie.

TEXT_SOURCE: Keep going, he said when she stopped on the landings.
VETA: Pokračuj, povedal, keď zastavila na odpočívadle.

TEXT_SOURCE: She giggled and climbed, giggled and climbed again, stopped at the top.
VETA: Rehotala sa a stúpala, chichotala sa a znova stúpala, zastavila sa na vrchole.

TEXT_SOURCE: The door needed oil; the hinges creaked when he pushed it back.
VETA: Dvere potrebovali olej; pánty vŕzgali, keď ho zatlačil späť.

TEXT_SOURCE: The walls of his flat were plain and pale, the sills dusty.
VETA: Steny jeho bytu boli hladké a bledé, parapety zaprášené.

TEXT_SOURCE: One stained mug sat lonely in the sink.
VETA: Jeden zašpinený hrnček ležal osamotený v umývadle.

TEXT_SOURCE: A white Persian cat jumped off a couch in the living room.
VETA: Biela perzská mačka vyskočila z pohovky v obývačke.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was neglected, like a place where someone used to live; the rubber plant in the lounge crawled across the carpet towards a rectangular pool of streetlight under a high window.
VETA: Bolo to zanedbané, ako miesto, kde niekto býval; kaučukovník v salóniku sa plazil po koberci smerom k obdĺžnikovému bazénu pouličného osvetlenia pod vysokým oknom.

TEXT_SOURCE: Dank smells.
VETA: Vďaka vonia.

TEXT_SOURCE: A big cast-iron tub stood in the bathroom on blue, steel claws.
VETA: V kúpeľni stála na modrých oceľových pazúroch veľká liatinová vaňa.

TEXT_SOURCE: Some bath, she said.
VETA: Trochu kúpeľa, povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: You want a bath? he said.
VETA: Chceš sa kúpať? povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: Try it out.
VETA: Vyskúšaj to.

TEXT_SOURCE: Fill her up and dive in.
VETA: Naplňte ju a ponorte sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: Go ahead, be my guest.
VETA: Pokračuj, buď mojím hosťom.

TEXT_SOURCE: She filled the tub, kept the water as hot as she could stand it.
VETA: Napustila vaňu, udržiavala vodu tak horúcu, ako len mohla vydržať.

TEXT_SOURCE: He came in and stripped to the waist, and shaved at the handbasin with his back to her.
VETA: Vošiel, vyzliekol sa do pása a oholil sa pri umývadle chrbtom k nej.

TEXT_SOURCE: She closed her eyes and listened to him work the lather, tapping the razor against the sink, shaving.
VETA: Zavrela oči a počúvala, ako robí penu, búcha žiletkou o umývadlo a holil sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was like they’d done it all before.
VETA: Bolo to, ako keby to všetko urobili predtým.

TEXT_SOURCE: She thought him the least threatening man she’d ever known.
VETA: Považovala ho za najmenej hrozivého muža, akého kedy poznala.

TEXT_SOURCE: She held her nose and slid underwater, listened to the blood pumping in her head, the rush and cloud in her brain.
VETA: Držala si nos a skĺzla pod vodu, počúvala pumpovanie krvi v hlave, zhon a mrak v mozgu.

TEXT_SOURCE: When she surfaced, he was standing there in the steam, wiping traces of shaving foam off his chin, smiling.
VETA: Keď sa vynorila, stál tam v pare, utieral si z brady stopy peny na holenie a usmieval sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: Having fun? he said.
VETA: Zabávať sa? povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: When he lathered a flannel, she got up.
VETA: Keď namydlil flanel, vstala.

TEXT_SOURCE: Water fell off her shoulders and trickled down her legs.
VETA: Voda jej padala z pliec a stekala po nohách.

TEXT_SOURCE: He began at her feet and work upwards, washing her in strong, slow circles.
VETA: Začal pri jej nohách a pracoval nahor, umýval ju silnými, pomalými kruhmi.

TEXT_SOURCE: She looked good in the yellow shaving light, raised her feet and arms and turned like a child for him.
VETA: V žltom svetle na holenie vyzerala dobre, zdvihla nohy a ruky a otočila sa za ním ako dieťa.

TEXT_SOURCE: He made her sink back down into the water and rinsed her off, wrapped her in a towel.
VETA: Nechal ju klesnúť späť do vody, opláchol ju a zabalil do uteráka.

TEXT_SOURCE: I know what you need, he said.
VETA: Viem, čo potrebuješ, povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: You need looking after.
VETA: Potrebujete sa starať.

TEXT_SOURCE: There isn’t a woman on the earth who doesn’t need looking after.
VETA: Na svete nie je žena, ktorá by sa nepotrebovala starať.

TEXT_SOURCE: Stay there.
VETA: Zostaň tam.

TEXT_SOURCE: He went out and came back with a comb, began combing the knots from her hair.
VETA: Vyšiel von a vrátil sa s hrebeňom a začal jej rozčesávať uzly z vlasov.

TEXT_SOURCE: Look at you, he said.
VETA: Pozri sa na seba, povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: You’ve blond fuzz, like a peach.
VETA: Máš blond fúzy ako broskyňa.

TEXT_SOURCE: His knuckle slid down the back of her neck, followed her vertebrae.
VETA: Jeho kĺb skĺzol po jej zadnej časti krku a nasledoval jej stavce.

TEXT_SOURCE: His bed was brass with a white, goose-down duvet and black pillowcases.
VETA: Jeho posteľ bola mosadzná s bielou perinou z husacieho peria a čiernymi obliečkami na vankúše.

TEXT_SOURCE: She undid his belt, slid it from the loops.
VETA: Rozopla mu opasok a vysunula ho zo slučiek.

TEXT_SOURCE: The buckle jingled when it hit the floor.
VETA: Spona zacinkala, keď dopadla na podlahu.

TEXT_SOURCE: She loosened his trousers.
VETA: Rozviazala mu nohavice.

TEXT_SOURCE: Naked, he wasn’t beautiful, yet there was something voluptuous about him, something unbreakable and sturdy in his build.
VETA: Nahý nebol krásny, no bolo na ňom niečo zmyselné, niečo nerozbitné a pevné v jeho stavbe.

TEXT_SOURCE: His skin was hot.
VETA: Jeho pokožka bola horúca.

TEXT_SOURCE: Pretend you’re America, she said.
VETA: Predstierajte, že ste Amerika, povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: I’ll be Columbus.
VETA: Ja budem Kolumbus.

TEXT_SOURCE: Under the bedclothes, down between the damp of his thighs, she explored his nakedness.
VETA: Pod posteľnou bielizňou, dole medzi vlhkými stehnami, skúmala jeho nahotu.

TEXT_SOURCE: His body was a novelty.
VETA: Jeho telo bolo novinkou.

TEXT_SOURCE: When her feet became entangled in the sheets, he flung them off.
VETA: Keď sa jej nohy zamotali do plachty, odhodil ich.

TEXT_SOURCE: She had surprising strength in bed, an urgency that bruised him.
VETA: V posteli mala prekvapivú silu, naliehavosť, ktorá ho rozdrvila.

TEXT_SOURCE: She pulled his head back by the hair, drank in the smell of strange soap on his neck.
VETA: Stiahla mu hlavu za vlasy a napila sa pachu zvláštneho mydla na jeho krku.

TEXT_SOURCE: He kissed her and kissed her.
VETA: Pobozkal ju a pobozkal.

TEXT_SOURCE: There wasn’t any hurry.
VETA: Nikam sa neponáhľalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: His palms were the rough hands of a working man.
VETA: Jeho dlane boli drsné ruky pracujúceho muža.

TEXT_SOURCE: They battled against their lust, wrestled against what in the end carried them away.
VETA: Bojovali proti svojej žiadostivosti, zápasili s tým, čo ich nakoniec odnieslo.

TEXT_SOURCE: Afterwards they smoked – she hadn’t smoked in years, quit before the first baby.
VETA: Potom fajčili – nefajčila roky, prestala pred prvým bábätkom.

TEXT_SOURCE: She was reaching over for the ashtray when she saw the shotgun cartridge behind his clock-radio.
VETA: Natiahla sa po popolník, keď za jeho rádiobudíkom uvidela náboj do brokovnice.

TEXT_SOURCE: What’s this? she picked it up.
VETA: Čo je toto? zdvihla to.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was heavier than it looked.
VETA: Bolo to ťažšie, ako to vyzeralo.

TEXT_SOURCE: Oh that.
VETA: Ach to.

TEXT_SOURCE: That’s a present for somebody.
VETA: To je darček pre niekoho.

TEXT_SOURCE: Some present, she said.
VETA: Niektorí sú prítomní, povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: Looks like pool isn’t the only thing you shoot. She said this and laughed.
VETA: Zdá sa, že bazén nie je jediná vec, ktorú strieľate. Povedala to a zasmiala sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: Come here.
VETA: Poď sem.

TEXT_SOURCE: She snuggled up against him, and they fell swiftly into sleep, the sweet sleep of children, and woke in darkness, hungry.
VETA: Pritúlila sa k nemu a oni rýchlo upadli do spánku, sladkého spánku detí, a zobudili sa v tme, hladní.

TEXT_SOURCE: While he took charge of dinner, she sat in the couch with the cat on her lap and watched a documentary on Antarctica, miles of snow, penguins shuffling against the sub-zero winds, Captain Cook sailing down to find the lost continent, icebergs.
VETA: Kým sa on ujal večere, ona sedela na pohovke s mačkou na kolenách a pozerala dokument o Antarktíde, kilometroch snehu, tučniakoch šúchajúcich sa proti mínusovým vetrom, ako sa kapitán Cook plaví dole, aby našiel stratený kontinent, ľadovce.

TEXT_SOURCE: He came out with a tea towel draped across his shoulder and handed her a glass of Chianti.
VETA: Vyšiel s utierkou prehodenou cez rameno a podal jej pohár Chianti.

TEXT_SOURCE: You, he said, have a thing for explorers.
VETA: Povedal, že máš niečo pre prieskumníkov.

TEXT_SOURCE: He leaned down over the back of the couch and kissed her.
VETA: Naklonil sa cez operadlo pohovky a pobozkal ju.

TEXT_SOURCE: Can I do anything? she asked.
VETA: Môžem niečo urobiť? opýtala sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: No, he said and went back into the kitchen.
VETA: Nie, povedal a vrátil sa do kuchyne.

TEXT_SOURCE: She sipped her wine and felt her throat opening again, cold sliding down into her stomach.
VETA: Popíjala víno a cítila, ako sa jej opäť otvára hrdlo, chlad jej kĺže do žalúdka.

TEXT_SOURCE: She could hear him chopping vegetables, the bubble of water boiling on the stove.
VETA: Počula, ako seká zeleninu a na sporáku vrie bublina vody.

TEXT_SOURCE: Dinner smells drifted through the rooms.
VETA: Miestnosťami sa niesli pachy z večere.

TEXT_SOURCE: She could stay drunk; she could live like this.
VETA: Mohla zostať opitá; mohla takto žiť.

TEXT_SOURCE: He came out and laid two places at table, lit a thick, green candle, folded paper napkins.
VETA: Vyšiel von a položil dve miesta k stolu, zapálil hrubú zelenú sviečku a zložil papierové obrúsky.

TEXT_SOURCE: They looked like small white pyramids under a vigil of flame.
VETA: Vyzerali ako malé biele pyramídy pod strážou plameňa.

TEXT_SOURCE: She turned the TV off, and stroked the cat.
VETA: Vypla televízor a pohladila mačku.

TEXT_SOURCE: Its white hairs fell on to his dark-blue dressing gown that was much too big for her.
VETA: Jeho biele chĺpky padali na jeho tmavomodrý župan, ktorý jej bol príliš veľký.

TEXT_SOURCE: She saw the smoke from another man’s fire cross the window, but she did not think about her husband, and her lover never mentioned her home life either, not once.
VETA: Videla dym z ohňa iného muža cez okno, ale nemyslela na svojho manžela a ani jej milenec nikdy nespomenul jej rodinný život, ani raz.

TEXT_SOURCE: Instead, over Greek salad and grilled trout the conversation somehow turned to the subject of Hell.
VETA: Namiesto toho sa pri gréckom šaláte a grilovaných pstruhoch rozhovor nejako zvrtol na tému Peklo.

TEXT_SOURCE: As a child, she had been told that Hell was different for everyone, your own worst possible scenario.
VETA: Ako dieťa jej bolo povedané, že peklo je pre každého iné, váš najhorší možný scenár.

TEXT_SOURCE: I always thought Hell would be unbearably cold, a place where you stayed half-frozenbut you never quite lost consciousness and you never really felt anything, she said.
VETA: Vždy som si myslela, že v pekle bude neznesiteľne zima, miesto, kde ste zostali napoly zamrznutí, ale nikdy ste úplne nestratili vedomie a nikdy ste skutočne nič necítili, povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: There’d be nothing, only a cold sun and the Devil there, watching you.
VETA: Nebolo by tam nič, len studené slnko a diabol, ktorí by ťa sledovali.

TEXT_SOURCE: She shivered and shook herself.
VETA: Triasla sa a triasla sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: Her colour was high.
VETA: Jej farba bola vysoká.

TEXT_SOURCE: She had a nice, long neck.
VETA: Mala pekný, dlhý krk.

TEXT_SOURCE: In that case, he said, Hell for me would be deserted; there’d be nobody there.
VETA: V tom prípade povedal: Peklo pre mňa bude pusté; nikto by tam nebol.

TEXT_SOURCE: Not even the Devil.
VETA: Dokonca ani diabol.

TEXT_SOURCE: I’ve always taken heart in the fact that Hell is populated; all my friends will be there.
VETA: Vždy ma bavilo, že peklo je obývané; budú tam všetci moji priatelia.

TEXT_SOURCE: He ground more pepper over his salad plate and tore the doughy heart out of the loaf.
VETA: Nad šalátovým tanierom pomlel ešte korenie a z bochníka vytrhol cesto.

TEXT_SOURCE: The nun at school told us it would last for all eternity, she said, pulling the skin off her trout.
VETA: Mníška v škole nám povedala, že to bude trvať celú večnosť, povedala a stiahla si kožu zo svojho pstruha.

TEXT_SOURCE: And when we asked how long eternity lasted, she said: Think of all the sand in the world, all the beaches, all the sand quarries, the ocean beds, the deserts.
VETA: A keď sme sa opýtali, ako dlho trvala večnosť, povedala: Myslite na všetok piesok na svete, všetky pláže, všetky pieskové lomy, dna oceánov, púšte.

TEXT_SOURCE: Now imagine all that sand in an hour-glass, like a gigantic egg-timer.
VETA: Teraz si predstavte všetok ten piesok v presýpacích hodinách, ako gigantický časovač na vajcia.

TEXT_SOURCE: If one grain of sand drops every year, eternity is the length of time it takes for all the sand in the world to pass through that glass.
VETA: Ak každý rok padne jedno zrnko piesku, večnosť je čas, ktorý trvá, kým všetok piesok na svete prejde cez toto sklo.

TEXT_SOURCE: Just think!
VETA: Len premýšľajte!

TEXT_SOURCE: We were very young.
VETA: Boli sme veľmi mladí.

TEXT_SOURCE: You don’t still believe in Hell? he said.
VETA: Ešte stále neveríš v peklo? povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: No. Can’t you tell?
VETA: Nie. Nevieš povedať?

TEXT_SOURCE: If only Sister Emmanuel could see me now, fucking a complete stranger, what a laugh.
VETA: Keby ma len sestra Emmanuel teraz videla, kurva ako úplne cudzieho človeka, aký smiech.

TEXT_SOURCE: She broke off a flake of trout and ate it with her fingers.
VETA: Odlomila si lupienok zo pstruha a zjedla ho prstami.

TEXT_SOURCE: He put his cutlery down, folded his hands in his lap and looked at her.
VETA: Zložil príbor, zložil si ruky do lona a pozrel na ňu.

TEXT_SOURCE: She was full now, playing with her food.
VETA: Teraz bola plná a hrala sa s jedlom.

TEXT_SOURCE: So you think all your friends will be in Hell too, she said.
VETA: Takže si myslíš, že všetci tvoji priatelia budú tiež v pekle, povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: That’s nice.
VETA: To je milé.

TEXT_SOURCE: Not by your nun’s definition.
VETA: Nie podľa definície vašej mníšky.

TEXT_SOURCE: You have lots of friends?
VETA: Máš veľa priateľov?

TEXT_SOURCE: I suppose you know people from work.
VETA: Predpokladám, že poznáte ľudí z práce.

TEXT_SOURCE: A few, he said.
VETA: Niekoľko, povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: And you?
VETA: a ty?

TEXT_SOURCE: I have two good friends, she said.
VETA: Mám dvoch dobrých priateľov, povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: You’re lucky, he said, and got up to make the coffee.
VETA: Máš šťastie, povedal a vstal, aby uvaril kávu.

TEXT_SOURCE: That night, he was ravenous, like a man leasing himself out to her.
VETA: Tej noci bol nenásytný, ako muž, ktorý sa jej prenajíma.

TEXT_SOURCE: There was nothing he wouldn’t do.
VETA: Nebolo nič, čo by neurobil.

TEXT_SOURCE: You’re a very generous lover, she said afterwards, passing him the cigarette.
VETA: Si veľmi štedrý milenec, povedala potom a podala mu cigaretu.

TEXT_SOURCE: You’re very generous full stop.
VETA: Si veľmi štedrý bodka.

TEXT_SOURCE: The cat jumped up on the bed and startled her.
VETA: Mačka vyskočila na posteľ a vyplašil ju.

TEXT_SOURCE: Jesus Christ! she said.
VETA: Ježiš Kristus! povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: There was something creepy about his cat.
VETA: Na jeho mačke bolo niečo strašidelné.

TEXT_SOURCE: Cigarette ash fell on the duvet but they were too drunk to care.
VETA: Popol z cigariet padol na perinu, ale boli príliš opití, aby sa o to starali.

TEXT_SOURCE: Drunk and careless and occupying the same bed on the same night.
VETA: Opitý a neopatrný a v tú istú noc sediaci na tej istej posteli.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was all so simple, really.
VETA: Všetko to bolo také jednoduché, naozaj.

TEXT_SOURCE: Loud Christmas music started up in the apartment downstairs.
VETA: V byte na prízemí sa spustila hlasná vianočná hudba.

TEXT_SOURCE: Who’s your neighbour?
VETA: kto je tvoj sused?

TEXT_SOURCE: Oh, some granny.
VETA: Oh, nejaká babka.

TEXT_SOURCE: Deaf as a coot.
VETA: Hluchý ako lyska.

TEXT_SOURCE: She’s on her own down there; keeps odd hours.
VETA: Je tam dole sama; udržiava nepárne hodiny.

TEXT_SOURCE: They settled down to sleep, she with her head captured in the crook of his shoulder.
VETA: Uložili sa spať, ona s hlavou zachytenou v ohybe jeho ramena.

TEXT_SOURCE: He stroked her arm, petting her like an animal.
VETA: Hladil ju po ruke a hladkal ju ako zviera.

TEXT_SOURCE: She imitated the cat purring, rolling her rs the way they’d taught her in Spanish class while hailstones rapped the windows panes.
VETA: Napodobňovala mračiacu sa mačku, kotúľala sa tak, ako ju to naučili na hodinách španielčiny, zatiaľ čo na okenné tabule búchali krúpy.

TEXT_SOURCE: I’ll miss you when you go, he whispered.
VETA: Budeš mi chýbať, keď pôjdeš, zašepkal.

TEXT_SOURCE: She said nothing, just lay there watching the red numbers on his clock-radio change until she drifted off.
VETA: Nepovedala nič, len tam ležala a sledovala, ako sa menia červené čísla na jeho rádiu, kým nezmizla.

TEXT_SOURCE: On Sunday she woke early.
VETA: V nedeľu sa zobudila skoro.

TEXT_SOURCE: She dressed, watched him sleeping, his head on the black pillow.
VETA: Obliekla sa, sledovala ho, ako spí, s hlavou na čiernom vankúši.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the bathroom she looked inside the cabinet.
VETA: V kúpeľni nazrela do skrinky.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was empty.
VETA: Bola prázdna.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the lounge, she read the titles of his books.
VETA: V salóniku čítala názvy jeho kníh.

TEXT_SOURCE: She walked back along treacherous pavement to check out of her hotel.
VETA: Vrátila sa po zradnom chodníku, aby sa odhlásila zo svojho hotela.

TEXT_SOURCE: She got lost and had to ask a troubled-looking lady with a poodle where to go.
VETA: Stratila sa a musela sa spýtať utrápenej pani s pudlíkom, kam má ísť.

TEXT_SOURCE: A huge Christmas tree sparkled in the lobby.
VETA: Vo vestibule sa trblietal obrovský vianočný stromček.

TEXT_SOURCE: Her suitcase lay open on the bed.
VETA: Jej kufor ležal otvorený na posteli.

TEXT_SOURCE: She showered and changed.
VETA: Osprchovala sa a prezliekla.

TEXT_SOURCE: The cleaning lady knocked at ten but she waved her off, told her not to bother, told her nobody should work on Sundays.
VETA: Upratovačka zaklopala o desiatej, ale odkývala ju, povedala jej, aby sa neobťažovala, povedala jej, že v nedeľu by nikto nemal pracovať.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the lobby, she sat in the telephone booth and called home.
VETA: Vo vestibule sedela v telefónnej búdke a volala domov.

TEXT_SOURCE: She asked about the children, the weather, asked her husband about his day, told him about the children’s gifts.
VETA: Pýtala sa na deti, počasie, pýtala sa manžela na jeho deň, hovorila mu o darčekoch pre deti.

TEXT_SOURCE: She would return to untidy, cluttered rooms, dirty floors, cut knees, a hall with mountain-bikes and roller-skates.
VETA: Vrátila sa do neupravených, upchatých izieb, špinavých podláh, podrezaných kolien, haly s horskými bicyklami a kolieskovými korčuľami.

TEXT_SOURCE: Questions.
VETA: Otázky.

TEXT_SOURCE: She hung up, became aware of a presence behind her, waiting.
VETA: Zavesila, uvedomila si prítomnosť za sebou a čakala.

TEXT_SOURCE: You never said goodbye.
VETA: Nikdy si nepovedal zbohom.

TEXT_SOURCE: She felt his breath on her neck.
VETA: Cítila jeho dych na svojom krku.

TEXT_SOURCE: He was standing there, a black wool cap pulled down low over his ears, hiding his forehead.
VETA: Stál tam, čiernu vlnenú čiapku stiahnutú nízko cez uši a skrývajúc si čelo.

TEXT_SOURCE: You were sleeping, she said.
VETA: Spal si, povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: You sneaked off, he said.
VETA: Vykradli ste sa, povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: You’re a sneaky one.
VETA: Si zákerná.

TEXT_SOURCE: I – You want to sneak off to lunch and get drunk?
VETA: Ja – Chceš sa odkradnúť na obed a opiť sa?

TEXT_SOURCE: He pushed her into the booth and kissed her, a long, wet kiss.
VETA: Strčil ju do kabínky a pobozkal ju, dlhý, vlhký bozk.

TEXT_SOURCE: I woke this morning with your scent in the sheets, he said.
VETA: Dnes ráno som sa zobudil s tvojou vôňou v obliečkach, povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was beautiful.
VETA: Bolo to krásne.

TEXT_SOURCE: Bottle it, she said, we’ll make a fortune.
VETA: Nalejte do fliaš, povedala, zarobíme bohatstvo.

TEXT_SOURCE: They ate lunch in a place with six-foot walls, arched windows and a flagstone floor.
VETA: Obed jedli na mieste s dvojmetrovými stenami, klenutými oknami a dláždenou podlahou.

TEXT_SOURCE: Their table was next to a fire.
VETA: Ich stôl bol pri ohni.

TEXT_SOURCE: Over plates of roast beef and Yorkshire pudding they got drunk again, but they didn’t talk much.
VETA: Nad taniermi pečeného hovädzieho mäsa a yorkshirského pudingu sa opäť opili, ale veľa toho nerozprávali.

TEXT_SOURCE: She drank Bloody Marys, told the waitress to go heavy on the Tabasco.
VETA: Vypila Bloody Marys a povedala čašníčke, aby išla na Tabasco.

TEXT_SOURCE: He started on ale then switched to gin and tonics, anything to stave off the imminent prospect of their separation.
VETA: Začal s pivom a potom prešiel na gin s tonikom, čokoľvek, čo by odvrátilo hroziacu vyhliadku na ich rozchod.

TEXT_SOURCE: I don’t normally drink like this, she said.
VETA: Normálne takto nepijem, povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: How about you?
VETA: A čo ty?

TEXT_SOURCE: Nah, he said, and signalled the waitress for another round.
VETA: Nie, povedal a naznačil čašníčke ďalšie kolo.

TEXT_SOURCE: They dawdled over dessert and the Sunday newspapers.
VETA: Povaľovali sa nad dezertom a nedeľnými novinami.

TEXT_SOURCE: The landlady came round and threw more wood on the fire.
VETA: Gazdiná obišla a hodila ďalšie drevo do ohňa.

TEXT_SOURCE: Once, while turning a page of the newspaper, she looked up.
VETA: Raz, keď otáčala stránku novín, pozrela hore.

TEXT_SOURCE: He was staring intently at her mouth.
VETA: Uprene hľadel na jej ústa.

TEXT_SOURCE: Smile, he said.
VETA: Usmej sa, povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: What?
VETA: Čo?

TEXT_SOURCE: Smile.
VETA: Usmievajte sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: She smiled and he reached over and pressed the tip of his index finger against her tooth.
VETA: Usmiala sa a on sa natiahol a pritlačil špičkou ukazováka na jej zub.

TEXT_SOURCE: There, he said, showing her a tiny speck of food.
VETA: Tam, povedal a ukázal jej malý kúsok jedla.

TEXT_SOURCE: It’s gone now.
VETA: Teraz je to preč.

TEXT_SOURCE: When they walked out on to the market-place, a thick fog had fallen on the town, so thick she could hardly read the signs.
VETA: Keď vyšli na trhovisko, na mesto padla hustá hmla, taká hustá, že sotva čítala nápisy.

TEXT_SOURCE: A straggle of vendors, out to win the Christmas trade, were demonstrating their wares.
VETA: Skupina predajcov, ktorí chceli vyhrať vianočný obchod, predvádzala svoj tovar.

TEXT_SOURCE: Done your Christmas shopping? she said.
VETA: Máte za sebou vianočné nákupy? povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: Nah, got nobody to buy for, have I?
VETA: Nie, nemám pre koho kupovať, však?

TEXT_SOURCE: I’m an orphan.
VETA: som sirota.

TEXT_SOURCE: Remember?
VETA: Pamätáte si?

TEXT_SOURCE: I’m sorry.
VETA: Prepáč.

TEXT_SOURCE: Come on.
VETA: Poď.

TEXT_SOURCE: Let’s walk.
VETA: Poďme sa prejsť.

TEXT_SOURCE: He gripped her hand and took her down a dirt road that led into a black wood beyond the houses.
VETA: Chytil ju za ruku a viedol ju po poľnej ceste, ktorá viedla do čierneho lesa za domy.

TEXT_SOURCE: You’re hurting me, she said.
VETA: Ubližuješ mi, povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: He loosened his hold but he did not say sorry.
VETA: Uvoľnil zovretie, ale nepovedal prepáč.

TEXT_SOURCE: Light drained out of that day.
VETA: Svetlo z toho dňa vyprchalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: Dusk stoked the sky, bribing daylight into darkness.
VETA: Súmrak rozdúchal oblohu a podplatil denné svetlo do tmy.

TEXT_SOURCE: They walked for a long time without talking, just feeling the Sunday hush, listening to the trees straining against the icy wind.
VETA: Dlho kráčali bez rozprávania, len cítili nedeľné ticho a počúvali stromy namáhajúce sa proti ľadovému vetru.

TEXT_SOURCE: I was married once, went off to Africa for a honeymoon, he said suddenly.
VETA: Bol som raz ženatý, odišiel som do Afriky na svadobnú cestu, povedal zrazu.

TEXT_SOURCE: It didn’t last.
VETA: nevydržalo to.

TEXT_SOURCE: I had a big house, furniture, all that.
VETA: Mal som veľký dom, nábytok, to všetko.

TEXT_SOURCE: She was a good woman too, a wonderful gardener.
VETA: Bola to tiež dobrá žena, úžasná záhradníčka.

TEXT_SOURCE: You know that plant in my lounge?
VETA: Poznáte tú rastlinu v mojej obývačke?

TEXT_SOURCE: Well, that was hers.
VETA: No, to bolo jej.

TEXT_SOURCE: I’ve been waiting for years for that plant to die, but the fucking thing, it keeps on growing.
VETA: Roky som čakal, kým tá rastlina zomrie, ale kurva, stále rastie.

TEXT_SOURCE: She pictured the plant sprawled across the floor, the length of a grown man, its pot no bigger than a small saucepan, dried roots snarling up over the pot.
VETA: Predstavila si rastlinu roztiahnutú po podlahe, dlhú ako dospelý muž, jej črepník nie väčší ako malý kastról a nad črepníkom vrčia suché korene.

TEXT_SOURCE: A miracle it was still alive.
VETA: Zázrak, že to ešte žilo.

TEXT_SOURCE: Some things you just have no control over, he said, scratching his head.
VETA: Niektoré veci jednoducho nemáte pod kontrolou, povedal a poškrabal sa na hlave.

TEXT_SOURCE: She said I wouldn’t last a year without her.
VETA: Povedala, že bez nej nevydržím ani rok.

TEXT_SOURCE: Boy, was she wrong.
VETA: Chlapče, mýlila sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: He looked at her then, and smiled, a strange smile of victory.
VETA: Potom sa na ňu pozrel a usmial sa zvláštnym víťazným úsmevom.

TEXT_SOURCE: They had walked deep into the woods by now; except for the sound of their footsteps on the road and the ribbon of sky between the trees, she could not have been sure where the path was.
VETA: Už išli hlboko do lesa; okrem zvuku ich krokov na ceste a stuhy neba medzi stromami si nemohla byť istá, kde je cesta.

TEXT_SOURCE: He grabbed her suddenly and pulled her in under the trees, pushed her back against a tree-trunk.
VETA: Zrazu ju schmatol a vtiahol pod stromy, pritlačil ju chrbtom ku kmeňu stromu.

TEXT_SOURCE: She couldn’t see.
VETA: Nemohla vidieť.

TEXT_SOURCE: She felt the bark through her coat, his belly against hers, could smell gin on his breath.
VETA: Cítila kôru cez kabát, jeho brucho na svojom, cítila gin z jeho dychu.

TEXT_SOURCE: You won’t forget me, he said, smoothing her hair back from her eyes.
VETA: Nezabudneš na mňa, povedal a uhladil jej vlasy z očí.

TEXT_SOURCE: Say it.
VETA: Povedz to.

TEXT_SOURCE: Say you won’t forget me.
VETA: Povedz, že na mňa nezabudneš.

TEXT_SOURCE: I won’t forget you, she said.
VETA: Nezabudnem na teba, povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the darkness, he ran his fingers across her face, same as he was s blind man trying to memorise her.
VETA: V tme jej prešiel prstami po tvári, rovnako ako bol slepý muž, ktorý sa ju snažil zapamätať.

TEXT_SOURCE: Nor I, you.
VETA: Ani ja, ty.

TEXT_SOURCE: A little piece of you will be ticking right here, he said, taking her hand and placing it inside his shirt.
VETA: Malý kúsok z teba tu bude tikať, povedal, vzal ju za ruku a vložil si ju do košele.

TEXT_SOURCE: She felt his heart beneath his hot skin, beating.
VETA: Cítila, ako mu pod horúcou pokožkou bije srdce.

TEXT_SOURCE: He kissed her then as if there was something in her mouth he wanted.
VETA: Potom ju pobozkal, ako keby mala v ústach niečo, čo chcel.

TEXT_SOURCE: Words, probably.
VETA: Slová, pravdepodobne.

TEXT_SOURCE: At the moment the cathedral bells rang and she wondered what time it was.
VETA: V tom momente zazvonili katedrálne zvony a ona bola zvedavá, koľko je hodín.

TEXT_SOURCE: Her train left at six but she was all packed, there was no real hurry.
VETA: Vlak jej odišiel o šiestej, ale bola celá zbalená, nebolo sa kam ponáhľať.

TEXT_SOURCE: Did you check out this morning?
VETA: Odhlásili ste sa dnes ráno?

TEXT_SOURCE: Yes, she laughed.
VETA: Áno, zasmiala sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: They think I’m the tidiest guest they’ve ever had.
VETA: Myslia si, že som ten najčistejší hosť, akého kedy mali.

TEXT_SOURCE: My bag’s in the lobby.
VETA: Moja taška je vo vestibule.

TEXT_SOURCE: Come to my place.
VETA: Príď ku mne.

TEXT_SOURCE: I’ll get you a taxi, see you off.
VETA: Donesiem ti taxík, odprevadím ťa.

TEXT_SOURCE: She wasn’t in the mood for sex.
VETA: Nemala náladu na sex.

TEXT_SOURCE: In her mind she had already packed up and left, was facing her husband in the doorway.
VETA: V duchu sa už zbalila a odišla, vo dverách stála tvárou k manželovi.

TEXT_SOURCE: She felt clean and full and warm; all she wanted now was a good snooze on the train.
VETA: Cítila sa čistá, plná a teplá; všetko, čo teraz chcela, bolo poriadne si pospať vo vlaku.

TEXT_SOURCE: But in the end she could think of no reason not to go and, yielding like a parting gift to him, said yes.
VETA: Ale nakoniec nedokázala vymyslieť dôvod, prečo neísť a podvolila sa mu ako dar na rozlúčku a povedala áno.

TEXT_SOURCE: They retreated from the darkness of the woods, walked down Vicar’s Close and emerged below the moat near the hotel.
VETA: Ustúpili z temnoty lesa, prešli po Vicar’s Close a vynorili sa pod priekopou neďaleko hotela.

TEXT_SOURCE: The seagulls hovered above the water fowl, swooping down and snapping up the bread a bunch of Americans were throwing to the swans.
VETA: Čajky sa vznášali nad vodným vtáctvom, znášali sa dolu a lámali chlieb, ktorý hádzali labutiam banda Američanov.

TEXT_SOURCE: She collected her suitcase and walked the slippery streets to his place.
VETA: Zobrala si kufor a kráčala klzkými ulicami k nemu.

TEXT_SOURCE: The rooms were cold.
VETA: V izbách bola zima.

TEXT_SOURCE: Yesterday’s dirty dishes lay soaking in the sink, a rim of greasy water on the steel.
VETA: Včerajší špinavý riad ležal namočený v dreze, na oceli okraj mastnej vody.

TEXT_SOURCE: Remnant daylight filtered through gaps between the curtains, but he did not turn a light on.
VETA: Zvyšky denného svetla prenikli cez medzery medzi závesmi, ale nezapol svetlo.

TEXT_SOURCE: Come here, he said.
VETA: Poď sem, povedal.
