TEXT_SOURCE: The next set of exercises helps students learn how to determine what the objects actually are.
VETA: Ďalší súbor cvičení pomáha študentom naučiť sa, ako určiť, aké predmety v skutočnosti sú.

TEXT_SOURCE: This essentially involves three characteristics: where things are, how large they are and depth of structure, which refers to the geometric nature of the object or surface.
VETA: To v podstate zahŕňa tri charakteristiky: kde sa veci nachádzajú, aké sú veľké a hĺbku štruktúry, ktorá odkazuje na geometrickú povahu objektu alebo povrchu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Students answer questions such as, Is the object coarse or smooth?
VETA: Študenti odpovedajú na otázky ako: Je predmet hrubý alebo hladký?

TEXT_SOURCE: Is it highly solid or sparse? and Is it highly reflective or absorbent?
VETA: Je veľmi pevný alebo riedky? a Je vysoko reflexná alebo absorbujúca?

TEXT_SOURCE: Kish says all those patterns come back as acoustic imprints.
VETA: Kish hovorí, že všetky tieto vzory sa vracajú ako akustické odtlačky.

TEXT_SOURCE: The key is to notice the changes in the sound when it comes back from when it went out.
VETA: Kľúčom je všimnúť si zmeny vo zvuku, keď sa vráti z doby, keď zhasol.

TEXT_SOURCE: With determined practice, students eventually learn how to differentiate among general environmental stimuli.
VETA: S odhodlanou praxou sa študenti nakoniec naučia, ako rozlišovať medzi všeobecnými environmentálnymi stimulmi.

TEXT_SOURCE: Although the organization’s instructors are currently all blind echolocators, Kish anticipates that sighted instructors could teach the skill as well.
VETA: Hoci inštruktori organizácie sú v súčasnosti všetci slepí echolokátori, Kish predpokladá, že vidiaci inštruktori by mohli túto zručnosť tiež naučiť.

TEXT_SOURCE: Several sighted instructors are in training, showing promise of using echolocation themselves.
VETA: Niekoľko vidiacich inštruktorov je vo výcviku, ktorí sľubujú, že sami budú používať echolokáciu.

TEXT_SOURCE: His goal is to have sighted instructors performing just as well as blind echolocators, though he emphasizes that although both sighted and blind individuals can echolocate, they may have profoundly different phenomenological experiences.
VETA: Jeho cieľom je, aby vidiaci inštruktori fungovali rovnako dobre ako nevidomí echolokátori, hoci zdôrazňuje, že aj keď vidiaci aj nevidomí jedinci môžu echolokovať, môžu mať úplne odlišné fenomenologické skúsenosti.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the meantime, Kish is hard at work, teaching the blind how to use their ears to see.
VETA: Medzitým Kish tvrdo pracuje a učí nevidomých, ako používať uši na videnie.

TEXT_SOURCE: When the words 'Not Guilty' sounded through the crowded courtroom that dark December afternoon, Arthur Wilbraham, the great criminal KC, and leader for the triumphant defence, was represented by his junior; but Johnson, his private secretary, carried the verdict across to his chambers like lightning.
VETA: Keď v to tmavé decembrové popoludnie zazneli preplnenou súdnou sieňou slová Nevinný, Arthura Wilbrahama, veľkého zločinca KC a vodcu víťaznej obrany, zastupoval jeho junior; ale Johnson, jeho súkromný tajomník, preniesol rozsudok do svojich komnát ako blesk.

TEXT_SOURCE: It's what we expected, I think,' said the barrister, without emotion; 'and, personally, I am glad the case is over.
VETA: Myslím, že je to to, čo sme očakávali, povedal advokát bez emócií; A osobne som rád, že sa prípad skončil.

TEXT_SOURCE: There was no particular sign of pleasure that his defence of John Turk, the murderer, on a plea of insanity, had been successful, for no doubt he felt, as everybody who had watched the face felt, that no man had ever better deserved the gallows.
VETA: Neexistoval žiadny zvláštny náznak potešenia, že jeho obhajoba vraha Jána Turka pod zámienkou nepríčetnosti bola úspešná, pretože nepochybne cítil, ako každý, kto pozoroval jeho tvár, že nikto si nikdy nezaslúžil lepšie. šibenica.

TEXT_SOURCE: I'm glad too,' said Johnson.
VETA: Aj ja som rád, povedal Johnson.

TEXT_SOURCE: He had sat in the court for ten days watching the face of the man who had carried out with callous detail one of the most brutal and cold-blooded murders of recent years.
VETA: Desať dní sedel na súde a sledoval tvár muža, ktorý s bezcitnými detailmi vykonal jednu z najbrutálnejších a najchladnokrvnejších vrážd posledných rokov.

TEXT_SOURCE: The counsel glanced up at his secretary.
VETA: Poradca pozrel na svoju sekretárku.

TEXT_SOURCE: They were more than employer and employed; for family and other reasons, they were friends.
VETA: Boli viac ako zamestnávateľ a zamestnaní; z rodinných a iných dôvodov boli priateľmi.

TEXT_SOURCE: Ah, I remember, yes,' he said with a kind smile, 'and you want to get away for Christmas.
VETA: Ach, pamätám si, áno, povedal s láskavým úsmevom, a ty chceš na Vianoce ujsť.

TEXT_SOURCE: You're going to skate and ski in the Alps, aren't you?
VETA: Chystáte sa korčuľovať a lyžovať do Álp, však?

TEXT_SOURCE: If I was your age I'd come with you.'
VETA: Keby som bol v tvojom veku, išiel by som s tebou.

TEXT_SOURCE: Johnson laughed shortly.
VETA: Johnson sa krátko zasmial.

TEXT_SOURCE: He was a young man of twenty-six, with a delicate face like a girl's.
VETA: Bol to dvadsaťšesťročný mladík s jemnou tvárou ako dievča.

TEXT_SOURCE: I can catch the morning boat now,' he said; 'but that's not the reason I'm glad the trial is over.
VETA: Teraz môžem chytiť rannú loď, povedal; Ale to nie je dôvod, prečo som rád, že sa súdny proces skončil.

TEXT_SOURCE: I'm glad it's over because I've seen the last of that man's dreadful face.
VETA: Som rád, že je to za nami, pretože som videl posledný z hroznej tváre toho muža.

TEXT_SOURCE: It positively haunted me.
VETA: Pozitívne ma to prenasledovalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: That white skin, with the black hair brushed low over the forehead, is a thing I shall never forget, and the description of the way the dismembered body was crammed and packed with lime into that- 'Don't dwell on it, my dear fellow, ' interrupted the other, looking at him curiously out of his keen eyes, 'don't think about it.
VETA: Tá biela pokožka s čiernymi vlasmi vyčesanými nízko nad čelo je vec, na ktorú nikdy nezabudnem, a na popis toho, ako bolo rozštvrtené telo napchaté a zabalené vápnom do toho – Nezdržiavaj sa v tom, drahá chlapče,  prerušil ho druhý a zvedavo sa naňho pozrel z jeho bystrých očí, nemysli na to.

TEXT_SOURCE: Such pictures have a trick of coming back when one least wants them.'
VETA: Takéto obrázky majú trik vrátiť sa, keď ich človek najmenej chce.

TEXT_SOURCE: He paused a moment.
VETA: Na chvíľu sa odmlčal.

TEXT_SOURCE: Now go,' he added presently, 'and enjoy your holiday.
VETA: Teraz choď, dodal na chvíľu, a užívaj si prázdniny.

TEXT_SOURCE: I shall want all your energy for my Parliamentary work when you get back.
VETA: Keď sa vrátite, budem chcieť všetku vašu energiu na svoju parlamentnú prácu.

TEXT_SOURCE: And don't break your neck skiing.'
VETA: A nezlom si krk pri lyžovaní.

TEXT_SOURCE: Johnson shook hands and took his leave.
VETA: Johnson si potriasol rukou a odišiel.

TEXT_SOURCE: At the door he turned suddenly.
VETA: Pri dverách sa zrazu otočil.

TEXT_SOURCE: I knew there was something I wanted to ask you,' he said.
VETA: Vedel som, že sa ťa chcem niečo opýtať, povedal.

TEXT_SOURCE: Would you mind lending me one of your kit-bags?
VETA: Požičal by si mi jednu zo svojich tašiek?

TEXT_SOURCE: It's too late to get one tonight, and I leave in the morning before the shops are open.'
VETA: Dnes večer je príliš neskoro na to, aby som ho dostal, a odchádzam ráno, kým budú obchody otvorené.

TEXT_SOURCE: Of course; I'll send Henry over with it to your rooms.
VETA: Samozrejme; Pošlem s tým Henryho do vašich izieb.

TEXT_SOURCE: You shall have it the moment I get home.'
VETA: Budeš to mať, keď sa vrátim domov.

TEXT_SOURCE: I promise to take great care of it, ' said Johnson gratefully, delighted to think that within thirty hours he would be nearing the brilliant sunshine of the high Alps in winter.
VETA: Sľubujem, že sa o to veľmi postarám, povedal Johnson vďačne, s potešením si pomyslel, že do tridsiatich hodín sa bude blížiť k žiarivému slnečnému žiareniu vysokých Álp v zime.

TEXT_SOURCE: The thought of that criminal court was like an evil dream in his mind.
VETA: Myšlienka na trestný súd bola v jeho mysli ako zlý sen.

TEXT_SOURCE: He dined at his club and went on to Bloomsbury, where he occupied the top floor in one of those old, gaunt houses in which the rooms are large and lofty.
VETA: Navečeral sa vo svojom klube a pokračoval do Bloomsbury, kde obsadil najvyššie poschodie v jednom z tých starých vychudnutých domov, v ktorých sú izby veľké a vznešené.

TEXT_SOURCE: The floor below his own was vacant and unfurnished, and below that were other lodgers whom he did not know.
VETA: Poschodie pod jeho vlastným bolo prázdne a nezariadené a pod ním boli ďalší nájomníci, ktorých nepoznal.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was cheerless, and he looked forward heartily to a change.
VETA: Bolo to neveselé a on sa srdečne tešil na zmenu.

TEXT_SOURCE: The night was even more cheerless: it was miserable, and few people were about.
VETA: Noc bola ešte veselšia: bola mizerná a okolo bolo málo ľudí.

TEXT_SOURCE: A cold, sleety rain was driving down the streets before the keenest east wind he had ever felt.
VETA: Po uliciach sa valil studený, dusný dážď pred najprudším východným vetrom, aký kedy cítil.

TEXT_SOURCE: It howled dismally among the big, gloomy houses of the great squares, and when he reached his rooms he heard it whistling and shouting over the world of black roofs beyond his windows.
VETA: Medzi veľkými, ponurými domami veľkých námestí to pochmúrne zavýjalo, a keď sa dostal do svojich izieb, počul to pískať a kričať nad svetom čiernych striech za jeho oknami.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the hall he met his landlady, shading a candle from the draughts with her thin hand.
VETA: V predsieni sa stretol so svojou gazdinou, ktorá si tenkou rukou zatienila sviečku pred prievanom.

TEXT_SOURCE: This come by a man from Mr Wilbrim's, sir.'

TEXT_SOURCE: He felt exactly as though someone was hiding close about him, watching all his movements, trying to hinder his packing in some way. '
VETA: Cítil sa presne tak, ako keby sa niekto schovával blízko neho, sledoval všetky jeho pohyby a snažil sa mu nejakým spôsobom brániť v balení. '

TEXT_SOURCE: And two of my senses,' he added, keeping up the pretence, 'have played me the most absurd tricks: the steps I heard and the figure I saw were both entirely imaginary.'
VETA: A dva z mojich zmyslov, dodal a pokračoval v pretvárke, so mnou zahrali tie najabsurdnejšie triky: kroky, ktoré som počul, a postava, ktorú som videl, boli úplne vymyslené.

TEXT_SOURCE: He went back to the front room, poked the fire into a blaze, and sat down before it to think.
VETA: Vrátil sa do prednej izby, zapálil oheň a posadil sa pred ňu, aby premýšľal.

TEXT_SOURCE: What impressed him more than anything else was the fact that the kit-bag was no longer where he had left it.
VETA: Čo naňho zapôsobilo viac ako čokoľvek iné, bola skutočnosť, že taška už nebola tam, kde ju nechal.

TEXT_SOURCE: It had been dragged nearer to the door.
VETA: Bol pritiahnutý bližšie k dverám.

TEXT_SOURCE: What happened afterwards that night happened, of course, to a man already excited by fear, and was perceived by a mind that had not the full and proper control, therefore, of the senses.
VETA: To, čo sa stalo potom v tú noc, sa, samozrejme, stalo človeku, ktorý už bol vzrušený strachom, a vnímala to myseľ, ktorá teda nemala plnú a správnu kontrolu nad zmyslami.

TEXT_SOURCE: Outwardly, Johnson remained calm and master of himself to the end, pretending to the very last that everything he witnessed had a natural explanation, or was merely delusions of his tired nerves.
VETA: Navonok zostal Johnson až do konca pokojný a pán sám nad sebou a do poslednej chvíle predstieral, že všetko, čoho bol svedkom, malo prirodzené vysvetlenie alebo to boli len ilúzie jeho unavených nervov.

TEXT_SOURCE: But inwardly, in his very heart, he knew all along that someone had been hiding downstairs in the empty suite when he came in, that this person had watched his opportunity and then stealthily made his way up to the bedroom, and that all he saw and heard afterwards, from the moving of the kit-bag to—well, to the other things this story has to tell—were caused directly by the presence of this invisible person.
VETA: Ale vnútorne, vo svojom srdci celý čas vedel, že sa niekto schovával dole v prázdnom apartmáne, keď vošiel, že táto osoba sledovala svoju príležitosť a potom sa pokradmu dostala do spálne, a že všetko, čo videl a počuté potom, od premiestňovania tašky až po iné veci, ktoré má tento príbeh rozprávať, boli spôsobené priamo prítomnosťou tejto neviditeľnej osoby.

TEXT_SOURCE: And it was here, just when he most desired to keep his mind and thoughts controlled, that the vivid pictures received day after day upon the mental plates exposed in the courtroom of the Old Bailey, came strongly to light and developed themselves in the dark room of his inner vision.
VETA: A práve tu, práve vtedy, keď si najviac prial ovládať svoju myseľ a myšlienky, sa živé obrazy, ktoré dostával deň čo deň na mentálnych platniach vystavených v súdnej sieni Old Bailey, silno dostali na svetlo a rozvíjali sa v tmavej miestnosti. svojho vnútorného videnia.

TEXT_SOURCE: Unpleasant, haunting memories have a way of coming to life again just when the mind least desires them—in the silent watches of the night, on sleepless pillows, during the lonely hours spent by sick and dying beds.
VETA: Nepríjemné, strašidelné spomienky majú spôsob, ako znovu ožiť práve vtedy, keď si ich myseľ najmenej želá – v tichých nočných hodinách, na nevyspatých vankúšoch, počas osamelých hodín strávených pri chorých a umierajúcich posteliach.

TEXT_SOURCE: And so now, in the same way, Johnson saw nothing but the dreadful face of John Turk, the murderer, lowering at him from every corner of his mental field of vision; the white skin, the evil eyes, and the fringe of black hair low over the forehead.
VETA: A tak teraz, rovnakým spôsobom, Johnson nevidel nič iné ako strašnú tvár vraha Johna Turka, ktorý sa naňho spúšťal z každého kúta jeho mentálneho zorného poľa; biela pokožka, zlé oči a ofina čiernych vlasov nízko nad čelom.

TEXT_SOURCE: All the pictures of those ten days in court crowded back into his mind unbidden, and very vivid.
VETA: Všetky obrázky z tých desiatich dní na súde sa mu nežiadane vtlačili späť do mysle a boli veľmi živé.

TEXT_SOURCE: This is all rubbish and nerves,' he exclaimed at length, springing with sudden energy from his chair.
VETA: Toto je všetko svinstvo a nervy, zvolal dlho a náhle vyskočila energia zo stoličky.

TEXT_SOURCE: I shall finish my packing and go to bed.
VETA: ,,Dokončím si balenie a pôjdem spať.

TEXT_SOURCE: I'm overwrought, overtired.
VETA: Som prepracovaná, unavená.

TEXT_SOURCE: No doubt, at this rate I shall hear steps and things all night! '
VETA: Niet pochýb, že týmto tempom budem počuť kroky a veci celú noc! '

TEXT_SOURCE: But his face was deadly white all the same.
VETA: Ale jeho tvár bola smrteľne biela.

TEXT_SOURCE: He snatched up his field-glasses and walked across to the bedroom, humming a music-hall song as he went—a trifle too loud to be natural; and the instant he crossed the threshold and stood within the room something turned cold about his heart, and he felt that every hair on his head stood up.
VETA: Schmatol dioptrické okuliare a prešiel do spálne, pričom si pobrukoval pieseň z hudobnej sály – maličkosť príliš hlasná na to, aby to bolo prirodzené; a v okamihu, keď prekročil prah a postavil sa do miestnosti, mu v srdci niečo vychladlo a cítil, že mu vstali všetky vlasy na hlave.

TEXT_SOURCE: The kit-bag lay close in front of him, several feet nearer to the door than he had left it, and just over its crumpled top he saw a head and face slowly sinking down out of sight as though someone were crouching behind it to hide, and at the same moment a sound like a long- drawn sigh was distinctly audible in the still air about him between the gusts of the storm outside.
VETA: Taška ležala tesne pred ním, o niekoľko stôp bližšie k dverám, než ju nechal, a tesne nad jej pokrčeným vrchom videl hlavu a tvár pomaly klesať z dohľadu, akoby sa za ňou niekto krčil, aby sa skryl. a v tom istom momente bolo v tichom vzduchu okolo neho medzi poryvmi búrky zreteľne počuť zvuk ako dlhotrvajúci vzdych.

TEXT_SOURCE: A violent trembling ran down his back and legs, and he was conscious of a foolish, almost a hysterical, impulse to scream aloud.
VETA: Po chrbte a nohách mu prebehlo prudké chvenie a bol si vedomý hlúpeho, takmer hysterického nutkania nahlas kričať.

TEXT_SOURCE: That sigh seemed in his very ear, and the air still quivered with it.
VETA: Ten povzdych sa mu zdal priamo v uchu a vzduch sa ním stále chvel.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was unmistakably a human sigh.
VETA: Bol to neomylne ľudský povzdych.

TEXT_SOURCE: Who's there?' he said at length, finding his voice;
VETA: Kto je tam?' povedal dlho a našiel svoj hlas;

TEXT_SOURCE: but though he meant to speak with loud decision, the tones came out instead in a faint whisper, for he had partly lost the control of his tongue and lips.
VETA: no hoci mal v úmysle hovoriť nahlas, tóny sa namiesto toho ozvali slabým šepotom, pretože čiastočne stratil kontrolu nad jazykom a perami.

TEXT_SOURCE: He stepped forward, so that he could see all round and over the kit-bag.
VETA: Vykročil dopredu, aby videl dookola aj cez tašku.

TEXT_SOURCE: Of course there was nothing there, nothing but the faded carpet and the bulging canvas sides.
VETA: Samozrejme, nebolo tam nič, iba vyblednutý koberec a vyduté plátené strany.

TEXT_SOURCE: He put out his hands and threw open the mouth of the sack where it had fallen over, being only three parts full, and then he saw for the first time that round the inside, some six inches from the top, there ran a broad smear of dull crimson.
VETA: Natiahol ruky a otvoril ústa vreca tam, kde sa prevrátilo, bolo plné len z troch častí, a potom prvýkrát uvidel, že okolo zvnútra, asi šesť palcov od vrchu, bola široká škvrna. z matnej karmínovej.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was an old and faded blood stain.
VETA: Bola to stará a vyblednutá krvavá škvrna.

TEXT_SOURCE: He uttered a scream, and drew back his hands as if they had been burnt.
VETA: Vykríkol a stiahol ruky, akoby ich mal popálené.

TEXT_SOURCE: At the same moment the kit-bag gave a faint, but unmistakable, lurch forward towards the door.
VETA: V tom istom momente sa taška slabo, ale nezameniteľne pohla smerom k dverám.

TEXT_SOURCE: Johnson collapsed backwards, searching with his hands for the support of something solid, and the door, being further behind him than he realized, received his weight just in time to prevent his falling, and shut to with a resounding bang.
VETA: Johnson sa zrútil dozadu, rukami hľadal oporu o niečo pevné, a dvere, ktoré boli ďalej za ním, než si uvedomoval, prijali jeho váhu práve včas, aby zabránili jeho pádu, a zavreli sa so silným buchnutím.

TEXT_SOURCE: At the same moment the swinging of his left arm accidentally touched the electric switch, and the light in the room went out.
VETA: V tom istom momente sa švih jeho ľavej ruky náhodou dotkol elektrického vypínača a svetlo v miestnosti zhaslo.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was an awkward and disagreeable predicament, and if Johnson had not been possessed of real pluck he might have done all manner of foolish things.
VETA: Bola to nepríjemná a nepríjemná situácia, a keby Johnson nebol posadnutý skutočným trhnutím, mohol by robiť všetky druhy hlúpostí.

TEXT_SOURCE: As it was, however, he pulled himself together, and groped furiously for the little brass knob to turn the light on again.
VETA: Ako to však bolo, stiahol sa a zúrivo hľadal malý mosadzný gombík, aby opäť rozsvietil svetlo.

TEXT_SOURCE: But the rapid closing of the door had set the coats hanging on it a-swinging, and his fingers became entangled in a confusion of sleeves and pockets, so that it was some moments before he found the switch.
VETA: Ale rýchle zatvorenie dverí spôsobilo, že kabáty, ktoré na nich viseli, sa rozkývali a jeho prsty sa zaplietli do zmätku rukávov a vreciek, takže chvíľu trvalo, kým našiel vypínač.

TEXT_SOURCE: And in those few moments of bewilderment and terror two things happened that sent him beyond recall over the boundary into the region of genuine horror— he distinctly heard the kit-bag shuffling heavily across the floor in jerks, and close in front of his face sounded once again the sigh of a human being.
VETA: A v tých niekoľkých chvíľach zmätku a hrôzy sa stali dve veci, ktoré ho nepamätateľne poslali za hranicu do oblasti skutočnej hrôzy – zreteľne počul, ako sa taška so súpravou trhavo šúchala po podlahe a ozvalo sa blízko pred jeho tvárou. ešte raz povzdych ľudskej bytosti.

TEXT_SOURCE: In his anguished efforts to find the brass button on the wall he nearly scraped the nails from his fingers, but even then, in those frenzied moments of alarm—so swift and alert are the impressions of a mind keyed-up by a vivid emotion—he had time to realize that he dreaded the return of the light, and that it might be better for him to stay hidden in the merciful screen of darkness.
VETA: Vo svojom útrpnom úsilí nájsť mosadzný gombík na stene si takmer odškrabal nechty z prstov, ale aj vtedy, v tých šialených chvíľach poplachu – také rýchle a ostražité sú dojmy mysle naštartovanej živými emóciami – mal čas si uvedomiť, že sa obával návratu svetla a že by pre neho možno bolo lepšie zostať skrytý v milosrdnej clone temnoty.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was but the impulse of a moment, however, and before he had time to act upon it he had yielded automatically to the original desire, and the room was flooded again with light.
VETA: Bol to však len chvíľkový impulz a skôr, než ho stihol zareagovať, automaticky sa podvolil pôvodnej túžbe a miestnosť opäť zalialo svetlo.

TEXT_SOURCE: But the second instinct had been right.
VETA: Ale druhý inštinkt mal pravdu.

TEXT_SOURCE: It would have been better for him to have stayed in the shelter of the kind darkness. For there, close before him, bending over the half-packed kit-bag, clear as life in the merciless glare of the electric light, stood the figure of John Turk, the murderer.
VETA: Bolo by pre neho lepšie, keby zostal v úkryte láskavej tmy. Lebo tam, blízko pred ním, zohnutá nad napoly zbalenou taškou, čistá ako život v nemilosrdnom žiarení elektrického svetla, stála postava vraha Jána Turka.

TEXT_SOURCE: Not three feet from him the man stood, the fringe of black hair marked plainly against the pallor of the forehead, the whole horrible presentment of the scoundrel, as vivid as he had seen him day after day in the Old Bailey, when he stood there in the dock, cynical and callous, under the very shadow of the gallows.
VETA: Ani tri stopy od neho stál muž, strapec čiernych vlasov zreteľne zvýraznený proti bledosti čela, celá strašná podoba toho darebáka, taká živá, ako ho videl deň čo deň v Old Bailey, keď tam stál. na lavici obžalovaných, cynický a bezcitný, v samom tieni šibenice.

TEXT_SOURCE: In a flash Johnson realized what it all meant: the dirty and much-used bag; the smear of crimson within the top; the dreadful stretched condition of the bulging sides.
VETA: Johnson si bleskovo uvedomil, čo to všetko znamená: špinavá a často používaná taška; karmínová škvrna na vrchu; strašný natiahnutý stav vydutých strán.

TEXT_SOURCE: He remembered how the victim's body had been stuffed into a canvas bag for burial, the ghastly, dismembered fragments forced with lime into this very bag; and the bag itself produced as evidence—it all came back to him as clear as Very softly and stealthily his hand groped behind him for the handle of the door, but before he could actually turn it the very thing that he most of all dreaded came about, and John Turk lifted his devil's face and looked at him.
VETA: Spomenul si, ako telo obete napchali do plátenného vreca na pohreb, príšerné, rozštvrtené úlomky vtlačili vápnom práve do tohto vreca; a samotná taška bola dôkazom – všetko sa mu vrátilo tak jasné, ako veľmi jemne a pokradmu jeho ruka za ním šmátrala po kľučke dverí, no skôr, ako ňou stihol otočiť, prišla tá vec, ktorej sa najviac zo všetkého bál. a Ján Turek zdvihol svoju diabolskú tvár a pozrel na neho.

TEXT_SOURCE: At the same moment that heavy sigh passed through the air of the room, formulated somehow into words: 'It's my bag.
VETA: V tom istom okamihu prešiel vzduchom miestnosti ťažký povzdych, sformulovaný akosi do slov: To je moja taška.

TEXT_SOURCE: And I want it.'
VETA: A ja to chcem.

TEXT_SOURCE: Johnson just remembered clawing the door open, and then falling in a heap upon the floor of the landing, as he tried frantically to make his way into the front room.
VETA: Johnson si práve pamätal, ako otvoril dvere pazúrom a potom spadol na hromadu na podlahu odpočívadla, keď sa zúfalo pokúšal dostať do prednej miestnosti.

TEXT_SOURCE: He remained unconscious for a long time, and it was still dark when he opened his eyes and realized that he was lying, stiff and bruised, on the cold boards.
VETA: Zostal dlho v bezvedomí a bola ešte tma, keď otvoril oči a uvedomil si, že leží stuhnutý a pomliaždený na studených doskách.

TEXT_SOURCE: Then the memory of what he had seen rushed back into his mind, and he promptly fainted again.
VETA: Potom sa mu do mysle vrátila spomienka na to, čo videl, a okamžite znova omdlel.

TEXT_SOURCE: When he woke the second time the wintry dawn was just beginning to peep in at the windows, painting the stairs a cheerless, dismal grey, and he managed to crawl into the front room, and cover himself with an overcoat in the armchair, where at length he fell asleep.
VETA: Keď sa druhýkrát prebudil, zimný úsvit práve začínal nakúkať do okien a maľoval schody na neveselú, pochmúrnu sivú, a podarilo sa mu vliezť do prednej izby a zakryť sa kabátom v kresle, kde o dĺžky zaspal.

TEXT_SOURCE: A great clamour woke him.
VETA: Zobudil ho veľký krik.

TEXT_SOURCE: He recognized Mrs Monks's voice, loud and voluble.
VETA: Spoznal hlas pani Monksovej, hlasný a výrečný.

TEXT_SOURCE: What!
VETA: Čo!

TEXT_SOURCE: You ain't been to bed, sir!
VETA: Neboli ste v posteli, pane!

TEXT_SOURCE: Are you ill, or has anything 'appened?
VETA: Si chorý, alebo sa ti niečo prihodilo?

TEXT_SOURCE: And there's an urgent gentleman to see you, though it ain't seven o'clock yet, and—' 'Who is it? 'he stammered.
VETA: A je tu naliehavý pán, ktorý vás má vidieť, hoci ešte nie je sedem hodín, a – Kto to je? ' koktal.

TEXT_SOURCE: I'm all right, thanks.
VETA: Som v poriadku, ďakujem.

TEXT_SOURCE: Fell asleep in my chair, I suppose.'
VETA: Myslím, že som zaspal v kresle.

TEXT_SOURCE: Someone from Mr Wilb'rim's, and he says he ought to see you quick before you go abroad, and I told him—' 'Show him up, please, at once,' said Johnson, whose head was whirling, and his mind was still full of dreadful visions.
VETA: Niekto od pána Wilb'rima a hovorí, že by vás mal rýchlo vidieť, kým odídete do zahraničia, a povedal som mu – Ukážte ho, prosím, ihneď, povedal Johnson, ktorému sa točila hlava a jeho myseľ bola stále plná strašných vízií.

TEXT_SOURCE: Mr Wilbraham's man came in with many apologies, and explained briefly and quickly that an absurd mistake had been made, and that the wrong kit-bag had been sent over the night before. '
VETA: Muž pána Wilbrahama prišiel s mnohými ospravedlneniami a stručne a rýchlo vysvetlil, že došlo k absurdnej chybe a že v noci predtým bola odoslaná nesprávna taška. '

TEXT_SOURCE: Henry somehow got hold of the one that came over from the courtroom, and Mr Wilbraham only discovered it when he saw his own lying in his room, and asked why it had not gone to you ' the man said.
VETA: Henry sa nejakým spôsobom dostal k tej, ktorá prišla zo súdnej siene, a pán Wilbraham ju objavil, až keď uvidel svoju vlastnú ležať v jeho izbe a spýtal sa, prečo sa nedostal k vám, povedal muž.

TEXT_SOURCE: Oh!' said Johnson stupidly.'
VETA: Oh!' povedal Johnson hlúpo.

TEXT_SOURCE: And he must have brought you the one from the murder case instead, sir, I'm afraid, ' the man continued, without the ghost of an expression on his face.'
VETA: A namiesto toho vám musel priniesť toho z prípadu vraždy, pane, obávam sa, pokračoval muž bez ducha výrazu na tvári.

TEXT_SOURCE: The one John Turk packed the dead body in, Mr Wilbraham's awful upset about it, sir, and told me to come over first thing this morning with the right one, as you were leaving by the boat. '
VETA: Toho, do ktorého John Turk zbalil mŕtve telo, bol z toho pán Wilbraham strašne rozrušený, pane, a povedal mi, aby som dnes ráno prišiel ako prvý s tým správnym, keď ste odchádzali loďou. '

TEXT_SOURCE: He pointed to a clean-looking kit-bag on the floor, which he had just brought.
VETA: Ukázal na čisto vyzerajúcu tašku na súpravu na podlahe, ktorú si práve priniesol.

TEXT_SOURCE: And I was to bring the other one back, sir,' he added casually.
VETA: A toho druhého som mal priviesť späť, pane, dodal nenútene.

TEXT_SOURCE: For some minutes Johnson could not find his voice.
VETA: Johnson niekoľko minút nemohol nájsť svoj hlas.

TEXT_SOURCE: At last he pointed in the direction of his bedroom.
VETA: Nakoniec ukázal smerom k svojej spálni.

TEXT_SOURCE: Perhaps you would kindly unpack it for me.
VETA: Možno by ste mi to láskavo rozbalili.

TEXT_SOURCE: Just empty the things out on the floor.'
VETA: Len vyprázdnite veci na podlahe.

TEXT_SOURCE: The man disappeared into the other room, and was gone for five minutes.
VETA: Muž zmizol v druhej miestnosti a bol preč päť minút.

TEXT_SOURCE: Johnson heard the shifting to and fro of the bag, and the rattle of the skates and boots being unpacked.
VETA: Johnson počul posúvanie tašky a rachot vybaľovania korčúľ a topánok.

TEXT_SOURCE: Thank you, sir, ' the man said, returning with the bag folded over his arm.
VETA: Ďakujem, pane, povedal muž a vrátil sa s taškou preloženou cez ruku.

TEXT_SOURCE: And can I do anything more to help you, sir?'
VETA: A môžem urobiť ešte niečo, aby som vám pomohol, pane?

TEXT_SOURCE: What is it?' asked Johnson, seeing that he still had something he wished to say.
VETA: Čo je to?' spýtal sa Johnson, keď videl, že má stále niečo, čo by chcel povedať.

TEXT_SOURCE: The man shuffled and looked mysterious.
VETA: Muž sa zamiešal a vyzeral záhadne.

TEXT_SOURCE: Beg pardon, sir, but knowing your interest in the Turk case, I thought you'd maybe like to know what's happened—' 'Yes.'
VETA: Prepáčte, pane, ale keďže som poznal váš záujem o prípad Turkov, myslel som si, že by ste možno chceli vedieť, čo sa stalo – Áno.

TEXT_SOURCE: John Turk killed hisself last night with poison immediately on getting his release, and he left a note for Mr Wilbraham saying as he'd be much obliged if they'd have him put away, same as the woman he murdered, in the old kit-bag.'
VETA: John Turk sa minulú noc zabil jedom hneď po prepustení a nechal odkaz pánovi Wilbrahamovi, že by bol veľmi zaviazaný, keby ho dali preč, rovnako ako ženu, ktorú zavraždil, v starej súprave. -taška.'

TEXT_SOURCE: What time—did he do it?' asked Johnson.
VETA: O koľkej — urobil to? spýtal sa Johnson.

TEXT_SOURCE: Ten o'clock last night, sir, the warder says.'
VETA: Včera večer o desiatej, pane, hovorí dozorca.

TEXT_SOURCE: Dear Mr Moser On the afternoon of June 25 while on my last outing to Rhyolite, I was driving down Cane Springs Road some ten miles outside Beatty and happened upon what looked to be the debris left over from an auto accident.
VETA: Vážený pán Moser Popoludní 25. júna počas mojej poslednej vychádzky do Rhyolite som išiel po Cane Springs Road asi desať míľ od Beatty a narazil som na niečo, čo vyzeralo ako trosky, ktoré zostali po autonehode.

TEXT_SOURCE: I got out of my truck and took a look around.
VETA: Vystúpil som z auta a poobzeral sa okolo.

TEXT_SOURCE: The valley was bone dry.
VETA: Údolie bolo suché na kosti.

TEXT_SOURCE: A hot west wind took the puffs of dust from where I stepped and curled them away like ashes.
VETA: Horúci západný vietor vzal kúdoly prachu z miesta, kde som vystúpil, a skrútil ich ako popol.

TEXT_SOURCE: Near the wash I found broken glass, deep gouges in the dirt running off the side of the road, and an array of freshly bought groceries tumbled among the creosote.
VETA: Neďaleko umývadla som našiel rozbité sklo, hlboké ryhy v špine stekajúce z kraja cesty a medzi kreozotom sa povaľoval rad čerstvo nakúpených potravín.

TEXT_SOURCE: Coke cans (some full, some open and empty, some still sealed but dented and half full and leaking).
VETA: Plechovky od koksu (niektoré plné, niektoré otvorené a prázdne, niektoré stále zapečatené, ale pretlačené a poloplné a netesné).

TEXT_SOURCE: Bud Light cans in the same shape as the Coke. Fritos. Meat. Et cetera.
VETA: Plechovky Bud Light v rovnakom tvare ako Coca-Cola. Fritos. Mäso. A tak dalej.

TEXT_SOURCE: Of particular interest to me were the two almost-full prescriptions that had been filled at the pharmacy in Tonopah only three days before, and a sealed Ziploc bag full of letters signed M.
VETA: Osobitne ma zaujali dva takmer plné recepty, ktoré boli vyplnené v lekárni v Tonopah len pred tromi dňami, a zapečatená taška Ziploc plná listov s podpisom M.

TEXT_SOURCE: I also took notice of a bundle of photos of an old car, part primer, part rust, that I presume was or is going to be restored.
VETA: Všimol som si aj zväzok fotiek starého auta, časti základného náteru, časti hrdze, o ktorej predpokladám, že bola alebo bude zrekonštruovaná.

TEXT_SOURCE: The car was a Chevy Chevelle, a ’66, I believe.
VETA: Myslím, že to auto bolo Chevy Chevelle z roku '66.

TEXT_SOURCE: I once knew a man who drove a Chevelle.
VETA: Raz som poznal muža, ktorý šoféroval Chevelle.

TEXT_SOURCE: Both medications had bright yellow stickers on their sides warning against drinking alcohol while taking them.
VETA: Oba lieky mali na bokoch jasne žlté nálepky varujúce pred pitím alkoholu počas užívania.

TEXT_SOURCE: I copied your address off those prescription bottles.
VETA: Skopíroval som vašu adresu z tých liekoviek na predpis.

TEXT_SOURCE: What were you looking for out at Rhyolite?
VETA: Čo ste hľadali v Rhyolite?

TEXT_SOURCE: I hope this letter finds you, and finds you well.
VETA: Dúfam, že vás tento list nájde a bude vám dobre.

TEXT_SOURCE: Please write back.
VETA: Prosím odpíš späť.

TEXT_SOURCE: Truly, Thomas Grey PO Box 129, Verdi Nevada 89439
VETA: Truly, Thomas Grey PO Box 129, Verdi Nevada 89439

TEXT_SOURCE: PS: I left most of the debris in the desert, save for the medications, pictures and letters from M.
VETA: PS: Väčšinu trosiek som nechal v púšti, okrem liekov, obrázkov a listov od M.

TEXT_SOURCE: I also took the plastic grocery bags, which I untangled from the bushes and recycled on my way through Reno.
VETA: Zobral som si aj igelitové tašky s potravinami, ktoré som cestou cez Reno rozmotal z kríkov a zrecykloval.

TEXT_SOURCE: It didn’t feel right to just leave them out there.
VETA: Nezdalo sa mi správne nechať ich tam vonku.

TEXT_SOURCE: Dear Mr Moser
VETA: Vážený pán Moser

TEXT_SOURCE: This morning, as I fed the horses, clouds were just beginning to slide down the slope of the Sierras, and I was reminded once again of Rhyolite.
VETA: Dnes ráno, keď som kŕmil kone, sa po svahu Sierras práve začali sťahovať oblaky a opäť som si pripomenul Rhyolite.

TEXT_SOURCE: When I came inside I borrowed my father’s old copy of the Physician‘s Desk Reference from his room.
VETA: Keď som vošiel dnu, požičal som si otcovu starú kópiu Referencie lekára z jeho izby.

TEXT_SOURCE: From that book I have gathered that before driving out to Rhyolite you may have been feeling out of control, alone, or hopeless.
VETA: Z tejto knihy som usúdil, že predtým, ako ste vyšli do Rhyolite, ste sa mohli cítiť nekontrolovateľne, osamelo alebo beznádejne.

TEXT_SOURCE: You were possibly in a state of extreme depression; perhaps you were even considering hurting yourself.
VETA: Možno ste boli v stave extrémnej depresie; možno ste dokonca uvažovali o tom, že si ublížite.

TEXT_SOURCE: Judging by the date the prescriptions were filled and the number of pills left in the bottles – which I have counted, sitting out in the fields atop a tractor which I let sputter and die, eating the sandwich which my wife fixed me for lunch – you had not been taking the medications long enough for them to counteract your possible feelings of despair.
VETA: Súdiac podľa dátumu naplnenia receptov a počtu tabliet, ktoré zostali vo fľašiach – čo som spočítal, sedel som na poli na traktore, ktorý som nechal prskať a umrel, jedol sendvič, ktorý mi pripravila moja žena na obed – ty neužívali lieky dostatočne dlho na to, aby potlačili vaše možné pocity zúfalstva.

TEXT_SOURCE: ‘Despair’, ‘depression’, ‘hopeless’, ‘alone’.
VETA: Zúfalstvo, depresia, beznádej, sama.

TEXT_SOURCE: These are the words of the PDR, 41st Edition, which I returned to my father promptly, as per his request.
VETA: Toto sú slová PDR, 41. vydanie, ktoré som okamžite vrátil otcovi na jeho žiadosť.

TEXT_SOURCE: My father can be difficult.
VETA: Môj otec vie byť ťažký.

TEXT_SOURCE: He spends his days shut up in his room, reading old crime novels populated by dames and Negroes, or watching the TV we bought him with the volume up too high.
VETA: Dni trávi zavretý vo svojej izbe čítaním starých kriminálnych románov obsadených dámami a černochmi alebo pozeraním televízora, ktorý sme mu kúpili, s príliš vysokou hlasitosťou.

TEXT_SOURCE: Some days he refuses to eat.
VETA: Niektoré dni odmieta jesť.

TEXT_SOURCE: Duane Moser, my father never thought he would live this long.
VETA: Duane Moser, môj otec si nikdy nemyslel, že bude žiť tak dlho.

TEXT_SOURCE: I think there will be lightning tonight; the air has that feel.
VETA: Myslím, že dnes večer budú blesky; vzduch má ten pocit.

TEXT_SOURCE: Please, write back.
VETA: Prosím odpíš späť.

TEXT_SOURCE: Truly, Thomas Grey
VETA: Naozaj, Thomas Gray

TEXT_SOURCE: Dear Mr Moser I slept terribly last night, dreamed dreams not easily identified as such.
VETA: Vážený pán Moser, minulú noc som strašne spal, snívali sa mi sny, ktoré sa ako také nedajú ľahko identifikovať.

TEXT_SOURCE: Had I told my wife about them she might have given me a small quartz crystal or amethyst and insisted I carry it around in my pocket all day, to cleanse my mind and spirit.
VETA: Keby som o nich povedal svojej žene, možno by mi dala malý kremenný kryštál alebo ametyst a trvala na tom, aby som ho celý deň nosil vo vrecku, aby som si vyčistil myseľ a ducha.

TEXT_SOURCE: She comes from California.
VETA: Pochádza z Kalifornie.

TEXT_SOURCE: Here is a story she likes to tell.
VETA: Tu je príbeh, ktorý rada rozpráva.

TEXT_SOURCE: On one of our first dates we walked arm in arm around downtown Reno, where she was a clerk at a grocery store and I was a student of agriculture and business.
VETA: Na jednom z našich prvých stretnutí sme kráčali ruka v ruke po centre Rena, kde ona bola predavačkou v obchode s potravinami a ja som bol študentom poľnohospodárstva a obchodu.

TEXT_SOURCE: There she tried to pull me down a little flight of steps to the red-lit underground residence of a palm reader and psychic.
VETA: Tam sa ma pokúsila stiahnuť po malých schodoch do červeno osvetlenej podzemnej rezidencie čitateľa dlaní a jasnovidca.

TEXT_SOURCE: I declined.
VETA: odmietol som.

TEXT_SOURCE: Damn near an hour she pulled on me, saying what was I afraid of, asking what was the big deal.
VETA: Do pekla skoro hodinu si ma pritiahla, povedala, čoho som sa bála, spýtala sa, čo je na tom veľký problém.

TEXT_SOURCE: I am not a religious man but, as I told her then, there are some things I’d rather not fuck with.
VETA: Nie som nábožensky založený muž, ale ako som jej vtedy povedal, sú niektoré veci, s ktorými by som sa radšej neposral.

TEXT_SOURCE: Now she likes to say it’s a good thing I wouldn’t go in because if that psychic had told her that she’d be stuck with me for going on fourteen years now she would have turned and headed for the hills.
VETA: Teraz rada hovorí, že je dobrá vec, že by som do toho nešiel, pretože keby jej ten jasnovidec povedal, že by sa so mnou držala štrnásť rokov, otočila by sa a zamierila do kopcov.

TEXT_SOURCE: Ha!
VETA: On má!

TEXT_SOURCE: And I say, Honey, not as fast as I would’ve, ha, ha!
VETA: A ja hovorím: Zlato, nie tak rýchlo, ako by som to urobil, ha, ha!

TEXT_SOURCE: This is our old joke.
VETA: Toto je náš starý vtip.

TEXT_SOURCE: Like all our memories, we like to take it out once in a while and lay it flat on the kitchen table, the way my wife does with her sewing patterns, where we line up the shape of our life against that which we thought it would be by now.
VETA: Ako všetky naše spomienky, aj my ho radi raz za čas vytiahneme a položíme naplocho na kuchynský stôl, ako to robí moja žena so svojimi šijacími vzormi, kde si tvarujeme svoj život s tým, o čom sme si mysleli, že bude. byť už teraz.

TEXT_SOURCE: I’ll tell you what I don’t tell her, that there is something shameful in this, the buoying of our sinking spirits with old stories.
VETA: Poviem vám, čo jej nepoviem, že v tom je niečo hanebné, preháňanie našich potápajúcich sa duchov starými príbehmi.

TEXT_SOURCE: I imagine you a man alone, Duane Moser, with no one asking after your dreams in the morning, no one slipping healing rocks into your pockets.
VETA: Predstavujem si ťa samého, Duane Moser, bez toho, aby sa ti ráno nikto nepýtal na tvoje sny, nikto ti nevsúva liečivé kamene do vreciek.

TEXT_SOURCE: A bachelor.
VETA: Mládenec.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was the Fritos, finally, which reminded me of the gas station in Beatty where I worked when I was in high school and where I knew a man who owned a Chevelle like yours, a ’66.
VETA: Nakoniec to bol Fritos, ktorý mi pripomenul čerpaciu stanicu v Beatty, kde som pracoval, keď som bol na strednej škole a kde som poznal muža, ktorý vlastnil Chevelle, ako je tá vaša, 66.

TEXT_SOURCE: But it occurs to me perhaps this assumption is foolish; surely there are wives out there who have not banned trans fats and processed sugars, as mine has.
VETA: Ale zdá sa mi, že možno je tento predpoklad hlúpy; určite sú tam manželky, ktoré nezakázali trans-tuky a spracované cukry, ako to urobila moja.

TEXT_SOURCE: I haven’t had a Frito in eleven years.
VETA: Frito som nemal jedenásť rokov.

TEXT_SOURCE: Regardless, I write to enquire about your family, should you reply.
VETA: Bez ohľadu na to píšem, aby som sa spýtal na vašu rodinu, ak by ste odpovedali.

TEXT_SOURCE: Our children came to us later in life than most.
VETA: Naše deti k nám prišli neskôr v živote ako väčšina.

TEXT_SOURCE: My oldest, Danielle, has just started school.
VETA: Moja najstaršia, Danielle, práve začala chodiť do školy.

TEXT_SOURCE: Her little sister, Layla, is having a hard time with it.
VETA: Jej malá sestra Layla to má ťažké.

TEXT_SOURCE: She wants so badly to go to school with Danielle that she screams and cries as the school bus pulls away in the morning.
VETA: Tak veľmi chce ísť s Danielle do školy, že kričí a plače, keď školský autobus ráno odchádza.

TEXT_SOURCE: Sometimes she throws herself down to the ground, embedding little pieces of rock in the flesh of her fists.
VETA: Niekedy sa vrhne na zem a do pästí vloží malé kúsky kameňa.

TEXT_SOURCE: Then she is sullen and forlorn for the rest of the day.
VETA: Potom je po zvyšok dňa namosúrená a opustená.

TEXT_SOURCE: My wife worries for her, but truth be told, I am encouraged.
VETA: Moja žena sa o ňu bojí, ale pravdupovediac, povzbudzuje ma to.

TEXT_SOURCE: The sooner Layla understands that we are nothing but the sum of that which we endure, the better.
VETA: Čím skôr Layla pochopí, že nie sme nič iné ako súčet toho, čo znášame, tým lepšie.

TEXT_SOURCE: But my father has taken to walking Layla to the end of our gravel road in the afternoon to wait for Danielle at the bus stop.
VETA: Ale môj otec sa poobede rozhodol prejsť s Laylou na koniec našej štrkovej cesty, aby počkal na Danielle na autobusovej zastávke.

TEXT_SOURCE: Layla likes to go as early as she is allowed, as if her being there will bring the bus sooner.
VETA: Layla rada chodí tak skoro, ako jej to dovolia, ako keby tam bol autobus skôr.

TEXT_SOURCE: She would stand at the end of the road all day if we let her.
VETA: Celý deň by stála na konci cesty, keby sme jej to dovolili.

TEXT_SOURCE: She pesters my father so that he sometimes stands there in the heat with her for an hour or more, though his heart is in no condition to be doing so.
VETA: Otravuje môjho otca tak, že tam s ňou niekedy stojí v teple hodinu alebo aj viac, hoci jeho srdce nie je v stave, aby to urobil.

TEXT_SOURCE: In many ways he is better to my girls than I am.
VETA: V mnohých ohľadoch je pre moje dievčatá lepší ako ja.

TEXT_SOURCE: He is far better to them than he was to me.
VETA: Je k nim oveľa lepší ako bol ku mne.

TEXT_SOURCE: I am not a religious manbut I do thank God for that.
VETA: Nie som veriaci, ale ďakujem za to Bohu.

TEXT_SOURCE: I am beginning to think I dreamed you up.
VETA: Začínam si myslieť, že som si ťa vysníval.

TEXT_SOURCE: Please, write soon.
VETA: Prosím, napíšte čoskoro.

TEXT_SOURCE: Truly, Thomas Grey PO Box 129, Verdi Nevada 89439
VETA: Truly, Thomas Grey PO Box 129, Verdi Nevada 89439

TEXT_SOURCE: Dear Mr Moser
VETA: Vážený pán Moser

TEXT_SOURCE: I have read the letters from M, the ones you kept folded in the Ziploc bag.
VETA: Prečítal som si písmená od M, tie, ktoré si mal zložené v taške Ziploc.

TEXT_SOURCE: Forgive me, but for all I know you may be dead, and I could not resist.
VETA: Odpusť mi, ale napriek tomu, čo viem, môžeš byť mŕtvy a ja som nemohol odolať.

TEXT_SOURCE: I read them in my shed, where the stink and thickness of the air were almost unbearable, and then again in my truck in the parking lot of the Verdi post office.
VETA: Čítal som ich vo svojej kôlni, kde bol smrad a hustota vzduchu takmer neznesiteľná, a potom opäť v kamióne na parkovisku Verdiho pošty.

TEXT_SOURCE: I was struck, as I was when I first found them out near Rhyolite on Cane Springs Road, by how new the letters looked.
VETA: Bol som prekvapený, rovnako ako keď som ich prvýkrát našiel neďaleko Rhyolite na Cane Springs Road, ako nové písmená vyzerali.

TEXT_SOURCE: Though most were written nearly twenty years ago the paper is clean, the creases sharp.
VETA: Hoci väčšina z nich bola napísaná takmer pred dvadsiatimi rokmi, papier je čistý, záhyby ostré.

TEXT_SOURCE: Duane Moser, what I do not understand is this: why a Ziploc bag?
VETA: Duane Moser, čomu nerozumiem, je toto: prečo taška Ziploc?

TEXT_SOURCE: Did you worry they might get wet on your journey through the desert in the middle of summer?
VETA: Obávali ste sa, že by mohli zmoknúť na vašej ceste púšťou uprostred leta?

TEXT_SOURCE: Then again, I am reminded of the Coke and Bud Light.
VETA: Potom sa mi opäť vybaví Coca-Cola a Bud Light.

TEXT_SOURCE: Or am I to take the Ziploc bag as an indication of your fierce, protective love for M. ?
VETA: Alebo mám brať tašku Ziploc ako prejav tvojej divokej, ochranárskej lásky k M.?

TEXT_SOURCE: Is it a sign, as M. suggests, that little by little you sealed your whole self off, until there was nothing left for her?
VETA: Je to znamenie, ako naznačuje M., že si postupne celé svoje ja uzavrel, až jej nezostalo nič?

TEXT_SOURCE: Furthermore, I have to ask whether you committed this sealing purposefully.
VETA: Ďalej sa musím opýtať, či ste sa tohto pečatenia dopustili účelovo.

TEXT_SOURCE: She says she thinks she was always asking too much of you.
VETA: Hovorí, že si myslí, že od teba vždy žiadala príliš veľa.

TEXT_SOURCE: She is generous that way, isn’t she?
VETA: Takto je štedrá, však?

TEXT_SOURCE: She says you didn’t mean to become ‘so very alien’ to her.
VETA: Hovorí, že ste nechceli byť pre ňu ‚tak veľmi cudzí‘.

TEXT_SOURCE: I am not so sure.
VETA: nie som si taký istý.

TEXT_SOURCE: I love my wife. But I’ve never told her how I once knew a man in Beatty with a ’66 Chevelle.
VETA: Milujem svoju ženu. Ale nikdy som jej nepovedal, ako som kedysi poznal muža v Beatty s Chevelle z roku 1966.

TEXT_SOURCE: I know what men like us are capable of.
VETA: Viem, čoho sú muži ako my schopní.

TEXT_SOURCE: Duane Moser, what I come back to is this: how could you have left M. ’s letters by the side of Cane Springs Road near the ghost town Rhyolite where hardly anyone goes any more?
VETA: Duane Moser, vraciam sa k tomuto: ako si mohol nechať listy M. vedľa Cane Springs Road pri meste duchov Rhyolite, kam už takmer nikto nechodí?

TEXT_SOURCE: (In fact, I have never seen another man out on Cane Springs Road.
VETA: (V skutočnosti som na Cane Springs Road nikdy nevidel iného muža.

TEXT_SOURCE: I drive out there to be alone.
VETA: Jazdím tam, aby som bol sám.

TEXT_SOURCE: Maybe you do, too.
VETA: Možno aj vy.

TEXT_SOURCE: Or you did, anyway. )
VETA: Alebo si to urobil. )

TEXT_SOURCE: Did you not realize that someone just like you might find them?
VETA: Neuvedomili ste si, že by ich mohol nájsť niekto ako vy?

TEXT_SOURCE: How could you have left her again?
VETA: Ako si ju mohol znova opustiť?

TEXT_SOURCE: I have called the phone number listed on the prescription bottles, finally, though all I heard was the steady rising tones of the disconnected signal.
VETA: Nakoniec som zavolal na telefónne číslo uvedené na fľaštičkách s predpismi, hoci som počul len stále stúpajúce tóny odpojeného signálu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Still, I found myself listening for you there.
VETA: Napriek tomu som zistil, že ťa tam počúvam.

TEXT_SOURCE: Please, write soon.
VETA: Prosím, napíšte čoskoro.

TEXT_SOURCE: Truly, Thomas Grey PO Box 129, Verdi Nevada 89439
VETA: Truly, Thomas Grey PO Box 129, Verdi Nevada 89439

TEXT_SOURCE: PS On second thoughts, perhaps sometimes these things are best left by the side of the road, as it were.
VETA: PS Na druhej strane, možno je niekedy lepšie nechať tieto veci takpovediac na okraji cesty.

TEXT_SOURCE: Sometimes a person wants a part of you that’s no good.
VETA: Niekedy človek chce časť z vás, ktorá nie je dobrá.

TEXT_SOURCE: Sometimes love is a wound that opens and closes, opens and closes, all our lives.
VETA: Niekedy je láska ranou, ktorá sa otvára a zatvára, otvára a zatvára, celý náš život.

TEXT_SOURCE: My wife found your pictures, the ones of the Chevelle.
VETA: Moja žena našla tvoje obrázky, tie Chevelle.

TEXT_SOURCE: The one you maybe got from a junkyard or from a friend, or maybe it’s been in your family for years, rotting in a garage somewhere because after what happened nobody wanted to look at it.
VETA: Ten, ktorý si možno dostal zo smetiska alebo od priateľa, alebo ho možno roky nosíš v rodine, hnije niekde v garáži, pretože po tom, čo sa stalo, sa naň nikto nechcel pozerať.

TEXT_SOURCE: I kept the pictures tucked behind the visor in my truck, bound with a rubber band.
VETA: Obrázky som mal zastrčené za priezorom v kamióne, zviazané gumičkou.

TEXT_SOURCE: I don’t know why I kept them.
VETA: Neviem, prečo som si ich nechal.

TEXT_SOURCE: I don’t know why I’ve kept your letters from M. , or your medications.
VETA: Neviem, prečo som si nechal vaše listy od M. alebo vaše lieky.

TEXT_SOURCE: I don’t know what I would do if I found what I am looking for.
VETA: Neviem, čo by som robil, keby som našiel to, čo hľadám.

TEXT_SOURCE: When I was in high school I worked the graveyard shift at a gas station in Beatty.
VETA: Keď som bol na strednej škole, pracoval som na cintoríne na čerpacej stanici v Beatty.

TEXT_SOURCE: It’s still there, on the corner of I-95 and Highway 374, near the hot springs.
VETA: Stále je tam, na rohu I-95 a diaľnice 374, v blízkosti horúcich prameňov.

TEXT_SOURCE: Maybe you’ve been there.
VETA: možno ste tam boli.

TEXT_SOURCE: It’s a Shell station now, but back then it was called Hadley’sFuel.
VETA: Teraz je to stanica Shell, ale vtedy sa volala Hadley'sFuel.

TEXT_SOURCE: I worked there forty, fifty hours a week.
VETA: Pracoval som tam štyridsať, päťdesiat hodín týždenne.

TEXT_SOURCE: Bill Hadley was a friend of my father’s.
VETA: Bill Hadley bol priateľom môjho otca.

TEXT_SOURCE: He was a crazy sonofabitch, as my father would say, who kept a shotgun under the counter and always accused me of stealing from the till or sleeping on the job when I did neither.
VETA: Bol to šialený mrcha, ako by povedal môj otec, ktorý držal brokovnicu pod pultom a vždy ma obviňoval, že kradnem na pokladni alebo spím v práci, keď som nerobil ani jedno.

TEXT_SOURCE: I liked the graveyard shift, liked being up at night, away from Pop, listening to the tremors of the big walk-in coolers, the hum of the fluorescent lights outside.
VETA: Páčila sa mi smena na cintoríne, páčilo sa mi byť v noci hore, ďaleko od Popa, počúvať chvenie veľkých chladiacich boxov, hukot žiariviek vonku.

TEXT_SOURCE: Late that spring a swarm of grasshoppers moved through Beatty on their way out to the alfalfa fields down south.
VETA: Neskoro na jar sa cez Beatty presunul roj kobyliek na ceste von na lucernové polia na juh.

TEXT_SOURCE: They were thick and fierce, roaring like a thunderstorm in your head.
VETA: Boli husté a prudké, vo vašej hlave hučali ako búrka.

TEXT_SOURCE: The hoppers ate anything green.
VETA: Násypníci jedli čokoľvek zelené.

TEXT_SOURCE: In two days they stripped the leaves from all the cottonwoods and willows in town, then they moved on to the juniper and pine, the cheat grass and bitter salt cedar.
VETA: Za dva dni zbavili lístia zo všetkých topolov a vŕb v meste, potom sa presunuli k borievke a borovici, tráve a horkému slanému cédru.

TEXT_SOURCE: A swarm of them ate the wool right off of Abel Prince’s live sheep.
VETA: Roj z nich zožral vlnu priamo zo živých oviec Abela Prince.

TEXT_SOURCE: Things got so bad that the trains out to the mines shut down for a week because the guts of the bugs made the rails too slippery.
VETA: Veci sa tak zhoršili, že vlaky smerujúce do baní sa na týždeň zastavili, pretože kvôli vnútornostiam chrobákov boli koľajnice príliš šmykľavé.

TEXT_SOURCE: The grasshoppers were drawn to the fluorescent lights at Hadley’s.
VETA: Kobylky prilákali žiarivky v Hadley's.

TEXT_SOURCE: For weeks the parking lot pulsed with them.
VETA: Parkovisko nimi pulzovalo celé týždne.

TEXT_SOURCE: I would have felt them crunch under my feet when I walked out to the pumps that night, dead and dying under my shoes, only I never made it out to the pumps.
VETA: Cítila by som, ako mi v tú noc chrumkajú pod nohami, keď som v tú noc vyšla na lodičky, mŕtva a umierajúca pod topánkami, len som sa nikdy nedostala k lodičkám.

TEXT_SOURCE: I was doing schoolwork at the counter, calculus, for God’s sake.
VETA: Robil som školské úlohy pri pulte, kalkul, preboha.

TEXT_SOURCE: I looked up and the guy was already coming through the door at me.
VETA: Pozrel som sa hore a ten chlap už ku mne prichádzal dverami.

TEXT_SOURCE: I looked outside and saw the ’66 Chevelle, gleaming under the lights, grasshoppers falling all around it like rain.
VETA: Pozrel som sa von a videl som Chevelle z roku 1966, lesknúcu sa pod svetlami, kobylky padajúce všade naokolo ako dážď.

TEXT_SOURCE: I tried to stop him but he muscled back behind the counter.
VETA: Snažil som sa ho zastaviť, ale svalil sa späť za pult.

TEXT_SOURCE: He had a gun, held it like it was his own hand.
VETA: Mal zbraň, držal ju ako svoju vlastnú ruku.

TEXT_SOURCE: He said, You see this?
VETA: Povedal: Vidíš to?

TEXT_SOURCE: There was a bandanna over his face. But Beatty is a small town and it was even smaller then.
VETA: Na tvári mal šatku. Beatty je ale malé mesto a vtedy bolo ešte menšie.

TEXT_SOURCE: I knew who he was.
VETA: Vedel som, kto to je.

TEXT_SOURCE: I knew his mother worked as a waitress at the Stagecoach and that his sister had graduated the year before me.
VETA: Vedel som, že jeho matka pracovala ako čašníčka v Dostavníku a že jeho sestra skončila rok predo mnou.

TEXT_SOURCE: The money, he was saying.
VETA: Peniaze, hovoril.

TEXT_SOURCE: His name was Frankie.
VETA: Volal sa Frankie.

TEXT_SOURCE: The fucking money, Frankie said.
VETA: Tie posraté peniaze, povedal Frankie.

TEXT_SOURCE: I’d barely touched a gun before that night.
VETA: Pred tou nocou som sa sotva dotkol zbrane.

TEXT_SOURCE: I don’t know how I did it.
VETA: neviem ako sa mi to podarilo.

TEXT_SOURCE: I only felt my breath go out of me and reached under the counter to where the shotgun was and tried.
VETA: Len som cítil, ako mi vyšiel dych, siahol som pod pult, kde bola brokovnica, a skúsil som to.

TEXT_SOURCE: I shot him in the head.
VETA: Strelil som ho do hlavy.

TEXT_SOURCE: Afterwards, I called the cops.
VETA: Potom som zavolal policajtov.

TEXT_SOURCE: I did the right thing, they told me, the cops and Bill Hadley in his pyjamas, even my father.
VETA: Urobil som správnu vec, povedali mi, policajti a Bill Hadley v pyžame, dokonca aj môj otec.

TEXT_SOURCE: They said it over and over again.
VETA: Hovorili to znova a znova.

TEXT_SOURCE: I sat on the kerb outside the store listening to them inside, their boots squeaking on the tile.
VETA: Sedel som na obrubníku pred obchodom a počúval ich vnútri, čižmy im vŕzgali na dlaždici.

TEXT_SOURCE: The deputy sheriff, Dale Sullivan, who was also the assistant coach of the basketball team, came and sat beside me.
VETA: Zástupca šerifa Dale Sullivan, ktorý bol aj asistentom trénera basketbalového tímu, prišiel a posadil sa vedľa mňa.

TEXT_SOURCE: I had my hands over my head to keep the grasshoppers away.
VETA: Ruky som mal nad hlavou, aby som udržal kobylky preč.

TEXT_SOURCE: Kid, it was bound to happen, Dale said.
VETA: Chlapče, muselo sa to stať, povedal Dale.

TEXT_SOURCE: The boy was a troublemaker.
VETA: Chlapec bol problémový.

TEXT_SOURCE: A waste of skin.
VETA: Odpad kože.

TEXT_SOURCE: He told me I could go on home.
VETA: Povedal mi, že môžem ísť domov.

TEXT_SOURCE: I didn’t ask what would happen to the car.
VETA: Nepýtal som sa, čo sa stane s autom.

TEXT_SOURCE: That night, I drove out on Cane Springs Road to Rhyolite.
VETA: V tú noc som išiel po Cane Springs Road do Rhyolite.

TEXT_SOURCE: I drove around that old ghost town with the windows rolled down, listening to the gravel pop under my tyres.
VETA: Jazdil som po tom starom meste duchov so stiahnutými oknami a počúval som, ako mi pod pneumatikami praská štrk.

TEXT_SOURCE: The sun was coming up.
VETA: Slnko vychádzalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: There, in the milky light of dawn, I hated Beatty more than I ever had.
VETA: Tam, v mliečnom svetle úsvitu, som Beattyho nenávidel viac ako kedykoľvek predtým.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Stagecoach, the hot springs, all the trees looking so naked against the sky.
VETA: Dostavník, horúce pramene, všetky stromy vyzerajúce tak nahé proti oblohe.

TEXT_SOURCE: I’d never wanted to see any of it ever again.
VETA: Už nikdy som nič z toho nechcela vidieť.

TEXT_SOURCE: I was already on my way to college and everyone knew it.
VETA: Bol som už na ceste na vysokú školu a všetci to vedeli.

TEXT_SOURCE: I didn’t belong in Beatty.
VETA: Nepatril som k Beattymu.

TEXT_SOURCE: The boy’s family, his mother and sister and stepfather, moved away soon after it happened.
VETA: Chlapcova rodina, jeho matka, sestra a nevlastný otec, sa čoskoro po tom, čo sa to stalo, odsťahovali.

TEXT_SOURCE: I’d never see them around town, or at Hadley’s.
VETA: Nikdy by som ich nevidel v meste ani u Hadley's.

TEXT_SOURCE: For those last few weeks of school no one talked about it, at least not to me.
VETA: Posledných pár týždňov školy o tom nikto nehovoril, aspoň mne nie.

TEXT_SOURCE: Soon it was as though it had never happened.
VETA: Čoskoro sa zdalo, akoby sa to nikdy nestalo.

TEXT_SOURCE: But – and I think I realized this then, up in Rhyolite, that dead town picked clean – Beatty would never be a place I could come home to.
VETA: Ale – a myslím, že som si to vtedy uvedomil, hore v Rhyolite, v tom mŕtvom meste, ktoré bolo vyčistené – Beatty nikdy nebude miesto, kam by som sa mohol vrátiť.

TEXT_SOURCE: When my wife asked about your pictures, she said she didn’t realize I knew so much about cars.
VETA: Keď sa moja žena spýtala na vaše obrázky, povedala, že si neuvedomila, že viem toľko o autách.

TEXT_SOURCE: I said, Yeah, sure. Well, some. See the vents there? On the hood?
VETA: Povedal som: Áno, jasné. No, niektoré. Vidíte tam vetracie otvory? Na kapote?

TEXT_SOURCE: See the blackout grille?
VETA: Vidíte zatemňovaciu mriežku?

TEXT_SOURCE: That’s how you know it’s a ’66.
VETA: Takto viete, že ide o 66.

TEXT_SOURCE: I told her I’d been thinking about buying an old car, fixing it up, maybe this one.
VETA: Povedal som jej, že rozmýšľam nad kúpou starého auta, opravím ho, možno toto.

TEXT_SOURCE: Right then she just started laughing her head off.
VETA: Práve vtedy sa začala bezhlavo smiať.

TEXT_SOURCE: Sure, she managed through all her laughter, fix up a car.
VETA: Iste, dokázala cez všetok svoj smiech opraviť auto.

TEXT_SOURCE: She kept on laughing.
VETA: Stále sa smiala.

TEXT_SOURCE: She tossed the bundle of photos on the seat of the truck and said, You’re shitting me, Tommy.
VETA: Hodila zväzok fotiek na sedadlo kamiónu a povedala: Ty ma poserieš, Tommy.

TEXT_SOURCE: It’s not her fault.
VETA: Nie je to jej chyba.

TEXT_SOURCE: That man, the one who knows a ’66 when he sees one, that’s not the man she married.
VETA: Ten muž, ten, ktorý pozná 66-ku, keď ju uvidí, to nie je muž, za ktorého sa vydala.

TEXT_SOURCE: That’s how it has to be.
VETA: tak to musí byť.

TEXT_SOURCE: You understand, don’t you?
VETA: rozumieš, nie?

TEXT_SOURCE: I smiled at her.
VETA: Usmial som sa na ňu.

TEXT_SOURCE: No, ma’am, I said.
VETA: Nie, madam, povedal som.

TEXT_SOURCE: I wouldn’t shit you.
VETA: nesral by som ťa.

TEXT_SOURCE: You’re my favourite turd.
VETA: Si môj obľúbený hovno.

TEXT_SOURCE: She laughed – she’s generous that way – and said, A car.
VETA: Zasmiala sa – takto je veľkorysá – a povedala: Auto.

TEXT_SOURCE: That’s the last thing we need around here.
VETA: To je posledná vec, ktorú tu potrebujeme.

TEXT_SOURCE: When I was a boy my father took me hunting.
VETA: Keď som bol chlapec, môj otec ma brával na lov.

TEXT_SOURCE: Quail mostly and, one time, elk.
VETA: Väčšinou prepelice a raz aj losy.

TEXT_SOURCE: But I was no good at it and he gave up.
VETA: Ale nebol som v tom dobrý a on to vzdal.

TEXT_SOURCE: I didn’t have it in me, my father said, sad and plain as if it were a birth defect, the way I was.
VETA: Nemal som to v sebe, povedal môj otec, smutný a prostý, ako keby to bola vrodená chyba, tak ako som bol.

TEXT_SOURCE: Even now, deer come down from the mountains and root in our garden, stripping our tomatoes from the vine, eating the hearts of our baby cabbages. My father says, Kill one. String it up.
VETA: Dokonca aj teraz zliezajú jelene z hôr a zakoreňujú sa v našej záhrade, oberajú naše paradajky z viniča a jedia srdcia našej detskej kapusty. Môj otec hovorí: Zabi jedného. Zaveste to.

TEXT_SOURCE: They’ll learn.
VETA: Naučia sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: I tell him I can’t do that.
VETA: Hovorím mu, že to nemôžem urobiť.

TEXT_SOURCE: I spend my Sundays patching the holes in the fence, or putting up a taller one.
VETA: Nedeľu trávim opravovaním dier v plote alebo stavaním vyššieho.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Church of the Compassionate Heart, my wife calls it.
VETA: Moja žena to nazýva Cirkev milosrdného srdca.

TEXT_SOURCE: It makes her happy, this life of ours, the man I am.
VETA: Robí ju to šťastnou, tento náš život, muž, ktorým som.

TEXT_SOURCE: Layla helps me mend the fence.
VETA: Layla mi pomáha opraviť plot.

TEXT_SOURCE: She stands behind me and hands me my pliers or my wire cutters when I let her.
VETA: Stojí za mnou a podáva mi kliešte alebo nožnice na drôt, keď jej to dovolím.

TEXT_SOURCE: But here’s the truth, Duane Moser.
VETA: Ale tu je pravda, Duane Moser.

TEXT_SOURCE: Sometimes I see his eyes above that bandanna, see the grasshoppers leaping in the lights, hear them vibrating.
VETA: Niekedy vidím jeho oči nad šatkou, vidím, ako kobylky poskakujú vo svetlách, počujem ich vibrovať.

TEXT_SOURCE: I feel the kick of the rifle butt in my sternum.
VETA: Cítim kopnutie pažbou pušky v hrudnej kosti.

TEXT_SOURCE: I would do it again.
VETA: Urobil by som to znova.

TEXT_SOURCE: Dear Duane Moser
VETA: Vážený Duane Moser

TEXT_SOURCE: This will be the last I write to you.
VETA: Toto bude posledné, čo vám napíšem.

TEXT_SOURCE: I went back to Rhyolite.
VETA: Vrátil som sa k Rhyolite.

TEXT_SOURCE: I told my wife I was headed south to camp and hike for a few days.
VETA: Povedal som svojej žene, že mám namierené na juh do kempu a na pár dní na túru.

TEXT_SOURCE: She said, Why don’t you take Layla with you? It would be good for her.
VETA: Povedala: Prečo nezoberieš Laylu so sebou? Bolo by to pre ňu dobré.

TEXT_SOURCE: Layla slept nearly the whole drive.
VETA: Layla prespala takmer celú cestu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Six hours.
VETA: Šesť hodín.

TEXT_SOURCE: When I slowed the car and pulled on to Cane Springs Road she sat up and said, Dad, where are we?
VETA: Keď som spomalil auto a zamieril na Cane Springs Road, posadila sa a povedala: Ocko, kde sme?

TEXT_SOURCE: I said, We’re here.
VETA: Povedal som: Sme tu.

TEXT_SOURCE: I helped her with her coat and mittens and we took a walk through the ruins.
VETA: Pomohol som jej s kabátom a rukavicami a prešli sme sa po ruinách.

TEXT_SOURCE: I told her what they once were.
VETA: Povedal som jej, čím kedysi boli.

TEXT_SOURCE: Here, I said, was the schoolhouse. They finished it in 1909.
VETA: Tu, povedal som, bola škola. Dokončili ho v roku 1909.

TEXT_SOURCE: By then there weren’t enough children in town to fill it.
VETA: V tom čase už v meste nebolo dosť detí, aby to zaplnili.

TEXT_SOURCE: It burnt down the next year.
VETA: Nasledujúci rok vyhorela.

TEXT_SOURCE: She wanted to go closer.
VETA: Chcela ísť bližšie.

TEXT_SOURCE: I said, Stay where I can see you.
VETA: Povedal som: Zostaň tam, kde ťa vidím.

TEXT_SOURCE: Why? she said.
VETA: prečo? povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: I didn’t know how to say it.
VETA: nevedel som ako to povedať.

TEXT_SOURCE: Crumbling buildings, rotted-out floors, sinkholes, open mine shafts.
VETA: Rozpadajúce sa budovy, zhnité podlahy, ponory, otvorené šachty.

TEXT_SOURCE: Coyotes, rattlesnakes, mountain lions.
VETA: Kojoty, štrkáče, horské levy.

TEXT_SOURCE: Because, I said.
VETA: Pretože, povedal som.

TEXT_SOURCE: It’s not safe for little girls.
VETA: Nie je to bezpečné pre malé dievčatá.

TEXT_SOURCE: We went on.
VETA: Išli sme ďalej.

TEXT_SOURCE: There behind the fence is the post office, completed in 1908.
VETA: Tam za plotom je pošta, dokončená v roku 1908.

TEXT_SOURCE: This slab, these beams, that wall of brick, that was the train station.
VETA: Táto doska, tieto trámy, tá tehlová stena, to bola železničná stanica.

TEXT_SOURCE: It used to have marble floors, mahogany woodworking, one of the first telephones in the state.
VETA: Kedysi mala mramorové podlahy, mahagónové drevo, jeden z prvých telefónov v štáte.

TEXT_SOURCE: But those have been sold or stolen over the years.
VETA: Tie sa však v priebehu rokov predali alebo ukradli.

TEXT_SOURCE: Why? she said.
VETA: prečo? povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: That’s what happens when a town dies.
VETA: To sa stane, keď mesto zomrie.

TEXT_SOURCE: Why?
VETA: prečo?

TEXT_SOURCE: Because, sweetheart.
VETA: Pretože, srdiečko.

TEXT_SOURCE: Because.
VETA: Pretože.

TEXT_SOURCE: At dusk I tried to show Layla how to set a tent and build a fire but she wasn’t interested.
VETA: Za súmraku som sa snažil ukázať Layle, ako postaviť stan a zapáliť oheň, ale nemala záujem.

TEXT_SOURCE: Instead she concentrated on filling her pink vinyl backpack with stones and using them to build little pyramids along the path that led out to the town.
VETA: Namiesto toho sa sústredila na to, aby naplnila svoj ružový vinylový batoh kameňmi a použila ich na stavbu malých pyramíd pozdĺž cesty, ktorá viedla do mesta.

TEXT_SOURCE: She squatted over them, gingerly turning the stones to find a flat side, a stable base.
VETA: Sadla si nad ne, opatrne otáčala kamene, aby našla rovnú stranu, stabilnú základňu.

TEXT_SOURCE: What are those for? I asked.
VETA: Na čo sú tie? Opýtal som sa.

TEXT_SOURCE: For if we get lost, she said.
VETA: Lebo ak sa stratíme, povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: Pop Pop showed me.
VETA: Pop Pop mi ukázal.

TEXT_SOURCE: When it got dark we sat together listening to the hiss of the hot dogs at the ends of our sticks, the violent sizzle of sap escaping the firewood.
VETA: Keď sa zotmelo, sedeli sme spolu a počúvali syčanie párkov v rožku na koncoch našich palíc, prudké syčanie miazgy unikajúcej z palivového dreva.

TEXT_SOURCE: Layla fell asleep in my lap.
VETA: Layla zaspala v mojom lone.

TEXT_SOURCE: I carried her to the tent and zipped her inside a sleeping bag.
VETA: Odniesol som ju do stanu a zazipsoval do spacieho vaku.

TEXT_SOURCE: I stayed and watched her there, her chest rising and falling, hers the small uncertain breath of a bird.
VETA: Zostal som a pozoroval ju tam, jej hruď stúpajúca a klesajúca, jej malý neistý dych vtáka.

TEXT_SOURCE: When I bent to step out through the opening of the tent something fell from the pocket of my overalls.
VETA: Keď som sa zohol, aby som vyšiel von cez otvor stanu, niečo mi vypadlo z vrecka kombinézy.

TEXT_SOURCE: I held it up in the fire light.
VETA: Podržal som to vo svetle ohňa.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was a cloudy stump of amethyst, as big as a horse’s tooth.
VETA: Bol to zakalený peň ametystu, veľký ako konský zub.

TEXT_SOURCE: I’ve tried, Duane Moser, but I can’t picture you at 1077 Pincay Drive.
VETA: Skúšal som to, Duane Moser, ale neviem si ťa predstaviť na 1077 Pincay Drive.

TEXT_SOURCE: I can’t see you in Henderson period, out in the suburbs, on a cul-de-sac, in one of those prefab houses with the stucco and the garage gaping off the front like a mouth.
VETA: Nevidím ťa v Hendersonovom období, vonku na predmestí, v slepej uličke, v jednom z tých panelových domov so štukovou omietkou a garážou spredu ako ústa.

TEXT_SOURCE: I can’t see you standing like a bug under those street lights the colour of antibacterial soap.
VETA: Nevidím ťa stáť ako chrobák pod tými pouličnými svetlami farby antibakteriálneho mydla.

TEXT_SOURCE: At home at night I sit on my porch and watch the lights of Reno over the hills, the city marching out at us like an army.
VETA: Doma v noci sedím na verande a sledujem svetlá Rena nad kopcami, mesto, ktoré k nám pochoduje ako armáda.

TEXT_SOURCE: It’s no accident that the first step in what they call developing a plot of land is to put a fence around it.
VETA: Nie je náhodou, že prvým krokom v tom, čo nazývajú rozvoj pozemku, je postaviť okolo neho plot.

TEXT_SOURCE: I can’t see you behind a fence.
VETA: Nevidím ťa za plotom.

TEXT_SOURCE: When I see you, I see you here, at Rhyolite, harvesting sticks of charcoal from the half-burnt schoolhouse and writing your name on the exposed concrete foundation.
VETA: Keď ťa vidím, vidím ťa tu, v Rhyolite, ako zbieraš palice dreveného uhlia z napoly spálenej školskej budovy a píšeš svoje meno na odkrytý betónový základ.

TEXT_SOURCE: Closing one eye to look through the walls of Jim Kelly’s bottle house.
VETA: Zatvorením jedného oka sa pozriete cez steny domu fliaš Jima Kellyho.

TEXT_SOURCE: No, that’s my daughter.
VETA: Nie, to je moja dcéra.

TEXT_SOURCE: That’s me as a boy getting charcoal stains on my blue jeans.
VETA: To som ja ako chlapec, ktorému sa na modrých džínsoch objavujú škvrny od dreveného uhlia.

TEXT_SOURCE: That’s you in your Chevelle, the ’66, coming up Cane Springs Road, tearing past what was once the Porter Brothers’ Store.
VETA: To ste vy vo svojom Chevelle, 66, prichádzate po Cane Springs Road a prechádzate okolo toho, čo bolo kedysi obchodom Porter Brothers.

TEXT_SOURCE: I see you with M. , flinging Fritos and meat and half-full cans of Coke and Bud Light from the car like a goddamn celebration, a shedding of your old selves.
VETA: Vidím ťa s M., ako hádžeš z auta Fritos a mäso a poloplné plechovky koly a Bud Light ako prekliatu oslavu, zbavenie sa tvojho starého ja.

TEXT_SOURCE: It’s almost Christmas.
VETA: Sú skoro Vianoce.

TEXT_SOURCE: I’ve looked at the prescriptions, the letters, the photos.
VETA: Pozrel som si recepty, listy, fotky.

TEXT_SOURCE: You’re not Frankie, I know this.
VETA: Nie si Frankie, ja to viem.

TEXT_SOURCE: It’s just a coincidence, a packet of pictures flung from a car out in the middle of nowhere.
VETA: Je to len náhoda, balík obrázkov vymrštených z auta uprostred ničoho.

TEXT_SOURCE: The car is just a car.
VETA: Auto je len auto.

TEXT_SOURCE: The world is full of Chevelles, a whole year’s worth of the ’66.
VETA: Svet je plný Chevelles, čo je hodnota za celý rok 66.

TEXT_SOURCE: You know nothing of Hadley’s fuel in Beatty, of a boy who was killed there one night in late spring when the grasshoppers were so loud they sounded like a thunderstorm in your head.
VETA: Neviete nič o Hadleyho palive v Beatty, o chlapcovi, ktorého tam zabili jednej noci na konci jari, keď boli kobylky také hlasné, že vo vašej hlave zneli ako búrka.

TEXT_SOURCE: I don’t owe you anything.
VETA: nie som ti nič dlžný.

TEXT_SOURCE: When I woke this morning there was snow on the ground and Layla was gone.
VETA: Keď som sa dnes ráno zobudil, na zemi bol sneh a Layla bola preč.

TEXT_SOURCE: I pulled my boots on and walked around the camp.
VETA: Nazul som si topánky a prešiel som sa po tábore.

TEXT_SOURCE: A layer of white covered the hills and the valley and the skeletons of the old buildings, lighting the valley fluorescent.
VETA: Vrstva bielej pokrývala kopce, údolie a kostry starých budov a osvetľovala údolie žiarivkami.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was blinding.
VETA: Bolo to oslepujúce.

TEXT_SOURCE: I called my daughter’s name.
VETA: Zavolal som meno mojej dcéry.

TEXT_SOURCE: I listened, pressing the sole of my shoe against the blackened rocks lining the fire pit.
VETA: Počúval som a tlačil som podrážku topánky na sčernené kamene lemujúce ohnisko.

TEXT_SOURCE: I watched the snow go watery within my boot print.
VETA: Sledoval som, ako mi sneh v odtlačku topánok je vodnatý.

TEXT_SOURCE: There was no answer.
VETA: Neprišla žiadna odpoveď.

TEXT_SOURCE: I checked the truck.
VETA: Skontroloval som kamión.

TEXT_SOURCE: It was empty.
VETA: Bola prázdna.

TEXT_SOURCE: In the tent I found her coat and mittens.
VETA: V stane som našiel jej kabát a palčiaky.

TEXT_SOURCE: Her shoes had been taken.
VETA: Topánky jej zobrali.

TEXT_SOURCE: I scrambled up a small hill and looked for her from there.
VETA: Vyškriabal som sa na malý kopec a odtiaľ som ju hľadal.

TEXT_SOURCE: I scanned for the shape of her among the old buildings, on the hills, along Cane Springs Road.
VETA: Hľadal som jej tvar medzi starými budovami, na kopcoch, pozdĺž Cane Springs Road.

TEXT_SOURCE: Fence posts, black with moisture, strung across the valley like tombstones.
VETA: Plotové stĺpiky, čierne od vlhkosti, navlečené cez údolie ako náhrobné kamene.

TEXT_SOURCE: Sickness thickened in my gut and my throat.
VETA: V črevách a hrdle mi zhustla choroba.

TEXT_SOURCE: She was gone.
VETA: Bola preč.

TEXT_SOURCE: I called for her again and again.
VETA: Volal som na ňu znova a znova.

TEXT_SOURCE: I heard nothing, though surely my own voice echoed back to me.
VETA: Nič som nepočul, aj keď môj vlastný hlas sa mi určite ozval.

TEXT_SOURCE: Surely the snow creaked under my feet when I walked through our camp and out to the ruins.
VETA: Sneh mi určite vŕzgal pod nohami, keď som prechádzal cez náš tábor a vychádzal som k ruinám.

TEXT_SOURCE: Surely the frozen tendrils of creosote whipped against my legs when I began to run through the ghost town, up and down the gravel path.
VETA: Zmrznuté úponky kreozotu mi určite šľahali do nôh, keď som začal behať mestom duchov hore-dole po štrkovej ceste.

TEXT_SOURCE: But all sound had left me except for a low, steady roaring, the sound of my own blood in my ears, of a car rumbling up the old road.
VETA: Ale opustil ma všetok zvuk, okrem tichého, stáleho hukotu, zvuku mojej vlastnej krvi v ušiach a zvuku auta, ktoré sa hrnie po starej ceste.

TEXT_SOURCE: Suddenly my chest was burning.
VETA: Zrazu ma pálila hruď.

TEXT_SOURCE: I couldn’t breathe.
VETA: nemohla som dýchať.

TEXT_SOURCE: Layla Layla.
VETA: Layla Layla.

TEXT_SOURCE: I crouched and pressed my bare palms against the frozen earth.
VETA: Prikrčil som sa a pritlačil holými dlaňami na zamrznutú zem.

TEXT_SOURCE: The knees of my long johns soaked through, my fingers began to sting.
VETA: Kolená mojich dlhých nohavíc premokli, prsty ma začali štípať.

TEXT_SOURCE: Then I saw a shape near the burnt remains of the schoolhouse.
VETA: Potom som uvidel tvar blízko spálených zvyškov školského domu.

TEXT_SOURCE: A panic as hot and fierce as anything – fiercer – rose in me.
VETA: Vzniesla vo mne panika taká horúca a zúrivá ako čokoľvek iné – prudšia.

TEXT_SOURCE: The slick pink vinyl of her backpack.
VETA: Hladký ružový vinyl jej batohu.

TEXT_SOURCE: I ran to it.
VETA: Bežal som k tomu.

TEXT_SOURCE: When I bent to pick it up I heard something on the wind.
VETA: Keď som sa zohol, aby som to zdvihol, počul som niečo vo vetre.

TEXT_SOURCE: Something like the high, breathy language my daughters speak to each other when they play.
VETA: Niečo ako vysoký, dýchavý jazyk, ktorým sa moje dcéry medzi sebou rozprávajú, keď sa hrajú.

TEXT_SOURCE: I followed the sound around behind the schoolhouse and found Layla squatting there in her pyjamas, softly stacking one of her stone markers in the snow.
VETA: Sledoval som zvuk za školou a našiel som Laylu, ako tam čupí v pyžame a jemne ukladá jednu zo svojich kamenných značiek do snehu.

TEXT_SOURCE: Hi, Dad, she said.
VETA: Ahoj, ocko, povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: The snow had reddened her hands and cheeks as though she’d been burnt.
VETA: Sneh jej sčervenal ruky a líca, ako keby bola spálená.

TEXT_SOURCE: She handed me a stone.
VETA: Podala mi kameň.

TEXT_SOURCE: Here you go, she said.
VETA: Tu máš, povedala.

TEXT_SOURCE: I took my daughter by the shoulders and stood her up.
VETA: Vzal som dcéru za ramená a postavil som ju.

TEXT_SOURCE: I raised her sweet chin so her eyes met mineand then I slapped her across the face.
VETA: Zdvihol som jej sladkú bradu, aby sa jej oči stretli s mojimi, a potom som ju udrel po tvári.

TEXT_SOURCE: She began to cry.
VETA: Začala plakať.

TEXT_SOURCE: I held her.
VETA: Držal som ju.

TEXT_SOURCE: The Chevelle drove up and down Cane Springs Road, the gravel under its tyres going pop pop pop.
VETA: Chevelle jazdil hore-dole po Cane Springs Road, štrk pod jeho pneumatikami začal praskať.

TEXT_SOURCE: I said, Shh.
VETA: Povedal som: Pst.

TEXT_SOURCE: That’s enough.
VETA: To je dosť.

TEXT_SOURCE: A child means nothing out here.
VETA: Dieťa tu nič neznamená.

TEXT_SOURCE: Truly, Thomas Grey
VETA: Naozaj, Thomas Gray

TEXT_SOURCE: In full protective gear, Sterling Johnson sanitizes a Bay Area Rapid Transit train at a facility in Concord, California.
VETA: Sterling Johnson v kompletnej ochrannej výstroji dezinfikuje vlak rýchlej prepravy Bay Area v zariadení v Concorde v Kalifornii.

TEXT_SOURCE: RUBY MOSS SOMEHOW found the strength to drop to her knees in prayer.
VETA: RUBY MOSS NEJAK našla silu padnúť na kolená v modlitbe.

TEXT_SOURCE: Although severely weakened herself from the virus, she cried out to God to plead for the life of Adolphus Moss, her husband of 32 years.
VETA: Hoci bola vírusom vážne oslabená, kričala k Bohu, aby prosila o život Adolpha Mossa, svojho 32-ročného manžela.

TEXT_SOURCE: He was deteriorating rapidly.
VETA: Rýchlo sa zhoršoval.
